
 
_
Boy
and
Girl
_
  
Outside
Dorlcote
Mill
  
<EOS>
A
wide
plain
,
where
the
broadening
Floss
hurries
on
between
its
green
banks
to
the
sea
,
and
the
loving
tide
,
rushing
to
meet
it
<EOS>
,
checks
its
passage
with
an
impetuous
embrace
.
<EOS>
On
this
mighty
tide
the
black
ships
 
laden
with
the
fresh
-
scented
fir
-
planks
,
with
rounded
sacks
of
oil
-
bearing
seed
,
or
with
the
dark
glitter
of
coal
 
are
borne
along
to
the
town
of
St.
Ogg
's
,
which
shows
its
aged
,
fluted
red
roofs
and
the
broad
gables
of
its
wharves
between
the
low
wooded
hill
and
the
river
-
brink
,
tingeing
the
water
with
a
soft
purple
hue
under
the
transient
glance
of
this
February
sun
.
<EOS>
Far
away
on
each
hand
stretch
the
rich
pastures
,
and
the
patches
of
dark
earth
made
ready
for
the
seed
of
broad
-
leaved
green
crops
,
or
touched
already
with
the
tint
of
the
tender
-
bladed
autumn
-
sown
corn
.
<EOS>
There
is
a
remnant
still
of
last
year
's
golden
clusters
of
beehive
-
ricks
rising
at
intervals
beyond
the
hedgerows
;
and
everywhere
the
hedgerows
are
studded
with
trees
;
the
distant
ships
seem
to
be
lifting
their
masts
and
stretching
their
red
-
brown
sails
close
among
the
branches
of
the
spreading
ash
.
<EOS>
Just
by
the
red
-
roofed
town
the
tributary
Ripple
flows
with
a
lively
current
into
the
Floss
.
<EOS>
How
lovely
the
little
river
is
,
with
its
dark
changing
wavelets
!
<EOS>
It
seems
to
me
like
a
living
companion
while
I
wander
along
the
bank
,
and
listen
to
its
low
,
placid
voice
,
as
to
the
voice
of
one
who
is
deaf
and
loving
.
<EOS>
I
remember
those
large
dipping
willows
.
<EOS>
I
remember
the
stone
bridge
.
  
<EOS>
And
this
is
Dorlcote
Mill
.
<EOS>
I
must
stand
a
minute
or
two
here
on
the
bridge
and
look
at
it
,
though
the
clouds
are
threatening
,
and
it
is
far
on
in
the
afternoon
.
<EOS>
Even
in
this
leafless
time
of
departing
February
it
is
pleasant
to
look
at
,
 
perhaps
the
chill
,
damp
season
adds
a
charm
to
the
trimly
kept
,
comfortable
dwelling
-
house
,
as
old
as
the
elms
and
chestnuts
that
shelter
it
from
the
northern
blast
.
<EOS>
The
stream
is
brimful
now
,
and
lies
high
in
this
little
withy
plantation
,
and
half
drowns
the
grassy
fringe
of
the
croft
in
front
of
the
house
.
<EOS>
As
I
look
at
the
full
stream
,
the
vivid
grass
,
the
delicate
bright
-
green
powder
softening
the
outline
of
the
great
trunks
and
branches
that
gleam
from
under
the
bare
purple
boughs
,
I
am
in
love
with
moistness
,
and
envy
the
white
ducks
that
are
dipping
their
heads
far
into
the
water
here
among
the
withes
,
unmindful
of
the
awkward
appearance
they
make
in
the
drier
world
above
.
  
<EOS>
The
rush
of
the
water
and
the
booming
of
the
mill
bring
a
dreamy
deafness
,
which
seems
to
heighten
the
peacefulness
of
the
scene
.
<EOS>
They
are
like
a
great
curtain
of
sound
,
shutting
one
out
from
the
world
beyond
.
<EOS>
And
now
there
is
the
thunder
of
the
huge
covered
wagon
coming
home
with
sacks
of
grain
.
<EOS>
That
honest
wagoner
is
thinking
of
his
dinner
,
getting
sadly
dry
in
the
oven
at
this
late
hour
;
but
he
will
not
touch
it
till
he
has
fed
his
horses
,
 
the
strong
,
submissive
,
meek
-
eyed
beasts
,
who
,
I
fancy
,
are
looking
mild
reproach
at
him
from
between
their
blinkers
,
that
he
should
crack
his
whip
at
them
in
that
awful
manner
as
if
they
needed
that
hint
!
<EOS>
See
how
they
stretch
their
shoulders
up
the
slope
toward
the
bridge
,
with
all
the
more
energy
because
they
are
so
near
home
.
<EOS>
Look
at
their
grand
shaggy
feet
that
seem
to
grasp
the
firm
earth
,
at
the
patient
strength
of
their
necks
,
bowed
under
the
heavy
collar
,
at
the
mighty
muscles
of
their
struggling
haunches
!
<EOS>
I
should
like
well
to
hear
them
neigh
over
their
hardly
earned
feed
of
corn
,
and
see
them
,
with
their
moist
necks
freed
from
the
harness
,
dipping
their
eager
nostrils
into
the
muddy
pond
.
<EOS>
Now
they
are
on
the
bridge
,
and
down
they
go
again
at
a
swifter
pace
,
and
the
arch
of
the
covered
wagon
disappears
at
the
turning
behind
the
trees
.
  
<EOS>
Now
I
can
turn
my
eyes
toward
the
mill
again
,
and
watch
the
unresting
wheel
sending
out
its
diamond
jets
of
water
.
<EOS>
That
little
girl
is
watching
it
too
;
she
has
been
standing
on
just
the
same
spot
at
the
edge
of
the
water
ever
since
I
paused
on
the
bridge
.
<EOS>
And
that
queer
white
cur
with
the
brown
ear
seems
to
be
leaping
and
barking
in
ineffectual
remonstrance
with
the
wheel
;
perhaps
he
is
jealous
because
his
playfellow
in
the
beaver
bonnet
is
so
rapt
in
its
movement
.
<EOS>
It
is
time
the
little
playfellow
went
in
,
I
think
;
and
there
is
a
very
bright
fire
to
tempt
her
:
the
red
light
shines
out
under
the
deepening
gray
of
the
sky
.
<EOS>
It
is
time
,
too
,
for
me
to
leave
off
resting
my
arms
on
the
cold
stone
of
this
bridge
....
  
<EOS>
Ah
,
my
arms
are
really
benumbed
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
pressing
my
elbows
on
the
arms
of
my
chair
,
and
dreaming
that
I
was
standing
on
the
bridge
in
front
of
Dorlcote
Mill
,
as
it
looked
one
February
afternoon
many
years
ago
.
<EOS>
Before
I
dozed
off
,
I
was
going
to
tell
you
what
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Tulliver
were
talking
about
,
as
they
sat
by
the
bright
fire
in
the
left
-
hand
parlor
,
on
that
very
afternoon
I
have
been
dreaming
of
.
    
<EOS>
Mr.
Tulliver
,
of
Dorlcote
Mill
,
Declares
His
Resolution
about
Tom
  
<EOS>
"
What
I
want
,
you
know
,
"
said
Mr.
Tulliver
,
 
"
what
I
want
is
to
give
Tom
a
good
eddication
;
an
eddication
as'll
be
a
bread
to
him
.
<EOS>
That
was
what
I
was
thinking
of
when
I
gave
notice
for
him
to
leave
the
academy
at
Lady
-
day
.
<EOS>
I
mean

put

to
a
downright
good
school
at
Midsummer
.
<EOS>
The
two

at
th

.

.

They

,

<EOS>
Mrs.
Tulliver
was
what
is
called
a
good
-
tempered
person
,
 
never

,
when
she
was

,

.
<EOS>
But

,
and
when

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
Mr.
Riley

for
Tom
  
<EOS>

"

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>

,

,
had

,

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Tulliver
was
,

,

;
but

,

amongst

that

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
But

.
  
<EOS>
But

;

.
<EOS>
This

<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
This

a

,
as
he

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

?
<EOS>

<EOS>
I
know
he
would
not

,

.
<EOS>
If

,

:

Midsummer
,
but
I

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
there
's
summat
in
that
,
"
said

Tulliver
.
  
<EOS>
"
Father
,
"
broke
in
Maggie
,
who
had
stolen

to

,

,
 
"

?
<EOS>
Sha'n"t
<EOS>
we

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

,

"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ask

Riley
;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Maggie

Riley
,

,
"
How

,

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh

,
"
that

,

that

.
<EOS>
"
You

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's

!
"
<EOS>
said

,

,

,
with

.
<EOS>
She

to
dislike

Riley
;
it
was
evident
<EOS>
he
thought

silly

.
  
<EOS>
"
Hush
,
Maggie
!
<EOS>
for

of

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Come

,

.
<EOS>
But

"

,

,
"

?
"
  
"
<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Or
 
Stelling

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

's

,

,
"
said

Tulliver
,

.
  
<EOS>
The
entrance
of
supper
opportunely
adjourned
this
difficulty
,
and
relieved
Mr.
Riley
from
the
labor
of
suggesting
some
solution
or

,
 
a
labor
which
he
would
otherwise
doubtless
have
undertaken
;
for
,
as
you
perceive
,
he
was
a
man
of
very
obliging

.
<EOS>
And
he
had
really
given
himself
the
trouble
of
recommending
Mr.
Stelling
to
his
friend
Tulliver
without
any
positive
expectation
of
a
solid
,

resulting
to
himself
,
notwithstanding
the
subtle
indications
to
the
contrary
which
might
have
misled
a
too
-
sagacious
observer
.
<EOS>
For
there
is
nothing
more
widely
misleading
than
sagacity
if
it
happens
to
get
on
a
wrong
scent
;
and
sagacity
,
persuaded
that
men
usually
act
and
speak
from
distinct
motives
,
with
a
consciously
proposed
end
in
view
,
is
certain
to
waste
its
energies
on
imaginary
game
.
  
<EOS>
Plotting
covetousness
and
deliberate
contrivance
,
in
order
to
compass
a
selfish
end
,
are
nowhere
abundant
but
in
the
world
of
the
dramatist
:
they
demand
too
intense
a
mental
action
for
many
of
our
fellow
-
parishioners
to
be
guilty
of
them
.
<EOS>
It
is
easy
enough
to
spoil
the
lives
of
our
neighbors
without
taking
so
much
trouble
;
we
can
do
it
by
lazy
acquiescence
and
lazy
omission
,
by
trivial
falsities
for
which
we
hardly
know
a
reason
,
by
small
frauds
neutralized
by
small
extravagances
,
by
maladroit
flatteries
,
and
clumsily
improvised
insinuations
.
<EOS>
We
live
from
hand
to
mouth
,
most
of
us
,
with
a
small
family
of
immediate
desires
;
we
do
little
else
than
snatch
a
morsel
to
satisfy
the
hungry
brood
,
rarely
thinking
of
seed
-
corn
or
the
next
year
's
crop
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Riley
was
a
man
of
business
,
and
not
cold
toward
his
own
interest
,
yet
even
he
was
more
under
the
influence
of
small
promptings
than
of
far
-
sighted
designs
.
<EOS>
He
had
no
private
understanding
with
the
Rev.
Walter
Stelling
;
on
the
contrary
,
he
knew
very
little
of
that
M.A.
and
his
acquirements
,
 
not
quite
enough
,
perhaps
,
to
warrant
so
strong

recommendation
of
him
as
he
had
given
to
his
friend
Tulliver
.
<EOS>
But
he
believed
Mr.
Stelling
to
be
an
excellent
classic
,
for
Gadsby
had
said
so
,
and
Gadsby
's
first
cousin
was
an
Oxford
tutor
;
which
was
better
ground
for
the
belief
even
than
his
own
immediate
observation
would
have
been
,
for
though
Mr.
Riley
had
received
a
tincture
of
the
classics
at
the
great
Mudport
Free
School
,
and
had
a
sense
of
understanding
Latin
generally
,
his
comprehension
of
any
particular
Latin
was
not
ready
.
<EOS>
Doubtless
there
remained
a
subtle

from
his
juvenile
contact
with
the
"
De
Senectute
"
and
the
fourth

of

"
Æneid
,
"
but
it
had
ceased
to

as

,
and
was
only

in

higher

and

his

style
.
<EOS>
Then
,
Stelling
was
an
Oxford
man
,
and
the
Oxford
men
were
always
 
<EOS>
no
,
no
,
it
was
the
Cambridge
men
who
were
always
good

.
<EOS>
But
a
man
who
had
had
a
university
education
could
teach
anything
he
liked
;
especially
a
man
like
Stelling
,
who
had
made

at
a

on

,
and
had

himself
so
well
that
it

generally

,
this
son
-
in
-
law
of
Timpson
's
was
a
sharp

.
<EOS>
It
was
to
be
expected
of
a
Mudport
man
,
from
the
parish
of
St.
Ursula
,
that
he
would
not
omit
to
do
a
good

to
a
son
-
in
-
law
of
Timpson
's
,
for
Timpson
was
one

,
and
had
a
good

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Riley
liked
such
men
,
quite
apart

any

,
through
their

,
from
less

into

;

,
"
I

-

.
<EOS>
"
Timpson
had
a

;
Mr.
Riley
felt
for

;
besides
,
Louisa
Timpson
's
face
,

,
had

;
it

.
<EOS>
Moreover
,

Riley
knew

whom

any

in

;
why
,

,
should
he
not

Stelling
?
<EOS>
His
friend
Tulliver
had
asked
him
for
an
opinion
;
it
is
always
chilling
,
in
friendly
intercourse
,
to
say
you
have
no
opinion
to
give
.
<EOS>
And
if
you
deliver
an
opinion
at
all
,
it
is
mere
stupidity
not
to
do
it
with
an
air
of
conviction
and
well
-
founded

.
<EOS>
You
make
it
your
own
in
uttering
it
,
and
naturally
get
fond
of
it
.
<EOS>
Thus
Mr.
Riley
,
knowing
no
harm
of
Stelling
to
begin

,
and
wishing

well
,
so

,
had
no

him
than
he
began

think
with
admiration
of
a
man
recommended
on
such

,
and
would
soon
have
gathered
so
warm

interest
on
the
subject
,
that
if
Mr.
Tulliver
had
in
the
end
declined
to
send
Tom
to
Stelling
,
Mr.
Riley
would
have
thought
his
"
friend
of
the
old
school
"
a
thoroughly
pig
-
headed
fellow
.
  
<EOS>
If
you
blame
Mr.
Riley
very
severely
for
giving
a
recommendation
on
such
slight
grounds
,
I
must
say
you
are
rather
hard
upon
him
.
<EOS>
Why
should
an
auctioneer
and
appraiser
thirty
years
ago
,
who
had
as
good
as
forgotten
his
free
-
school

,
be
expected

delicate

which
is
not
always
exhibited
by
gentlemen
of
the
learned
professions
,
even
in
our
present
advanced
stage
of

?
  
<EOS>
Besides
,
a
man
with
the
milk
of
human
kindness
in
him
can
scarcely
abstain
from
doing
a
good
-
natured
action
,
and
one
can
not
be
good
-
natured
all
round
.
<EOS>
Nature
herself
occasionally
quarters
an
inconvenient
parasite
on
an
animal
toward
whom
she
has
otherwise
no
ill
will
.
<EOS>
What
then
?
<EOS>
We
admire
her
care
for
the
parasite
.
<EOS>
If
Mr.
Riley
had
shrunk
from
giving
a
recommendation
that
was
not
based
on
valid
evidence
,
he
would
not
have
helped
Mr.
Stelling
to
a
paying
pupil
,
and
that
would
not
have
been
so
well
for
the
reverend
gentleman
.
<EOS>
Consider
,
too
,
that
all
the
pleasant
little
dim
ideas
and
complacencies
 
of
standing
well
with
Timpson
,
of
dispensing
advice
when
he
was
asked
for
it
,
of
impressing
his
friend
Tulliver
with
additional
respect
,
of
saying
something
,
and
saying
it
emphatically
,
with
other
inappreciably
minute
ingredients
that
went
along
with
the
warm
hearth
and
the
brandy
-
and
-
water
to
make
up
Mr.
Riley
's
consciousness
on
this
occasion
 
would
have
been
a
mere
blank
.
    
<EOS>
Tom
Is
Expected
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
heavy
disappointment
to
Maggie
that
she
was
not
allowed
to
go
with
her
father
in
the
gig
when
he
went
to
fetch
Tom
home
from
the
academy
;
but
the
morning
was
too
wet
,
Mrs.
Tulliver
said
,
for
a
little
girl
to
go
out
in
her
best
bonnet
.
<EOS>
Maggie
took
the
opposite
view
very
strongly
,
and
it
was
a
direct
consequence
of
this
difference
of
opinion
<EOS>
that
when
her
mother
was
in
the
act
of
brushing
out
the
reluctant
black
crop
Maggie
suddenly
rushed
from
under
her
hands
and
dipped
her
head
in
a
basin
of
water
standing
near
,
in
the
vindictive
determination
that
there
should
be
no
more
chance
of
curls
that
day
.
  
<EOS>
"
Maggie
,
Maggie
!
"
exclaimed
Mrs.
Tulliver
,
sitting
stout
and
helpless
with
the
brushes
on
her
lap
,
"
what
is
to
become
of
you
if
you
're
so
naughty
?
<EOS>
I
'll
tell
your
aunt
Glegg
and
your
aunt
Pullet
when
they
come
next
week
,
and
they
'll
never
love
you
any
more
.
<EOS>
Oh
dear
,
<EOS>
oh
dear
!
<EOS>
look
at
your
clean
pinafore
,
wet
from
top
to
bottom
.
<EOS>
Folks
"
ull
think
it
's
a
judgment
on
me
as
I
've
got
such
a
child
,
 
they
'll
think
I
've
done
summat
wicked
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Before
this
remonstrance
was
finished
,
Maggie
was
already
out
of
hearing
,
making
her
way
toward
the
great
attic
that
run
under
the
old
high
-
pitched
roof
,
shaking
the
water
from
her
black
locks
as
she
ran
,
like
a
Skye
terrier
escaped
from
his
bath
.
<EOS>
This
attic
was
Maggie
's
favorite
retreat
on
a
wet
day
,
when
the
weather
was
not
too
cold
;
here
she
fretted
out
all
her
ill
humors
,
and
talked
aloud
to
the
worm
-
eaten
floors
and
the
worm
-
eaten
shelves
,
and
the
dark
rafters
festooned
with
cobwebs
;
and
here
she
kept
a
Fetish
which
she
punished
for
all
her
misfortunes
.
<EOS>
This
was
the
trunk
of
a
large
wooden
doll
,
which
once
stared
with
the
roundest
of
eyes
above
the
reddest
of
cheeks
;
but
was
now
entirely
defaced
by
a
long
career
of
vicarious
suffering
.
<EOS>
Three
nails
driven
into
the
head
commemorated
as
many
crises
in
Maggie
's
nine
years
of
earthly
struggle
;
that
luxury
of
vengeance
having
been
suggested
to
her
by
the
picture
of
Jael
destroying
Sisera
in
the
old
Bible
.
<EOS>
The
last
nail
had
been
driven
in
with
a
fiercer
stroke
than
usual
,
for
the
Fetish
on
that
occasion
represented
aunt
Glegg
.
<EOS>
But
immediately
afterward
Maggie
had
reflected
that
if
she
drove
many
nails
in
she
would
not
be
so
well
able
to
fancy
that
the
head
was
hurt
when
she
knocked
it
against
the
wall
,
nor
to
comfort
it
,
and
make
believe
to
poultice
it
,
when
her
fury
was
abated
;
for
even
aunt
Glegg
would
be
pitiable
when
she
had
been
hurt
very
much
,
and
thoroughly
humiliated
,
so
as
to
beg
her
niece
's
pardon
.
<EOS>
Since
then
she
had
driven
no
more
nails
in
,
but
had
soothed
herself
by
alternately
grinding
and
beating
the
wooden
head
against
the
rough
brick
of
the
great
chimneys
that
made
two
square
pillars
supporting
the
roof
.
<EOS>
That
was
what
she
did
this
morning
on
reaching
the
attic
,
sobbing
all
the
while
with
a
passion
that
expelled
every
other
form
of
consciousness
,
 
even
the
memory
of
the
grievance
that
had
caused
it
.
<EOS>
As
at
last
the
sobs
were
getting
quieter
,
and
the
grinding
less
fierce
,
a
sudden
beam
of
sunshine
,
falling
through
the
wire
lattice
across
the
worm
-
eaten
shelves
,
made
her
throw
away
the
Fetish
and
run
to
the
window
.
<EOS>
The
sun
was
really
breaking
out
;
the
sound
of
the
mill
seemed
cheerful
again
;
the
granary
doors
were
open
;
and
there
was
Yap
,
the
queer
white
-
and
-
brown
terrier
,
with
one
ear
turned
back
,
trotting
about
and
sniffing
vaguely
,
as
if
he
were
in
search
of
a
companion
.
<EOS>
It
was
irresistible
.
<EOS>
Maggie
tossed
her
hair
back
and
ran
downstairs
,
seized
her
bonnet
without
putting

on
,
peeped
,
and
then
dashed

lest
she

mother
,
and
was
quickly
out

,

,
and

,
"
Yap

"
<EOS>
while

as
much
as
to

,

"

.

<EOS>
Tom
Comes
Home
  
<EOS>
Tom
was
to

,

.
<EOS>

,
 
that

,
 
and

,

,

,

the
most
decided
intention
.
<EOS>
But
that
same
Nature
has
the
deep
cunning
which
hides
itself
under
the
appearance
of
openness
,
so
that
simple
people
think
they
can
see
through
her
quite
well
,
and
all

she
is
secretly

a
refutation
of
their
confident

.
<EOS>
Under
these
average
boyish

that
she
seems
to
turn
off
by
the
gross
,
she
conceals
some
of
her
most
rigid
,
inflexible

,
some
of
her
most
unmodifiable
characters
;
and
the
dark
-
eyed
,
demonstrative
,
rebellious
girl
may
after
all
turn
out
to
be
a
passive
being
compared
with
this
pink
-
and
-

bit
of
masculinity
with

.
  
<EOS>
"
Maggie
,
"
said
Tom
,

,

_
<EOS>
my
_

"

"
No
,
"

.
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

(

)

?
"

<EOS>

!

ca

<EOS>

<EOS>
She

;

.
  
<EOS>
Maggie

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Tom
was
come

,
and
she
had
thought
how

she
should

;
and
now
he
was
cruel
to
her
.
<EOS>
What
use
was
anything
if
Tom
did

her
?
<EOS>
Oh
,
he
was
very
cruel
!
<EOS>
Had

wanted

money
,
and
said

?
<EOS>
She

,
but
she
had
never
been

to
Tom
 
had
never
_
meant
_
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
he
is
cruel
!
"
<EOS>
Maggie
sobbed
aloud
,
finding
a
wretched

in
the
hollow

that
came
through
the
long
empty
space
of

attic
.
<EOS>
She
never
thought
of
beating
or
grinding
her
Fetish
;
she
was
too
miserable
to
be
angry
.
  
<EOS>
These
bitter
sorrows
of
childhood
!
<EOS>
when
sorrow
is
all
new
and
strange
,
when
hope
has
not
yet
got
wings
to
fly
beyond
the
days
and

,
and
the
space
from
summer
to
summer
seems

.
  
<EOS>
Maggie
soon
thought
she
had
been
hours
in
the
attic
,
and
it
must
be
tea
-
time
,
and
they
were
all
having
their
tea
,
and
not
thinking
of
her
.
<EOS>
Well
,
then
,
she
would
stay
up
there
and
starve

,
 
hide
herself
behind
the
tub
,
and
stay
there
all
night
,
 
and
then
they
would
all
be
frightened
,
and
Tom
would
be
sorry
.
<EOS>
Thus
Maggie
thought
in
the
pride
of
her
heart
,
as
she
crept
behind
the
tub
;
but
presently
she
began
to
cry
again
at
the
idea
that
they
did
n't
mind

being
there
.
<EOS>
If
she
went
down
again
to
Tom
now
 
would
he
forgive

?
<EOS>
Perhaps
her
father
would
be
there
,
and
he
would
take
her
part
.
<EOS>
But
then
she
wanted
Tom
to
forgive
her
because
he
loved
her
,
not
because
his
father
told
him
.
<EOS>
No
,
she
would
never
go
down
if
Tom
did
n't
come
to
fetch
her
.
<EOS>
This
resolution
lasted
in
great
intensity
for
five
dark
minutes
behind
the
tub
;
but
then
the
need
of
being
loved
 
the
strongest
need
in
poor
Maggie
's
nature
 
began
to
wrestle
with
her
pride
,
and
soon
threw
it
.
<EOS>
She
crept
from
behind
her
tub
into
the
twilight
of
the
long
attic
,
but
just
then
she
heard
a
quick
foot
-
step
on
the
stairs
.
  
<EOS>
Tom
had
been
too
much
interested
in
his
talk
with
Luke
,
in
going
the
round
of
the
premises
,
walking
in
and
out
where
he

,
and
whittling

,
 
except

did

whittle

,
 
to

of
Maggie
and
the
effect
his
anger
had
produced
on
her
.
<EOS>
He
meant
to
punish
her
,
and
that
business

been

,
he
occupied

with
other

,
like

.
<EOS>
But
when
he
had
been
called
in
to
tea
,

said
,
"
Why
,
where
's
the
little
wench
?
"
and
Mrs.
Tulliver
,

,

"

's

?
<EOS>
"
 
both

Tom
had
been

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
"
said
Tom
.
<EOS>
He
did
n't

to
"
tell
"
of
Maggie
,
though
he
was
angry
with
her
;
for
Tom
Tulliver
was
a

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
!
<EOS>
has

been
playing
with
you

this

?
"
said

father
.
<EOS>
"
She
'd
been
thinking
o
'
nothing
but

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
n't
seen

this
two
hours
,
"
says
Tom
,

on
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
Goodness
heart
;
she
's
got
drownded
!
"
exclaimed

Tulliver
,
rising

.
  
<EOS>
"
How

do

?
<EOS>
"
she

,
as

,

she

.
  
<EOS>
"
Nay
,

,

's
none

,
"

Tulliver
.
<EOS>
"
You
've

naughty
to

,

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm

have

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

's
in

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Perhaps
up

that
attic
,
"
said

Tulliver
,
"
a

,

about
meal

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

,

,
"
said

,

,
 
his

"
the

,
"

.
"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Else

.
"
  
<EOS>
Tom
never

his
father
,
for
Mr.
Tulliver
was
a

,
and
,
as

said
,
would
never

;
but

,

,
and
not

's

,

.
<EOS>
Tom
was
only
thirteen
,
and
had
no
decided
views
in
grammar
and

,
regarding

for
the
most

as

,
but

was
particularly

on
one

,
 
namely
,
that
he
would
punish
everybody
who

.
<EOS>
Why
,
he
would
n't
have

himself
if
he
deserved

;
but
,
then
,
he
never
_

_

.
  
<EOS>
It
was
Tom
's
step
,
then
,
that
Maggie
heard
on
the
stairs
,
when
her
need
of
love
had
triumphed
over

,
and
she
was
going

with
her

.
<EOS>
At
least
her
father
would
stroke

and
say
,
"
Never

,
my
wench
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
wonderful
subduer
,
this
need
of
love
,
 
this
hunger
of
the
heart
,
 
as
peremptory
as
that
other
hunger
by
which
Nature
forces
us
to
submit
to
the
yoke
,
and
change
the

.
  
<EOS>
But
she
knew
Tom
's
step
,
and
her
heart
began
to
beat
violently
with
the

of
hope
.
<EOS>
He
only
stood
still
at
the

and
said
,
"
Maggie
,
you
're
to
come
down
.
"
<EOS>
But
she
rushed
to

and
clung

,

,
"
Oh
,
Tom
,
please
forgive
me
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
bear
it
 
<EOS>
I
will
always
be
good
 
<EOS>
always
remember
things
 
<EOS>
do
love
me
 
please
,
dear
Tom
!
"
  
<EOS>
We
learn
to
restrain
ourselves
as
we
get
older
.
<EOS>
We
keep
apart
when
we
have
quarrelled
,
express
ourselves
in
well
-
bred
phrases
,
and
in
this

preserve
a
dignified

,
showing
much
firmness
on
one

,
and
swallowing
much

on

.
<EOS>
We
no
longer

in

to
the
mere

of
the
lower
animals
,
but
conduct
ourselves
in
every

like
members
of
a

civilized
society
.
<EOS>
Maggie
and
Tom
were
still
very
much
like
young
animals
,
and
so
she
could
rub
her
cheek
against
his
,
and
kiss
his
ear
in
a
random

;
and
there
were
tender
fibres
in
the
lad
that
had
been
used
to
answer
to
Maggie
's

,
so
that
he
behaved
with
a

quite
inconsistent
with
his
resolution
to
punish
her
as
much
as
she

.
<EOS>
He
actually
began
to
kiss

in

,
and

,
    
"
Do
n't
cry
,
then
,
Magsie
;
here
,

o
'
cake
.
"
  
<EOS>
Maggie
's

began
to
subside
,
and
she
put
out

mouth
for
the
cake
and
bit
a
piece
;
and
then
Tom
bit
a
piece
,
just
for

,
and
they
ate
together
and
rubbed
each

's

and
brows
and

together
,
while
they
ate
,
with
a

to

.
  
<EOS>
"
Come

,
Magsie
,

,
"
said

at

,
when
there
was
no
more
cake
except
what
was
down
-
stairs
.
  
<EOS>
So
ended
the
sorrows
of
this

,
and
the
next
morning
Maggie
was
trotting
with
her
own
fishing
-
rod
in

and
a
handle
of
the
basket
in

,
stepping
always
,
by

,
in
the

,
and
looking
darkly
radiant
from
under

-

because
Tom
was
good
to
her
.
<EOS>
She
had
told
Tom
,
however
,
that
she
should
like
him
to
put
the
worms
on
the
hook
for
her
,
although
she
accepted

word
when
he

that
worms
could
n't
feel
(
it
was
Tom
's
private

that

did

)
.
<EOS>
He
knew
all
about
worms
,
and

,
and
those

;
and
what
birds
were
mischievous
,
and
how
padlocks
opened
,
and
which

of

.
<EOS>
Maggie
thought
this
sort
of
knowledge
was
very
wonderful
,
 
much

than
remembering
what
was
in

;
and

awe

's

,

who
called

"
stuff
,
"

.
<EOS>
Tom
,

,
was
of
opinion
that
Maggie
was
a

;
all

were
silly
,
 
they
could
n't

anything
,
could
n't

anything

,

.
<EOS>
Still
,
he
was
very

of

,
and
meant

to
take

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
They
were
on

way
to
the
Round
Pool
,
 
that
wonderful
pool
,
which
the
floods
had
made
a
long

ago
.
<EOS>
No
one
knew
how
deep

was
;
and
it
was
mysterious
,
too
,
that

should

,

and

,
so
that

water

only

when

.
<EOS>
The

of
the
old
favorite

always
heightened
Tom
's
good

,
and

in

,

and

.
<EOS>
He
threw
her
line
for
her
,
and
put
the
rod
into

hand
.
<EOS>
Maggie
thought
it
probable
that
the
small
fish
would
come
to

,
and
the
large

to
Tom
's
.
<EOS>
But
she
had

about

,
and
was
looking

,

Tom

,
"
Look
,

,
Maggie
!
"
and
came

to

.
  
<EOS>
Maggie
was
frightened
lest
she
had

doing
something
wrong
,
as
usual
,
but
presently
Tom
drew
out
her
line
and
brought
a

.
  
<EOS>
Tom
was
excited
.
  
<EOS>
"
O
Magsie
,
you
little
duck
!
<EOS>
Empty
the
basket
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Maggie
was
not
conscious
of
unusual
merit
,
but
it
was
enough
that
Tom
called
her
Magsie
,
and
was

with

.
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
to
mar
her
delight
in
the

and
the

,
when
she

,
and

,
as
if
the

.
<EOS>
Maggie
thought
it
would
make
a
very
nice
heaven
to
sit
by
the
pool
in
that
way
,
and
never
be

.
<EOS>
She
never
knew
she
had
a
bite
till
Tom
told
her
;
but
she
liked
fishing
very
much
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
one
of
their
happy
mornings
.
<EOS>
They
trotted
along
and
sat
down
together
,
with
no
thought
that
life
would
ever
change
much
for
them
;
they
would
only
get
bigger
and
not
go
to
school
,
and
it
would
always
be
like
the
holidays
;
they
would
always
live
together
and
be
fond
of

other
.
<EOS>
And
the
mill
with
its
booming
;
the
great
chestnut
-
tree
under
which
they
played
at
houses
;
their
own
little
river
,
the
Ripple
,
where
the
banks
seemed
like
home
,
and
Tom
was
always
seeing
the
water
-
rats
,
while
Maggie
gathered
the
purple

tops
of
the
reeds
,
which
she

and
dropped
afterward
;
above

,

Floss
,
along
which

,
to

-

,
the
awful
Eagle
,
come

,

Great
Ash
which
had
once
wailed
and
groaned
like
a
man
,
these
things
would
always

just
the
same

.
<EOS>
Tom
thought
people
were
at
a
disadvantage
who
lived
on
any
other
spot
of
the
globe
;
and
Maggie
,
when
she
read
about
Christiana
passing
"
the
river
over
which
there
is
no
bridge
,
"
always
saw
the
Floss
between
the
green
pastures
by
the
Great
Ash
.
  
<EOS>
Life
did
change
for
Tom
and
Maggie
;
and
yet
they
were
not
wrong
in
believing
that
the
thoughts
and
loves
of
these
first
years
would
always
make
part
of
their
lives
.
<EOS>
We
could
never
have
loved
the
earth
so
well
if
we
had
had
no
childhood
in
it
,
 
if
it
were
not
the
earth
where
the
same
flowers
come
up
again
every
spring
that
we
used
to
gather
with
our
tiny
fingers
as
we
sat
lisping
to
ourselves
on
the
grass
;
the
same
hips
and
haws
on
the
autumn
's
hedgerows
;
the
same
redbreasts
that
we
used
to
call
"
God
's
birds
,
"
because
they
did
no
harm
to
the
precious
crops
.
<EOS>
What
novelty
is
worth
that
sweet
monotony
where
everything
is
known
,
and
_
loved
_
because
it
is
known
?
  
<EOS>
The
wood
I
walk
in
on
this
mild
May
day
,
with
the
young
yellow
-
brown
foliage
of
the
oaks
between
me
and
the
blue
sky
,
the
white
star
-
flowers
and
the
blue
-
eyed
speedwell
and
the
ground
ivy
at
my
feet
,
what
grove
of
tropic
palms
,
what
strange
ferns
or
splendid
broad
-
petalled
blossoms
,
could
ever
thrill
such
deep
and
delicate
fibres
within
me
as
this
home
scene
?
<EOS>
These
familiar
flowers
,
these
well
-
remembered
bird
-
notes
,
this
sky
,
with
its
fitful
brightness
,
these
furrowed
and
grassy
fields
,
each
with
a
sort
of
personality
given
to
it
by
the
capricious
hedgerows
,
 
such
things
as
these
are
the
mother
-
tongue
of
our
imagination
,
the
language
that
is
laden
with
all
the
subtle
,
inextricable
associations
the
fleeting
hours
of
our
childhood
left
behind
them
.
<EOS>
Our
delight
in
the
sunshine
on
the
deep
-
bladed
grass
to
-
day
might
be
no
more
than
the
faint
perception
of
wearied
souls
,
if
it
were
not
for
the
sunshine
and
the
grass
in
the
far
-
off
years
which
still
live
in
us
,
and
transform
our
perception
into
love
.
    
<EOS>
The
Aunts
and
Uncles
Are
Coming
  
<EOS>
It
was
Easter
week
,
and
Mrs.
Tulliver
's
cheesecakes
were
more
exquisitely
light
than
usual
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
puff
o
'
wind
'
<EOS>
ud

about

,
"
Kezia

,

;
so
that

.

What

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Few
wives
were
more
submissive
than
Mrs.
Tulliver
on
all
points
unconnected
with
her
family
relations
;
but
she
had
been
a
Miss
Dodson
,
and
the
Dodsons
were
a
very
respectable
family
indeed
,
 
as
much
looked
up
to
as
any
in
their
own
parish
,
or
the
next
to
it
.
<EOS>
The
Miss
Dodsons
had
always
been
thought
to
hold
up
their
heads
very
high
,
and
no
one
was
surprised
the
two
eldest
had
married
<EOS>
so
well
,
 
not
at
an
early
age
,
for
that
was
not
the
practice
of
the
Dodson
family
.
<EOS>
There
were
particular
ways
of
doing
everything
in
that
family
:
particular
ways
of
bleaching
the
linen
,
of
making
the
cowslip
wine
,
curing
the
hams
,
and
keeping
the
bottled
gooseberries
;
so
that
no
daughter
of
that
house
could
be
indifferent
to
the
privilege
of
having
been
born
a
Dodson
,
rather
than
a
Gibson
or
a
Watson
.
<EOS>
Funerals
were
always
conducted
with
peculiar
propriety
in
the
Dodson
family
:
the
hat
-
bands
were
never
of
a
blue
shade
,
the
gloves
never
split
at
the
thumb
,
everybody
was
a
mourner
who
ought
to
be
,
and
there
were
always
scarfs
for
the
bearers
.
<EOS>
When
one
of
the
family
was
in
trouble
or
sickness
,
all
the
rest
went
to
visit
the
unfortunate
member
,
usually
at
the
same
time
,
and
did
not
shrink
from
uttering
the
most
disagreeable
truths
that
correct
family
feeling
dictated
;
if
the
illness
or
trouble
was
the
sufferer
's
own
fault
,
it
was
not
in
the
practice
of
the
Dodson
family
to
shrink
from
saying
so
.
<EOS>
In
short
,
there
was
in
this
family
a
peculiar
tradition
as
to
what
was
the
right
thing
in
household
management
and
social
demeanor
,
and
the
only
bitter
circumstance
attending
this
superiority
was
a
painful
inability
to
approve
the
condiments
or
the
conduct
of
families
ungoverned
by
the
Dodson
tradition
.
<EOS>
A
female
Dodson
,
when
in
"
strange
houses
,
"
always
ate
dry
bread
with
her
tea
,
and
declined
any
sort
of
preserves
,
having
no
confidence
in
the
butter
,
and
thinking
that
the
preserves
had
probably
begun
to
ferment
from
want
of
due
sugar
and
boiling
.
<EOS>
There
were
some
Dodsons
less
like
the
family
than
others
,
that
was
admitted
;
but
in
so
far
as
they
were
"
kin
,
"
they
were
of
necessity
better
than
those
who
were
"
no
kin
.
"
<EOS>
And
it
is
remarkable
that
while
no
individual
Dodson
was
satisfied
with
any
other
individual
Dodson
,
each
was
satisfied
,
not
only
with
him
or
her
self
,
but
with
the
Dodsons
collectively
.
<EOS>
The
feeblest
member
of
a
family
 
<EOS>
the
one
who
has
the
least
character
 
is
often
the
merest
epitome
of
the
family
habits
and

;
and
Mrs.
Tulliver
was
a
thorough
Dodson
,

a
mild
one
,
as
small
-
beer
,
so
long
as
it
is
anything
,
is
only

as
very

:

,

still

,

was
not

Mrs.
Tulliver
to
be
an

the
family

.
<EOS>
She
was
thankful
to
have
been
a
Dodson
,
and
to
have
one
child
who
took
after

,

,
in

which

.
  
<EOS>
In

Tom
,

"
kin
"

,

,

a

.
<EOS>
It

that
Tom
always

without

secret
,
but
the
weaker

_

.
  
<EOS>
On

,

,

,
that

.
<EOS>
Tom

made

,

,

,

.

,

!
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

"
hoigh
!
"
<EOS>
as

friendly

<EOS>
But

,

,

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

'll
make
you
care
,
you
cheat
,
"
said
Tom
,
collaring
Bob
and
shaking

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
get
out
wi
'
you
,
"
said
Bob
,
giving
Tom
a
kick
.
  
<EOS>
Tom
's
blood
was
thoroughly
up
:
he
went
at
Bob
with

and
threw
him
down
,
but
Bob
seized
hold
and
kept

like

,
and
pulled
Tom

.
<EOS>
They

,
till
Tom
,

Bob

,
thought

.
  
<EOS>
"
_
You
_
,

,
"
he

,
with

,

's

.
  
<EOS>
But

,

,

<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
But

,
who

no

in

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No

I
sha'n"t

;
you

.
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

;

.
<EOS>
His

,

,

.
<EOS>
And

,

!
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
No

,

.
<EOS>
So

in

,

in

,
in

,

.
<EOS>
Poor
Bob
!
<EOS>
he
was
not
sensitive
on
the
point

,
not
a

.
<EOS>
That

,

;

Tom
had

.
  
<EOS>
But
Tom
,
you

,

,

boy

,

,

.
<EOS>
Maggie
saw

,

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
But

,

"

.
<EOS>
"

;
whereas

.
    
<EOS>
Enter
the
Aunts
and
Uncles
  
<EOS>
The
Dodsons
were
certainly
a
handsome
family
,
and
Mrs.
Glegg
was
not
the
least
handsome
of
the
sisters
.
<EOS>
As

in
Mrs.
Tulliver
's
arm
-

,

could
have

that
for

of
fifty
she

and

,
though
Tom
and
Maggie
considered
their
aunt
Glegg
as
the
type

ugliness
.
<EOS>
It
is
true

despised
the
advantages
of

,
for
though
,

often

,
no

,

her
way
to

.
<EOS>
Other

,

,

;
but

,

,

.
<EOS>
So
of

:

,

;

.
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
But

!
  
<EOS>
So

<EOS>
:

,
but
the
results
had
been
such
that
Mrs.
Tulliver
was
obliged
to
bury
them
in
her
maternal

;
for
Maggie
,
declaring
that
the
frock
smelt
of
nasty
dye
,
had
taken
an
opportunity
of
basting
it
together
with
the
roast
beef
the
first
Sunday
she

it
,
and
finding
this
scheme
answer
,
she
had
subsequently
pumped
on
the
bonnet
with
its
green

,
so
as
to
give
it
a
general

to
a
sage

.
<EOS>
I
must
urge
in
excuse
for
Maggie
,
that
Tom
had
laughed
at
her
in
the
bonnet
,
and
said
she
looked
like
an
old
Judy
.
<EOS>
Aunt
Pullet
,
too
,
made
presents
of
clothes
,
but
these
were
always
pretty
enough
to
please
Maggie
as
well
as
her
mother
.
<EOS>
Of
all
her
sisters
,
Mrs.
Tulliver
certainly
preferred
her
sister
Pullet
,
not
without

;
but
Mrs.
Pullet
was
sorry
Bessy
had
those
naughty
,

children
;
she
would
do

best

by

,
but
it
was
a

they
were
n't
as
good
and
as
pretty
as
sister

's

.
<EOS>
Maggie
and
Tom
,

,
thought
their
aunt

tolerable
,
chiefly
because

was
not
their
aunt

.
<EOS>
Tom
always

to
go
more

.
<EOS>
Both

,

;

there

to

,
so
that
he

to

.
<EOS>
Maggie
shuddered

,
and
dreamed
of

,
but
she
liked
her
uncle
Pullet
's
musical

.
<EOS>
Still
,
it
was
agreed
by
the
sisters
,
in
Mrs.
Tulliver
's

,
that
the

;
that

Tullivers
,

Tom
,

,
was
likely

"

"

.
<EOS>
As

,
she
was
the

aunt

,
Mr.
Tulliver
's

,
 
a
large

,
who
had
married
as

;
had
no

,

had

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
But

_

-

Mrs.

with

;

.
<EOS>
It

,

,

<EOS>
And

always

.
  
<EOS>
She

to
-

,

.
<EOS>
Maggie

<EOS>
Certainly

<EOS>

<EOS>
Lucy

,

,

;

.
<EOS>
Maggie

.
  
<EOS>
She

,

,

"

<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

Bessy

<EOS>

,

,

_

_

,

,

.
<EOS>
You
may

,

;

.
  
<EOS>
He
held
a

,

,

,

that

.
<EOS>
Mr.

's

,

.
<EOS>
No

;

,

.

,

,

!
<EOS>

Snip
!
<EOS>

;

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Never

,

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
Her

were
quite

.
  
<EOS>
The

were
so
thick
,
nothing

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
One

,

crying
;
father'll
take
your
part
.
"
  
<EOS>
Delicious
words
of
tenderness
!
<EOS>
Maggie
never
forgot
any
of
these
moments
when
her
father
"
took
her
part
"
;
she
kept
them
in
her
heart
,
and
thought
of
them
long
years
after
,
when
every
one
else
said
that
her
father
had
done
very
ill
by

children
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
your
husband
does
spoil
that
child
,
Bessy
!
"
said
Mrs.
Glegg
,
in
a
loud
"
aside
,
"
to

Tulliver
.
<EOS>
"
It
'll
be
the
ruin
of

,
if
you
do

.
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
My
_
father
never
brought
his
children
up
so
,
else
we
should
ha
'
been
a
different
sort
o
'
family
to
what
we
are
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Tulliver
's
domestic

seemed
at
this

to
have
reached
the
point
at
which
insensibility
begins
.
<EOS>
She
took
no

of
her

's

,
but
threw

capstrings
and
dispensed

,
in

.
  
<EOS>
With
the
dessert
there
came
entire
deliverance
for
Maggie
,
for
the
children
were
told
they
might
have
their
nuts
and
wine
in
the
summer
-
house
,
since
the
day
was
so

;
and
they
scampered

the
budding

of
the

with
the
alacrity
of
small
animals
getting
from
under

.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Tulliver
had
her
special
reason
for
this
permission
:
now
the
dinner
was
despatched
,
and
every
one
's
mind

,
it
was
the
right
moment
to
communicate
Mr.
Tulliver
's
intention
concerning
Tom
,
and
it
would
be
as
well
for
Tom
himself
to
be
absent
.
<EOS>
The
children
were
used
to
hear
themselves
talked
of
as
freely
as
if
they
were
birds
,
and
could
understand
nothing
,
however
they
might
stretch
their
necks
and
listen
;
but
on
this
occasion
Mrs.
Tulliver
manifested
an
unusual
discretion
,
because
she
had
recently
had
evidence
that
the
going
to
school
to
a
clergyman
was
a
sore
point
with
Tom
,
who
looked
at
it
as
very
much
on
a
par
with
going
to
school
to
a
constable
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Tulliver
had
a
sighing
sense
that
her
husband
would
do
as
he
liked
,
whatever
sister
Glegg
said
,
or
sister
Pullet
either
;
but
at
least
they
would
not
be
able
to
say
,
if
the
thing
turned
out
ill
,
that
Bessy
had
fallen
in
with
her
husband
's
folly
without
letting
her
own
friends
know
a
word
about
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Tulliver
,
"
she

,
interrupting

in

Deane
,
"

's

're

Tom
,

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Very

,
"

,

,
"
I
've

.
<EOS>
I
've

,
"

,

,
 
<EOS>
"

,

,
down

King
's

,
there
,
 
an
uncommon
clever
fellow
<EOS>
,
I
understand
,
as'll

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
a

of

in

,
such

in

country

when

.
<EOS>
It

equally

to

to

introduced
into
Mr.
Tulliver
's

.
<EOS>
As
for
uncle
Pullet
,
he
could

more

if
Mr.

had
said

to

;
for
uncle
Pullet
belonged
to
that

class
of
British
yeoman
who
,
dressed
in
good

,
paid
high
rates
and
taxes
,
went
to
church
,
and
ate
a
particularly
good

on

,
without
dreaming
that
the
British
constitution
in
Church
and
State
had
a
traceable
origin
any

than

and

.
  
<EOS>
It
is
melancholy
,
but
true
,
that
Mr.
Pullet
had
the
most
confused
idea
of
a
bishop
as
a
sort
of
a

,
who
might
or

a

;
and
as

his
own

was

,

be

was

's

to

.
<EOS>
I
know

to

uncle
Pullet
's
ignorance
;
but
let

reflect
on
the
remarkable
results
of
a
great
natural
faculty
under
favoring
circumstances
.
<EOS>
And
uncle
Pullet
had
a
great
natural
faculty
for
ignorance
.
<EOS>
He
was
the
first
to
give

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what

?
"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

,

,
"

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Jacobs

th

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

,

,

,

?
<EOS>
The

,

,
"

Deane
,
taking

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

!
<EOS>
do

,

,

,

,

<EOS>

i

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mrs.

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

giving
,
"
said
Mrs.
Glegg
.
<EOS>
"
There
's
folks
I
've
lent
money
to
,
<EOS>
as
perhaps
I
shall
repent
o
'
lending
money
to
kin
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Come
,
come
,
come
,
"
said
Mr.
Glegg
,
soothingly
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Tulliver
was
not
to
be
hindered
of
his
retort
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
've
got
a
bond
for
it
<EOS>
,
I
reckon
,
"
he
said
;
"
and
you
've
had
your
five
per
cent
,
kin

no
kin
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sister
,
"
said
Mrs.
Tulliver
,
pleadingly
,
"
drink
your
wine
,
and
let
me
give
you
some
almonds
and
raisins
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Bessy
,
I
'm
sorry
for
you
,
"
said
Mrs.
Glegg
,
very
much
with
the
feeling
of
a
cur
that
seizes
the
opportunity
of
diverting
his
bark
toward
the
man
who
carries
no
stick
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
poor
work
talking
o
'
almonds
and
raisins
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Lors
,
sister
Glegg
,
do
n't
be
so
quarrelsome
,
"
said
Mrs.
Pullet
,
beginning
to
cry
a
little
.
<EOS>
"
You
may
be
struck
with
a
fit
,
getting
so
red
in
the
face
after
dinner
,
and
we
are
but
just
out
<EOS>
o
'
mourning
,
all
of
us
,
 
and
all
wi
'
gowns
craped
alike
and
just
put
by
;
it
's
very
bad
among
sisters
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
it
_
is
_
bad
,
"
said
Mrs.
Glegg
.
<EOS>
"
Things
are
come
to
a
fine
pass
when
one
sister
invites
the
other
to
her
house
o
'
purpose
to
quarrel
with
her
and

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Softly
,
softly
,
Jane
;
be
reasonable
,
be
reasonable
,
"
said
Mr.
Glegg
.
  
<EOS>
But
while
he
was
speaking
,
Mr.
Tulliver
,
who
had
by
no

enough
to

anger
,
burst

again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
wants
to
quarrel
with
you
?
"
<EOS>
he

.
<EOS>
"
It
's
you
as
ca
n't
let
people
alone
,
but
must
be
gnawing
at
'em
forever
.
<EOS>
_
I
_
should
never
want
to
quarrel
with
any
woman
if
she
kept

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
place
,

!
"
said
Mrs.
Glegg
,

rather

.
<EOS>
"
There
's
your
betters
,
Mr.
Tulliver
,
as
are
dead
and
in
their
grave
,
treated
me
with
a
different

o
'
respect

;
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
though
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
I
've
got
a
husband
<EOS>
as'll
sit
by
and
see
me
abused
by
them
as
'
ud
never
ha
'
had
the
chance
if
there
had
n't

them
in

as
married
worse

ha
'

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
talk
o
'
that
,
"
said

Tulliver
,
"

's

,

,
for

has
n't

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said

Glegg
,

,
"
I
do

,

;
but

.
<EOS>
You
can

,
and
come

,

'll

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
heart
,

!
"
said
Mr.
Glegg
in

,
as

wife

of

room
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Tulliver
,
how
could
you
talk
so
?
"
said
Mrs.
Tulliver
,
with
the
tears
in
her

.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
her
go
,
"
said
Mr.
Tulliver
,
too
hot
to
be
damped
by
any

of

.
<EOS>
"
Let
her
go
,
and
the
sooner
the
better
;
she
wo
n't
be
trying
to
domineer
over
_
me
_
again
in

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sister
Pullet
,
"
said
Mrs.
Tulliver
,
helplessly
,
"
do
you
think
it
'
ud
be
any
use
for
you
to
go
after

and

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Better
not
,
better
not
,
"
said
Mr.
Deane
.
<EOS>
"
You
'll
make
it
up
another
day
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
sisters
,
shall
we
go
and
look
at
the
children
?
"
said
Mrs.
Tulliver
,
drying
her
eyes
.
  
<EOS>
No
proposition
could
have
been
more
seasonable
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Tulliver
felt
very
much
as
if
the
air
had
been
cleared
of
obtrusive
flies
now
the
women
were
out
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
There
were
few
things
he
liked
better
than
a
chat
with
Mr.
Deane
,
whose
close
application
to
business
allowed
the
pleasure
very
rarely
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Deane
,
he
considered
,
was
the
"
knowingest
"
man
of
his
acquaintance
,
and
he
had
besides
a
ready
causticity
of
tongue
that
made
an
agreeable
supplement
to
Mr.
Tulliver
's
own
tendency
that
way
,
which
had
remained
in
rather
an
inarticulate
condition
.
<EOS>
And
now
the
women
were
gone
,
they
could
carry
on
their
serious
talk
without
frivolous
interruption
.
<EOS>
They
could
exchange
their
views
concerning
the
Duke
of
Wellington
,
whose
conduct
in
the
Catholic
Question
had
thrown
such
an
entirely
new
light
on
his
character
;
and
speak
slightingly
of
his
conduct
at
the
battle
of
Waterloo
,
which
he
would
never
have
won
if
there
had
n't
been
a
great
many
Englishmen
at
his
back
,
not
to
speak
of
Blucher
and
the
Prussians
,
who
,
as
Mr.
Tulliver
had
heard
from
a
person
of
particular
knowledge
in
that
matter
,
had
come
up
in
the
very
nick
of
time
;
though
here
there
was
a
slight
dissidence
,
Mr.
Deane
remarking
that
he
was
not
disposed
to
give
much
credit
to
the
Prussians
,
 
the
build
of
their
vessels
,
together
with
the
unsatisfactory
character
of
transactions
in
Dantzic
beer
,
inclining
him
to
form
rather
a
low
view
of
Prussian
pluck
generally
.
<EOS>
Rather
beaten
on
this
ground
,
Mr.
Tulliver
proceeded
to
express
his
fears
that
the
country
could
never
again
be
what
it
used
to
be
;
but
Mr.
Deane
,
attached
to
a
firm
of
which
the
returns
were
on
the
increase
,
naturally
took
a
more
lively
view
of
the
present
,
and
had
some
details
to
give
concerning
the
state
of
the
imports
,
especially
in
hides
and
spelter
,
which
soothed
Mr.
Tulliver
's
imagination
by
throwing
into
more
distant
perspective
the
period
when
the
country
would
become
utterly
the
prey
of
Papists
and
Radicals
,
and
there
would
be
no
more
chance
for
honest
men
.
  
<EOS>
Uncle
Pullet
sat
by
and
listened
with
twinkling
eyes
to
these
high
matters
.
<EOS>
He
did
n't
understand
politics
himself
,
 
thought
they
were
a
natural
gift
,
 
<EOS>
but
by
what
he
could
make
out
,
this
Duke
of
Wellington
was
no
better
than
he
should
be
.
    
<EOS>
Mr.
Tulliver
Shows
His
Weaker
Side
  
"
<EOS>
Suppose
sister
Glegg
should
call
her
money
in
;
it
'
ud
be
very
awkward
for
you
to
have
to
raise
five
hundred
pounds
now
,
"
said
Mrs.
Tulliver
to
her
husband
that
evening
,
as
she
took
a
plaintive
review
of
the
day
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Tulliver
had
lived
thirteen
years
with
her
husband
,
yet
she
retained
in
all
the
freshness
of
her
early
married
life
a
facility
of
saying
things
which
drove
him
in
the
opposite
direction
to
the
one
she
desired
.
<EOS>
Some
minds
are
wonderful
for
keeping
their
bloom
in
this
way
,
as
a
patriarchal
goldfish
apparently
retains
to
the
last
its
youthful
illusion
that
it
can
swim
in
a
straight
line
beyond
the
encircling
glass
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Tulliver
was
an
amiable
fish
of
this
kind
,
and
after
running
her
head
against
the
same
resisting
medium
for
thirteen
years
would
go
at
it
again
to
-
day
with
undulled
alacrity
.
  
<EOS>
This
observation
of
hers
tended
directly
to
convince
Mr.
Tulliver
that
it
would
not
be
at
all
awkward
for
him
to
raise
five
hundred
pounds
;
and
when
Mrs.
Tulliver
became
rather
pressing
to
know
_
<EOS>
how
_
he
would
raise
it
without
mortgaging
the
mill
and
the
house
which
he
had
said
he
never
_
would
<EOS>
_
mortgage
,
since
nowadays
people
were
none
so
ready
to
lend
money
without
security
,
Mr.
Tulliver
,
getting
warm
,
declared
that
Mrs.
Glegg
might
do
as
she
liked
about
calling
in
her
money
,
he
should
pay
it
in
whether
or
not
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
going
to
be
beholden
to
his
wife
's
sisters
.
<EOS>
When
a
man
had
married
into
a
family
where
there
was
a
whole
litter
of
women
,
he
might
have
plenty
to
put
up
with
if
he
chose
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Tulliver
did
_
not
_
choose
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Tulliver
cried
a
little
in
a
trickling
,
quiet
way
as
she
put
on
her
nightcap
;
but
presently
sank
into
a
comfortable
sleep
,
lulled
by
the
thought
that
she
would
talk
everything
over
with
her
sister
Pullet
to
-
morrow
,
when
she
was
to
take
the
children
to
Garum
Firs
to
tea
.
<EOS>
Not
that
she
looked
forward
to
any
distinct
issue
from
that
talk
;
but
it
seemed
impossible
that
past
events
should
be
so
obstinate
as
to
remain
unmodified
when
they
were
complained
against
.
  
<EOS>
Her
husband
lay
awake
rather
longer
,
for
he
too
was
thinking
of
a
visit
he
would
pay
on
the
morrow
;
and
his
ideas
on
the
subject
were
not
of
so
vague
and
soothing
a
kind
as
those
of
his
amiable
partner
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Tulliver
,
when
under
the
influence
of
a
strong
feeling
,
had
a
promptitude
in
action
that
may
seem
inconsistent
with
that
painful
sense
of
the
complicated
,
puzzling
nature
of
human
affairs
under
which
his
more
dispassionate
deliberations
were
conducted
;
but
it
is
really
not
improbable
that
there
was
a
direct
relation
between
these
apparently
contradictory
phenomena
,
since
I
have
observed
that
for
getting
a
strong
impression
that
a
skein
is
tangled
there
is
nothing
like
snatching
hastily
at
a
single
thread
.
<EOS>
It
was
owing
to
this
promptitude
that
Mr.
Tulliver
was
on
horseback
soon
after
dinner
the
next
day
(
he
was
not
dyspeptic
)
on
his
way
to
Basset
to
see
his
sister
Moss
and
her
husband
.
<EOS>
For
having
made
up
his
mind
irrevocably
that
he
would
pay
Mrs.
Glegg
her
loan
of
five
hundred
pounds
,
it
naturally
occurred
to
him
that
he
had
a
promissory
note
for
three
hundred
pounds
lent
to
his
brother
-
in
-
law
Moss
;
and
if
the
said
brother
-
in
-
law
could
manage
to
pay
in
the
money
within
a
given
time
,
it
would
go
far
to
lessen
the
fallacious
air
of
inconvenience
which
Mr.
Tulliver
's
spirited
step
might
have
worn
in
the
eyes
of
weak
people
who
require
to
know
precisely
_
how
_
a
thing
is
to
be
done
before
they
are
strongly
confident
that
it
will
be
easy
.
  
<EOS>
For
Mr.
Tulliver
was
in
a
position
neither
new
nor
striking
,
but
,
like
other
every
-
day
things
,
sure
to
have
a
cumulative
effect
that
will
be
felt
in
the
long
run
:
he
was
held
to
be
a
much
more
substantial
man
than
he
really
was
.
<EOS>
And
as
we
are
all
apt
to
believe
what
the
world
believes
about
us
,
it
was
his
habit
to
think
of
failure
and
ruin
with
the
same
sort
of
remote
pity
with
which
a
spare
,
long
-
necked
man
hears
that
his
plethoric
short
-
necked
neighbor
is
stricken
with
apoplexy
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
always
used
to
hear
pleasant
jokes
about
his
advantages
as
a
man
who
worked
his
own
mill
,
and
owned
a
pretty
bit
of
land
;
and
these
jokes
naturally
kept
up
his
sense
that
he
was
a
man
of
considerable
substance
.
<EOS>
They
gave
a
pleasant
flavor
to
his
glass
on
a
market
-
day
,
and
if
it
had
not
been
for
the
recurrence
of
half
-
yearly
payments
,
Mr.
Tulliver
would
really
have
forgotten
that
there
was
a
mortgage
of
two
thousand
pounds
on
his
very
desirable
freehold
.
<EOS>
That
was
not
altogether
his
own
fault
,
since
one
of
the
thousand
pounds
was
his
sister
's
fortune
,
which
he
had
to
pay
on
her
marriage
;
and
a
man
who
has
neighbors
that
_
will
_
go
to
law
with
him
is
not
likely
to
pay
off
his
mortgages
,
especially
if
he
enjoys
the
good
opinion
of
acquaintances
who
want
to
borrow
a
hundred
pounds
on
security
too
lofty
to
be
represented
by
parchment
.
<EOS>
Our
friend
Mr.
Tulliver
had
a
good
-
natured
fibre
in
him
,
and
did
not
like
to
give
harsh
refusals
even
to
his
sister
,
who
had
not
only
come
in
to
the
world
in
that
superfluous
way
characteristic
of
sisters
,
creating
a
necessity
for
mortgages
,
but
had
quite
thrown
herself
away
in
marriage
,
and
had
crowned
her
mistakes
by
having
an
eighth
baby
.
<EOS>
On
this
point
Mr.
Tulliver
was
conscious
of
being
a
little
weak
;
but
he
apologized
to
himself
by
saying
that
poor
Gritty
had
been
a
good
-
looking
wench
before
she
married
Moss
;
he
would
sometimes
say
this
even
with
a
slight
tremulousness
in
his
voice
.
<EOS>
But
this
morning
he
was
in
a
mood
more
becoming
a
man
of
business
,
and
in
the
course
of
his
ride
along
the
Basset
lanes
,
with
their
deep
ruts
,
 
lying
so
far
away
from
a
market
-
town
that
the
labor
of
drawing
produce
and
manure
was
enough
to
take
away
the
best
part
of
the
profits
on
such
poor
land
as
that
parish
was
made
of
,
 
he
got
up
a
due
amount

irritation
against
Moss
as
a
man
without
capital
,
who
,
if
murrain
and

were
abroad
,
was
sure
to
have
his
share
of
them
,
and
who
,
the

,

further
in
.
<EOS>
It
would
do

;

,

this

,

-

,
and

let

run

,

likely

.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Tulliver
was
determined

such
shuffling
people
any

;
and
a
ride
along
the
Basset
lanes
was
not
likely
to
enervate
a
man
's
resolution
by

.
<EOS>
The
deep
-
trodden

marks
,

in
the

of

,
gave

shake
now

then
which
suggested
a

at
the
father
of
lawyers
,
who
,

,

;

<EOS>
If

;

;

.
<EOS>
Basset

,
    
"
Why
,
you
've
got
wheat
again
in
that
Corner
Close
,
I
see
;
and
never
a
bit
o
'
dressing
on
it
.
<EOS>
You
'll
do
no
good
with
it
this
year
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Moss
,
who
,
when
he
married
Miss
Tulliver
,
had
been
regarded
as
the
buck
of
Basset
,
now
wore
a
beard
nearly
a
week
old
,
and
had
the
depressed
,
unexpectant
air
of
a
machine
-
horse
.
<EOS>
He
answered
in
a
patient
-
grumbling
tone
,
"
Why
,
poor
farmers
like
me
must
do
as
they
can
;
they
must
leave
it
to
them
as
have
got
money
to
play
with
,
to
put
half
as
much
into
the
ground
as
they
mean
to
get
out
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
who
should
have
money
to
play
with
,
if
it
is
n't
them
as
can
borrow
money
without
paying
interest
,
"
said
Mr.
Tulliver
,
who
wished
to
get
into
a
slight

;
it
was
the
most
natural
and
easy
introduction
to
calling
in
money
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
I
'm
behind
with
the
interest
,
"
said
Mr.
Moss
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
was
so
unlucky
<EOS>
wi
'
the
wool
last
year
;
and
what
with
the
Missis
being
laid
up
so
,
things
have
gone
awk'arder
nor
usual
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
"
snarled
Mr.
Tulliver
,
"
there
's
folks
as
things
"
ull
allays
go
awk'ard
with
;
empty
sacks
"
ull
never
stand
upright
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
do
n't
know
what
fault
you
've
got
to
find
wi
'
me
,
Mr.
Tulliver
,
"
said
Mr.
Moss
,
deprecatingly
;
<EOS>
"
I
know
there
is
n't
a
day
-
laborer
works
harder
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
use
o
'
that
,
"
said
Mr.
Tulliver
,
sharply
,
"
when
a
man
marries
,
and
's
got
no
capital
to
work
his
farm
but
<EOS>
his
wife
's
bit
o
'
<EOS>
fortin
?
<EOS>
I
was
against
it
from
the
first
;
but
you
'd
neither
of

listen

me
.
<EOS>
And
I
ca
n't
lie
out
<EOS>
o
'
<EOS>
my
money
any
longer
,
for
I
've
got
to
pay
five
hundred
o
'
<EOS>
Mrs.
Glegg
's
,
and
there
'll
be
Tom
an

.
<EOS>
I
should
find
myself
short
,
even

I
'd

all

own
.
<EOS>
You
must
look
about
and
see
how
you
can

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
if
that
's
what
you
mean
,
"
said
Mr.
Moss
,
looking

before
him
,
"
we
'd
better
be
sold
up
,
and
ha
'
done
with
it
;
I
must
part
wi
'
every
head
o
'
stock
I
've
got
,
to
pay
you
and
the
landlord
too
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Poor
relations
are
undeniably
irritating
,
 
their
existence
is
so
entirely
uncalled
for
on
our
part
,
and
they
are
almost
always
very
faulty
people
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Tulliver
had
succeeded
in
getting
quite
as
much
irritated
with
Mr.
Moss
as
he
had
desired
,
and
he
was
able
to
say
angrily
,
rising
from
his
seat
,
    
<EOS>
"
Well
,
you
must
do
as
you
can
.
<EOS>
_
I
_
ca
n't
find
money
for
everybody
else
as
well
as
myself
.
<EOS>
I
must
look
to
my
own
business
and
my
own
family
.
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
lie
out
<EOS>
o
'
my
money
any
longer
.
<EOS>
You
must
raise
it
as
quick
as
you
can
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Tulliver
walked
abruptly
out
of
the
arbor
as
he
uttered
the
last
sentence
,
and
,
without
looking
round
at
Mr.
Moss
,
went
on
to
the
kitchen
door
,
where
the
eldest
boy
was
holding
his
horse
,
and
his
sister
was
waiting
in
a
state
of
wondering
alarm
,
which
was
not
without
its
alleviations
,
for
baby
was
making
pleasant
gurgling
sounds
,
and
performing
a
great
deal
of
finger
practice
on
the
faded
face
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Moss
had
eight
children
,
but
could
never
overcome
her
regret
that
the
twins
had
not
lived
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Moss
thought
their
removal
was
not
without
its
consolations
.
<EOS>
"
Wo
n't
you
come
in
,
brother
?
"
she
said
,
looking
anxiously
at
her
husband
,
who
was
walking
slowly
up
,
while
Mr.
Tulliver
had
his
foot
already
in
the
stirrup
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
;
good
-
by
,
"
said
he
,
turning
his
horse
's
head
,
and
riding
away
.
  
<EOS>
No
man
could
feel
more
resolute
till
he
got
outside
the
yard
gate
,
and
a
little
way
along
the
deep
-
rutted
lane
;
but
before
he
reached
the
next
turning
,
which
would
take
him
out
of
sight
of
the
dilapidated
farm
-
buildings
,
he
appeared
to
be
smitten
by
some
sudden
thought
.
<EOS>
He
checked
his
horse
,
and
made
it
stand
still
in
the
same
spot
for
two
or
three
minutes
,
during
which
he
turned
his
head
from
side
to
side
in
a
melancholy
way
,
as
if
he
were
looking
at
some
painful
object
on
more
sides
than
one
.
<EOS>
Evidently
,
after
his
fit
of
promptitude
,
Mr.
Tulliver
was
relapsing
into
the
sense
that
this
is
a
puzzling
world
.
<EOS>
He
turned
his
horse
,
and
rode
slowly
back
,
giving
vent
to
the
climax
of
feeling
which
had
determined
this
movement
by
saying
aloud
,
as
he
struck
his
horse
,
"
Poor
little
wench
!
<EOS>
she
'll
have
nobody
but
Tom
,
belike
,
when
I
'm
gone
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Tulliver
's
return
into
the
yard
was
descried
by
several
young
Mosses
,
who
immediately
ran
in
with
the
exciting
news
to
their
mother
,
so
that
Mrs.
Moss
was
again
on
the
door
-
step
when
her
brother
rode
up
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
crying
,
but
was
rocking
baby
to
sleep
in
her
arms
now
,
and
made
no
ostentatious
show
of
sorrow
as
her
brother
looked
at

,
but
merely
said
:
  
"
The
father
's
gone
to
the
field
,
again
,
if
you
want
him
,
brother
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Gritty
,
no
,
"
said
Mr.
Tulliver
,
in
a
gentle
tone
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
fret
,
 
<EOS>
that
's
all
,
 
<EOS>
I
'll
make
a
shift
without
the
money
a
bit
,
only
you
must
be
as
clever
and
contriving
as
you
can
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Moss
's
tears
came
again
at
this
unexpected
kindness
,
and
she
could
say
nothing
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
,
come
!
 
<EOS>
the
little
wench
shall
come
and
see

.
<EOS>
I
'll
bring
her
and
Tom
some
day
before
he
goes

.
<EOS>
You
must
n't
fret
.
<EOS>
I
'll
allays
be
a
good
brother
to
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
for
that
word
,
brother
,
"
said
Mrs.
Moss
,
drying

;
then
turning
to
Lizzy
,
she
said
,
"
Run
now
,
and
fetch
the
colored

for
cousin

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Lizzy
ran
in
,
and
quickly

with
a
small

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
boiled
hard
,
brother
,
and
colored
with
thrums
,
very
pretty
;
it
was
done
o
'
purpose
for
Maggie
.
<EOS>
Will

to

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
ay
,
"
said
Mr.
Tulliver
,
putting

carefully
in
his
side

.
<EOS>
"
Good
-
by
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And
so
the
respectable
miller
returned
along
the
Basset
lanes
rather
more
puzzled
than
before
as
to
ways
and
means
,
but
still
with
the
sense
of
a
danger
escaped
.
<EOS>
It
had
come
across
his
mind
that
if
he
were
hard
upon
his
sister
,
it
might
somehow
tend
to
make
Tom
hard
upon
Maggie
at
some
distant
day
,
when
her
father
was
no
longer
there
to
take
her
part
;
for
simple
people
,
like
our
friend
Mr.
Tulliver
,
are
apt
to
clothe
unimpeachable
feelings
in
erroneous
ideas
,
and
this
was
his
confused
way
of
explaining
to
himself
that
his
love
and
anxiety
for
"
the
little
wench
"
had
given
him
a
new
sensibility
toward
his
sister
.
    
<EOS>
To
Garum
Firs
  
<EOS>
While
the
possible
troubles
of
Maggie
's
future
were
occupying
her
father
's
mind
,
she
herself
was
tasting
only
the
bitterness
of
the
present
.
<EOS>
Childhood
has
no
forebodings
;
but
then
,
it
is
soothed
by
no
memories
of
outlived
sorrow
.
  
<EOS>
The
fact
was
,
the
day
had
begun
ill
with
Maggie
.
<EOS>
The
pleasure
of
having
Lucy
to
look
at
,
and
the
prospect
of
the
afternoon
visit
to
Garum
Firs
,
where
she
would
hear
uncle
Pullet
's
musical
box
,
had
been
marred
as
early
as
eleven
o'clock
by
the
advent
of
the
hair
-
dresser
from
St.
Ogg
's
,
who
had
spoken
in
the
severest
terms
of
the
condition
in
which
he
had
found
her
hair
,
holding
up
one
jagged
lock
after
another
and
saying
,
"
See
here
!
<EOS>
tut
,
tut
,
tut
!
"
<EOS>
in
a
tone
of
mingled
disgust
and
pity
,
which
to
Maggie
's
imagination
was
equivalent
to
the
strongest
expression
of
public
opinion
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Rappit
,
the
hair
-
dresser
,
with
his
well
-
anointed
coronal
locks
tending
wavily
upward
,
like
the
simulated
pyramid
of
flame
on
a
monumental
urn
,
seemed
to
her
at
that
moment
the
most
formidable
of
her
contemporaries
,
into
whose
street
at
St.
Ogg
's
she
would
carefully
refrain
from
entering
through
the
rest
of
her
life
.
  
<EOS>
Moreover
,
the
preparation
for
a
visit
being
always
a
serious
affair
in
the
Dodson
family
,
Martha
was
enjoined
to
have
Mrs.
Tulliver
's
room
ready
an
hour
earlier
than
usual
,
that
the
laying
out
of
the
best
clothes
might
not
be
deferred
till
the
last
moment
,
as
was
sometimes
the
case
in
families
of
lax
views
,
where
the
ribbon
-
strings
were
never
rolled
up
,
where
there
was
little
or
no
wrapping
in
silver
paper
,
and
where
the
sense
that
the
Sunday
clothes
could
be
got
at
quite
easily
produced
no
shock
to
the
mind
.
<EOS>
Already
,
at
twelve
o'clock
,
Mrs.
Tulliver
had
on
her
visiting
costume
,
with
a
protective
apparatus
of
brown
holland
,
as
if
she
had
been
a
piece
of
satin
furniture
in
danger
of
flies
;
Maggie
was
frowning
and
twisting
her
shoulders
,
that
she
might
if
possible
shrink
away
from
the
prickliest
of
tuckers
,
while
her
mother
was
remonstrating
,
"
Do
n't
,
Maggie
,
my
dear
;
do
n't
make
yourself
so
ugly
!
"
<EOS>
and
Tom
's
cheeks
were
looking
particularly
brilliant
as
a
relief
to
his
best
blue
suit
,
which
he
wore
with
becoming
calmness
,
having
,
after
a
little
wrangling
,
effected
what
was
always
the
one
point
of
interest
to
him
in
his
toilet
:
he
had
transferred
all
the
contents
of
his
every
-
day
pockets
to
those
actually
in
wear
.
  
<EOS>
As
for
Lucy
,
she
was
just
as
pretty
and
neat
as
she
had
been
yesterday
;
no
accidents
ever
happened
to
her
clothes
,
and
she
was
never
uncomfortable
in
them
,
so
that
she
looked
with
wondering
pity
at
Maggie
,
pouting
and
writhing
under
the
exasperating
tucker
.
<EOS>
Maggie
would
certainly
have
torn
it
off
,
if
she
had
not
been
checked
by
the
remembrance
of
her
recent
humiliation
about
her
hair
;
as
it
was
,
she
confined
herself
to
fretting
and
twisting
,
and
behaving
peevishly
about
the
card
-
houses
which
they
were
allowed
to
build
till
dinner
,
as
a
suitable
amusement
for
boys
and
girls
in
their
best
clothes
.
<EOS>
Tom
could
build
perfect
pyramids
of
houses
;
but
Maggie
's
would
never
bear
the
laying
on
the
roof
.
<EOS>
It
was
always
so
with
the
things
that
Maggie
made
;
and
Tom
had
deduced
the
conclusion
that
no
girls
could
ever
make
anything
.
<EOS>
But
it
happened
that
Lucy
proved
wonderfully
clever
at
building
;
she
handled
the
cards
so
lightly
,
and
moved
so
gently
,
that
Tom
condescended
to
admire
her
houses
as
well
as
his
own
,
the
more
readily
because
she
had
asked
him
to
teach
her
.
<EOS>
Maggie
,
too
,
would
have
admired
Lucy
's
houses
,
and
would
have
given
up
her
own
unsuccessful
building
to
contemplate
them
,
without
ill
temper
,
if
her
tucker
had
not
made
her
peevish
,
and
if
Tom
had
not
inconsiderately
laughed
when
her
houses
fell
,
and
told
her
she
was
"
a
stupid
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
laugh
at
me
,
Tom
!
"
she
burst
out
angrily
;
"
I
'm
not
a
stupid
.
<EOS>
I
know
a
great
many
things
you
do
n't
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
dare
say
,
Miss
Spitfire
!
<EOS>
I
'd
never
be
such
a
cross
thing
as
you
,
making
faces
like
that
.
<EOS>
Lucy
does
n't
do
so
.
<EOS>
I
like
Lucy
better
than
you
;
_
<EOS>
I
_
wish
<EOS>
Lucy
was
_
my
_
sister
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
it
's
very
wicked
and
cruel
of
you
to
wish
so
,
"
said
Maggie
,
starting
up
hurriedly
from
her
place
on
the
floor
,
and
upsetting
Tom
's
wonderful
pagoda
.
<EOS>
She
really
did
not
mean
it
,
but
the
circumstantial
evidence
was
against
her
,
and
Tom
turned
white
with
anger
,
but
said
nothing
;
he
would
have
struck
her
,
only
he
knew
it
was
cowardly
to
strike
a
girl
,
and
Tom
Tulliver
was
quite
determined
he
would
never
do
anything
cowardly
.
  
<EOS>
Maggie
stood
in
dismay
and
terror
,
while
Tom
got
up
from
the
floor
and
walked
away
,
pale
,
from
the
scattered

of
his
pagoda
,
and
Lucy
looked
on
mutely
,
like

from

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Tom
,
"
said
Maggie
,
at

,
going
half

,
"
I
did

mean
to
knock
it
down
,
indeed
,
indeed
I
did

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Tom
took
no
notice
of
her
,
but
took
,
instead
,
two
or
three
hard
peas
out
of

pocket
,
and
shot

with

thumbnail
against
the
window
,
vaguely

,
but
presently

of
hitting
a
superannuated
blue
-

which
was
exposing

in
the
spring

,
clearly
against

views
of
Nature
,
who
had
provided
Tom
and
the

for
the
speedy

of
this
weak

.
  
<EOS>
Thus

morning
had
been
made
heavy
to
Maggie
,
and
Tom
's
persistent
coldness
to
her
all
through

spoiled
the
fresh

for

.
<EOS>
He
called

to

at

half

's

without

to
show
it
Maggie
,
and
peeled
a
willow

for

,
without

to

.
<EOS>
Lucy
had
said
,
"
Maggie
,
should

_
you
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
like
one
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
but
Tom
was
deaf
.
  
<EOS>
Still
,
the
sight
of
the
peacock
opportunely
spreading

on
the
stackyard
wall
,
just

Garum
Firs
,
was
enough
to

.
<EOS>
And
this
was
only
the
beginning
of
beautiful
sights
at
Garum

.
<EOS>
All
the
farmyard
life
was
wonderful
there
,
 
bantams
,
speckled
and
top

;
Friesland
hens
,
with
their
feathers
all
turned
the
wrong

;
Guinea
-

that

;
pouter

;

a

,
and

dog
,
half

,
as

.
<EOS>
Then
there
were
white
railings
and

all

,
and

of

,
and
garden
-

in

patterns
,
 
nothing
was
quite
common
at
Garum
Firs
;
and
Tom
thought
that
the
unusual
size
of
the
toads
there
was

uncle

's

.
<EOS>
Toads
who
paid
rent
were
naturally
leaner
.
<EOS>
As

the
house
,
it
was
not
less

;
it
had
a

,
and
two

with

,
and
was

.
  
<EOS>
Uncle
Pullet
had
seen

from

,
and
made

,
kept

from

know
of

<EOS>
Aunt

,

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
Tom

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

"

"

<EOS>

uncle

,
that
Tom
could
not

,

,

;

but

's

.
<EOS>
Not

was
in
awe
of

;

,

had

,
 
a

.
<EOS>
A

;
and

a
sense

your

,
ten

one

.
<EOS>
The
only

is
,
that
the
Greek
boys
probably
thought
the
same
of
Aristotle
.
<EOS>
It

,

<EOS>
At

,

<EOS>
In

.
<EOS>
Now
,

"

Maggie

idea

Maggie
.
<EOS>
So
she
kept
a
few
yards
behind
them
,
unobserved
by
Tom
,
who
was
presently
absorbed
in
watching
for
the
pike
,
 
a
highly
interesting
monster
;
he
was
said
to
be
so
very
old
,
so
very
large
,
and
to
have
such
a
remarkable
appetite
.
<EOS>
The
pike
,
like
other
celebrities
,
did
not
show
when
he
was
watched
for
,
but
Tom
caught
sight
of
something
in
rapid
movement
in
the
water
,
which
attracted
him
to
another
spot
on
the
brink
of
the
pond
.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
,
Lucy
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
in
a
loud
whisper
,
"
come
here
!
<EOS>
take
care
!
<EOS>
keep
on
the
grass
!
 
<EOS>
do
n't
step
where
the
cows
have
been
!
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
pointing
to
a
peninsula
of
dry
grass
,
with
trodden
mud
on
each
side
of
it
;
for
Tom
's
contemptuous
conception
of
a
girl
included
the
attribute
of
being
unfit
to
walk
in
dirty
places
.
  
<EOS>
Lucy
came
carefully
as
she
was
bidden
,
and
bent
down
to
look
at
what
seemed
a
golden
arrow
-
head
darting
through
the
water
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
water
-
snake
,
Tom
told
her
;
and
Lucy
at
last
could
see
the
serpentine
wave
of
its
body
,
very
much
wondering
that
a
snake
could
swim
.
<EOS>
Maggie
had
drawn
nearer
and
nearer
;
she
_
must
_
see
it
too
,
though
it
was
bitter
to
her
,
like
everything
else
,
since
Tom
did
not
care
about
her
seeing
it
.
<EOS>
At
last
she
was
close
by
Lucy
;
and
Tom
,
who
had
been
aware
of
her
approach
,
but
would
not
notice
it
till
he
was
obliged
,
turned
round
and
said
,
    
"
Now
,
get
away
,
Maggie
;
there
's
no
room
for
you
on
the
grass
here
.
<EOS>
Nobody
asked
_
you
_
to
come
.
"
  
<EOS>
There
were
passions
at
war
in
Maggie
at
that
moment
to
have
made
a
tragedy
,
if
tragedies
were
made
by
passion
only
;
but
the
essential
[
Greek
text
]
which
was
present
in
the
passion
was
wanting
to
the
action
;
the
utmost
Maggie
could
do
,
with
a
fierce

of
her
small
brown
arm
,
was
to
push
poor
little
pink
-
and
-
white
Lucy
into
the
cow
-
trodden
mud
.
  
<EOS>
Then
Tom
could
not
restrain
himself
,
and
gave
Maggie
two
smart
slaps
on
the
arm
as
he
ran
to
pick
up
Lucy
,
who
lay
crying
helplessly
.
<EOS>
Maggie
retreated
to
the
roots
of
a
tree
a
few
yards
off
,
and
looked
on
impenitently
.
<EOS>
Usually
her
repentance
came
quickly
after
one
rash
deed
,
but
now
Tom
and
Lucy
had
made
her
so
miserable
,
she
was
glad
to
spoil
their
happiness
,
 
glad
to
make
everybody
uncomfortable
.
<EOS>
Why
should
she
be
sorry
?
<EOS>
Tom
was
very
slow
to
forgive
_
her
_
,
however
sorry
she
might
have
been
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
tell
mother
,
you
know
,
Miss
Mag
,
"
said
Tom
,
loudly
and

,

.
<EOS>
It
was
not
Tom
's
practice
to
"
tell
,
"
but
here
justice
clearly
demanded
that
Maggie
should
be
visited
with
the
utmost

;
not
that
Tom
had
learned
to
put

in

;
he
never

"

,
"
and
had

his

might

.
<EOS>
Lucy
was
too
entirely
absorbed
by
the
evil
that
had
befallen
her
,
 
the
spoiling
of
her
pretty
best

,
and
the
discomfort
of
being
wet
and
dirty
,
 
to
think
much
of
the

,
which
was
entirely

to

.
<EOS>
She
could
never
have
guessed
what
she
had
done
to
make
Maggie
angry
with
her
;
but
she
felt
that
Maggie
was
very
unkind

,
and

no

to
Tom
that
he

not
"
tell
,
"
only
running
along

,
while
Maggie
sat
on
the
roots

the

looked

with
her
small

.
  
<EOS>
"
Sally
,
"
said
Tom
,
when
they

,

Sally

,
with

-

,
 
<EOS>
"
Sally
,

it
was
Maggie

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
Lors
ha
'

,

?
"

,

,

_

_
.
  
<EOS>
Tom

not

to

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

to
that

guessing
which

ready

.
  
<EOS>
Sally
,
as
you

,

,

<EOS>
so

at
Garum

.
  
<EOS>
"
Goodness

!
"
<EOS>
aunt

,

;
"

!
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,
"

,

into

<EOS>
"

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

;

"

,

"

's

,
 
<EOS>
there

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Tulliver
was

,
feeling

a

.
<EOS>
As

,
the
thought
pressed

that

,

.
<EOS>
Meantime

to

cook
,
and
the
two

children
were
to
have
theirs
in

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Tulliver
went
out
to

these

,
supposing

be
close

;
but

of

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Tom
,

,

?
"
said

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

,
"
said

;

on

had

.
  
<EOS>
"

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
And

think
o
'

,

where

?
<EOS>
You
know

'll

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It

's

,

,
to

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
The

she
mounted

to

by
a
sight

that
fatal
child
,
while
Tom

not

.
  
<EOS>
"
They
're

for

,

,
"

;
"

.
<EOS>
I
wish
that
river
was
far
enough
.
"
  
<EOS>
But
when

not
only
failed
to
discern
Maggie
,
but
presently
saw
Tom

from
the
pool
alone
,
this
hovering
fear
entered
and
took
complete

,
and
she

to
meet

.
  
<EOS>
"
Maggie
's
nowhere
about
the
pond
,
mother
,
"
said
Tom
;
"
she
's
gone
away
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
You
may
conceive
the
terrified

for
Maggie
,
and
the
difficulty
of

mother
that
she
was
not

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Pullet
observed
that
the
child
might
come
to
a
worse
end
<EOS>
if
she
lived
,
there
was
no
knowing
;
and
Mr.
Pullet
,
confused
and
overwhelmed
by
this
revolutionary
aspect
of
things
,
 
the
tea
deferred
and
the
poultry
alarmed
by

unusual

to

,
 
took
up
his
spud
as
an
instrument
of

,
and
reached
down
a
key
to
unlock
the
goose
-
pen
,
as
a
likely
place
for
Maggie
to
lie

.
  
<EOS>
Tom
,
after
a
while
,
started
the
idea
that
Maggie
was
gone
home
(
without
thinking

done

under

)
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Sister
,
for
goodness
'

let
'em

and

;

.
<EOS>
Lucy
ca
n't

in
her
dirty

,
"
she

,
looking
at
that

victim
,
who
was

up
in
a
shawl
,
and
sitting
with

on
the

.
  
<EOS>
Aunt
Pullet
was
quite
willing
to
take
the
shortest
means
of
restoring
her
premises
to
order
and

,
and
it
was
not
long
before
Mrs.
Tulliver
was
in
the

,
looking

at
the
most

point
before
her
.
<EOS>
What
the
father
would
say
if
Maggie
was
lost
,
was
a
question
that
predominated
over
every
other
.
    
<EOS>
Maggie
Tries
to
Run
away
from
Her
Shadow
  
Maggie
's
intentions
,
as
usual
,
were
on
a
larger
scale
than
Tom
imagined
.
<EOS>
The
resolution
that
gathered
in
her
mind
,
after
Tom
and
Lucy
had
walked
away
,
was
not
so
simple
as
that
of
going
home
.
<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>
she
would
run
away
and
go
to
the
gypsies
,
and
Tom
should
never
see
her
any
more
.
<EOS>
That
was
by
no
means
a
new
idea
to
Maggie
;
she
had
been
so
often
told
she
was
like
a
gypsy
,
and
"
half
wild
,
"
that
when
she
was
miserable
it
seemed
to
her
the
only
way
of
escaping
opprobrium
,
and
being
entirely
in
harmony
with
circumstances
,
would
be
to
live
in
a
little
brown
tent
on
the
commons
;
the
gypsies
,
she
considered
,
would
gladly
receive
her
and
pay
her
much
respect
on
account
of
her
superior
knowledge
.
<EOS>
She
had
once
mentioned
her
views
on
this
point
to
Tom
and
suggested
that
he
should
stain
his
face
brown
,
and
they
should
run
away
together
;
but
Tom
rejected
the
scheme
with
contempt
,
observing
that
gypsies
were
thieves
,
and
hardly
got
anything
to
eat
and
had
nothing
to
drive
but
a
donkey
.
<EOS>
To
-
day
however
,
Maggie
thought
her
misery
had
reached
a
pitch
at
which
gypsydom
was
her
refuge
,
and
she
rose
from
her
seat
on
the
roots
of
the
tree
with
the
sense
that
this
was
a
great
crisis
in
her
life
;
she
would
run
straight
away
till
she
came
to
Dunlow
Common
,
where
there
would
certainly
be
gypsies
;
and
cruel
Tom
,
and
the
rest
of
her
relations
who
found
fault
with
her
,
should
never
see
her
any
more
.
<EOS>
She
thought
of
her
father
as
she
ran
along
,
but
she
reconciled
herself
to
the
idea
of
parting
with
him
,
by
determining
that
she
would
secretly
send
him
a
letter
by
a
small
gypsy
,
who
would
run
away
without
telling
where
she
was
,
and
just
let
him
know
that
she
was
well
and
happy
,
and
always
loved
him
very
much
.
  
<EOS>
Maggie
soon
got
out
of
breath
with
running
,
but
by
the
time
Tom
got
to
the
pond
again
she
was
at
the
distance
of
three
long
fields
,
and
was
on
the
edge
of
the
lane
leading
to
the
highroad
.
<EOS>
She
stopped
to
pant
a
little
,
reflecting
that
running
away
was
not
a
pleasant
thing
until
one
had
got
quite
to
the
common
where
the
gypsies
were
,
but
her
resolution
had
not
abated
;
she
presently
passed
through
the
gate
into
the
lane
,
not
knowing
where
it
would
lead
her
,
for
it
was
not
this
way
that
they
came
from
Dorlcote
Mill
to
Garum
Firs
,
and
she
felt
all
the
safer
for
that
,
because
there
was
no
chance
of
her
being
overtaken
.
<EOS>
But
she
was
soon
aware
,
not
without
trembling
,
that
there
were
two
men
coming
along
the
lane
in
front
of
her
;
she
had
not
thought
of
meeting
strangers
,
she
had
been
too
much
occupied
with
the
idea
of
her
friends
coming
after
her
.
<EOS>
The
formidable
strangers
were
two
shabby
-
looking
men
with
flushed
faces
,
one
of
them
carrying
a
bundle
on
a
stick
over
his
shoulder
;
but
to
her
surprise
,
while
she
was
dreading
their
disapprobation
as
a
runaway
,
the
man
with
the
bundle
stopped
,
and
in
a
half
-
whining
,
half
-
coaxing
tone
asked
her
if
she
had
a
copper
to
give
a
poor
man
.
<EOS>
Maggie
had
a
sixpence
in
her
pocket
,
 
her
uncle
Glegg
's
present
,
 
which
she
immediately
drew
out
and
gave
this
poor
man
with
a
polite
smile
,
hoping
he
would
feel
very
kindly
toward
her
as
a
generous
person
.
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
only
money
I
've
got
,
"
she
said
apologetically
.
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
little
miss
,
"
said
the
man
,
in
a
less
respectful
and
grateful
tone
than
Maggie
anticipated
,
and
she
even
observed
that
he
smiled
and
winked
at
his
companion
.
<EOS>
She
walked
on
hurriedly
,
but
was
aware
that
the
two
men
were
standing
still
,
probably
to
look
after
her
,
and
she
presently
heard
them
laughing
loudly
.
<EOS>
Suddenly
it
occurred
to
her
that
they
might
think
she
was
an
idiot
;
Tom
had
said
that
her
cropped
hair
made
her
look
like
an
idiot
,
and
it
was
too
painful
an
idea
to
be
readily
forgotten
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
she
had
no
sleeves
on
,
 
only
a
cape
and
bonnet
.
<EOS>
It
was
clear
that
she
was
not
likely
to
make
a
favorable
impression
on
passengers
,
and
she
thought
she
would
turn
into
the
fields
again
,
but
not
on
the
same
side
of
the
lane
as
before
,
lest
they
should
still
be
uncle
Pullet
's
fields
.
<EOS>
She
turned
through
the
first
gate
that
was
not
locked
,
and
felt
a
delightful
sense
of
privacy
in
creeping
along
by
the
hedgerows
,
after
her
recent
humiliating
encounter
.
<EOS>
She
was
used
to
wandering
about
the
fields
by
herself
,
and
was
less
timid
there
than
on
the
highroad
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
she
had
to
climb
over
high
gates
,
but
that
was
a
small
evil
;
she
was
getting
out
of
reach
very
fast
,
and
she
should
probably
soon
come
within
sight
of
Dunlow
Common
,
or
at
least
of
some
other
common
,
for
she
had
heard
her
father
say
that
you
could
n't
go
very
far
without
coming
to
a
common
.
<EOS>
She
hoped
so
,
for
she
was
getting
rather
tired
and
hungry
,
and
until
she
reached
the
gypsies
<EOS>
there
was
no
definite
prospect
of
bread
and
butter
.
<EOS>
It
was
still
broad
daylight
,
for
aunt
Pullet
,
retaining
the
early
habits
of
the
Dodson
family
,
took
tea
at
half
-
past
four
by
the
sun
,
and
at
five

the
kitchen

;
so
,
though
it
was
nearly
an
hour
since
Maggie
started
,
there
was
no

gloom
on
the
fields
to
remind

that
the
night
would
come
.
<EOS>
Still
,
it
seemed
to
her
that
she
had
been
walking
a
very
great
distance
indeed
,
and
it
was
really
surprising
that
the
common
did
not
come
within

.
<EOS>
Hitherto
<EOS>
she
had
been
in
the
rich
parish
of
Garum
,
where
was
a
great
deal
of
pasture
-
land
,
and
she
had
only
seen
one
laborer
at

distance
.
<EOS>
That
was
fortunate
in
some
respects
,
as
laborers
might
be
too

to
understand
the
propriety
of
her
wanting
to
go
to
Dunlow
Common
;
yet
it
would
have
been
better
if
she
could

met
some

who
would
tell

the
way
without

.
<EOS>
At
last
,
however
,
the
green
fields
came
to
an
end
,
and
Maggie
found
herself
looking
through
the
bars
of
a
gate
into
a
lane
with
a
wide
margin
of
grass
on
each
side

.
<EOS>
She
had
never
seen
such
a
wide
lane
before
,
and
,
without
her
knowing
why
,
it
gave

that
the
common

be
far

;

because

saw
a
donkey
with
a
log

on

grassy

,
for
she
had
seen
a
donkey
with
that

encumbrance
on
Dunlow
Common
when
she
had
been
across
it
in
her
father
's

.
<EOS>
She
crept
through
the
bars
of
the
gate
and
walked
on
with
new
spirit
,
though
not
without
haunting
images
of
Apollyon
,
and
a

,

.
<EOS>
For
poor
little
Maggie
had
at
once
the
timidity
of
an
active

and
the

that
comes
from

.
<EOS>
She
had
rushed
into
the

of
seeking
her
unknown

,
the
gypsies
;
and
now

,

hardly

,

.
<EOS>
It

not

;

,
 
a

;
for

too
much
agitated

.
<EOS>
It

a
boy
asleep
,
and

trotted

faster

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

-

,

;

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
She

on
,

,
and
thought

most

,

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
Maggie

,
and

her
aunt

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
My

,

?
"
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
It

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

"

_
<EOS>
you
_
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

;

.
<EOS>
Why

,

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Maggie

<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>
An

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

,

,
    
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
and

,

,

,

.

?
"

.

_

"

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Where

?

"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Where

"

<EOS>

?

.

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
Maggie

.
<EOS>

passed

,
 
a
rough

about

Tom
.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
She

coming

him
alone
.
<EOS>
This

as

<EOS>
"

!
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

!
"
  
<EOS>
The

<EOS>

o

"

"

<EOS>
Mr.
and

Glegg

Home
  
<EOS>
In

,

the

of
St.
Ogg
's
,
 
that

with

,
where

,

,

,

my

.
  
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
It

a

"
familiar

.
<EOS>
"
The

-

,

in
the
days

.
<EOS>
It

Normans

,
which

,

,

;

,

<EOS>
But

,

Ogg
,
the

saint
of
this

,
of
whose

I
possess

.
<EOS>
I
incline
to
the
briefest
,
since
,
if
it
should
not

wholly

,
it
is
at
least

.
"
<EOS>
Ogg
the
son
of
Beorl
,
"
says
my
private

,
"
was
a
boatman
who
gained

by
ferrying

across
the
river
Floss
.
<EOS>
And
it
came
to
pass
,
<EOS>
one

when
the

were

,
that
there

a

with

;
and

was

,
and
had
a

,
and

to
be
rowed
across

.
<EOS>
And
the
men
thereabout
questioned

,
and
said
,
"
Wherefore
dost

to
cross

river
?
<EOS>
Tarry

,
and

the
night
<EOS>
;

.
"
<EOS>
Still

went

to

.
<EOS>
But
Ogg
the
son
of
Beorl
came

said
,
"
I
will

thee
across
;
it
is
enough
that
thy

needs

.
"
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
And

came
to
pass
,
<EOS>
when
she

,
that

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
And

,
"

,

's

,

wast

,

.
<EOS>
And

<EOS>
steps

;

.
"
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

.
<EOS>
Yet

,
that

of

,
Ogg
the
son

Beorl
was

,
and
the
Blessed
Virgin
sat

,

as
of

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
This

,

,
reflects
from
a

-

the

of
the

,
which
,

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

town

even

,
 
troubles
of
the

,
when

was

-

,
where
first

thanked

for

,

for

.
<EOS>
Many
honest
citizens
lost
all
their

for
conscience
'

in
those

,
and
went
forth
beggared
from

.
<EOS>
Doubtless

are
many

now
on

in
sorrow
,
 
quaint

,

,

,

turn

angles

lead

on
a

overflowed
continually

.
<EOS>
Everywhere
the
brick
houses
have
a
mellow

,
and
in
Mrs.
Glegg
's
day
there
was
no
incongruous
new
-

,
no
plate
-

in

,
no

stucco
-
facing
or

make
fine
old
red
St.
Ogg
's
wear
the
air
of
a
town
that
sprang
up

.
<EOS>
The
shop
-
windows
were
small
and
unpretending
;
for
the
farmers
'
wives
and

who
came

on

-

were
not

;
and
the

had
no
wares
intended
for

who
would
go

and
be

no
more
.
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
even
Mrs.
Glegg
's
day
seems
far
back
in
the
past
now
,
separated
from
us
by
changes
that
widen
the
years
.
<EOS>
War
and
the
rumor
of
war
had
then
died
out
from
the
minds
of
men
,
and
if
they
were
ever
thought
of
by
the
farmers
in
drab

,
who
shook
the
grain
out
of

-

and

in
the
full
market
-

,
it
was
as
a

things
that
belonged
to
a
past
golden
age
when
prices
were
high
.
<EOS>
Surely
the
time
was
gone
forever
when
the
broad
river
could
bring
up
unwelcome
ships
;
Russia
was
only
the
place
where
the
linseed
came
from
,
 
the
more
the
better
,
 
making

for
the

with

,

.
<EOS>
The
Catholics
,
bad

,
and
the

of
trade
were
the
three
evils
mankind
had
to
fear
;
even
the
floods
had
not
been
great
of
late

.
<EOS>
The
mind
of
St.
Ogg
's
did
not
look
extensively
before
or
after
.
<EOS>
It
inherited
a
long
past
without
thinking
of
it
,
and
had
no

for
the
spirits
that
walk
the

.
<EOS>
Since
the
centuries
when
St.
Ogg
with
his
boat
and
the
Virgin
Mother
at
the
prow
had
been
seen
on
the
wide
water
,
so
many

had
been
left
behind
,
and
had
gradually

like

!
<EOS>
And
the
present
time
was
like
the
level
plain
where
men
lose
their
belief
in
volcanoes
and
earthquakes
,
thinking
to
-
morrow
will
be
as

,
and
the
giant
forces
that
used
to
shake

are

.
<EOS>
The
days
were
gone
when
people
could
be
greatly
wrought
upon
by
their
faith
,
<EOS>
still
less
change
it
;
the
Catholics
were
formidable
because
they
would
lay
hold
of
government
and
property
,
and
burn
men
alive
;
not
because
any
sane
and
honest
parishioner
of
St.
Ogg
's
could
be
brought
to
believe
in
the
Pope
.
<EOS>
One
aged
person
remembered
how
a
rude
multitude
had
been
swayed
when
John
Wesley
preached
in
the

-

;
but
for
a
long
while
it
had
not
been
expected
of
preachers
that
they
should
shake
the
souls
of
men
.
<EOS>
An
occasional
burst
of
fervor
in
Dissenting
pulpits
on
the
subject
of
infant
baptism
was
the
only
symptom
of
a
zeal
unsuited
to
sober
times
when
men
had
done
with
change
.
<EOS>
Protestantism
sat
at
ease
,
unmindful
of
schisms
,
careless
of
proselytism
:
Dissent
was
an
inheritance
along
with
a
superior
pew
and
a
business
connection
;
and
Churchmanship
only
wondered
contemptuously
at
Dissent
as
a
foolish
habit
that
clung
greatly
to
families
in
the
grocery
and
chandlering
lines
,
though
not
incompatible
with
prosperous
wholesale

.
<EOS>
But
with
the
Catholic
Question
had
come
a
slight
wind
of
controversy
to
break
the
calm
:
the
elderly
rector
had
become
occasionally
historical
and

;
and
Mr.
Spray
,
the
Independent

,

to
preach

,
in
which
he
distinguished
with
much

between
his
fervent
belief
in
the
right
of
the
Catholics
to
the
