and
his
fervent
belief
in
their
eternal
perdition
.
<EOS>
Most
of
Mr.
Spray
's
hearers
,
however
,
were
incapable
of
following
his
subtleties
,
and
many
old
-
fashioned
Dissenters
were
much
pained
by
his
"
siding
with
the
Catholics
"
;
while
others
thought
he
had
better
let
politics
alone
.
<EOS>
Public
spirit
was
not
held
in
high
esteem
at
St.
Ogg
's
,
and
men
who
busied
themselves
with
political
questions
were
regarded
with
some
suspicion
,
as
dangerous
characters
;
they
were
usually
persons
who
had
little
or
no
business
of
their
own
to
manage
,
or
,
if
they
had
,
were
likely
enough
to

.
  
<EOS>
This
was
the
general
aspect
of
things
at
St.
Ogg
's
in
Mrs.
Glegg
's
day
,
and
at
that
particular
period
in
her
family
history
when
she
had
had
her
quarrel
with
Mr.
Tulliver
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
time
when
ignorance
was
much
more
comfortable
than
at
present
,
and
was
received
with
all
the
honors
in
very
good
society
,
without
being
obliged
to
dress
itself
in
an
elaborate

of
knowledge
;
a
time
when
cheap
periodicals
were
not
,
and
when
country
surgeons
never
thought
of
asking
their
female
patients
if
they
were
fond
of
reading
,
but
simply
took
it
for

that
they
preferred
gossip
;
a
time
when
ladies
in
rich
silk
gowns
wore
large
pockets
,
in
which
they
carried
a
mutton
-
bone
to
secure
them
against
cramp
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Glegg
carried
such
a
bone
,
which
she
had
inherited
from
her
grandmother
with
a
brocaded
gown
that
would
stand
up
empty
,
like
a
suit
of
armor
,
and
a
silver
-
headed
walking
-

;
for
the
Dodson
family
had
been
respectable
for
many
generations
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Glegg
had
both
a
front
and
a
back
parlor
in
her
excellent
house
at
St.
Ogg
's
,
so
that
she
had
two
points
of
view
from
which
she
could
observe
the
weakness
of
her
fellow
-
beings
,
and
reinforce
her
thankfulness
for
her
own
exceptional
strength
of
mind
.
<EOS>
From
her
front
window
she
could
look
down
the
Tofton
Road
,
leading
out
of
St.
Ogg
's
,
and
note
the
growing
tendency
to
"
gadding
about
"
in
the
wives
of
men
not
retired
from
business
,
together
with
a
practice
of
wearing
woven

,
which
opened
a
dreary
prospect
for
the
coming
generation
;
and
from
her
back
windows
she
could
look
down
the
pleasant
garden
and
orchard
which
stretched
to
the
river
,
and
observe
the
folly
of
Mr.
Glegg
in
spending
his

among
"
them
flowers
and
vegetables
.
"
<EOS>
For
Mr.
Glegg
,
having
retired
from
active
business
as
a
wool
-

for
the
purpose
of
enjoying
himself
through
the
rest

his
life
,
had
found
this
last

so
much
more
severe
than

business
,
that
he
had
been
driven
into
amateur
hard
labor
as
a

,
and
habitually
relaxed
by
doing
the
work
of
two
ordinary

.
<EOS>
The
economizing
of
a
gardener
's

might
perhaps
have
induced
Mrs.
Glegg
to
wink

this

,
if

were

's

.
<EOS>
But
it
is
well

that
this

only

weaker

of

sex
,
who
are

the

of

on
her

's

,
which
are
hardly

of

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Glegg
on
his
side
,
too
,
had
a
double

of
mental

,
which
gave
every

of

.
<EOS>
On

one

,

,

that

,

and

as
,

.
<EOS>
(
Mr.
Glegg
had
an

,

,

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
That

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Glegg
had
chosen

Miss

as

of
female

,

himself

,

.
<EOS>
But

,
the

,

;
and

may

.
<EOS>
Now
,
good
Mr.
Glegg
himself
was
stingy
in
the
most

;
his
neighbors
called
him
"
near
,
"
which
always
means
that
the
person
in
question
is
a
lovable
skinflint
.
<EOS>
If
you
expressed

for
cheese
-
parings
,
Mr.
Glegg
would
remember
to
save

for
you
,
with
a
good
-

in
gratifying
your
palate
,
and
he
was
given
to
pet
all
animals
which
required
no

.
<EOS>
There
was
no
humbug
or

about
Mr.
Glegg
;
his

would
have
watered
with
true
feeling
over
the

a

's

,
which

-

;
but
a

to

"

of

"
would
have
seemed
to

a
mad
kind
of

rather

"

,
"
which
had
always

to

as
a
contribution
of
small

,
not
a

of

.
<EOS>
And
Mr.
Glegg
was
just
as
fond
of
saving
other
people
's

as
his
own
;
he
would
have
ridden
as
far
round
to

when

were
to

,
as

to

own

,
and
was
quite
zealous
in
trying
to
induce

to

a
cheap

for
blacking
.
<EOS>
This
inalienable
habit
of
saving
,
as
an
end
in
itself
,
belonged
to
the
industrious
men
of
business
of
a
former

,
who
made

slowly
,
almost
as
the

,
 
it

a
"
race
,
"
which

in
these
days
of

money
-

,
when
lavishness
comes
close
on

back

.
<EOS>
In
old
-
fashioned
times
an
"

"
was

without
a
little

as

,
and

,

.
<EOS>
The
true
Harpagons
were
always
marked
and

;
not

,
who
,

,

,

,

,

clear
five

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Glegg
was
one

these
men
,
found

by

the

;
and

,

,

-

's

.
<EOS>
A
man

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Glegg
,

of

,
and

,

much

;

<EOS>

,

,

;

,

's

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Glegg
's

-

was

,
that

,

,

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
Still
,

that
,
now

Glegg
had
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
She

;

"

;

<EOS>
For

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
It

;

morning
<EOS>

<EOS>
By

;

,

.

But

;

,

,

,
lest
,

,

.
<EOS>
People

ill

keeping

fine

.
<EOS>
That
was
Mrs.
Glegg
's

.
<EOS>
She
made

this

,
and

.
<EOS>
It
was
a
hard
case
that
a

,
so

,
should
not

.
<EOS>
But

,

's

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Mr.
Glegg
!
<EOS>

I

wife

<EOS>

,

,

,
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,

G.
,

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Done

,

Glegg
?
<EOS>
_
done

?
<EOS>
_
 
<EOS>
I
'm

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Not

way
to
any

,

Glegg

.
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
husbands
in
the
world
,

.
<EOS>
To

,

,

,

(

;

"

.

So

good
Mr.
Glegg
,

"

!

.
"
  
<EOS>
Baxter
had
been
open
at
least
eight

by
this

,
for
it
was
nearly
five
o'clock
;
and
if
people
are
to
quarrel
often
,
it
follows
as
a
corollary
that
their
quarrels
can
not
be

beyond

limits
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Glegg
talked
quite

the
Tullivers
that

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Glegg
went
the

that
Tulliver
was
a
sad
man
for
getting
into

,
and
was
like
enough
to
run
through

;
and
Mrs.
Glegg
,

-
way
,

,

,

<EOS>
she
should
only

.
    
<EOS>
Mr.
Tulliver
Further
Entangles
the
Skein
of
Life
  
<EOS>
Owing
to
this
new
adjustment
of
Mrs.
Glegg
's
thoughts
,
Mrs.
Pullet
found
her
task
of
mediation
the
next
day
surprisingly
easy
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Glegg
,
indeed
checked
her
rather
sharply
for
thinking
it
would
be
necessary
to
tell
her
elder
sister
<EOS>
what
was
the
right
mode
of
behavior
in
family
matters
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Pullet
's
argument
,
that
it
would
look
ill
in
the
neighborhood
if
people
should
have
it
in
their
power
to
say
that
there
was
a
quarrel
in
the
family
,
was
particularly
offensive
.
<EOS>
If
the
family
name
never
suffered
except
through
Mrs.
Glegg
,
Mrs.
Pullet
might
lay
her
head
on
her
pillow
in
perfect
confidence
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
to
be
expected
,
I
suppose
,
"
observed
Mrs.
Glegg
,
by
way
of
winding
up
the
subject
,
"
as
I
shall
go
to
the
mill
again
before
Bessy
comes
to
see

,
or
as
I
shall
go
and
fall
down
o
'
my
knees
to
Mr.
Tulliver
,
and
ask
his
pardon
for
showing
him
favors
;
but
I
shall
bear
no
malice
,
and
when
Mr.
Tulliver
speaks
civil
to
me
,
I
'll
speak
civil
to
him
.
<EOS>
Nobody
has
any
call
to
tell
me
what
's
becoming
.
"
  
<EOS>
Finding
it
unnecessary
to
plead
for
the
Tullivers
,
it
was
natural
that
aunt
Pullet
should
relax
a
little
in
her
anxiety
for
them
,
and
recur
to
the
annoyance
she
had
suffered
yesterday
from
the
offspring
of
that
apparently
ill
-
fated
house
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Glegg
heard
a
circumstantial
narrative
,
to
which
Mr.
Pullet
's
remarkable
memory
furnished
some
items
;
and
while
aunt
Pullet
pitied
poor
Bessy
's
bad
luck
with
her
children
,
and
expressed
a
half
-
formed
project
of
paying
for
Maggie
's
being
sent
to
a
distant
boarding
-
school
,
which
would
not
prevent
her
being
so
brown
,
but
might
tend
to
subdue
some
other
vices
in
her
,
aunt
Glegg
blamed
Bessy
for
her
weakness
,
and
appealed
to
all
witnesses
who
should
be
living
when
the
Tulliver
children
had
turned
out
ill
,
that
she
,
Mrs.
Glegg
,
had
always
said
how
it
would
be
from
the
very
first
,
observing
that
it
was
wonderful
to
herself
how
all
her
words
came
true
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
may
call
and
tell
Bessy
you
'll
bear
no

,
and
everything
be
as
it
was
before
?
"
<EOS>
Mrs.
Pullet
said
,
just
before

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
you
may
,
Sophy
,
"
said
Mrs.
Glegg
;
"
you
may
tell
Mr.
Tulliver
,
and
Bessy
too
,
as
I
'm
not
going
to
behave
ill
because
folks
behave
ill
to
me
;
I
know
it
's
my
place
,
as
the
eldest
,
to
set
an
example
in
every
respect
,
and
I
do
it
.
<EOS>
Nobody
can
say
different
of
me
,
if
they
'll
keep
to
the
truth
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Glegg
being
in
this
state
of
satisfaction
in
her
own
lofty
magnanimity
,
I
leave
you
to
judge
what
effect
was
produced
on
her
by
the

of
a
short
letter
from
Mr.
Tulliver
that
very

,
after
Mrs.
Pullet
's

,
informing
her
that
she
need
n't
trouble

about
her
five

,
for

should
be

back

her
in

course

the
next
month
at
farthest
,
together
with
the
interest
due
thereon
until
the

.
<EOS>
And
furthermore
,
that
Mr.
Tulliver
had
no
wish
to
behave

to
Mrs.
Glegg
,
and
she
was
welcome

house

liked

,
but
he
desired
no
favors
from
her
,
either
for

or

children
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
poor
Mrs.
Tulliver
who
had
hastened
this
catastrophe
,
entirely
through
that
irrepressible
hopefulness
of
hers
which
led
her
to
expect
that
similar
causes
may
at
any
time
produce
different
results
.
<EOS>
It
had
very
often
occurred
in
her
experience
that
Mr.
Tulliver
had
done
something
because
other
people
had
said
he
was
not
able
to
do

,
or
had
pitied
him
for
his
supposed

,
or
in
any

piqued
his

;
still
,
she
thought

-
day
,
if

in
to
tea
that
sister
Pullet
was
gone
to
try
and

up
with
sister
Glegg
,
so
that
he
need
n't
think
about
paying
in
the
money
,
it
would
give
a

to

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Tulliver
had
never
slackened
in
his
resolve
to
raise
the
money
,
but
now
he
at
once
determined
to
write
a
letter
to
Mrs.
Glegg
,
which
should
cut
off
all
possibility
of
mistake
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Pullet
gone
to
beg
and
pray
for
_
him
_
indeed
!
<EOS>
Mr.
Tulliver
did
not
willingly
write
a
letter
,
and
found
the
relation
between
spoken
and
written
language
,
briefly
known
as
spelling
,
one
of
the
most
puzzling
things
in
this
puzzling
world
.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
like
all
fervid
writing
,
the
task
was
done
in
less
time
than
usual
,
and
if
the
spelling
differed
from
Mrs.
Glegg
's
,
 
why
,
she
belonged
,
like
himself
,
to
a
generation
with
whom
spelling
was
a
matter
of
private
judgment
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Glegg
did
not
alter
her
will
in
consequence
of
this
letter
,
and
cut
off
the
Tulliver
children
from
their
sixth
and
seventh
share
in
her
thousand
pounds
;
for
she
had
her
principles
.
<EOS>
No
one
must
be
able
to
say
of
her
when
she
was
dead
that
she
had
not
divided
her
money
with
perfect
fairness
among
her
own
kin
.
<EOS>
In
the
matter
of
wills
,
personal
qualities
were
subordinate
to
the
great
fundamental
fact
of
blood
;
and
to
be
determined
in
the
distribution
of
your
property
by
caprice
,
and
not
make
your
legacies
bear
a
direct
ratio
to
degrees
of
kinship
,
was
a
prospective
disgrace
that
would
have
embittered
her
life
.
<EOS>
This
had
always
been
a
principle
in
the
Dodson
family
;
it
was
one
form
if
that
sense
of
honor
and
rectitude
which
was
a
proud
tradition
in
such
families
,
 
a
tradition
which
has
been
the
salt
of
our
provincial
society
.
  
<EOS>
But
though
the
letter
could
not
shake
Mrs.
Glegg
's
principles
,
it
made
the
family
breach
much
more
difficult
to
mend
;
and
as
to
the
effect
it
produced
on
Mrs.
Glegg
's
opinion
of
Mr.
Tulliver
,
she
begged
to
be
understood
from
that
time
forth
that
she

nothing
whatever

say
about

;
his

of

,

,
was
too

for
her

contemplate

.
<EOS>
It
was
not
until
the

before
Tom
went
to
school
,
at
the

of
August
,
that

Glegg
paid
a

her

Tulliver
,
sitting
in
her

all

,
and
showing

by
markedly

from
all

and

;
for
,

she
observed
to
her

,
"
Bessy
must
bear
the
consequence
o
'

such

,
though
I
'm
sorry

her
,
"
and
<EOS>
Mrs.
Deane
agreed
that
Bessy
was
pitiable
.
  
<EOS>
That
evening
Tom
observed
to
Maggie
:
"
<EOS>
Oh
my
!
<EOS>
Maggie
,
aunt
Glegg
's

;
I
'm
glad

'm

.
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
You
'll
_
catch

all

!
"
  
<EOS>
Maggie
was
already
so
full
of
sorrow
at
the

Tom
's
going
away
from

,
that
this
playful

of
his
seemed
very
unkind
,
and
she
cried

to

that
night
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Tulliver
's
prompt
procedure
entailed
on
him
further
promptitude
in
finding
the
convenient
person
who
was
desirous
of
lending
five
hundred

on

.
<EOS>
"
It
must
be
no
client
of
Wakem
's
,
"
he
said

;
and
yet

the
end

turned
out
to
the
contrary
;
not
because
Mr.
Tulliver
's
will
was
feeble
,
but
because
external
fact
was
stronger
.
<EOS>
Wakem
's
client
was
the
only

person
to
be
found
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Tulliver
had
a
destiny
as
well
as
Œdipus
,
and
in
this
case
he
might
plead
,
like
Œdipus
,
that
his
deed

on

rather

.
    
<EOS>
_
School
-
Time
<EOS>
_
  
<EOS>
Tom
's
"
First
Half
"
  
Tom
Tulliver
's
sufferings
during
the
first
quarter
he
was
at
King
's
Lorton
,
under
the
distinguished
care
of
the
Rev.
Walter
Stelling
,
were
rather
severe
.
<EOS>
At
Mr.
Jacob
's
academy
life
had
not
presented
itself
to
him
as
a
difficult
problem
;
there
were
plenty
of
fellows
to
play
with
,
and
Tom
being
good
at
all
active
games
,
 
<EOS>
fighting
especially
<EOS>
,
 
had
that
precedence
among
them
which
appeared
to
him
inseparable
from
the
personality
of
Tom
Tulliver
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Jacobs
himself
,
familiarly
known
as
Old
Goggles
,
from
his
habit
of
wearing
spectacles
,
imposed
no
painful
awe
;
and
if
it
was
the
property
of
snuffy
old
hypocrites
like
him
to
write
like
copperplate
and
surround
their
signatures
with
arabesques
,
to
spell
without
forethought
,
and
to
spout
"
my
name
is
Norval
"
without
bungling
,
Tom
,
for
his
part
,
was
glad
he
was
not
in
danger
of
those
mean
accomplishments
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
going
to
be
a
snuffy
schoolmaster
,
he
,
but
a
substantial
man
,
like
his
father
,
who
used
to
go
hunting
when
he
was
younger
,
and
rode
a
capital
black
mare
,
 
as
pretty
a
bit
of
horse
-
flesh
as
ever
you
saw
<EOS>
;
Tom
had
heard
what
her
points
were
a
hundred
times
.
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
He
_
meant
to
go
hunting
too
,
and
to
be
generally
respected
.
<EOS>
When
people
were
grown
up
,
he
considered
,
nobody
inquired
about
their
writing
and
spelling
;
when
he
was
a
man
,
he
should
be
master
of
everything
,
and
do
just
as
he
liked
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
very
difficult
for
him
to
reconcile
himself
to
the
idea
that
his
school
-
time
was
to
be
prolonged
and
that
he
was
not
to
be
brought
up
to
his
father
's
business
,
which
he
had
always
thought
extremely
pleasant
;
for
it
was
nothing
but
riding
about
,
giving
orders
,
and
going
to
market
;
and
he
thought
that
a
clergyman
would
give
him
a
great
many
Scripture
lessons
,
and
probably
make
him
learn
the
Gospel
and
Epistle
on
a
Sunday
,
as
well
as
the
Collect
.
<EOS>
But
in
the
absence
of
specific
information
,
it
was
impossible
for
him
to
imagine
that
school
and
a
schoolmaster
would
be
something
entirely
different
from
the
academy
of
Mr.
Jacobs
.
<EOS>
So
,
not
to
be
at
a
deficiency
,
in
case
of
his
finding
genial
companions
,
he
had
taken
care
to
carry
with
him
a
small
box
of
percussion
-
caps
;
not
that
there
was
anything
particular
to
be
done
with
them
,
but
they
would
serve
to
impress
strange
boys
with
a
sense
of
his
familiarity
with
guns
.
<EOS>
Thus
poor
Tom
,
though
he
saw
very
clearly
through
Maggie
's
illusions
,
was
not
without
illusions
of
his
own
,
which
were
to
be
cruelly
dissipated
by
his
enlarged
experience
at
King
's
Lorton
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
not
been
there
a
fortnight
before
it
was
evident
to
him
<EOS>
that
life
,
complicated
not
only
with
the
Latin
grammar
but
with
a
new
standard
of
English
pronunciation
,
was
a
very
difficult
business
,
made
all
the
more
obscure
by
a
thick
mist
of
bashfulness
.
<EOS>
Tom
,
as
you
have
observed
,
was
never
an
exception
among
boys
for
ease
of
address
;
but
the
difficulty
of
enunciating
a
monosyllable
in
reply
to
Mr.
or
Mrs.
Stelling
was
so
great
,
that
he
even
dreaded
to
be
asked
at
table
whether
he
would
have
more
pudding
.
<EOS>
As
to
the
percussion
-
caps
,
he
had
almost
resolved
,
in
the
bitterness
of
his
heart
,
that
he
would
throw
them
into
a
neighboring
pond
;
for
not
only
was
he
the
solitary
pupil
,
but
he
began
even
to
have
a
certain
scepticism
about
guns
,
and
a
general
sense
that
his
theory
of
life
was
undermined
.
<EOS>
For
Mr.
Stelling
thought
nothing
of
guns
,
or
horses
either
,
apparently
;
and
yet
it
was
impossible
for
Tom
to
despise
Mr.
Stelling
as
he
had
despised
Old
Goggles
.
<EOS>
If
there
were
anything
that
was
not
thoroughly
genuine
about
Mr.
Stelling
,
it
lay
quite
beyond
Tom
's
power
to
detect
it
;
it
is
only
by
a
wide
comparison
of
facts
that
the
wisest
full
-
grown
man
can
distinguish
well
-
rolled
barrels
from
mere
supernal
thunder
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Stelling
was
a
well
-
sized
,
broad
-
chested
man
,
not
yet
thirty
,
with
flaxen
hair
standing
erect
,
and
large
lightish
-
gray
eyes
,
which
were
always
very
wide
open
;
he
had
a
sonorous
bass
voice
,
and
an
air
of
defiant
self
-
confidence
inclining
to
brazenness
.
<EOS>
He
had
entered
on
his
career
with
great
vigor
,
and
intended
to
make
a
considerable
impression
on
his
fellowmen
.
<EOS>
The
Rev.
Walter
Stelling
was
not
a
man
who
would
remain
among
the
"
inferior
clergy
"
all
his
life
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
true
British
determination
to
push
his
way
in
the
world
,
 
as
a
schoolmaster
,
in
the
first
place
,
for
there
were
capital
masterships
of
grammar
-
schools
to
be
had
,
and
Mr.
Stelling
meant
to
have
one
of
them
;
but
as
a
preacher
also
,
for
he
meant
always
to
preach
in
a
striking
manner
,
so
as
to
have
his
congregation
swelled
by
admirers
from
neighboring
parishes
,
and
to
produce
a
great
sensation
whenever
he
took
occasional
duty
for
a
brother
clergyman
of
minor
gifts
.
<EOS>
The
style
of
preaching
he
had
chosen
was
the
extemporaneous
,
which
was
held
little
short
of
the
miraculous
in
rural
parishes
like
King
's
Lorton
.
<EOS>
Some
passages
of
Massillon
and
Bourdaloue
,
which
he
knew
by
heart
,
were
really
very
effective
when
rolled
out
in
Mr.
Stelling
's
deepest
tones
;
but
as
comparatively
feeble
appeals
of
his
own
were
delivered
in
the
same
loud
and
impressive
manner
,
they
were
often
thought
quite
as
striking
by
his
hearers
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Stelling
's
doctrine
was
of
no
particular
school
;
if
anything
,
it
had
a
tinge
of
evangelicalism
,
<EOS>
for
that
was
"
the
telling
thing
"
just
then
in
the
diocese
to
which
King
's
Lorton
belonged
.
<EOS>
In
short
,
Mr.
Stelling
was
a
man
who
meant
to
rise
in
his
profession
,
and
to
rise
by
merit
,
clearly
,
since
he
had
no
interest
beyond
what
might
be
promised
by
a
problematic
relationship
to
a
great
lawyer
who
had
not
yet
become
Lord
Chancellor
.
<EOS>
A
clergyman
who
has
such
vigorous
intentions
naturally
gets
a
little
into
debt
at
starting
;
it
is
not
to
be
expected
that
he
will
live
in
the
meagre
style
of
a
man
who
means
to
be
a
poor
curate
all
his
life
;
and
if
the
few
hundreds
Mr.
Timpson
advanced
toward
his
daughter
's
fortune
did
not
suffice
for
the
purchase
of
handsome
furniture
,
together
with
a
stock
of
wine
,
a
grand
piano
,
and
the
laying
out
of
a
superior
flower
-
garden
,
it
followed
in
the
most
rigorous
manner
,
either
that
these
things
must
be
procured
by
some
other
means
,
or
else
that
the
Rev.
Mr.
Stelling
must
go
without
them
,
which
last
alternative
would
be
an
absurd
procrastination
of
the
fruits
of
success
,
where
success
was
certain
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Stelling
was
so
broad
-
chested
and
resolute
that
he
felt
equal
to
anything
;
he
would
become
celebrated
by
shaking
the
consciences
of
his
hearers
,
and
he
would
by
and
by
edit
a
Greek
play
,
and
invent
several
new
readings
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
yet
selected
the
play
,
for
having
been
married
little
more
than
two
years
,
his
leisure

had
been
much
occupied
with
attentions
to
Mrs.
Stelling
;
but
he
had
told
that
fine
woman
what
he
meant
to
do
some
day
,
and
she
felt
great
confidence
in
her
husband
,
as
a
man
who
understood
everything
of
that
sort
.
  
<EOS>
But
the
immediate
step
to
future
success
was
to
bring
on
Tom
Tulliver
during
this
first
half
-
year
;
for
,
by
a
singular

,
there
had
been
some

concerning
another

from
the
same

and

might
further

in
Mr.
Stelling
's

,
if

understood
that
young
Tulliver
,
who
,
Mr.
Stelling
observed
in
conjugal

,
was
rather

rough

,
had
made
prodigious

in
a
short

.
<EOS>
It
was
on
this
ground
that
he
was
severe
with
Tom
about

;
he
was
clearly
a
boy
whose
powers
would
never
be
developed
through
the
medium
of
the
Latin

,
without
the
application
of
some

.
<EOS>
Not
that
Mr.
Stelling
was
a
harsh

or

;
quite
the
contrary
.
<EOS>
He
was
jocose
with
Tom
at
table
,
and
corrected
his
provincialisms
and
his
deportment
in
the
most
playful

;
but
poor
Tom
was
only
the
more

by
this

,
for
he
had
never
been
used

all
like

Stelling
's
;
and
for
the
first

in
his
life

had
a
painful
sense
that
he
was
all
wrong
somehow
.
<EOS>
When
Mr.
Stelling
said
,
as

roast

was

,
"
Now
,
Tulliver
!
<EOS>
which

decline
,
roast
-

the
Latin
for

?
"
<EOS>
Tom
,
to

in
his
coolest
moments
a

would
have
been

,
was
thrown
into

,
"
Roast
-

,
"

with

plates

that

had

,
and
,

"

.
<EOS>
"
If

could

seen

fellow

in

,

.
<EOS>
But
there
are
two
expensive
forms

,
either

procure
for
his

by

:
<EOS>
one

;

.
<EOS>
It

for

Mr.
Tulliver
paid
a

in
Tom
's

at
King
's

.
  
<EOS>
That
respectable
miller
and
maltster
had
left
Tom
behind
,
and
driven
homeward
in
a

of
great

.
<EOS>
He
considered
that

a

for
him
when

's

about

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Stelling
's

,

's
with

"
<EOS>
I

,

"
;
<EOS>
"
To

,
to
be

"
;
"
You

"
 
that

<EOS>
Except

,
 
not

,

;

.
<EOS>
Mr.

was
not
by

for

;
most

thought
Stelling
shrewd
,
and
a

powers
generally
;
it
was
chiefly

.
<EOS>
But

several

"

"

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

no

this
first

,

Tom

,
which

himself

_
<EOS>
not
_

,
and
so

for

.
<EOS>
It

,

<EOS>
As

,

<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
Sister

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah

"

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
Perhaps

.
<EOS>
There

Tom
"
ull
<EOS>
be

,

,

;
he

comes

.
<EOS>
That
's

,

,
"

Tulliver
,

,
and

on

.
  
<EOS>
Perhaps
it
was
because
teaching
came
naturally
to
Mr.
Stelling
,
that
he
set
about
it
with
that
uniformity
of

and
independence
of
circumstances
which
distinguish
the
actions
of
animals
understood
to
be
under
the
immediate

of

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Broderip
's
amiable
beaver
,
as
that
charming
naturalist
tells
us
,
busied
himself
as
earnestly
in

,
in
a

up
three

in
London
,
as
if

had
been

in

in

.
<EOS>
It
was
"
Binny
's
"
function
to
build
;
the
absence
of
water
or
of
possible
progeny
was
an

for
which
he
was
not

.
<EOS>
With
the
same
unerring

Mr.
Stelling
set
to
work
at
his
natural
method
of
instilling
the
Eton

and
Euclid
into
the
mind

Tom
Tulliver
.
<EOS>
This
,
he
considered
,
was
the
only
basis
of
solid
instruction
;
all
other
means
of
education
were
mere
charlatanism
,
and
could
produce
nothing
better
than
smatterers
.
<EOS>
Fixed
on
this
firm
basis
,
a
man
might
observe
the
display
of
various
or
special
knowledge
made
by
irregularly
educated
people
with
a
pitying

;
all
that
sort
of
thing
was
very
well
,
but
it
was
impossible
these
people
could
form
sound
opinions
.
<EOS>
In
holding
this
conviction
Mr.
Stelling
was
not
biassed
,
as
some
tutors
have
been
,
by
the
excessive
accuracy
or

own

;
and
as
to
his
views
about
Euclid
,
no
opinion
could
have
been
freer
from
personal
partiality
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Stelling
was
very
far
from
being
led
astray
by
enthusiasm
,
either
religious
or
intellectual
;
on
the
other
hand
,
he
had
no
secret
belief
that
everything
was
humbug
.
<EOS>
He
thought
religion
was
a
very
excellent
thing
,
and
Aristotle
a
great
authority
,
and
deaneries
and
prebends
useful
institutions
,
and
Great
Britain
the
providential
bulwark
of
Protestantism
,
and
faith
in
the
unseen
a
great
support
to
afflicted
minds
;
he
believed
in
all
these
things
,
as
a
Swiss
hotel
-
keeper
believes
in
the
beauty
of
the
scenery
around
him
,
and
in
the
pleasure
it
gives
to
artistic
visitors
.
<EOS>
And
in
the
same
way
Mr.
Stelling
believed
in
his
method
of
education
;
he
had
no
doubt
that
he
was
doing
the
very
best
thing
for
Mr.
Tulliver
's
boy
.
<EOS>
Of
course
,
when
the
miller
talked
of
"
mapping
"
and
"
summing
"
in
a
vague
and
diffident

,
Mr
Stelling
had
set
his
mind
at
rest
by
an
assurance
that
he
understood
what
was
wanted
;
for
how
was
it
possible
the
good
man
could
form
any
reasonable
judgment
about
the
matter
?
<EOS>
Mr
Stelling
's
duty
was
to
teach
the
lad
in
the
only
right
way
,
 
indeed
he
knew
no
other
;
he
had
not
wasted
his
time
in
the
acquirement
of
anything
abnormal
.
  
<EOS>
He
very
soon
set
down
poor
Tom
as
a
thoroughly
stupid
lad
;
for
though
by
hard
labor
he
could
get
particular
declensions
into
his
brain
,
anything
so
abstract
as
the
relation
between
cases
and
terminations
could
by
no
means
get
such
a
lodgment
there
as
to
enable
him
to
recognize
a
chance
genitive
or
dative
.
<EOS>
This
struck
Mr.
Stelling
as
something
more
than
natural
stupidity
;
he
suspected
obstinacy
,
or
at
any
rate
indifference
,
and
lectured
Tom
severely
on
his
want
of
thorough
application
.
<EOS>
"
You
feel
no
interest
in
what
you
're
doing
,
sir
,
"
Mr.
Stelling
would
say
,
and
the
reproach
was
painfully
true
.
<EOS>
Tom
had
never
found
any
difficulty
in
discerning
a
pointer
from
a
setter
,
when
once
he
had
been
told
the
distinction
,
and
his
perceptive
powers
were
not
at
all
deficient
.
<EOS>
I
fancy
they
were
quite
as
strong
as
those
of
the
Rev.
Mr.
Stelling
;
for
Tom
could
predict
with
accuracy
what
number
of
horses
were
cantering
behind
him
,
he
could
throw
a
stone
right
into
the
centre
of
a
given
ripple
,
he
could
guess
to
a
fraction
how
many
lengths
of
his
stick
it
would
take
to
reach
across
the
playground
,
and
could
draw
almost
perfect
squares
on
his
slate
without
any
measurement
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Stelling
took
no
note
of
these
things
;
he
only
observed
that
Tom
's
faculties
failed
him
before
the
abstractions
hideously
symbolized
to
him
in
the
pages
of
the
Eton
Grammar
,
and
that
he
was
in
a
state
bordering
on
idiocy
with
regard
to
the
demonstration
that
two
given
triangles
must
be
equal
,
though
he
could
discern
with
great
promptitude
and
certainty
the
fact
that
they
_
were
_
equal
.
<EOS>
Whence
Mr.
Stelling
concluded
that
Tom
's
brain
,
being
peculiarly
impervious
to
etymology
and
demonstrations
,
was
peculiarly
in
need
of
being
ploughed
and
harrowed
by
these
patent
implements
;
it
was
his
favorite
metaphor
,
that
the
classics
and
geometry
constituted
that
culture
of
the
mind
which
prepared
it
for
the
reception
of
any
subsequent
crop
.
<EOS>
I
say
nothing
against
Mr.
Stelling
's
theory
;
if
we
are
to
have
one
regimen
for
all
minds
,
his
seems
to
me
as
good
as
any
other
.
<EOS>
I
only
know
it
turned
out
as
uncomfortably
for
Tom
Tulliver
as
if
he
had
been
plied
with
cheese
in
order
to
remedy
a
gastric
weakness
which
prevented
him
from
digesting
it
.
<EOS>
It
is
astonishing
what
a
different
result
one
gets
by
changing
the
metaphor
!
<EOS>
Once
call
the
brain
an
intellectual
stomach
,
and
one
's
ingenious
conception
of
the
classics
and
geometry
as
ploughs
and
harrows
seems
to
settle
nothing
.
<EOS>
But
then
it
is
open
to
some
one
else
to
follow
great
authorities
,
and
call
the
mind
a
sheet
of
white
paper
or
a
mirror
,
in
which
case
one
's
knowledge
of
the
digestive
process
becomes
quite
irrelevant
.
<EOS>
It
was
doubtless
an
ingenious
idea
to
call
the
camel
the
ship
of
the
desert
,
but
it
would
hardly
lead
one
far
in
training
that
useful
beast
.
<EOS>
O
Aristotle
!
<EOS>
if
you
had
had
the
advantage
of
being
"
the
freshest
modern
"
instead
of
the
greatest
ancient
,
would
you
not
have
mingled
your
praise
of
metaphorical
speech
,
as
a
sign
of
high
intelligence
,
with
a
lamentation
that
intelligence
so
rarely
shows
itself
in
speech
without
metaphor
,
 
that
we
can
so
seldom
declare
what
a
thing
is
,
except
by
saying
it
is
something
else
?
  
<EOS>
Tom
Tulliver
,
being
abundant
in
no
form
of
speech
,
did
not
use
any
metaphor
to
declare
his
views
as
to
the
nature
of
Latin
;
he
never
called
it
an
instrument
of
torture
;
and
it
was
not
until
he
had
got
on
some
way
in
the
next
half
-
year
,
and
in
the
Delectus
,
that
he
was
advanced
enough
to
call
it
a
"
bore
"
and
"
beastly
stuff
.
<EOS>
"
At
present
,
in
relation
to
this
demand
that
he
should
learn
Latin
declensions
and
conjugations
,
Tom
was
in
a
state
of
as
blank
unimaginativeness
concerning
the
cause
and
tendency
of
his
sufferings
,
as
if

had

<EOS>
It

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,

need

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Phee

!
<EOS>

<EOS>
It

_
Nomen
<EOS>
non

_
.
<EOS>
"
  
"

"

,

<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
"

"
  
<EOS>
They

<EOS>

Nevertheless

<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
The

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
It

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
This

this

,
which
were

.
  
<EOS>
But

dreary
half
-

_
did
_

to

end
.
<EOS>
How

Tom
was
to

!
<EOS>
The
dark

and
the

seemed

far

;
and
that

about

,

,
when

,
and

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
But

was

,

of
the
Latin

,
the

light
in
the

at

,
as

gig
passed

;
<EOS>
the

of
passing
from

to
the

and
the

and
the

of
that

,
where
the

were
"
first
ideas
"
that
it

no

than
the
solidity
and

of
matter
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
sense
of
ease
like
the

in

where
we
were

,
where

,
and
where

;
we

.
<EOS>
Very

,

,
that

might

;

,

,

?
<EOS>
But

where
that

might

,
if

not

;

.
<EOS>
One
's

,

,

who

.
<EOS>
And

,

,
but

of
my

,
that
wove

when

were
vivid
.
    
<EOS>
The
Christmas
Holidays
  
Fine
old
Christmas
,
with
the
snowy

and
ruddy

,
had
done
his
duty
that
year
in
the
noblest
fashion
,
and
had
set
off
his
rich
gifts
of
warmth
and
color
with
all

heightening
contrast
of
frost
and
snow
.
  
<EOS>
Snow
lay
on
the
croft
and
river
-

in
undulations
softer
than
the

of
infancy
;
it
lay
with
the
neatliest
finished
border
on
every

,
making
the
dark
-
red
gables
stand

;
it
weighed

on
the

and

,
till

fell
from

with

;
it
clothed

rough

with

,
and
made
the

like
dark

;
the
gates
were
all
blocked
up
with
the
sloping

,
and
here
and
there
a
disregarded
four
-

stood
as
if
petrified
"
in
unrecumbent

"
;
there
was
no
gleam
,
no
shadow
,
for
the
heavens
,
too
<EOS>
,
were
one
still
,
pale

;
no

or

in
anything
but
the
dark

that

and

.
<EOS>
But
old
Christmas
smiled
as
he
laid
this

-

on
the
outdoor
world
,
for
he
meant
to
light

with
new

,
to
deepen

of

,
and

;

to

that
would

of

,
and

.
<EOS>
His

fell
but

,
 
fell
but

the
homes
where
the

not

,
and
where

;

had
had

,

.
<EOS>
But
the
fine
old
season
meant
well
;
and

how
to
bless

,

his
father
Time
,
with

-
unrelenting
unrelenting

,
still

,

.
  
<EOS>
And

this

,

Tom
's

,
was
not
,

,

<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>
There

,

,

,

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
The
midnight
chant
had
helped
as
usual
to
lift
the
morning
above
the
level
of
common
days
;
and
then

were
the

of
hot

and
ale
from
the
kitchen
,
at
the
breakfast

;
the
favorite

,
the
green

,
and
the
short

gave
the
appropriate

to
the
church
-
going
;
and
aunt
and
uncle
Moss
,
with
all

seven
children
,

looking

of

,
when

-

,

.
<EOS>
The
plum
-
pudding
was
of
the
same

roundness
as
ever
,
and
came
in
with
the

flames
around

,

from
the

,

had

;
the

was
as

as
ever
,
with
its

,
brown
nuts
,
and
the
crystalline
light
and
dark
of
apple
-
jelly
and
damson

;
in
all
these
things
Christmas
was
as

had
always

since
Tom
could

;
it
was
only

,
if

anything
,

superior

and

.
  
<EOS>
Christmas
was
cheery
,
but
not
so
Mr.
Tulliver
.
<EOS>
He
was
irate
and
defiant
;
and
Tom
,
though
he
espoused
his
father
's
quarrels
and
shared
his
father
's
sense
of
injury
,
was
not
without
some
of
the
feeling
that
oppressed
Maggie
when

got
louder
and
more
angry
in

and

with
the
increased

of
dessert
.
<EOS>

,

,

;

,

's

.
<EOS>
And

,

,

<EOS>
A

!
<EOS>
as

,
 
always

!
<EOS>
And

Lawyer
Gore
was
not

,

was

,

;

Wakem
.
<EOS>
Gore
was
a

fellow
.
<EOS>
His

did
not
lie

;

the
largest
amount
of
winking
,

,

not

;

,

Pivart

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

employ

,

;

's
made

,
as
Mr.
Tulliver
's

,
was
alluring

.
  
<EOS>
Much

had
Mr.

gray

;

.
<EOS>
That

.
<EOS>
Iteration
,

,

,
and

Tulliver
's

was

.
<EOS>

,

that
Pivart

as
"
thick

"
with

.

Father
,

<EOS>
The
New
Schoolfellow
  
<EOS>

;

<EOS>

.

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
The

"
  
<EOS>

Philip

<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>
No

.
  
<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>

;

,

.
<EOS>
So

Tom

;

,

?
<EOS>
By

Tom

,

"

,
"

in

,

.
  
<EOS>
All
this
,
you
remember
,
happened
in
those
dark
ages
when
there
were
no
schools
of
design
;
before

were

of

,
and

.
<EOS>
In

less

,
it

that

other

Mr.
Stelling
who
had
narrow

and
large

,
and
whose
income
,
by
a
logical

to
which
<EOS>
Fortune
,
being
a
female
as
well

,
is

,
was

not
to
their
wants
but
to
their
intellect
,
with
which
income
has
clearly
no
inherent

.
<EOS>
The
problem
these
gentlemen
had
to
solve
was
to
readjust
the
proportion
between
their
wants
and
their
income
;
and
since
wants
are
not
easily
starved
to
death
,
the
simpler
method
appeared
to
be
to
raise
their
income
.
<EOS>
There
was
but
one
way
of
doing
this
;
any
of
those
low

in
which
men
are

to

were
forbidden
to
clergymen
;
was
it
their
fault
if
their
only
resource
was
to
turn

poor
work
at

?
<EOS>
Besides
,
how
should
Mr.
Stelling
be

know
that

,

?
<EOS>
Mr.
Stelling
's

had
been
early
trained
to

in
a

,
and
he
had
no
faculty
to
spare
.
<EOS>
But
among
Tom
's
contemporaries
,
whose
fathers
cast
their
sons
on

to
find
them

after

,

were
many

less

than
Tom
Tulliver
.
<EOS>
Education
was
almost
entirely
a
matter
of
luck
 
usually
of
ill
-
luck
 
in
those
distant
days
.
<EOS>
The
state
of
mind
in
which
you
take
a

-

or

-
box
in

is
one

compared

-
fashioned
fathers
,
like
Mr.
Tulliver
,
when

or

.
<EOS>
Excellent
men
,
who
had
been
forced
all
their
lives
to

on
an
impromptu
-
phonetic
system
,
and
having
carried
on
a
successful
business
in

this

,
had
acquired
money
enough
to
give
their
sons
a
better

in
life
than
they
had
had
themselves
,
must
necessarily
take
their
chance
as
to
the
conscience
and
the
competence
of
the
schoolmaster
whose
circular
fell
in
their
way
,
and
appeared
to
promise
so
much
more
than
they
would
ever
have
thought
of
asking
for
,
including
the
return
of
linen
,
fork
,
and
spoon
.
<EOS>
It
was
happy
for
them
if
some
ambitious
draper
of
their
acquaintance
had
not
brought
up
his
son
to
the
Church
,
and
if
that
young
gentleman
,
at
the
age
of
four
-
and
-
twenty
,
had
not
closed
his
college
dissipations
by
an
imprudent
marriage
;
otherwise
,
these
innocent
fathers
,
desirous
of
doing
the
best
for
their
offspring
,
could
only
escape
the
draper
's
son
by
happening
to
be
on
the
foundation
of
a
grammar
-
school
as
yet
unvisited
by
commissioners
,
where
two
or
three
boys
could
have
,
all
to
themselves
,
<EOS>
the
advantages
of
a
large
and
lofty
building
,
together
with
a
head
-
master
,
toothless
,
dim
-
eyed
and
deaf
,
whose
erudite
indistinctness
and
inattention
were
engrossed
by
them
at
the
rate
of
three
hundred
pounds
a
-
head
,
 
a
ripe
scholar
,
doubtless
,
when
first
appointed
;
but
all
ripeness
beneath
the
sun
has
a
further
stage
less
esteemed
in
the
market
.
  
<EOS>
Tom
Tulliver
,
then
,
compared
with
many
other
British
youths
of
his
time
who
have
since
had
to
scramble
through
life
with
some
fragments
of
more
or
less
relevant
knowledge
,
and
a
great
deal
of
strictly
relevant
ignorance
,
was
not
so
very
unlucky
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Stelling
was
a
broad
-
chested
,
healthy
man
,
with
the
bearing
of
a
gentleman
,
a
conviction
that
a
growing
boy
required
a
sufficiency
of
beef
,
and
a
certain
hearty
kindness
in
him
that
made
him
like
to
see
Tom
looking
well
and
enjoying
his
dinner
;
not
a
man
of
refined
conscience
,
or
with
any
deep
sense
of
the
infinite
issues
belonging
to
every
-
day
duties
,
not
quite
competent
to
his
high
offices
;
but
incompetent
gentlemen
must
live
,
and
without
private
fortune
it
is
difficult
to
see
how
they
could
all
live
genteelly
if
they
had
nothing
to
do
with
education
or
government
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
it
was
the
fault
of
Tom
's
mental
constitution
that
his
faculties
could
not
be
nourished
on
the
sort
of
knowledge
Mr.
Stelling
had
to
communicate
.
<EOS>
A
boy
born
with
a
deficient
power
of
apprehending
signs
and
abstractions
must
suffer
the
penalty
of
his
congenital
deficiency
,
just
as
if
he
had
been
born
with
one
leg
shorter
than
the
other
.
<EOS>
A
method
of
education
sanctioned
by
the
long
practice
of
our
venerable
ancestors
was
not
to
give
way
before
the
exceptional
dulness
of
a
boy
who
was
merely
living
at
the
time
then
present
.
<EOS>
And
Mr.
Stelling
was
convinced
that
a
boy
so
stupid
at
signs
and
abstractions
must
be
stupid
at
everything
else
,
even
if
that
reverend
gentleman
could
have
taught
him
everything
else
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
practice
of
our
venerable
ancestors
to
apply
that
ingenious
instrument
the
thumb
-
screw
,
and
to
tighten
and
tighten
it
in
order
to
elicit
non
-
existent
facts
;
they
had
a
fixed
opinion
to
begin
with
,
that
the
facts
were
existent
,
and
what
had
they
to
do
but
to
tighten
the
thumb
-
screw
?
<EOS>
In
like
manner
,
Mr.
Stelling
had
a
fixed
opinion
that
all
boys
with
any
capacity
could
learn
what
it
was
the
only
regular
thing
to
teach
;
if
they
were
slow
,
the
thumb
-
screw
must
be
tightened
,
 
the
exercises
must
be
insisted
on
with
increased
severity
,
and
a
page
of
Virgil
be
awarded
as
a
penalty
,
to
encourage
and
stimulate
a
too
languid
inclination
to
Latin
verse
.
  
<EOS>
The
thumb
-
screw
was
a
little
relaxed
,
however
,
during
this
second
half
-
year
.
<EOS>
Philip
was
so
advanced
in
his
studies
,
and
so
apt
,
that
Mr.
Stelling
could
obtain
credit
by
his
facility
,
which
required
little
help
,
much
more
easily
than
by
the
troublesome
process
of
overcoming
Tom
's
dulness
.
<EOS>
Gentlemen
with
broad
chests
and
ambitious
intentions
do
sometimes
disappoint
their
friends
by
failing
to
carry
the
world
before
them
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
it
is
that
high
achievements
demand
some
other
unusual
qualification
besides
an
unusual
desire
for
high
prizes
;
perhaps
it
is
that
these
stalwart
gentlemen
are
rather
indolent
,
their
_
divinæ
particulum
auræ
_
being
obstructed
from
soaring
by
a
too
hearty
appetite
.
<EOS>
Some
reason
or
other
there
was
why
Mr.
Stelling
deferred
the
execution
of
many
spirited
projects
,
 
why
he
did
not
begin
the
editing
of
his
Greek
play
,
or
any
other
work
of
scholarship
,
in
his
leisure
hours
,
but
,
after
turning
the
key
of
his
private
study
with
much
resolution
,
sat
down
to
one
of
Theodore
Hook
's
novels
.
<EOS>
Tom
was
gradually
allowed
to
shuffle
through
his
lessons
with
less
rigor
,
and
having
Philip
to
help
him
,
he
was
able
to
make
some
show
of
having
applied
his
mind
in
a
confused
and
blundering
way
,
without
being
cross
-
examined
into
a
betrayal
that
his
mind
had
been
entirely
neutral
in
the
matter
.
<EOS>
He
thought
school
much
more
bearable
under
this
modification
of
circumstances
;
and
he
went
on
contentedly
enough
,
picking
up
a
promiscuous
education
chiefly
from
things
that
were
not
intended
as
education
at
all
.
<EOS>
What
was
understood
to
be
his
education
was
simply
the
practice
of
reading
,
writing
,
and
spelling
,
carried
on
by
an
elaborate
appliance
of
unintelligible
ideas
,
and
by
much
failure
in
the
effort
to
learn
by
rote
.
  
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
there
was
a
visible
improvement
in
Tom
under
this
training
;
perhaps
because
he
was
not
a
boy
in
the
abstract
,
existing
solely
to
illustrate
the
evils
of
a
mistaken
education
,
but
a
boy
made
of
flesh
and
blood
,
with
dispositions
not
entirely
at
the
mercy
of
circumstances
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
great
improvement
in
his
bearing
,
for
example
;
and
some
credit
on
this
score
was
due
to
Mr.
Poulter
,
the
village
schoolmaster
,
who
,
being
an
old
Peninsular
soldier
,
was
employed
to
drill
Tom
,
 
a
source
of
high
mutual
pleasure
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Poulter
,
who
was
understood
by
the
company
at
the
Black
Swan
to
have
once
struck
terror
into
the
hearts
of
the
French
,
was
no
longer
personally
formidable
.
<EOS>
He
had
rather
a
shrunken
appearance
,
and
was
tremulous
in
the
mornings
,
not
from
age
,
but
from
the
extreme
perversity
of
the
King
's
Lorton
boys
,
which
nothing
but
gin
could
enable
him
to
sustain
with
any
firmness
.
<EOS>
Still
,
he
carried
himself
with
martial
erectness
,
had
his
clothes
scrupulously
brushed
,
and
his
trousers
tightly
strapped
;
and
on
the
Wednesday
and
Saturday
afternoons
,
when
he
came
to
Tom
,
he
was
always
inspired
with
gin
and
old
memories
,
which
gave
him
an
exceptionally
spirited
air
,
as
of
a
superannuated
charger
who
hears
the
drum
.
<EOS>
The
drilling
-
lessons
were
always
protracted
by
episodes
of
warlike
narrative
,
much
more
interesting
to
Tom
than
Philip
's
stories
out
of
the
Iliad
;
for
there
were
no
cannon
in
the
Iliad
,
and
besides
,
Tom
had
felt
some
disgust
on
learning
that
Hector
and
Achilles
might
possibly
never
have
existed
.
<EOS>
But
the
Duke
of
Wellington
was
really
alive
,
and
Bony
had
not
been
long
dead
;
therefore
Mr.
Poulter
's
reminiscences
of
the
Peninsular
War
were
removed
from
all
suspicion
of
being
mythical
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Poulter
,
it
appeared
,
had
been
a
conspicuous
figure
at
Talavera
,
and
had
contributed
not
a
little
to
the
peculiar
terror
with
which
his
regiment
of
infantry
was
regarded
by
the
enemy
.
<EOS>
On
afternoons
when
his
memory
was
more
stimulated
than
usual
,
he
remembered
that
the
Duke
of
Wellington
had
(
in
strict
privacy
,
lest
jealousies
should
be
awakened
)
<EOS>
expressed
his
esteem
for
that
fine
fellow
Poulter
.
<EOS>
The
very
surgeon
who
attended
him
in
the
hospital
after
he
had
received
his
gunshot
-
wound
had
been
profoundly
impressed
with
the
superiority
of
Mr.
Poulter
's
flesh
,
 
no
other
flesh
would
have
healed
in
anything
like
the
same
time
.
<EOS>
On
less
personal
matters
connected
with
the
important
warfare
in
which
he
had
been
engaged
,
Mr.
Poulter
was
more
reticent
,
only
taking
care
not
to
give
the
weight
of
his
authority
to
any
loose
notions
concerning
military
history
.
<EOS>
Any
one
who
pretended
to
a
knowledge
of
what
occurred
at
the
siege
of
Badajos
was
especially
an
object
of
silent
pity
to
Mr.
Poulter
;
he
wished
that
prating
person
had
been
run
down
,
and
had
the
breath
trampled
out
of
him
at
the
first
go
-
off
,
as
he
himself
had
,
 
he
might
talk
about
the
siege
of
Badajos
then
!
<EOS>
Tom
did
not
escape
irritating
his
drilling
-
master
occasionally
,
by
his
curiosity
concerning
other
military
matters
than
Mr.
Poulter
's
personal
experience
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
General
Wolfe
,
Mr.
Poulter
,
 
was
n't
he
a
wonderful
fighter
?
"
said
Tom
,
who
held

that
all

commemorated
on

public
-

were
engaged
in
the
war
with
Bony
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
!
"
said
Mr.
Poulter
,
contemptuously
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nothing
o
'
the
sort
!
<EOS>
Heads
up
!
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
in
a

,
which
delighted
Tom
,
and
made
him
feel
as
if
he
were
a
regiment
in
his

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
!
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Poulter
would
continue
,
on
coming
to
a
pause
in
his
discipline
;
"
they
'd
better
not

General
Wolfe
.
<EOS>
He
did
nothing
but
die
of
his
wound
;
that
's

poor
haction
,
I

.
<EOS>
Any
other
man
'
ud
have
died
o
'
the
wounds
I
've

.
<EOS>
One

my
sword
-
cuts
'
ud
ha
'
killed
a
fellow
like
General
Wolfe
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Poulter
,
"
Tom

,
at

,
"
I

'd

and
do

sword

!
"
  
<EOS>
For
a

Mr.
Poulter
only

in

this

,
and
smiled

,
as
Jupiter
may

done

.
<EOS>
But

,

detained

twenty

usual

,
the
sword
was
brought
,
 
just
for
Tom
to
look
at
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
this
is
the
real
sword
you
fought

,
Mr.
Poulter
?
"
said
Tom
,
handling

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Has
it
ever
cut
a

's

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Head
off
?
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
and
would
,
if
he
'd
had
three

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
had

?
"
said
Tom
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
_
I
_
should
like
the
gun
and
bayonet

,
because
you
could
shoot

first
and
spear

.
<EOS>
Bang
!
<EOS>
Ps
-
s
-
s
-
s
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Tom
gave
the
requisite

to
indicate
the
double

of
pulling
the
trigger
and
thrusting

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
,
but
the
sword
's
the

when

,
"
said

Poulter
,

with
Tom
's

,
and
drawing

so

that
Tom

with
much

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
but
,
Mr.
Poulter
,

do

,
"
said
Tom
,
a

,
"
let

and

.
<EOS>
He
'll
like

see
you
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
!
<EOS>
the
humpbacked
lad
?
<EOS>
"
said
Mr.
Poulter
,
contemptuously
;
"
what
's
the
use

_
his
_

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,

,
"
said

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let

,

.
<EOS>
I
'll
show

something
different

his
bows
and
arrows
,
"
said
Mr.
Poulter
,
coughing
and

himself
up
,
while
he
gave
a
little
preliminary
play
to
his
wrist
.
  
<EOS>
Tom
ran
in
to
Philip
,
who
was
enjoying
his
afternoon
's

at
the
piano
,
in
the
drawing

room
,
picking

for

and
singing

.
<EOS>
He
was
supremely
happy
,
perched
like
an
amorphous
bundle
on
the
high

,
with
his
head
thrown
back
<EOS>
,
his

fixed
on
the

,
and
his

wide

,

forth
,
with

<EOS>
,

to
a

Arne
's
which
had
hit

.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
,
Philip
,
"
said
Tom
,
bursting
in
;
"
do
n't
stay
roaring
"
<EOS>
la
la
'
there
;
come
and
see
old
Poulter
do
his

-

in
the

!
"
  
<EOS>
The
jar
of
this
interruption
,
the
discord
of
Tom
's

coming
across
the
notes
to
which
Philip
was
vibrating
in

and

,
would
have
been
enough
to
unhinge

,
even

no
question
of
Poulter
the

;

.
<EOS>
Tom

.
  
<EOS>
Philip

.
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

.

<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

Tulliver

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
Maggie
's
Second
Visit
  
<EOS>
This
last

between
the
two
lads
was
not
readily
mended
,
and
for
some
time
they
spoke
to
each
other
no
more
than
was
necessary
.
<EOS>
Their
natural
antipathy
of
temperament
made
resentment
an
easy
passage
to
hatred
,
and
in
Philip
the
transition
seemed
to
have
begun
;
there
was
no
malignity
in
his
disposition
,
but
there
was
a
susceptibility
that
made
him
peculiarly
liable
to
a
strong
sense
of
repulsion
.
<EOS>
The
ox
 
<EOS>
we
may
venture
to
assert
it
on
the
authority
of
a
great
classic
 
is
not
given
to
use
his

as
an
instrument
of
attack
,
and
Tom
was
an
excellent
bovine
lad
,
who
ran
at
questionable

in
a
truly
ingenious
bovine
manner
;
but
he
had
blundered
on
Philip
's
tenderest
point
,
and
had
caused
him
as
much
acute
pain
as
if
he
had
studied
the
means
with
the
nicest
precision
and
the
most
envenomed
spite
.
<EOS>
Tom
saw
no
reason
why
they
should
not
make
up
this
quarrel
as
they
had
done
many
others
,
by
behaving
as
if
nothing
had
happened
;
for
though
he
had
never
before
said

Philip
that
his
father
was
a

,

so

as
to
the
relation
between

and

dubious

,

,
that

.
<EOS>
And

hectored

_
him
_
,

names
.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

would
have
"
put

"
such

.
  
<EOS>
When

,

,

,

,

<EOS>
Tom
,

,

end

,

;

;

_

,

.
<EOS>
Maggie
,

,

;

.
<EOS>

_

<EOS>
In

at

's
that

<EOS>
Tom
was

Latin
grammar
,
moving

<EOS>

<EOS>
But

<EOS>

"

!
"
  
<EOS>
Nothing

<EOS>

(

<EOS>

red

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
I
_

<EOS>

<EOS>
Oh

I
wish

"
  
<EOS>
The

"

<EOS>
March
!
<EOS>
"
stamping

<EOS>

;

One

"

"

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
She

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
She

<EOS>
A
Love
-
Scene
  
<EOS>
Poor
Tom
bore

,

was

not
"
telling
"
of
Mr.
Poulter
<EOS>
more

;

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
But
Philip

<EOS>
"

"

"

<EOS>
"

"

"

"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

"
;

<EOS>
Philip

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Philip
had
only

,
but

had
,
most

,

steeped

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Askern

,

,

?
"
<EOS>
he

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Tom

's

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

,
"

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
soon

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good

,
"

<EOS>
"
I

,
"

"

,
Wakem

and

Robert
Bruce
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
After

,
Philip

out

school
-
hours
with
Tom
and

.
<EOS>
Tom
liked
to
hear
fighting
stories
as
much
as
ever
,
but
he
insisted
strongly
on
the
fact
that
those
great
fighters
who
did
so
many

things
and
came
off
unhurt
,
wore
excellent
armor
from
head
to

,
which
made
fighting
easy
work
,
he
considered
.
<EOS>
He
should
not
have
hurt
his
foot
if
he
had
had
an
iron

on
.
<EOS>
He
listened
with
great
interest
to
a
new
story
of
Philip
's
about
a
man
who
had
a
very
bad
wound
in
his
foot
,
and
cried
out
so
dreadfully
with
the
pain
that
his
friends
could
bear
with
him
no
longer
,
but
put
him
ashore
on
a

,
with
nothing
but
some
wonderful

arrows
to
kill
animals
with
for

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
did

roar

bit
,
you

"

"

I

his
.
<EOS>
It
's

to

.
"
  
<EOS>
But

would
have
it
that
when

very

,

,

.
<EOS>

_

_

.
  
<EOS>
One

.
<EOS>
Philip

<EOS>

"

,

What
?
"

.

"

<EOS>
The

<EOS>
When

<EOS>
Philip

.
<EOS>

,

that
will
mix
,
else
they
inevitably
fall
asunder
when
the
heat

out
.
    
<EOS>
The
Golden
Gates
Are
Passed
  
<EOS>
So
Tom
went
on
even
to
the
fifth
half
-
year
 
till
he
was
turned
sixteen
 
at
King
's
Lorton
,
while
Maggie
was
growing
with
a
rapidity
which
her
aunts
considered
highly

,
at
Miss

's

in

,
with

.
<EOS>
In

Tom

had

,

,

about
Tom
's

,

,
with

.
<EOS>
She

that
Philip
was
as

again
,
and
often
cross
.
<EOS>
They
were
no

,
she

;
and
when

Tom
that
he
ought

Philip
for

:
"
Well
,

;
_

_
do

.
"
<EOS>
She
hardly

Philip
during

;
in
the
Midsummer

he
was
always
away
at
the

,
and

could

at
long

Ogg
's
.
<EOS>
When

,
she
remembered

to

,
but
,

,

was

,

Philip

.
<EOS>
The

was
void
,

,

of

;
void
as
promises
made
in
Eden
before
the

were
divided
,
and
when

starry

grew
side
by

with
the
ripening
peach
,
 
impossible
to
be
fulfilled
when
the
golden

had
been
passed
.
  
<EOS>
But
when
their
father
was
actually

in
the
long
-

,
and
Wakem
,
as
the
agent
at
once
of
Pivart

,
was

,

,

,

to
have
any

with
Philip
again
;
the

of
Wakem

her

angry
,
and
she
had
once

that
if
that

-
backed
son
lived
to
inherit

father
's
ill

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Have

to
do

,
my
lad
<EOS>
,
"

Tom
;
and

was
obeyed
the
more

because
Mr.
Sterling
by
this

;

had
expected

demanded
so
wide

,
he
had
yet
enough
of
growing

to
enable
him
to
increase
his

in
continued

to
his
income
.
  
<EOS>
As
for
Tom
's
school
course
,
it
went
on
with
mill
-
like

,
his
mind
continuing
to
move
with
a
slow
,
half
-

in
a
medium
uninteresting
or
unintelligible
ideas
.
<EOS>
But
each
vacation
he
brought
home
larger
and
larger
drawings
with
the
satiny
rendering
of
landscape
,
and
water
-
colors
in
vivid
greens
,
together
with
manuscript
books
full
of

and

,
in
which
the
handwriting
was
all
the
finer
because
he
gave
his
whole
mind
to
it
.
<EOS>
Each
vacation
he
brought
home
a
new
book
or
two
,
indicating
his
progress
through
different
stages
of
history
,
Christian
doctrine
,
and
Latin
literature
;
and
that
passage
was
not
entirely
without
results
,
besides
the
possession
of
the
books
.
<EOS>
Tom
's
ear
and
tongue
had
become
accustomed
to
a
great
many
words
and
phrases
which
are
understood
to
be
signs
of
an
educated
condition
;
and
though
he
had
never
really
applied
his
mind
to
any
one
of
his
lessons
,
the
lessons
had
left
a
deposit
of
vague
,
fragmentary
,
ineffectual
notions
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Tulliver
,
seeing
signs
of
acquirement
beyond
the
reach
of
his
own
criticism
,
thought
it
was
probably
all
right
with
Tom
's
education
;
he
observed
,
indeed
,
that
there
were
no
maps
,
and
not
enough
"
summing
"
;
but
he
made
no
formal
complaint
to
Mr.
Stelling
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
puzzling
business
,
this
schooling
;
and
if
he
took
Tom
away
,
where
could
he
send
him
with
better
effect
?
  
<EOS>
By
the
time
Tom
had
reached
his
last
quarter
at
King
's
Lorton
,
the
years
had
made
striking
changes
in
him
since
the
day
we
saw
him
returning
from
Mr.
Jacobs
's
academy
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
tall
youth
now
,
carrying
himself
without
the
least
awkwardness
,
and
speaking
without
more
shyness
than
was
a
becoming
symptom
of
blended
diffidence
and
pride
;
he
wore
his
tail
-
coat
and
his
stand
-
up
collars
,
and
watched
the
down
on
his
lip
with
eager
impatience
,
looking
every
day
at
his
virgin
razor
,
with
which
he
had
provided
himself
in
the
last
holidays
.
<EOS>
Philip
had
already
left
,
 
at
the
autumn
quarter
,
 
that
he
might
go
to
the
south
for
the
winter
,
for
the
sake
of
his
health
;
and
this
change
helped
to
give
Tom
the
unsettled
,
exultant
feeling
that
usually
belongs
to
the
last
months
before
leaving
school
.
<EOS>
This
quarter
,
too
,
there
was
some
hope
of
his
father
's
lawsuit
being
decided
;
_
that
_
made
the
prospect
of
home
more
entirely
pleasurable
.
<EOS>
For
Tom
,
who
had
gathered
his
view
of
the
case
from
his
father
's
conversation
,
had
no
doubt
that
Pivart
would
be
beaten
.
  
<EOS>
Tom
had
not
heard
anything
from
home
for
some
weeks
,
 
a
fact
which
did
not
surprise
him
,
for
his
father
and
mother
were
not
apt
to
manifest
their
affection
in
unnecessary
letters
,
 
when
,
to
his
great
surprise
,
on
the
morning
of
a
dark
,
cold
day
near
the
end
of
November
,
he
was
told
,
soon
after
entering
the
study
at
nine
o'clock
,
that
his
sister
was
in
the
drawing
-
room
.
<EOS>
It
was
Mrs.
Stelling
who
had
come
into
the
study
to
tell
him
,
and
she
left
him
to
enter
the
drawing
-
room
alone
.
  
<EOS>
Maggie
,
too
,
was
tall
now
,
with
braided
and
coiled
hair
;
she
was
almost
as
tall
as
Tom
,
though
she
was
only
thirteen
;
and
she
really
looked
older
than
he
did
at
that
moment
.
<EOS>
She
had
thrown
off
her
bonnet
,
her
heavy
braids
were
pushed
back
from
her
forehead
,
as
if
it
would
not
bear
that
extra
load
,
and
her
young
face
had
a
strangely
worn
look
,
as
her
eyes
turned
anxiously
toward
the
door
.
<EOS>
When
Tom
entered
she
did
not
speak
,
but
only
went
up
to
him
,
put
her
arms
round
his
neck
,
and
kissed
him
earnestly
.
<EOS>
He
was
used
to
various
moods
of
hers
,
and
felt
no
alarm
at
the
unusual
seriousness
of
her
greeting
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
how
is
it
<EOS>
you
're
come
so
early
this
cold
morning
,
Maggie
?
<EOS>
Did
you
come
in
the
gig
?
"
<EOS>
said
Tom
,
as
she
backed
toward
the
sofa
,
and
drew
him
to
her
side
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
came
by
the
coach
.
<EOS>
I
've
walked
from
the
turnpike
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
how
is
it
<EOS>
you
're
not
at
school
?
<EOS>
The
holidays
have
not
begun
yet
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Father
wanted
me
at
home
,
"
said
Maggie
,
with
a
slight
trembling
of
the
lip
.
<EOS>
"
I
came
home
three
or
four
days
ago
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Is
n't
my
father
well
?
"
said
Tom
,
rather
anxiously
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
quite
,
"
said
Maggie
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
's
very
unhappy
,
Tom
.
<EOS>
The
lawsuit
is
ended
,
and
I
came
to
tell
you
because
I
thought
it
would
be
better
for
you
to
know
it
before
you
came
home
,
and
I
did
n't
like
only
to
send
you
a
letter
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
father
has
n't
lost
?
"
said
Tom
,
hastily
,
springing
from
the
sofa
,
and
standing
before
Maggie
with
his
hands
suddenly
thrust
into
his
pockets
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
dear
Tom
,
"
said
Maggie
,
looking
up
at
him
with
trembling
.
  
<EOS>
Tom
was
silent
a
minute
or
two
,
with
his
eyes
fixed
on
the
floor
.
<EOS>
Then
he
said
:
  
"
My
father
will
have
to
pay
a
good
deal
of
money
,
then
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Maggie
,
rather
faintly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
it
ca
n't
be
helped
,
"
said
Tom
,
bravely
,
not
translating
the
loss
of
a
large
sum
of
money
into
any
tangible
results
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
my
father
's
very
much
vexed
<EOS>
,
I
dare
say
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
looking
at
Maggie
,
and
thinking
that
her
agitated
face
was
only
part
of
her
girlish
way
of
taking
things
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Maggie
,
again
faintly
.
<EOS>
Then
,
urged
to
fuller
speech
by
Tom
's
freedom
from
apprehension
,
she
said
loudly
and
rapidly
,
as
if
the
words
_
would
_
burst
from
her
:
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Tom
,
he
will
lose
the
mill
and
the
land
and
everything
;
he
will
have
nothing
left
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Tom
's
eyes
flashed
out
one
look
of
surprise
at
her
,
before
he
turned
pale
,
and
trembled
visibly
.
<EOS>
He
said
nothing
,
but
sat
down
on
the
sofa
again
,
looking
vaguely
out
of
the
opposite
window
.
  
<EOS>
Anxiety
about
the
future
had
never
entered
Tom
's
mind
.
<EOS>
His
father
had
always
ridden
a
good
horse
,
kept
a
good
house
,
and
had
the
cheerful
,
confident
air
of
a
man
who
has
plenty
of
property
to
fall
back
upon
.
<EOS>
Tom
had
never
dreamed
that
his
father
would
"
fail
"
;
_
that
_
was
a
form
of
misfortune
which
he
had
always
heard
spoken
of
as
a
deep
disgrace
,
and
disgrace
was
an
idea
that
he
could
not
associate
with
any
of
his
relations
,
least
of
all
with
his
father
.
<EOS>
A
proud
sense
of
family
respectability
was
part
of
the
very
air
Tom
had
been
born
and
brought
up
in
.
<EOS>
He
knew
there
were
people
in
St.
Ogg
's
who
made
a
show
without
money
to
support
it
,
and
he
had
always
heard
such
people
spoken
of
by
his
own
friends
with
contempt
and
reprobation
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
strong
belief
,
which
was
a
lifelong
habit
,
and
required
no
definite
evidence
to
rest
on
,
that
his
father
could
spend
a
great
deal
of
money
if
he
chose
;
and
since
his
education
at
Mr.
Stelling
's
had
given
him
a
more
expensive
view
of
life
,
he
had
often
thought
that
when
he
got
older
he
would
make
a
figure
in
the
world
,
with
his
horse
and
dogs
and
saddle
,
and
other
accoutrements
of
a
fine
young
man
,
and
show
himself
equal
to
any
of
his
contemporaries
at
St.
Ogg
's
,
who
might
consider
themselves
a
grade
above
him
in
society
because
their
fathers
were
professional
men
,
or
had
large
oil
-
mills
.
<EOS>
As
to
the
prognostics
and
headshaking
of
his
aunts
and
uncles
,
they
had
never
produced
the
least
effect
on
him
,
except
to
make
him
think
that
aunts
and
uncles
were
disagreeable
society
;
he
had
heard
them
find
fault
in
much
the
same
way
as
long
as
he
could
remember
.
<EOS>
His
father
knew
better
than
they
did
.
  
<EOS>
The
down
had
come
on
Tom
's
lip
,
yet
his
thoughts
and
expectations
had
been
hitherto
only
the
reproduction
,
in
changed
forms
,
of
the
boyish
dreams
in
which
he
had
lived
three
years
ago
.
<EOS>
He
was
awakened
now
with
a
violent
shock
.
  
<EOS>
Maggie
was
frightened
at
Tom
's
pale
,
trembling
silence
.
<EOS>
There
was
something
else
to
tell
him
,
 
something
worse
.
<EOS>
She
threw
her
arms
round
him
at
last
,
and
said
,
with
a
half
sob
:
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Tom
 
dear
,
dear
Tom
,
do
n't
fret
too
much
;
try
and
bear
it
well
.
"
  
<EOS>
Tom
turned
his
cheek
passively
to
meet
her
entreating
kisses
,
and
there
gathered
a
moisture
in
his
eyes
,
which
he
just
rubbed
away
with
his
hand
.
<EOS>
The
action
seemed
to
rouse
him
,
for
he
shook
himself
and
said
:
"
I
shall
go
home
,
with
you
,
Maggie
.
<EOS>
Did
n't
my
father
say
I
was
to
go
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
,
Tom
,
father
did
n't
wish
it
,
"
said
Maggie
,
her
anxiety
about
_
his
_
feeling
helping
her
to
master
her
agitation
.
<EOS>
What
_
would
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
he
do
when
she
told
him
all
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
mother
wants
you
to
come
,
 
poor
mother
!
 
<EOS>
she
cries
so
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
Tom
,
it
's
very
dreadful
at
home
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Maggie
's
lips
grew
whiter
,
and
she
began
to
tremble
almost
as
Tom
had
done
.
<EOS>
The
two
poor
things
clung
closer
to
each
other
,
both
trembling
,
 
the
one
at
an
unshapen
fear
,
the
other
at
the
image
of
a
terrible
certainty
.
<EOS>
When
Maggie
spoke
,
it
was
hardly
above
a
whisper
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
 
and
 
poor
father
   
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Maggie
could
not
utter
it
.
<EOS>
But
the
suspense
was
intolerable
to
Tom
.
<EOS>
A
vague
idea
of
going
to
prison
,
as
a
consequence
of
debt
,
was
the
shape
his
fears
had
begun
to
take
.
  
<EOS>
"
Where
's
my
father
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
impatiently
.
"
<EOS>
_
Tell
_
me
,
Maggie
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
's
at
home
,
"
said
Maggie
,
finding
it
easier
to
reply
to
that
question
.
<EOS>
"
But
,
"
she
added
,
after
a
pause
,
"
not
himself
 
<EOS>
he
fell
off
his
horse
.
<EOS>
He
has
known
nobody
but
me
ever
since
 
he
seems
to
have
lost
his
senses
.
<EOS>
O
father
,
father
   
"
  
With
these
last
words
,
Maggie
's
sobs
burst
forth
with
the
more
violence
for
the
previous
struggle
against
them
.
<EOS>
Tom
felt
that
pressure
of
the
heart
which
forbids
tears
;
he
had
no
distinct
vision
of
their
troubles
as
Maggie
had
,
who
had
been
at
home
;
he
only
felt
the
crushing
weight
of
what
seemed
unmitigated
misfortune
.
<EOS>
He
tightened
his
arm
almost
convulsively
round
Maggie
as
she
sobbed
,
but
his
face
looked
rigid
and
tearless
,
his
eyes
blank
,
 
as
if
a
black
curtain
of
cloud
had
suddenly
fallen
on
his
path
.
  
<EOS>
But
Maggie
soon
checked
herself
abruptly
;
a
single
thought
had
acted
on
her
like
a
startling
sound
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
must
set
out
,
Tom
,
we
must
not
stay
.
<EOS>
Father
will
miss
me
;
we
must
be
at
the
turnpike
at
ten
to
meet
the
coach
.
"
<EOS>
She
said
this
with
hasty
decision
,
rubbing
her
eyes
,
and
rising
to
seize
her
bonnet
.
  
<EOS>
Tom
at
once
felt
the
same
impulse
,
and
rose
too
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Wait
a
minute
,
Maggie
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
speak
to
Mr.
Stelling
,
and
then
we
'll
go
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
thought
he
must
go
to
the
study
where
the
pupils
were
;
but
on
his
way
he
met
Mr.
Stelling
,
who
had
heard
from
his
wife
that
Maggie
appeared
to
be
in
trouble
when
she
asked
for
her
brother
,
and
now
that
he
thought
the
brother
and
sister
had
been
alone
long
enough
,
was
coming
to
inquire
and
offer
his
sympathy
.
  
<EOS>
"
Please
,
sir
,
I
must
go
home
,
"
<EOS>
Tom
said
abruptly
,
as
he
met
Mr.
Stelling
in
the
passage
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
go
back
with
my
sister
directly
.
<EOS>
My
father
's
lost
his
lawsuit
 
<EOS>
he
's
lost
all
his
property
 
<EOS>
and
he
's
very
ill
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Stelling
felt
like
a
kind
-
hearted
man
;
he
foresaw
a
probable
money
loss
for
himself
,
but
this
had
no
appreciable
share
in
his
feeling
,
while
he
looked
with
grave
pity
at
the
brother
and
sister
for
whom
youth
and
sorrow
had
begun
together
.
<EOS>
When
he
knew
how
Maggie
had
come
,
and
how
eager
she
was
to
get
home
again
,
he
hurried
their
departure
,
only
whispering
something
to
Mrs.
Stelling
,
who
had
followed
him
,
and
who
immediately
left
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
Tom
and
Maggie
were
standing
on
the
door
-
step
,
ready
to
set
out
,
when
Mrs.
Stelling
came
with
a
little
basket
,
which
she
hung
on
Maggie
's
arm
,
saying
:
"
Do
remember
to
eat
something
on
the
way
,
dear
.
<EOS>
"
Maggie
's
heart
went
out
toward
this
woman
whom
she
had
never
liked
,
and
she
kissed
her
silently
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
first
sign
within
the
poor
child
of
that
new
sense
which
is
the
gift
of
sorrow
,
 
that
susceptibility
to
the
bare
offices
of
humanity
which
raises
them
into
a
bond
of
loving
fellowship
,
as
to
haggard
men
among
the
ice
-
bergs
the
mere
presence
of
an
ordinary
comrade
stirs
the
deep
fountains
of
affection
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Stelling
put
his
hand
on
Tom
's
shoulder
and
said
:
"
God
bless
you
,
my
boy
;
let
me
know
how
you
get
on
.
<EOS>
"
Then
he
pressed
Maggie
's
hand
;
but
there
were
no
audible
good
-
byes
.
<EOS>
Tom
had
so
often
thought
how
joyful
he
should
be
the
day
he
left
school
"
for
good
"
!
<EOS>
And
now
his
school
years
seemed
like
a
holiday
that
had
come
to
an
end
.
  
<EOS>
The
two
slight
youthful
figures
soon
grew
indistinct
on
the
distant
road
,
 
were
soon
lost
behind
the
projecting
hedgerow
.
  
<EOS>
They
had
gone
forth
together
into
their
life
of
sorrow
,
and
they
would
never
more
see
the
sunshine
undimmed
by
remembered
cares
.
<EOS>
They
had
entered
the
thorny
wilderness
,
and
the
golden
gates
of
their
childhood
had
forever
closed
behind
them
.
    
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
The
Downfall
_
  
<EOS>
What
Had
Happened
at
Home
  
<EOS>
When
Mr.
Tulliver
first
knew
the
fact
that
the
law
-
suit
was
decided
against
him
,
and
that
Pivart
and
Wakem
were
triumphant
,
every
one
who
happened
to
observe
him
at
the
time
thought
that
,
for
so
confident
and
hot
-
tempered
a
man
,
he
bore
the
blow
remarkably
well
.
<EOS>
He
thought
so
himself
;
he
thought
he
was
going
to
show
that
if
Wakem
or
anybody
else
considered
him
crushed
,
they
would
find
themselves
mistaken
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
refuse
to
see
that
the
costs
of
this
protracted
suit
would
take
more
than
he
possessed
to
pay
them
;
but
he
appeared
to
himself
to
be
full
of
expedients
by
which
he
could
ward
off
any
results
but
such
as
were
tolerable
,
and
could
avoid
the
appearance
of
breaking
down
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
All
the
obstinacy
and
defiance
of
his
nature
,
driven
out
of
their
old
channel
,
found
a
vent
for
themselves
in
the
immediate
formation
of
plans
by
which
he
would
meet
his
difficulties
,
and
remain
Mr.
Tulliver
of
Dorlcote
Mill
in
spite
of
them
.
<EOS>
There
was
such
a
rush
of
projects
in
his
brain
,
that
it
was
no
wonder
his
face
was
flushed
when
he
came
away
from
his
talk
with
his
attorney
,
Mr.
Gore
,
and
mounted
his
horse
to
ride
home
from
Lindum
.
<EOS>
There
was
Furley
,
who
held
the
mortgage
on
the
land
,
 
a
reasonable
fellow
,
who
would
see
his
own
interest
,
Mr.
Tulliver
was
convinced
,
and
who
would
be
glad
not
only
to
purchase
the
whole
estate
,
including
the
mill
and
homestead
,
but
would
accept
Mr.
Tulliver
as
tenant
,
and
be
willing
to
advance
money
to
be
repaid
with
high
interest
out
of
the
profits
of
the
business
,
which
would
be
made
over
to
him
,
Mr.
Tulliver
only
taking
enough
barely
to
maintain
himself
and
his
family
.
<EOS>
Who
would
neglect
such
a
profitable
investment
?
<EOS>
Certainly
not
Furley
,
for
Mr.
Tulliver
had
determined
that
Furley
should
meet
his
plans
with
the
utmost
alacrity
;
and
there
are
men
whoses
brains
have
not
yet
been
dangerously
heated
by
the
loss
of
a
lawsuit
,
who
are
apt
to
see
in
their
own
interest
or
desires
a
motive
for
other
men
's
actions
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
doubt
(
in
the
miller
's
mind
)
<EOS>
that
Furley
would
do
just
what
was
desirable
;
and
if
he
did
 
why
,
things
would
not
be
so
very
much
worse
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Tulliver
and
his
family
must
live
more
meagrely
and
humbly
,
but
it
would
only
be
till
the
profits
of
the
business
had
paid
off
Furley
's
advances
,
and
that
might
be
while
Mr.
Tulliver
had
still
a
good
many
years
of
life
before
him
.
<EOS>
It
was
clear
that
the
costs
of
the
suit
could
be
paid
without
his
being
obliged
to
turn
out
of
his
old
place
,
and
look
like
a
ruined
man
.
<EOS>
It
was
certainly
an
awkward
moment
in
his
affairs
.
<EOS>
There
was
that
suretyship
for
poor
Riley
,
who
had
died
suddenly
last
April
,
and
left
his
friend
saddled
with
a
debt
of
two
hundred
and
fifty
pounds
,
 
a
fact
which
had
helped
to
make
Mr.
Tulliver
's
banking
book
less
pleasant
reading
than
a
man
might
desire
toward
Christmas
.
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
he
had
never
been
one
of
those
poor
-
spirited
sneaks
who
would
refuse
to
give
a
helping
hand
to
a
fellow
-
traveller
in
this
puzzling
world
.
<EOS>
The
really
vexatious
business
was
the
fact
that
some
months
ago
the
creditor
who
had
lent
him
the
five
hundred
pounds
to
repay
Mrs.
Glegg
had
become
uneasy
about
his
money
(
set
on
by
Wakem
,
of
course
)
,
and
Mr.
Tulliver
,
still
confident
that
he
should
gain
his
suit
,
and
finding
it
eminently
inconvenient
to
raise
the
said
sum
until
that
desirable
issue
had
taken
place
,
had
rashly
acceded
to
the
demand
that
he
should
give
a
bill
of
sale
on
his
household
furniture
and
some
other
effects
,
as
security
in
lieu
of
the
bond
.
<EOS>
It
was
all
one
,
he
had
said
to
himself
;
he
should
soon
pay
off
the
money
,
and
there
was
no
harm
in
giving
that
security
any
more
than
another
.
<EOS>
But
now
the
consequences
of
this
bill
of
sale
occurred
to
him
in
a
new
light
,
and
he
remembered
that
the
time
was
close
at
hand
when
it
would
be
enforced
unless
the
money
were
repaid
.
<EOS>
Two
months
ago
he
would
have
declared
stoutly
that
he
would
never
be
beholden
to
his
wife
's
friends
;
but
now
he
told
himself
as
stoutly
that
it
was
nothing
but
right
and
natural
<EOS>
that
Bessy
should
go
to
the
Pullets
and
explain
the
thing
to
them
<EOS>
;
they
would
hardly
let
Bessy
's
furniture
be
sold
,
and
it
might
be
security
to
Pullet
if
he
advanced
the
money
,
 
there
would
,
after
all
,
be
no
gift
or
favor
in
the
matter
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Tulliver
would
never
have
asked
for
anything
from
so
poor
-
spirited
a
fellow
for
himself
,
but
Bessy
might
do
so
if
she
liked
.
  
<EOS>
It
is
precisely
the
proudest
and
most
obstinate
men
who
are
the
most
liable
to
shift
their
position
and
contradict
themselves
in
this
sudden
manner
;
everything
is
easier
to
them
than
to
face
the
simple
fact
that
they
have
been
thoroughly
defeated
,
and
must
begin
life
anew
.
<EOS>
And
Mr.
Tulliver
,
you
perceive
,
though
nothing
more
than
a
superior
miller
and
maltster
,
was
as
proud
and
obstinate
as
if
he
had
been
a
very
lofty
personage
,
in
whom
such
dispositions
might
be
a
source
of
that
conspicuous
,
far
-
echoing
tragedy
,
which
sweeps
the
stage
in
regal
robes
,
and
makes
the
dullest
chronicler
sublime
.
<EOS>
The
pride
and
obstinacy
of
millers
and
other
insignificant
people
,
whom
you
pass
unnoticingly
on
the
road
every
day
,
have
their
tragedy
too
;
but
it
is
of
that
unwept
,
hidden
sort
that
goes
on
from
generation
to
generation
,
and
leaves
no
record
,
 
such
tragedy
,
perhaps
,
as
lies
in
the
conflicts
of
young
souls
,
hungry
for
joy
,
under
a
lot
made
suddenly
hard
to
them
,
under
the
dreariness
of
a
home
where
the
morning
brings
no
promise
with
it
,
and
where
the
unexpectant
discontent
of
worn
and
disappointed
parents
weighs
on
the
children
like
a
damp
,
thick
air
,
in
which
all
the
functions
of
life
are
depressed
;
or
such
tragedy
as
lies
in
the
slow
or
sudden
death
that
follows
on
a
bruised
passion
,
though
it
may
be
a
death
that
finds
only
a
parish
funeral
.
<EOS>
There
are
certain
animals
to
which
tenacity
of
position
is
a
law
of
life
,
 
they
can
never
flourish
again
,
after
a
single
wrench
:
and
there
are
certain
human
beings
to
whom
predominance
is
a
law
of
life
,
 
<EOS>
they
can
only
sustain
humiliation
so
long
as
they
can
refuse
to
believe
in
it
,
and
,
in
their
own
conception
,
predominate
still
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Tulliver
was
still
predominating
,
in
his
own
imagination
,
as
he
approached
St.
Ogg
's
,
through
which
he
had
to
pass
on
his
way
homeward
.
<EOS>
But
what
was
it
that
suggested
to
him
,
as
he
saw
the
Laceham
coach
entering
the
town
,
to
follow
it
to
the
coach
-
office
,
and
get
the
clerk
there
to
write
a
letter
,
requiring
Maggie
to
come
home
the
very
next
day
?
<EOS>
Mr.
Tulliver
's
own
hand
shook
too
much
under
his
excitement
for
him
to
write
himself
,
and
he
wanted
the
letter
to
be
given
to
the
coachman
to
deliver
at
Miss
Firniss
's
school
in

morning
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
craving
which
he
would
not
account
for
to

,
to
have
Maggie
near
him
,
without
delay
,
 
she
must
come
back
by
the
coach
to
-
morrow
.
  
<EOS>
To
Mrs.
Tulliver
,
when
he
got
home
,
he
would
admit
no
difficulties
,
and
scolded
down
her
burst
of
grief
on
hearing
that
the
lawsuit
was
lost
,
by
angry

that
there

nothing
to

.
<EOS>
He
said
nothing
to
her
that
night
about
the
bill
of
sale
and

to
Mrs.
Pullet
,
for
he
had
kept
her
in

of
the
nature
of
that
transaction
,
and
had
explained
the
necessity
for
taking
an
inventory
of
the
goods
as
a
matter
connected
with
his
will
.
<EOS>
The
possession
of
a
wife
conspicuously
one
's
inferior
in
intellect
is
,
like
other
high
privileges
,
attended
with
a
few
inconveniences
,
and
,
among
the
rest
,
with
the
occasional
necessity
for
using
a
little
deception
.
  
<EOS>
The
next
day
Mr.
Tulliver
was
again
on
horseback
in
the
afternoon
,
on
his
way
to
Mr.
Gore
's
office
at
St.
Ogg
's
.
<EOS>
Gore
was
to
have
seen
Furley
in
the
morning
,
and
to
have
sounded
him
in
relation
to
Mr.
Tulliver
's
affairs
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
not
gone
half
-
way
when
he
met
a
clerk
from
Mr.
Gore
's
office
,
who
was
bringing
a
letter
to
Mr.
Tulliver
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Gore
had
been
prevented
by
a
sudden
call
of
business
from
waiting
at
his
office
to
see
Mr.
Tulliver
,
according
to
appointment
,
but
would
be
at
his
office
at
eleven
to
-
morrow
morning
,
and
meanwhile
had
sent
some
important
information
by
letter
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
Mr.
Tulliver
,
taking
the
letter
,
but
not
opening
it
.
"
<EOS>
Then
tell
Gore
I
'll
see
him
to
-
morrow
at
eleven
"
;
and
he
turned
his
horse
.
  
<EOS>
The
clerk
,
struck
with
Mr.
Tulliver
's
glistening
,
excited
glance
,
looked
after
him
for
a
few
moments
,
and
then
rode
away
.
<EOS>
The
reading
of
a
letter
was
not
the
affair
of
an
instant
to
Mr.
Tulliver
;
he
took
in
the
sense
of
a
statement
very
slowly
through
the
medium
of
written
or
even
printed
characters
;
so
he
had
put
the
letter
in
his
pocket
,
thinking
he
would
open
it
in
his
armchair
at
home
.
<EOS>
But
by
-
and
-
by
it
occurred
to
him
that
there
might
be
something
in
the
letter
Mrs.
Tulliver
must
not
know
about
,
and
if
so
,
it
would
be
better
to
keep
it
out
of
her
sight
altogether
.
<EOS>
He
stopped
his
horse
,
took
out
the
letter
,
and
read
it
.
<EOS>
It
was
only
a
short
letter
;
the
substance
was
,
that
Mr.
Gore
had
ascertained
,
on
secret
,
but
sure
authority
,
that
Furley
had
been
lately
much
straitened
for
money
,
and
had
parted
with
his
securities
,
 
among
the
rest
,
the
mortgage
on
Mr.
Tulliver
's
property
,
which
he
had
transferred
to
   
Wakem
.
  
<EOS>
In
half
an
hour
after
this
Mr.
Tulliver
's
own
wagoner
found
him
lying
by
the
roadside
insensible
,
with
an
open
letter
near
him
,
and
his
gray
horse
snuffing
uneasily
about
him
.
  
<EOS>
When
Maggie
reached
home
that
evening
,
in
obedience
to
her
father
's
call
,
he
was
no
longer
insensible
.
<EOS>
About
an
hour
before
he
had
become
conscious
,
and
after
vague
,
vacant
looks
around
him
,
had
muttered
something
about
"
a
letter
,
"
which
he
presently
repeated
impatiently
.
<EOS>
At
the
instance
of
Mr.
Turnbull
,
the
medical
man
,
Gore
's
letter
was
brought
and
laid
on
the
bed
,
and
the
previous
impatience
seemed
to
be
allayed
.
<EOS>
The
stricken
man
lay
for
some
time
with
his
eyes
fixed
on
the
letter
,
as
if
he
were
trying
to
knit
up
his
thoughts
by
its
help
.
<EOS>
But
presently
a
new
wave
of
memory
seemed
to
have
come
and
swept
the
other
away
;
he
turned
his
eyes
from
the
letter
to
the
door
,
and
after
looking
uneasily
,
as
if
striving
to
see
something
his
eyes
were
too
dim
for
,
he
said
,
"
The
little
wench
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
repeated
the
words
impatiently
from
time
to
time
,
appearing
entirely
unconscious
of
everything
except
this
one
importunate
want
,
and
giving
no
sign
of
knowing
his
wife
or
any
one
else
;
and
poor
Mrs.
Tulliver
,
her
feeble
faculties
almost
paralyzed
by
this
sudden
accumulation
of
troubles
,
went
backward
and
forward
to
the
gate
to
see
if
the
Laceham
coach
were
coming
,
though
it
was
not
yet
time
.
  
<EOS>
But
it
came
at
last
,
and
set
down
the
poor
anxious
girl
,
no
longer
the
"
little
wench
,
"
except
to
her
father
's
fond
memory
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
mother
,
what
is
the
matter
?
"
<EOS>
Maggie
said
,
with
pale
lips
,
as
her
mother
came
toward
her
crying
.
<EOS>
She
did
n't
think
her
father
was
ill
,
because
the
letter
had
come
at
his
dictation
from
the
office
at
St.
Ogg
's
.
  
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Turnbull
came
now
to
meet
her
;
a
medical
man
is
the
good
angel
of
the
troubled
house
,
and
Maggie
ran
toward
the
kind
old
friend
,
whom
she
remembered
as
long
as
she
could
remember
anything
,
with
a
trembling
,
questioning
look
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
alarm
yourself
too
much
,
my
dear
,
"
he
said
,
taking
her
hand
.
<EOS>
"
Your
father
has
had
a
sudden
attack
,
and
has
not
quite
recovered
his
memory
.
<EOS>
But
he
has
been
asking
for
you
,
and
it
will
do
him
good
to
see
you
.
<EOS>
Keep
as
quiet
as
you
can
;
take
off
your
things
,
and
come
upstairs
with
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Maggie
obeyed
,
with
that
terrible
beating
of
the
heart
which
makes
existence
seem
simply
a
painful
pulsation
.
<EOS>
The
very
quietness
with
which
Mr.
Turnbull
spoke
had
frightened
her
susceptible
imagination
.
<EOS>
Her
father
's
eyes
were
still
turned
uneasily
toward
the
door
when
she

<EOS>
Poor

!
<EOS>

<EOS>
Tom

.

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
"

to
turn
up
his
nose
at
his
father
's
customers
,
and
be
a
fine
gentleman
,
 
not
much
else
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Tom
,
roused
from
his
dream
of
the
future
to
a
thorough
consciousness
of
the
present
,
made
all
the
greater
haste
to
reach
the
warehouse
offices
of
Guest
&
Co.
,
where
he
expected
to
find
his
uncle
Deane
.
<EOS>
But
this
was
Mr.
Deane
's
morning
at
the
band
,
a
clerk
told
him
,
and
with
some
contempt
for
his
ignorance
;
Mr.
Deane
was
not
to
be
found
in
River
Street
on
a
Thursday
morning
.
  
<EOS>
At
the
bank
Tom
was
admitted
into
the
private
room
where
his
uncle
was
,
immediately
after
sending
in
his
name
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Deane
was
auditing
accounts
;
but
he
looked
up
as
Tom
entered
,
and
putting
out
his
hand
,
said
,
"
Well
,
Tom
,
nothing
fresh
the
matter
at
home
<EOS>
,
I
hope
?
<EOS>
How
's
your
father
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Much
the
same
,
thank
you
,
uncle
,
"
said
Tom
,
feeling
nervous
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
want
to
speak
to
you
,
please
,
when
you
're
at
liberty
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Sit
down
,
sit
down
,
"
said
Mr.
Deane
,
relapsing
into
his
accounts
,
in
which
he
and
the
managing
-

remained
so
absorbed
for
the
next
half

hour
that
Tom
began
to
wonder
whether
he
should
have
to
sit
in
this
way
till
the
bank
closed
,
 
there
seemed
so
little
tendency
toward
a
conclusion
in
the
quiet
,

procedure
of
these
sleek
,
prosperous
men
of
business
.
<EOS>
Would
his
uncle
give
him
a
place
in
the
bank
?
<EOS>
It
would
be
very
dull
,
prosy
work
,
he
thought
,
writing
there
forever
to
the
loud

of
a
timepiece
.
<EOS>
He
preferred
some
other
way
of
getting
rich
.
<EOS>
But
at
last
there
was
a
change
;
his
uncle
took
a

and
wrote
something
with
a

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
'll

's

,

,

?
"
said
Mr.
Deane
,
and
the
clock
suddenly

less
loud
and
deliberate
in
Tom
's
ears
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Tom
,
"
said
Mr.
Deane
,
when

,
turning
his
substantial
person
a
little
in

,
and
taking
out
his
snuff

;
<EOS>
"
what
's
the
business
,

;
what

business
?
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Deane
,
who

what

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

,

,

;
"
<EOS>
but
I

you

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"

,

,
and

,
"
let

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
want

a
situation
,

,
so
that
I
may

some
money
,
"
said
Tom
,
who
never

.
  
<EOS>
"
A
situation
?
"
said
Mr.
Deane
,
and
then
took
his
pinch
of
snuff
with
elaborate
justice
to
each
nostril
.
<EOS>
Tom
thought
snuff
-
taking
a
most
provoking

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
let
me
see
,
how
old
are
you
?
"
said
Mr.
Deane
,
as

backward

.
  
<EOS>
"
Sixteen
;
I
mean
,
I
am
going
in
seventeen
,
"
said
Tom
,
hoping
his
uncle
noticed
how
much

he

.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
me

;
your
father

some

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
do

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

;
but
people

,

.
<EOS>
You

,

;

,

?
<EOS>
You

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"

Tom
,

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Stelling

I

,

.
<EOS>
That
's

,
"
added

,

a

.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
that
's
good
<EOS>
,
that
's
good
.
<EOS>
But
,

,
the

than
a

-

's
,
if

know

book
-

,
 
nothing
of

.
<EOS>
And
a
copying
-
clerk
's

.
<EOS>
But
what
have
you
been

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Deane
had
not
occupied
himself
with
methods
of
education
,
and
had
no
precise

of
what
went
forward
in
expensive
schools
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
learned
Latin
,
"
said
Tom
,
pausing
a
little
between
each
item
,
as
if

were
turning
over
the
books
in
his
school
-

to

,
 
"
a
good
deal
of
Latin
;
and
the
last
year
I
did
Themes
,
one
week
in
Latin
and
one
in
English
;
and
Greek
and
Roman
history
;
and
Euclid
;
and
I

,
but
I

again
;
and
we

one

every
week
for
Arithmetic
.
<EOS>
Then
I
used
to
have
drawing
-
lessons
;
and
there
were
several
other
books
we
either
read
or
learned
out
of
,
 
English
Poetry
,
and
Horæ
Pauliné
and
Blair
's
Rhetoric
,
the
last
half
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Deane
tapped
his
snuff
-
box
again
and
screwed
up
his
mouth
;
he
felt
in
the
position
of
many
estimable
persons
when
they
had
read
the
New
Tariff
,
and
found
how
many
commodities
were
imported
of
which
they
knew
nothing
;
like
a
cautious
man
of
business
,
he
was
not
going
to
speak
rashly
of
a
raw
material
in
which
he
had
had
no
experience
.
<EOS>
But
the
presumption
was
,
that
if
it
had
been
good
for
anything
,
so
successful
a
man
as
himself
would
hardly
have
been
ignorant
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
About
Latin
he
had
an
opinion
,
and
thought
that
in
case
of
another
war
,
since
people
would
no
longer
wear
hair
-
powder
,
it
would
be
well
to
put
a
tax
upon
Latin
,
as
a
luxury
much
run
upon
by
the
higher
classes
,
and
not
telling
at
all
on
the
ship
-
owning
department
.
<EOS>
But
,
for
what
he
knew
,
the
Horé
Pauliné
might
be
something
less
neutral
.
<EOS>
On
the
whole
,
this
list
of
acquirements
gave
him
a
sort
of
repulsion
toward
poor
Tom
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
he
said
at
last
,
in

,

,
"
you
've
had
three
years
at
these
things
,
 
you
must
be
pretty
strong
in
'em
.
<EOS>
Had
n't
you
better
take
up
some
line
where
they
'll
come
in

?
"
  
<EOS>
Tom
colored
,
and
burst
out
,
with
new

:
  
<EOS>
"
I
'd
rather
not
have
any
employment
of
that
sort
,
uncle
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
like
Latin
and

.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
what
I
could
do
with

unless

as
usher
in
a
school
;
and
I
do
n't
know
them
well
enough
for
that
!
<EOS>
besides
,
I
would
as

a

.
<EOS>
I
do

that

.
<EOS>
I
should

to
enter
into
some

where
I

,
 
a

,
where
I
should

,
and

.
<EOS>
And
I
shall

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
young

,
"
said

Deane
,
with
that

which

of

,
"
that
's
sooner

done
<EOS>
,
 
sooner

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
did

_
<EOS>
you
_
get
on
in
that

,
uncle
?
"
<EOS>
said
Tom
,
a

Mr.

.
<EOS>
"
I
mean
,
did

you
rise

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,

,

,
"
said

Deane
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
But
I
'll
tell

how
I

.
<EOS>
It
was
n't
by
getting
astride
a

and
thinking

would

horse

.
<EOS>
I
kept

,
