,
and
I
was
n't
too
fond
of
my
own

,
and
I
made
my
master
's
interest
my
own
.
<EOS>
Why
,
with
only

what

in

,
,
I

-

that
might

hindered
.
<EOS>
Why
,

,
I
had
n't
more

to

than

;
but
I
saw
pretty

that
I
could
n't
get

far
enough
without
mastering
accounts
,
and
I
learned
'em
between

,
after

'd

.
<EOS>
Look
here
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Deane
opened
a
book
and
pointed
to
the
page
.
<EOS>
"
I
write
a
good
hand
enough
,
and
I
'll
match

at
all

of
reckoning
by
the
head
;
and
I
got
it
all
by
hard

,
and
paid
for

own

,
 
often

own

.
<EOS>
And
I
looked
into
the
nature
of
all

to

in

,
and
picked
up

as
I

about

,
and
turned

.
<EOS>
Why
,
I
'm
no
mechanic
,
 
I
never
pretended
to
be
 
<EOS>
but
I
've
thought
of
a
thing
or
two
that
the
mechanics
never
thought
of
,
and
it
's
made
a
fine
difference
in

.
<EOS>
And
there
is
n't
an
article
shipped
or
unshipped
at
our
wharf
<EOS>
but
I
know
the
quality
of
it
.
<EOS>
If
I
got
places
,
sir
,
it
was
because
I
made
myself
fit
for
'em
.
<EOS>
If
you
want
to
slip
into
a
round
hole
,
you
must
make
a
ball
of
yourself
;
that
's
where
it
is
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Deane
tapped
his
box
again
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
led
on
by
pure
enthusiasm
in
his
subject
,
and
had
really
forgotten
what
bearing
this
retrospective
survey
had
on
his
listener
.
<EOS>
He
had
found
occasion
for
saying
the
same
thing
more
than
once
before
,
and
was
not
distinctly
aware
that
he
had
not
his
port
-
wine
before
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
uncle
,
"
said
Tom
,
with
a
slight
complaint
in
his
tone
,
<EOS>
"
that
's
what
I
should
like
to
do
.
<EOS>
Ca
n't
_
I
_
get
on
in
the
same
way
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
In
the
same
way
?
"
said
Mr.
Deane
,
eyeing
Tom
with
quiet
deliberation
.
<EOS>
"
There
go
two
or
three
questions
to
that
,
Master
Tom
.
<EOS>
That
depends
on
what
sort
of
material
you
are
,
to
begin
with
,
and
whether
you
've
been
put
into
the
right
mill
.
<EOS>
But
I
'll
tell
you
what
it
is
.
<EOS>
Your
poor
father
went
the
wrong
way
to
work
in
giving
you
an
education
.
<EOS>
It
was
n't
my
business
,
and
I
did
n't
interfere
;
but
it
is
as
I
thought
it
would
be
.
<EOS>
You
've
had
a
sort
of
learning
that
's
all
very
well
for
a
young
fellow
like
our
Mr.
Stephen
Guest
,
who
'll
have
nothing
to
do
but
sign
checks
all
his
life
,
and
may
as
well
have
Latin
inside
his
head
as
any
other
sort
of
stuffing
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
,
uncle
,
"
said
Tom
,
earnestly
,
"
I
do
n't
see
why
the
Latin
need
hinder
me
from
getting
on
in
business
.
<EOS>
I
shall
soon
forget
it
all
;
it
makes
no
difference
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
had
to
do
my
lessons
at
school
,
but
I
always
thought
they
'd
never
be
of
any
use
to
me
afterward
;
I
did
n't
care
about
them
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
ay
,
that
's
all
very
well
,
"
said
Mr.
Deane
;
"
but
it
does
n't
alter
what
I
was
going
to
say
.
<EOS>
Your
Latin
and
rigmarole
may
soon
dry
off
you
,
but
you
'll
be
but
a
bare
stick
after
that
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
it
's
whitened
your
hands
and
taken
the
rough
work
out
of
you
.
<EOS>
And
what
do
you
know
?
<EOS>
Why
,
you
know
nothing
about
book
-
keeping
,
to
begin
with
,
and
not
so
much
of
reckoning
as
a
common
shopman
.
<EOS>
You
'll
have
to
begin
at
a
low
round
of
the
ladder
,
let
me
tell
you
,
if
you
mean
to
get
on
in
life
.
<EOS>
It
's
no
use
forgetting
the
education
your
father
's
been
paying
for
,
if
you
do
n't
give
yourself
a
new
un
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Tom
bit

hard
;
he
felt

rising
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

a

,
"

Deane

;
"
<EOS>
well
,
I

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
But

;

.
<EOS>
Now

<EOS>
"

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
So

<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Poor

formed

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
Apparently

,
Tom

,

;

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
Poor
Tom
!
<EOS>
he
had

;

;

.
<EOS>
Maggie
's

,

's

.
<EOS>
She

;

,

,

:
  
"

I
'm

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

;

.
<EOS>
But

,
Tom
.
"
  
<EOS>
With

the

was
rising
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
'm
not
harsh
,
"
said
Tom
,
with

.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
always

,

so
I
shall

;
I

.
<EOS>
But
you
must

what
I
say
.
<EOS>
"
  
Their
mother
came
in
now
,
and
Maggie
rushed
away
,
that
her
burst
of
tears
,
which
she
felt
must
come
,
might
not
happen
till
she
was
safe
upstairs
.
<EOS>
They
were
very
bitter
tears
;
everybody
in
the
world
seemed
so
hard
and
unkind
to
Maggie
;
there
was
no
indulgence
,
no
fondness
,
such
as
she
imagined
when
she
fashioned
the
world
afresh
in
her
own
thoughts
.
<EOS>
In
books
there
were
people
who
were
always
agreeable
or
tender
,
and
delighted
to
do
things
that
made
one
happy
,
and
who
did
not
show
their
kindness
by
finding
fault
.
<EOS>
The
world
outside
the
books
was
not
a
happy
one
,
Maggie
felt
;
it
seemed
to
be
a
world
where
people
behaved
the
best
to
those
they
did
not
pretend
to
love
,
and
that
did
not
belong
to
them
.
<EOS>
And
if
life
had
no
love
in
it
,
what
else
was
there
for
Maggie
?
<EOS>
Nothing
but
poverty
and
the
companionship
of
her
mother
's
narrow
griefs
,
perhaps
of
her
father
's
heart
-
cutting
childish
dependence
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
hopelessness
so
sad
as
that
of
early
youth
,
when
the
soul
is
made
up
of
wants
,
and
has
no
long
memories
,
no
superadded
life
in
the
life
of
others

<EOS>
Maggie

<EOS>
How
a
Hen
Takes
to
Stratagem
  
<EOS>
The
days
passed
,
and
Mr.
Tulliver
showed
,
at
least
to
the
eyes
of
the
medical
man
,
stronger
and
stronger
symptoms
of
a
gradual
return
to
his
normal
condition
;
the
paralytic
obstruction
was
,
little
by
little
,
losing
its
tenacity
,
and
the
mind
was
rising
from
under
it
with
fitful
struggles
,
like
a
living
creature
making
its
way
from
under
a
great
snowdrift
,
that
slides
and
slides
again
,
and
shuts
up
the
newly
made
opening
.
  
<EOS>
Time
would
have
seemed
to
creep
to
the
watchers
by
the
bed
,
if
it
had
only
been
measured
by
the
doubtful
,
distant
hope
which
kept
count
of
the
moments
within
the
chamber
;
but
it
was
measured
for
them
by
a
fast
-
approaching
dread
which
made
the
nights
come
too
quickly
.
<EOS>
While
Mr.
Tulliver
was
slowly
becoming
himself
again
,
his
lot
was
hastening
toward
its
moment
of
most
palpable
change
.
<EOS>
The
taxing
-
masters
had
done
their
work
like
any
respectable
gunsmith
conscientiously
preparing
the
musket
,
that
,
duly
pointed
by
a
brave
arm
,
will
spoil
a
life
or
two
.
<EOS>
Allocaturs
,
filing
of
bills
in
Chancery
,
decrees
of
sale
,
are
legal
chain
-
shot
or
bomb
-
shells
that
can
never
hit
a
solitary
mark
,
but
must
fall
with
widespread
shattering
.
<EOS>
So
deeply
inherent
is
it
in
this
life
of
ours
that
men
have
to
suffer
for
each
other
's
sins
,
<EOS>
so
inevitably
diffusive
is
human
suffering
,
that
even
justice
makes
its
victims
,
and
we
can
conceive
no
retribution
that
does
not
spread
beyond
its
mark
in
pulsations
of
unmerited
pain
.
  
<EOS>
By
the
beginning
of
the
second
week
in
January
,
the
bills
were
out
advertising
the
sale
,
under
a
decree
of
Chancery
,
of
Mr.
Tulliver
's
farming
and
other
stock
,
to
be
followed
by
a
sale
of
the
mill
and
land
,
held
in
the
proper
after
-
dinner
hour
at
the
Golden
Lion
.
<EOS>
The
miller
himself
,
unaware
of
the
lapse
of
time
,
fancied
himself
still
in
that
first
stage
of
his
misfortunes
when
expedients
might
be
thought
of
;
and
often
in
his
conscious
hours
talked
in
a
feeble
,
disjointed
manner
of
plans
he
would
carry
out
when
he
"
got
well
.
"
<EOS>
The
wife
and
children
were
not
without
hope
of
an
issue
that
would
at
least
save
Mr.
Tulliver
from
leaving
the
old
spot
,
and
seeking
an
entirely
strange
life
.
<EOS>
For
uncle
Deane
had
been
induced
to
interest
himself
in
this
stage
of
the
business
.
<EOS>
It
would
not
,
he
acknowledged
,
be
a
bad
speculation
for
Guest
&
Co.
to
buy
Dorlcote
Mill
,
and
carry
on
the
business
,
which
was
a
good
one
,
and
might
be
increased
by
the
addition
of
steam
power
;
in
which
case
Tulliver
might
be
retained
as
manager
.
<EOS>
Still
,
Mr.
Deane
would
say
nothing
decided
about
the
matter
;
the
fact
that
Wakem
held
the
mortgage
on
the
land
might
put
it
into
his
head
to
bid
for
the
whole
estate
,
and
further
,
to
outbid
the
cautious
firm
of
Guest
&
co.
,
who
did
not
carry
on
business
on
sentimental
grounds
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Deane
was
obliged
to
tell
Mrs.
Tulliver
something
to
that
effect
,
when
he
rode
over
to
the
mill
to
inspect

books
in
company

Mrs.
Glegg
;
for
she
had
observed
that
"
if
Guest
&
co.
would
only
think
about
it
,
Mr.
Tulliver
's
father
and
grandfather
had
been
carrying
on
Dorlcote
Mill
long
before
the
oil
-
mill
of
that
firm
had
been
so
much
as
thought
of
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Deane
,
in
reply
,
doubted
whether
that
was
precisely
the
relation
between
the
two
mills
which
would
determine
their
value
as
investments
.
<EOS>
As
for
uncle
Glegg
,
the
thing
lay
quite
beyond
his
imagination
;
the
good
-
natured
man
felt
sincere
pity
for
the
Tulliver
family
,
but
his
money
was
all
locked
up
in
excellent
mortgages
,
and
he
could
run
no
risk
;
that
would
be
unfair
to
his
own
relatives
;
but
he
had
made
up

mind
that
Tulliver
should
have
some
new
flannel

which
he
had
himself
renounced
in
favor
of
a
more
elastic
commodity
,
and
that
he
would
buy
Mrs.
Tulliver
a
pound

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mrs.

,

his

very

;
he
was
one

who
can

,
because
their

run

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
To

like

can

.
<EOS>
The
roach
necessarily

the
pike

,
and

pike
is
likely

that

good

;

that

pike

.
<EOS>
If
Mr.
Tulliver

,

.

But

,

<EOS>

"
Wakem

"
;

,

.
<EOS>
A

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
And
I

Mr.
Tulliver

,

,

,

,

"

"
;

,

.
<EOS>
Tulliver
,
then
,
could
be
no

Wakem
;

the

,

was
a
poor

whom

;
a

-

fellow
,
who
would
always

you

against

.
<EOS>
Wakem
's
conscience
was
not
uneasy
because
he
had
used
a
few
tricks
against
the
miller
;
why
should
he
hate
that
unsuccessful
plaintiff
,
that
pitiable
,
furious

entangled
in
the

of
a
net
?
  
<EOS>
Still
,
among
the
various

to
which
human
nature
is
subject
,
moralists
have
never
numbered
that
of
being
too
fond
of
the
people
who
openly
revile
us
.
<EOS>
The
successful
Yellow
candidate
for
the
borough
of
Old
Topping
,
perhaps
,
feels
no
pursuant
meditative
hatred
toward
the
Blue
editor
who
consoles
his

with
vituperative

against
Yellow
men
who
sell
their
country
,
and
are
the
demons
of
private

;
but
he
might

,
if
law
and

favored
,
to
kick
that
Blue
editor
to
a
deeper
shade
of
his
favorite

.
<EOS>
Prosperous
men
take
a
little
vengeance
now
and
then
,
as
they
take
a
diversion
,
when
it
comes
easily
in
their
way
,
and
is
no
hindrance
to
business
;
and
such
small
unimpassioned
revenges
have
an
enormous
effect
in
life
,
running
through
all
degrees
of
pleasant
infliction
,
blocking
the
fit
men
out
of
places
,
and
blackening
characters
in
unpremeditated
talk
.
<EOS>
Still
more
,
to
see
people
who
have
been
only
insignificantly
offensive
to
us
reduced
in
life
and
humiliated
,
without
any
special
effort
of
ours
,
is
apt
to
have
a
soothing
,
flattering
influence
.
<EOS>
Providence
or
some
other
prince
of
this
world
,
it
appears
,
has
undertaken
the
task
of
retribution
for
us
;
and
really
,
by
an
agreeable
constitution
of
things
,
our
enemies
somehow
_
do
n't
_
prosper
.
  
<EOS>
Wakem
was
not
without
this
parenthetic
vindictiveness
toward
the
uncomplimentary
miller
;
and
now
Mrs.
Tulliver
had
put
the
notion
into
his
head
,
it
presented

to
him
as
a
pleasure
to
do
the
very
thing
that
would
cause
Mr.
Tulliver
<EOS>
the
most
deadly
mortification
,
  
and
a
pleasure
of
a
complex
kind
,
not
made
up
of
crude
malice
,
but
mingling
with
it
the
relish
of
self
-
approbation
.
<EOS>
To
see
an
enemy
humiliated
gives
a
certain
contentment
,
but
this
is
jejune
compared
with
the
highly
blent
satisfaction
of
seeing
him
humiliated
by
your
benevolent
action
or
concession
on
his
behalf
.
<EOS>
That
is
a
sort
of
revenge
which
falls
into
the
scale
of
virtue
,
and
Wakem
was
not
without
an
intention
of
keeping
that
scale
respectably
filled
.
<EOS>
He
had
once
had
the
pleasure
of
putting
an
old
enemy
of
his
into
one
of
the
St.
Ogg
's
alms
-
houses
,
to
the
rebuilding
of
which
he
had
given
a
large
subscription
;
and
here
was
an
opportunity
of
providing
for
another
by
making
him
his
own
servant
.
<EOS>
Such
things
give
a
completeness
to
prosperity
,
and
contribute
elements
of
agreeable
consciousness
that
are
not
dreamed
of
by
that
short
-
sighted
,
overheated
vindictiveness
which
goes
out
its
way
to
wreak
itself
in
direct
injury
.
<EOS>
And
Tulliver
,
with
his
rough
tongue
filed
by
a
sense
of
obligation
,
would
make
a
better
servant
than
any
chance
-
fellow
who
was
cap
-
in
-
hand
for
a
situation
.
<EOS>
Tulliver
was
known
to
be
a
man
of
proud
honesty
,
and
Wakem
was
too
acute
not
to
believe
in
the
existence
of
honesty
.
<EOS>
He
was
given
too
observing
individuals
,
not
to
judging
of
them
according
to
maxims
,
and
no
one
knew
better
than
he
that
all
men
were
not
like
himself
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
he
intended
to
overlook
the
whole
business
of
land
and
mill
pretty
closely
;
he
was
fond
of
these
practical
rural
matters
.
<EOS>
But
there
were
good
reasons
for
purchasing
Dorlcote
Mill
,
quite
apart
from
any
benevolent
vengeance
on
the
miller
.
<EOS>
It
was
really
a
capital
investment
;
besides
,
Guest
&
co.
were
going
to
bid
for
it
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Guest
and
Mr.
Wakem
were
on
friendly
dining
terms
,
and
the
attorney
liked
to
predominate
over
a
ship
-
owner
and
mill
-
owner
who
was
a
little
too
loud
in
the
town
affairs
as
well
as
in
his
table
-
talk
.
<EOS>
For
Wakem
was
not
a
mere
man
of
business
;
he
was
considered
a
pleasant
fellow
in
the
upper
circles
of
St.
Ogg
's
 
chatted
amusingly
over
his
port
-
wine
,
did
a
little
amateur
farming
,
and
had
certainly
been
an
excellent
husband
and
father
;
at
church
,
when
he
went
there
,
he
sat
under
the
handsomest
of
mural
monuments
erected
to
the
memory
of
his
wife
.
<EOS>
Most
men
would
have
married
again
under
his
circumstances
,
but
he
was
said
to
be
more
tender
to
his
deformed
son
than
most
men
were
to
their
best
-
shapen
offspring
.
<EOS>
Not
that
Mr.
Wakem
had
not
other
sons
beside
Philip
;
but
toward
them
he
held
only
a
chiaroscuro
parentage
,
and
provided
for
them
in
a
grade
of
life
duly
beneath
his
own
.
<EOS>
In
this
fact
,
indeed
,
there
lay
the
clenching
motive
to
the
purchase
of
Dorlcote
Mill
.
<EOS>
While
Mrs.
Tulliver
was
talking
,
it
had
occurred
to
the
rapid
-
minded
lawyer
,
among
all
the
other
circumstances
of
the
case
,
that
this
purchase
would
,
in
a
few
years
to
come
,
furnish
a
highly
suitable
position
for
a
certain
favorite
lad
whom
he
meant
to
bring
on
in
the
world
.
  
<EOS>
These
were
the
mental
conditions
on
which
Mrs.
Tulliver
had
undertaken
to
act
persuasively
,
and
had
failed
;
a
fact
which
may
receive
some
illustration
from
the
remark
of
a
great
philosopher
,
that
fly
-
fishers
fail
in
preparing
their
bait
so
as
to
make
it
alluring
in
the
right
quarter
,
for
want
of
a
due
acquaintance
with
the
subjectivity
of
fishes
.
    
<EOS>
Daylight
on
the
Wreck
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
clear
frosty
January
day
on
which
Mr.
Tulliver
first
came
downstairs
.
<EOS>
The
bright
sun
on
the
chestnut
boughs
and
the
roofs
opposite
his
window
had
made
him
impatiently
declare
that
he
would
be
caged
up
no
longer
;
he
thought
everywhere
would
be
more
cheery
under
this
sunshine
than
his
bedroom
;
for
he
knew
nothing
of
the
bareness
below
,
which
made
the
flood
of
sunshine
importunate
,
as
if
it
had
an
unfeeling
pleasure
in
showing
the
empty
places
,
and
the
marks
where
well
-
known

once
had
been
.
<EOS>
The
impression
on
his
mind
that
it
was
<EOS>
but
yesterday
when
he
received

letter
from
Mr.
Gore
was
so
continually
implied
in
his
talk
,
and
the

that
many
weeks
had
passed
and
much

happened

had
been
so
soon

away

,
that
even
Mr.
Turnbull

to
despair

preparing

meet
the
facts
by
previous
knowledge
.
<EOS>
The
full

of
the
present
could
only

by
new
experience
,
 
not
by
mere
words
,
which
must

weaker
than
the

by
the
_
old
_

.
<EOS>
This

children
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Tulliver
said
Tom

;
and

though

.
<EOS>
The

of

had
been

than

during

.
<EOS>
For
Guest
&
Co.
had
not

;
both

had
been
knocked
down
to
Wakem
,
who
had

over

,
and
had
laid
before
Mr.
Deane

,
in

,

to

,
as

.
<EOS>
This

had

.
<EOS>
Uncles

were
almost

that

when

nothing

,

,

,

as

ought

against

for

,

.
<EOS>
Here

to

daughter

.
<EOS>
Mr.

,

;

,
 
_

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
Kezia

.
<EOS>

"

"
<EOS>

,

.

Poor

,

.

<EOS>
An
Item
Added
to
the
Family
Register
  
<EOS>
That
first
moment
of
renunciation
and
submission
was
followed
by
days
of
violent
struggle
in
the
miller
's
mind
,
as
the
gradual
access
of
bodily
strength
brought
with
it
increasing
ability
to
embrace
in
one
view
all
the
conflicting
conditions
under
which
he
found
himself
.
<EOS>
Feeble
limbs
easily
resign
themselves
to
be
tethered
,
and
when
we
are
subdued
by
sickness
it
seems
possible
to
us
to
fulfil
pledges
which
the
old
vigor
comes
back
and
breaks
.
<EOS>
There
were
times
when
poor
Tulliver
thought
the
fulfilment
of
his
promise
to
Bessy
was
something
quite
too
hard
for
human
nature
;
he
had
promised
her
without
knowing
what
she
was
going
to
say
,
 
she
might
as
well
have
asked
him
to
carry
a
ton
weight
on
his
back
.
<EOS>
But
again
,
there
were
many
feelings
arguing
on
her
side
,
besides
the
sense
that
life
had
been
made
hard
to
her
by
having
married
him
.
<EOS>
He
saw
a
possibility
,
by
much
pinching
,
of
saving
money
out
of
his
salary
toward
paying
a
second
dividend
to
his
creditors
,
and
it
would
not
be
easy
elsewhere
to
get
a
situation
such
as
he
could
fill
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
led
an
easy
life
,
ordering
much
and
working
little
,
and
had
no
aptitude
for
any
new
business
.
<EOS>
He
must
perhaps
take
to
day
-
labor
,
and
his
wife
must
have
help
from
her
sisters
,
 
a
prospect
doubly
bitter
to
him
,
now

had
let
all

's
precious
things
be
sold
,
probably
because
they
liked
to
set
her
against
him
,
by
making
her
feel
that
he
had
brought
her
to
that
pass
.
<EOS>
He
listened
to
their
admonitory
talk
,
when
they
came
to
urge
on
him
what
he
was
bound
to
do
for
poor

's
sake
,
with
averted
eyes
,
that
every
now
and
then
flashed
on
them
furtively
when
their
backs
were
turned
.
<EOS>
Nothing
but
the
dread
of
needing
their
help
could
have
made
it
an
easier
alternative
to
take
their
advice
.
  
<EOS>
But
the
strongest
influence
of
all
was
the
love
of
the
old
premises
where
he
had
run
about
when
he
was
a
boy
,
just
as
Tom
had
done
after
him
.
<EOS>
The
Tullivers
had
lived
on
this
spot
for

the
Devil
's
doing
.
<EOS>
Do
as
I
tell
you
,
Tom
.
<EOS>
Write
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
am
I
to
write
?
"
said
Tom
,
with

.
  
<EOS>
"

as
your
father
,
Edward
Tulliver
,
took

John
Wakem
,
the

what
amends

,

.

you

how

,

.
<EOS>

.
"
  
<EOS>
There

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

"

Tulliver
,
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"

write

,

,

.

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.

<EOS>

<EOS>
The
Valley
of
Humiliation
_
  
<EOS>
A
Variation
of
Protestantism
Unknown
to
Bossuet
  
<EOS>
Journeying
down
the
Rhone
on
a
summer
's
day
,
you
have
perhaps
felt
the
sunshine
made
dreary
by
those
ruined
villages
which
stud
the
banks
in
certain
parts
of
its
course
,
telling
how
the
swift
river
once
rose
,
like
an
angry
,
destroying
god
,
sweeping
down
the
feeble
generations
whose
breath
is
in
their
nostrils
,
and
making
their
dwellings
a
desolation
.
<EOS>
Strange
contrast
,
you
may
have
thought
,
between
the
effect
produced
on
us
by
these
dismal
remnants
of
commonplace
houses
,
which
in
their
best
days
were
but
the
sign
of
a
sordid
life
,
belonging
in
all
its
details
to
our
own
vulgar
era
,
and
the
effect
produced
by
those
ruins
on
the
castled
Rhine
,
which
have
crumbled
and
mellowed
into
such
harmony
with
the
green
and
rocky
steeps
that
they
seem
to
have
a
natural
fitness
,
like
the
mountain
-
pine
;
nay
,
even
in
the
day
when
they
were
built
they
must
have
had
this
fitness
,
as
if
they
had
been
raised
by
an
earth
-
born
race
,
who
had
inherited
from
their
mighty
parent
a
sublime
instinct
of
form
.
<EOS>
And
that
was
a
day
of
romance
;
If
those
robber
-
barons
were
somewhat
grim
and
drunken
ogres
,
they
had
a
certain
grandeur
of
the
wild
beast
in
them
,
 
they
were
forest
boars
with
tusks
,
tearing
and
rending
,
not
the
ordinary
domestic
grunter
;
they
represented
the
demon
forces
forever
in
collision
with
beauty
,
virtue
,
and
the
gentle
uses
of
life
;
they
made
a
fine
contrast
in
the
picture
with
the
wandering
minstrel
,
the
soft
-
lipped
princess
,
the
pious
recluse
,
and
the
timid
Israelite
.
<EOS>
That
was
a
time
of
color
,
when
the
sunlight
fell
on
glancing
steel
and
floating
banners
;
a
time
of
adventure
and
fierce
struggle
,
 
nay
,
of
living
,
religious
art
and
religious
enthusiasm
;
for
were
not
cathedrals
built
in
those
days
,
and
did
not
great
emperors
leave
their
Western
palaces
to
die
before
the
infidel
strongholds
in
the
sacred
East
?
<EOS>
Therefore
it
is
that
these
Rhine
castles
thrill
me
with
a
sense
of
poetry
;
they
belong
to
the
grand
historic
life
of
humanity
,
and
raise
up
for
me
the
vision
of
an
echo
.
<EOS>
But
these
dead
-
tinted
,
hollow
-
eyed
,
angular
skeletons
of
villages
on
the
Rhone
oppress
me
with
the
feeling
that
human
life
 
very
much
of
it
 
is
a
narrow
,
ugly
,
grovelling
existence
,
which
even
calamity
does
not
elevate
,
but
rather
tends
to
exhibit
in
all
its
bare
vulgarity
of
conception
;
and
I
have
a
cruel
conviction
that
the
lives
these
ruins
are
the
traces
of
<EOS>
were
part
of
a
gross
sum
of
obscure
vitality
,
that
will
be
swept
into
the
same
oblivion
with
the
generations
of
ants
and
beavers
.
  
<EOS>
Perhaps
something
akin
to
this
oppressive
feeling
may
have
weighed
upon
you
in
watching
this
old
-
fashioned
family
life
on
the
banks
of
the
Floss
,
which
even
sorrow
hardly
suffices
to
lift
above
the
level
of
the
tragi
-

.
<EOS>
It
is
a
sordid
life
,
you
say
,
this
of
the
Tullivers
and
Dodsons
,
irradiated
by
no

,
no

,
no
active
,
self

;
moved

none

wild

which

;
without
that

,
that
hard

ill

,
<EOS>
that
childlike
spelling
-
out
of
what
nature
has
written
,
which
gives

.
<EOS>
Here
one
has
conventional
worldly
notions
and
habits
without
instruction
and
without
polish
,
surely
the
most
prosaic
form
of
human
life
;
proud

in
a
gig
of
unfashionable
build
;
worldliness
without
side
-
dishes
.
<EOS>
Observing
these
people
narrowly
,
even
when
the
iron

of

has
shaken

from
their
unquestioning
hold
on
the
world
,
one
sees
little
trace
of
religion
,
still
less
of

.
<EOS>
Their
belief
in
the
Unseen
,
so
far
as

manifests
itself
at
all
,
seems
to
be
rather
a
pagan
kind
;
their
moral
notions
,
though
held
with
strong
tenacity
,
seem
to
have
no
standard
beyond
hereditary
custom
.
<EOS>
You
could
not
live
among
such
people
;
you
are
stifled
for
want
of
an
outlet
toward
something
beautiful
,
great
,
or
noble
;
you
are
irritated
with
these
dull
men
and
women
,
as
a
kind
of
population
out
of
keeping
with
the
earth
on
which
they
live
,
 
with
this
rich
plain
where
the
great
river
flows
forever
onward
,
and
links
the
small
pulse
of
the
old
English
town
with
the
beatings
of
the
world
's
mighty
heart
.
<EOS>
A
vigorous
superstition
,
that
lashes
its
gods
or
lashes
its
own
back
,
seems
to
be
more
congruous
with
the
mystery
of
the
human
lot
,
than
the
mental
condition
of
these
emmet
-
like
Dodsons
and
Tullivers
.
  
<EOS>
I
share
with
you
this
sense
of
oppressive
narrowness
;
but
it
is
necessary
that
we
should
feel
it
,
if

care

how
it
acted
on
the
lives
of
Tom
and

,
 
how

,
that
in

human

have
risen
above

mental

of
the
generation
before
them
,
to

they
have
been
nevertheless

by

of

.
<EOS>
The
suffering
,
whether
of

or

,
which
belongs
to
every

of
mankind
,
is
represented
in
this
way
in

,
and

hundreds

;
and
we
need

this
comparison

;
for
does

science

that
its
highest
striving
is
after
the

of
a
unity
which
shall
bind
the
smallest

with
the
greatest
?
<EOS>
In
natural
science
,
I
have
understood
,
there
is
nothing
petty
to
the
mind
that
has
a
large
vision
of
relations
,
and
to
which
every

a
vast
sum
of
conditions
.
<EOS>
It
is
surely
the
same
with
the
observation
of

life
.
  
<EOS>
Certainly
the
religious
and
moral
ideas
of
the
Dodsons
and
Tullivers
were
of
too
specific
a
kind
to
be
arrived
at

,
from
the
statement
that
they
were
part
of
the
Protestant
population
of
Great
Britain
.
<EOS>
Their
theory
of
life
had
its
core
of
soundness
,
as
all
theories
must
have
on
which
decent
and

families
have
been
reared
and
have

;
but
it
had
the
very
slightest
tincture
of
theology
.
<EOS>
If
,
in
the
maiden
days
of
the
Dodson
sisters
,
their
Bibles
opened
more
easily
at
some

than
others
,
it
was
because
of
dried
tulip
-

,
which
had
been
distributed
quite
impartially
,
without

for

,

,
or

.
<EOS>
Their
religion
was
of
a
simple
,
semi
-
pagan
kind
,
but
there
was
no
heresy
in
it
,
 
if
heresy
properly
means
choice
,
 
for
they
did
n't
know
there
was
any
other
religion
,
except
that
of
chapel
-
goers
,
which
appeared
to
run
in

,
like
asthma
.
<EOS>
How
_
should
_
they
know
?
<EOS>
The
vicar
of
their
pleasant
rural
parish
was
not
a
controversialist
,
but
a
good
hand
at
whist
,
and
one
who
had
a
joke
always
ready
for
a
blooming
female

.
<EOS>
The
religion
of
the
Dodsons
consisted
in
revering
whatever
was
customary
and
respectable
;
it
was
necessary
to
be
baptized
,
else
one
could
not
be
buried
in
the
church
-
yard
,
and
to
take
the
sacrament
before
death
,
as
a
security
against
more
dimly
understood
perils
;
but
it
was
of
equal
necessity
to
have
the
proper
pall
-
bearers
and
well
-
cured
hams
at
one
's
funeral
,
and
to
leave
an
unimpeachable
will
.
<EOS>
A
Dodson
would
not
be
taxed
with
the
omission
of
anything
that
was
becoming
,
or
that
belonged
to
that
eternal
fitness
of
things
which
was
plainly
indicated
in
the
practice
of
the
most
substantial

,
and
in
the
family

,
 
such
as

to
parents
,
faithfulness
to
kindred
,
industry
,
rigid

,
thrift
,
the
thorough

of

and

,
the
hoarding
of
coins
likely
to
disappear
from

currency
,
the
production
of
first
-
rate

for
the
market
,
and
the
general
preference
of
whatever
was
home
-
made
.
<EOS>
The
Dodsons
were
a
very
proud
race
,
and
their
pride
lay
in
the
utter
frustration
of
all
desire
to
tax
them
with
a
breach
of
traditional
duty
or
propriety
.
<EOS>
A
wholesome
pride
in
many
respects
,
since
it
identified
honor
with
perfect
integrity
,
thoroughness
of
work
,
and
faithfulness
to
admitted
rules
;
and
society
owes
some
worthy
qualities
in
many
of
her
members
to
mothers
of
the
Dodson
class
,
who
made
their
butter
and
their
fromenty
well
,
and
would
have
felt
disgraced
to
make
it
otherwise
.
<EOS>
To
be
honest
and
poor
was
never
a
Dodson
motto
,
still
less
to
seem
rich
though
being
poor
;
rather
,
the
family
badge
was
to
be
honest
and
rich
,
and
not
only
rich
,
but
richer
than
was
supposed
.
<EOS>
To
live
respected
,
and
have
the
proper
bearers
at
your

,
was
an
achievement
of
the
ends
of
existence
that
would
be
entirely
nullified
if
,
on
the
reading
of
your
will
,
you
sank
in
the
opinion
of
your
fellow
-
men
,
either
by
turning

to
be
poorer
than
they
expected
,
or
by
leaving
your
money
in
a
capricious

,
without
strict
regard
to
degrees
of
kin
.
<EOS>
The
right
thing
must
always
be
done
toward
kindred
.
<EOS>
The
right
thing
was
to
correct
them
severely
,
if
they
were
other
than
a
credit
to
the
family
,
but
still
not
to
alienate
from
them
the
smallest
rightful
share
in
the
family
shoebuckles
and
other
property
.
<EOS>
A
conspicuous
quality
in
the
Dodson
character
was
its
genuineness
;
its
vices
and
virtues
alike
were
phases
of
a
proud
honest
egoism
,
which
had
a
hearty
dislike
to
whatever
made
against
its
own
credit
and
interest
,
and
would
be
frankly
hard
of
speech
to
inconvenient
"
kin
,
"
but
would
never
forsake
or
ignore
them
,
 
would
not
let
them
want
bread
,
but
only
require
them
to
eat
it
with
bitter
herbs
.
  
<EOS>
The
same
sort
of
traditional
belief
ran
in
the
Tulliver
veins
,
but
it
was
carried
in
richer
blood
,
having
elements
of
generous
imprudence
,
warm
affection
,
and
hot

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Tulliver
's
grandfather
had
been
heard
to
say
that
he
was
descended
from
one
Ralph
Tulliver
,
a
wonderfully
clever
fellow
,
who
had
ruined
himself
.
<EOS>
It
is
likely
enough
that
the
clever
Ralph
was
a
high
liver
,
rode
spirited
horses
,
and
was
very
decidedly
of
his
own
opinion
.
<EOS>
On
the
other
hand
,
nobody
had
ever
heard
of
a
Dodson
who
had
ruined
himself
;
it
was
not
the
way
of
that
family
.
  
<EOS>
If
such
were
the
views
of
life
on
which
the
Dodsons
and
Tullivers
had
been
reared
in
the
praiseworthy
past
of
Pitt
and
high
prices
,
you
will
infer
from
what
you
already
know
concerning
the
state
of
society
in
St.
Ogg
's
,
that
there
had
been
no
highly
modifying
influence
to
act

in
their

.
<EOS>
It
was
still
possible
,
even
in
that
later
time
of
anti
-
Catholic

,
for
people
to
hold
many
pagan
ideas
,
and
believe
themselves
good
church
-
people
,
notwithstanding
;
so
we
need
hardly
feel
any
surprise
at
the
fact
that
Mr.
Tulliver
,
though
a
regular
church
-

,
recorded
his

on
the
fly
-

of
his
Bible
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
that
any
harm
could
be
said
concerning
the
vicar
of
that
charming
rural
parish
to
which
Dorlcote
Mill
belonged
;
he
was
a
man
of
excellent
family

The

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
When

same
mood
accompanies
them
;
the
end
of
the
year
finds
them
as
much
what
they
were
at
the
beginning
as
if
they
were
machines
set
to
a
recurrent
series
of
movements
.
  
<EOS>
The
sameness
of
the
days
was
broken
by
few
visitors
.
<EOS>
Uncles
and
aunts
paid
only
short
visits
now
;
of
course
,
they
could
not
stay
to
meals
,
and
the
constraint
caused
by
Mr.
Tulliver
's
savage
silence
,
which
seemed
to
add
to
the
hollow
resonance
of
the
bare
,
uncarpeted
room
when
the
aunts
were
talking
,
heightened
the
unpleasantness
of
these
family
visits
on
all
sides
,
and
tended
to
make
them
rare
.
<EOS>
As
for
other
acquaintances
,
there
is
a
chill
air
surrounding
those
who
are
down
in
the
world
,
and
people
are
glad
to
get
away
from
them
,
as
from
a
cold
room
;
human
beings
,
mere
men
and
women
,
without
furniture
,
without
anything
to
offer
you
,
who
have
ceased
to
count
as
anybody
,
present
an
embarrassing
negation
of
reasons
for
wishing
to
see
them
,
or
of
subjects
on
which
to
converse
with
them
.
<EOS>
At
that
distant
day
,
there
was
a
dreary
isolation
in
the
civilized
Christian
society
of
these
realms
for
families
that
had
dropped
below
their
original
level
,
unless
they
belonged
to
a
sectarian
church
,
which
gets
some
warmth
of
brotherhood
by
walling
in
the
sacred
fire
.
    
<EOS>
A
Voice
from
the
Past
  
<EOS>
One
afternoon
,
when
the
chestnuts
were
coming
into
flower
,
Maggie
had
brought
her
chair
outside
the
front
door
,
and
was
seated
there
with
a
book
on
her
knees
.
<EOS>
Her
dark
eyes
had
wandered
from
the
book
,
but
they
did
not
seem
to
be
enjoying
the
sunshine
which
pierced
the
screen
of
jasmine
on
the
projecting
porch
at
her
right
,
and
threw
leafy
shadows
on
her
pale
round
cheek
;
they
seemed
rather
to
be
searching
for
something
that
was
not
disclosed
by
the
sunshine
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
a
more
miserable
day
than
usual
;
her
father
,
after
a
visit
of
Wakem
's
had
had
a
paroxysm
of
rage
,
in
which
for
some
trifling
fault
he
had
beaten
the
boy
who
served
in
the
mill
.
<EOS>
Once
before
,
since
his
illness
,
he
had
had
a
similar
paroxysm
,
in
which
he
had
beaten
his
horse
,
and
the
scene
had
left
a
lasting
terror
in
Maggie
's
mind
.
<EOS>
The
thought
had
risen
,
that
some
time
or
other
he
might
beat
her
mother
if
she
happened
to
speak
in
her
feeble
way
at
the
wrong
moment
.
<EOS>
The
keenest
of
all
dread
with
her
<EOS>
was
lest
her
father
should
add
to
his
present
misfortune
the
wretchedness
of
doing
something
irretrievably
disgraceful
.
<EOS>
The
battered
school
-
book
of
Tom
's
which
she
held
on
her
knees
could
give
her
no
fortitude
under
the
pressure
of
that
dread
;
and
again
and
again
her
eyes
had
filled
with
tears
,
as
they
wandered
vaguely
,
seeing
neither
the
chestnut
-
trees
,
nor
the
distant
horizon
,
but
only
future
scenes
of
home
-
sorrow
.
  
<EOS>
Suddenly
she
was
roused
by
the
sound
of
the
opening
gate
and
of
footsteps
on
the
gravel
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
Tom
who
was
entering
,
but
a
man
in
a
sealskin

and

,

pack

,
and

a

of

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
Bob
,

's
you
!
"
<EOS>

kind

;
"
I

.

"

The

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
Maggie
's

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Every

.
<EOS>
There

no

,

,

,

<EOS>
And

now

that

<EOS>
Even

_

;

.
<EOS>
And

without

Télémaque
was

;

;

,

.
<EOS>
Sometimes

;

<EOS>
then
,

.
<EOS>
And

<EOS>
She

,
but
no

.
<EOS>
She
wanted
some

of
this
hard
,

,
 
the
unhappy
-

father
,

;

some

;

that
Tom
did

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

"

"

;

,
that

!
<EOS>

<EOS>
She

,

.
  
<EOS>

's

,

<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
Still

,

,

,

which

,

.
<EOS>

;

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

as
the
days
went

,
and
the

gained
faster

faster

.
<EOS>
Somehow
,

_

_

,

.
<EOS>
She

,

,
and

,

,

<EOS>

;

,
perhaps

,

.
<EOS>
But
,

,

,

,

,
"

,

?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The

;

another

,

she
had
been
thinking

.
  
<EOS>
This

,

's

.
<EOS>
She

part

laid
upon

the

,

,

.
<EOS>
She

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Poor
child
!
<EOS>
as

against
the
window
-

,
with

tighter
and

,

,

as

,

-

,
than

,

,

of

within

,

,

,

,

,
 
as

by

,
not

of
their
own
early

,
when
need
was

.
  
<EOS>
At
last

's

glanced
down

window

,
and

half

"
Portrait

,
"
but

soon

to

books
tied

with

.
<EOS>
"
Beauties
of
the
Spectator
,
"
"

,
"
"
Economy
of
Human
Life
,
"
"
Gregory
's

,
"
 
<EOS>
she
knew
the

that
was

;

"
Christian
Year
,
"
 
that
seemed

a

,

;
but
_
Thomas
à
Kempis
?
<EOS>
_
 
<EOS>
the
name
had
come
across
her
in
her
reading
,
and
she
felt
the
satisfaction
,
which
every
one
knows
,
of
getting
some
ideas
to
attach
to
a
name
that
strays
solitary
in

memory
.
<EOS>
She
took
up
the
little
,
old
,
clumsy
book
with
some

;
it
had
the
corners
turned
down
in
many
places
,
and
some
hand
,
now
forever

,
had
made

pen
-
and
-
ink

,
long
since

.
<EOS>
Maggie
turned
from
leaf
to
leaf
,
and
read
where
the
quiet
hand
pointed
:
"
Know
that
the
love
of
thyself
doth
hurt
thee
more
than
anything
in
the
world
....
<EOS>
If
thou
seekest
this
or
that
,
and
wouldst
be
here
or
there
to
enjoy
thy
own
will
and

,
thou
shalt
never
be
quiet
nor
free
from
care
;
for
in
everything
somewhat
will
be
wanting
,
and
in
every
place
there
will
be
some
that
will
cross
thee
....
<EOS>
Both
above
and
below
,
which
way
soever
thou
dost
turn
thee
,
everywhere
thou
shalt
find
the
Cross
;
and
everywhere
of
necessity
thou
must
have
patience
,
if
thou
wilt
have
inward
peace
,
and
enjoy
an
everlasting
crown
....
<EOS>
If
thou
desirest
to
mount
unto
this
height
,
thou
must
set
out
courageously
,
and
lay
the
axe
to
the
root
,
that
thou
mayest
pluck
up
and
destroy
that
hidden
inordinate
inclination
to
thyself
,
and
unto
all
private

earthly
good
.
<EOS>
On
this
sin
,
that
a
man
inordinately
loveth
himself
,
almost
all
dependeth
,
whatsoever
is
thoroughly
to
be
overcome
;
which
evil
being
once
overcome
and
subdued
,
there
will
presently
ensue
great
peace
and
tranquillity
....
<EOS>
It
is
but
<EOS>
little
thou
sufferest
in
comparison
of
them
that
have
suffered
so
much
<EOS>
,
were
so
strongly
tempted
,
so

,
so
many

and

.
<EOS>
Thou
oughtest
therefore
to
call

mind
the
more
heavy
sufferings
of
others
,
that
thou
mayest
<EOS>
the
easier
bear
thy
little

.
<EOS>
And
if
they
seem
not
little
unto
thee
,
beware
lest
thy
impatience
be
the
cause
<EOS>
thereof
....
<EOS>
Blessed

those

that
receive
the

of
the

,
and

not
to

of

.
<EOS>
Blessed

those
ears
which
hearken
not
unto
the
voice
which
soundeth
outwardly
,
but
unto
the
Truth
,
which
teacheth
inwardly
.
"
  
<EOS>
A
strange

of
awe
passed
through
Maggie
while
she
read
,
as

had
been
wakened
in
the

by
a
strain
of
solemn

,
telling
of

whose

.
<EOS>
She
went
on
from
one
brown

another
,
where
the
quiet
hand
seemed
to
point
,

,
seeming

to
listen
while
a

said
;
  
"
<EOS>
Why
dost
thou
here
gaze
about
,
since
this

not
the

rest
?
<EOS>
In

ought
to

,
and
all

forward

.
<EOS>
All

pass
away
,
and
thou
together

.
<EOS>
Beware

,

and
perish
....
<EOS>
If

,
yet

.
<EOS>
And

great

,

but

.
<EOS>
And

,

.
<EOS>
And

,

;
to

,

,

.
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
That

,

leave

,
and

,
and

-

....
<EOS>
I

,

,

,

....
<EOS>
Then

;
then
shall

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Maggie
drew

<EOS>
Here

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
She

,

;

.
<EOS>
With

<EOS>
She

not

how

until

?
 
<EOS>
the
inmost
truth
of
the
old

's
out

,
that

remains
sorrow
,
though
a

borne

.
<EOS>
Maggie
was
still
panting
for

,
and
was
in

.
<EOS>
She
knew
nothing
of

,

;
but
this

out

a
human

's
belief

,

.
  
<EOS>
I
suppose
that
is
the

why
the
small
old
-

,

need

,

;

,

,

.
<EOS>
It
was

that

heart
's

;

is

,

.
<EOS>
And

;
the

who
,

,
felt

,
 
in

,
perhaps
,

,

,

,
 
but

far
-

,
and

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
In

of
unfashionable

,
one
is
apt
to
fall
into
a
tone
of
emphasis
which
is
very

being
the
tone
of
good
society
,
where

are

,
but

always

,
no

.
<EOS>
But

good
society
has
its

and

,
its

-

<EOS>
six

,
its

its

;

_

_

;

;

;

,

are
to

the
best

,
 
how

?
<EOS>
But
good
society
,
floated
on
gossamer

of
light

,
is
of
very
expensive
production
;
requiring
nothing
less
than
a
wide

condensed

unfragrant

,

in

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

the

,

look

.
<EOS>
This
wide

life
is
based
entirely
on
emphasis
,
 
the
emphasis
of
want
,
which
urges
it
into
all
the

necessary
for
the

of
good

and

;
it
spends

heavy

often
in

,

.
<EOS>
Under

,
there
are
many

who
have
absolutely
needed

emphatic

,

in
this

demanding
some

even
to

,
 
just

anything

,
whereas
eider
-
down

.
<EOS>
Some

belief
in

,

_

_

;
but

that

"

,
"
something
that
will
present

in

;

,

;
something
,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Now

;

,

,

;

.
<EOS>
From

,

,

;

.
<EOS>
And
so

came
to
pass
that
she
often
lost

spirit

by

;

,

little

.
<EOS>
For

,

,
that

,

,

,

,

;

nothing

but

,

,

,

's

.
<EOS>
"

_

"

,
"
_

_

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

;

,

.
<EOS>
Tom
was

to

,
she

,

,

;

.
<EOS>
That

,

.
  
<EOS>
The

,

,

that

of
knowledge

.
<EOS>
In

;

"

"

,

like

.
  
<EOS>
Hanging

,

was
a

.
<EOS>
That

hers
,

,
yet

.
<EOS>
Her
mother
felt
the
change
in
her
with
a
sort
of
puzzled
wonder
that
Maggie
should
be
"
growing
up
so
good
"
;
it
was
amazing
that
this
once
"
contrairy
"
child
was
become
so
submissive
,
so
backward
to
assert
her
own
will
.
<EOS>
Maggie
used
to
look
up
from
her
work
and
find
her
mother
's
eyes
fixed
upon
her
;
they
were
watching
and
waiting
for
the
large
young
glance
,
as
if
her
elder
frame
got
some
needful
warmth
from
it
.
<EOS>
The
mother
was
getting
fond
of
her
tall
,
brown
girl
,
 
the
only
bit
of
furniture
now
on
which
she
could
bestow
her
anxiety
and
pride
;
and
Maggie
,
in
spite
of
her
own
ascetic
wish
to
have
no
personal
adornment
,
was
obliged
to
give
way
to
her
mother
about
her
hair
,
and
submit
to
have
the
abundant
black
locks
plaited
into
a
coronet
on
the
summit
of
her
head
,
after
the
pitiable
fashion
of
those
antiquated
times
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
your
mother
have
that
bit
<EOS>
o
'
pleasure
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mrs.
Tulliver
;
"
I
'd
trouble
enough
with
your
hair
once
.
"
  
<EOS>
So
Maggie
,
glad
of
anything
that
would
soothe
her
mother
,
and
cheer
their
long
day
together
,
consented
to
the
vain
decoration
,
and
showed
a
queenly
head
above
her
old
frocks
,
steadily
refusing
,
however
,

look
at

in

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Tulliver
liked
to
call

father
's
attention
to
Maggie
's
hair
and
other

,
but
he

a
brusk

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
knew
well
enough
what
she
'd
be
,
before
now
,
 
<EOS>
it
's

.
<EOS>
But
it

a
pity
<EOS>
she
is
n't
made
o
'
commoner
stuff
;
she
'll
be
thrown

,
I
doubt
,
 
there
'll
be
nobody
to
marry

as
is
fit
for

.
"
  
<EOS>
And
Maggie
's
graces
of
mind
and
body
fed
his
gloom
.
<EOS>
He
sat
patiently
enough
while
she
read

a
chapter
,
or

about
trouble
being

.
<EOS>
He
took

all
as

his
daughter
's

,
which
made

the
sadder
to

because

damaged
her

in

.
<EOS>
In

charged

an

,
there
is
no

for
new

;
Mr.
Tulliver
did
not

spiritual
consolation
 
<EOS>
he
wanted
to
shake
off
the
degradation
of
debt
,
and
to

.
    
<EOS>
_
Wheat
and
Tares
_
  
<EOS>
In
the
Red
Deeps
  
<EOS>
The
family
sitting
-
room
was
a
long
room
with
a
window
at
each
end
;
one
looking
toward
the
croft
and
along
the
Ripple
to
the
banks
of
the
Floss
,
the
other
into
the
mill
-
yard
.
<EOS>
Maggie
was
sitting
with
her
work
against
the
latter
window
when
she
saw
Mr.
Wakem
entering
the
yard
,
as
usual
,
on
his
fine
black
horse
;
but
not
alone
,
as
usual
.
<EOS>
Some
one
was
with
him
,
 
a
figure
in
a
cloak
,
on
a
handsome
pony
.
<EOS>
Maggie
had
hardly
time
to
feel
that
it
was
Philip
come
back
,
before
they
were
in
front

window
,
and
he
was
raising

hat
to

;
while
his
father
,
catching
the

by
a
side

,
looked
sharply
round

.
  
<EOS>
Maggie
hurried
away
from
the
window
and
carried
her
work
upstairs
;
for
Mr.
Wakem
sometimes
came
in
and
inspected
the
books
,
and
Maggie
felt
that
the
meeting
with
Philip
would
be
robbed
of
all
pleasure
in
the
presence
of
the
two

.
<EOS>
Some
day
,
perhaps
,
she
could
see
him
when
they
could
just
shake
hands
,
and
she
could
tell
him
that
she
remembered
his
goodness
to
Tom
,
and
the
things
he
had
said
to
her
in
the
old
days
,
though
they
could
never
be
friends

.
<EOS>
It

not

to

to
see
Philip
again
;
she
retained

,
and
remembered

;
and
in
the

had
continually
recalled
the

of
him
among
the

who
had
been
kind

her
in
life
,
often

she
had
him
for
a
brother
and

,
as
they
had
fancied

might
have

,
in

together
.
<EOS>
But

had
been
banished
along
with
other

that
savored
of
seeking
her
own
will
;
and
she

,

,
that
Philip
might
be
altered

abroad
,
 
he
might
have

worldly
,
and
really
not

about
her
saying

now
.
<EOS>
And
yet
his
face
was
wonderfully
little
altered
,
 
it
was
only
a
larger
,
more
manly
copy
of
the
pale
,

-

boy
's

,
with

,

;

the
old

;
and

,

felt
that
she
really
_
should
_
like

.
<EOS>
He
might
still

melancholy
,
as
he
always
used

and
like

to

.
<EOS>
She

;

square

-

,

until

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
It
was
far
on
in
June
now
,
and

was

one

;
but

she
never

beyond
the
gate
,
and

.
<EOS>
One

,

Ogg

,

beyond

"
Hill
,
"
 
an

,

the

which
ran

the

Dorlcote

.
<EOS>
Insignificant
I
call

,
because

;
but

;

,

<EOS>
the

,

.
<EOS>
Just

by
-

,

,

,
and
here

.
<EOS>
In

days
Maggie
held
this

,
called

Red
Deeps
,

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

had
the

her
which
any

,

rock

,
have
for

eyes
that

;

,

.
<EOS>
In

,

,

,

,

,
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
You

,

Deeps
by

,

-

and

<EOS>
she

.
<EOS>
One

to
be
farther
on
in

her
seventeenth
year
 
perhaps

.
<EOS>
Youth

have

well

her

,

lain

;
the

,

brown

,
the
full

.
<EOS>
With

and
jet

,

grand

,
at
which

.
<EOS>
Yet

,
 
a

opposing

,

;

a

,
such

,
<EOS>
out

resistant

,

,

,

dissipate

,
like

again
when

.
  
<EOS>
But

herself
was
not

.
<EOS>
She
was

,
while

,
and
thought
that
those

ends
of

were
the
records

past
storms
,

had

.
<EOS>
But

,

Philip
Wakem
,
who
first

,
and
then
,

,

.
<EOS>
Maggie
,

,
colored
with

,
which
soon
gave
way
to

.
<EOS>
She

,

nothing

child
's

,
 
a

that
was
always

.
<EOS>
She

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
startled
me
,
"
she

,

;
"
I
never

any
one
here
.
<EOS>
How
came

to

here
?
<EOS>
Did

come

_
me
?
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was

not

that
Maggie
felt
herself

child

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I

,
"

Philip
,

;
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
Then

-

,

,
I

,
behind

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"

,

,

on
as

,
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
I

Tom
,

;
but

.
<EOS>
Tom

,

I

_
that
_

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
believe
that
you
have
thought

me
so
much

I
have

you
,
"

Philip
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do

,

,

you
as

that

study
when

.
"
  
<EOS>
Philip
drew
a
large

-
case
from

,
and
opened

.
<EOS>
Maggie
saw
her
old
self
leaning

,
with

down

,

,

.
<EOS>
It

water
-

,
of

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh

,
"
said

,

,
and

,
"
what

queer
little

!
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Then
,

,

;

except

.
    
<EOS>
Aunt
Glegg
Learns
the
Breadth
of
Bob
's
Thumb
  
<EOS>
While
Maggie
's
life
-
struggles
had
lain
almost
entirely
within
her
own
soul
,
one
shadowy

fighting
another
,
and
the
slain
shadows
forever
rising
again
<EOS>
,
Tom
was
engaged
in
a
dustier
,
noisier

,
grappling
with
more
substantial

,
and
gaining
more

.
<EOS>
So
it
has
been
since
the
days
of
Hecuba
,
and
of
Hector
,
Tamer
of
horses
;
inside

,

,
watching

's

,

and

;
outside
,
the
men
,
in

with
things
divine
and

,
quenching
memory
in
the
stronger
light
of
purpose
,
losing
the
sense
of
dread
and
even
of
wounds
in
the
hurrying
ardor
of
action
.
  
<EOS>
From
what
you
have
seen
of
Tom
,
I
think
he
is
not
a
youth
of
whom
you
would
prophesy
failure
in
anything
he
had
thoroughly
wished
;
the
wagers
are
likely
to
be
on
his
side
,
notwithstanding
his
small
success
in
the
classics
.
<EOS>
For
Tom
had
never
desired
success
in
this
field
of
enterprise
;
and
for
getting
a
fine
flourishing
growth
of

there
is
nothing
like
pouring
out
on
a
mind
a
good
amount

subjects
in
which
it
feels
no

.
<EOS>
But
now
Tom
's
strong
will
bound
together

,
his

,
his
family

,
and
his
personal
ambition
,
and
made

one
force
,
concentrating
his
efforts
and
surmounting
discouragements
.
<EOS>
His
uncle
Deane
,
who
watched
him
closely
,
soon
began
to
conceive
hopes
of
him
,
and
to
be
rather

that
he
had
brought
into
the
employment
of
the
firm
a
nephew
who
appeared
to
be
made
of
such
good
commercial
stuff
.
<EOS>
The
real
kindness
of
placing
him
in
the
warehouse
first
was
soon

to
Tom
,
in
the
hints
his
uncle
began
to
throw
out
,
that
after

time
he
might
perhaps

trusted
to
travel
at
certain
seasons
,
and
buy
in
for
the
firm
various

with
which
I
need
not
shock
refined
ears
in
this

;
and

was
doubtless
with
a
view
to
this
result
that
Mr.
Deane
,
when
he
expected

take
his
wine
alone
,
would

Tom
to
step
in
and
sit
with
him
an
hour
,
and
would
pass
that

in
much

and

concerning

of

,
with

of
more

on
the
relative

to
the

of
St.
Ogg
's
of
having

brought
in
their
own
and

,
 
a

Deane
,
as
a

-
owner
,
naturally
threw

a
few

when
he
got
warmed
with
talk

.
  
<EOS>
Already
,
in
the
second
year
,
Tom
's

was
raised
;
but

,

,

and
he
shunned
comradeship
,
lest
it
should
lead
him
into
expenses
in

of
himself
.
<EOS>
Not
that
Tom
was
moulded
on
the
spoony
type
of
the
Industrious
Apprentice
;
he
had
a
very
strong
appetite
for
pleasure
,
 
would
have
liked
to
be
a
Tamer
of

and
to

in
all

,

well

,
and

one
of
the

young

of
those

;
nay
,
he
determined
to
achieve
these

sooner

;
but

told

that
the
means
no
such

could

lie
for

in
present

and

-

;
there
were
certain

,

's

.
<EOS>
Having

,
he
strode
along

,

some

,
as
a

to
do
who

call
upon

for
self
-

.
<EOS>
Tom
felt
intensely
that
common
cause
with
his
father
which
springs
from
family
pride
,
and
was
bent
on
being
irreproachable
as

;
but
his
growing

caused
him
to
pass
much

on
the

of
his
father
's
past
conduct
;
their
dispositions
were
not
in
sympathy
,
and
Tom
's
face
showed
little

during
his
few

.
<EOS>
Maggie
had
an
awe
of
him
,
against
which
she
struggled
as
something
unfair
to
her
consciousness
of
wider

and
deeper

;
but
it
was
of
no
use
to
struggle
.
<EOS>
A
character
at
unity
with
itself
 
<EOS>
that
performs
what
it
intends
,
subdues
every
counteracting
impulse
,
and
has
no
visions
beyond
the
distinctly
possible
 
<EOS>
is
strong
by

negations
.
  
<EOS>
You
may

that
Tom
's
more
and

to

father
was

;

to

.
<EOS>
He
was
likely
,

,
to
do

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Pullet
had
always

Tom
's

,
so
entirely
that
of
the
Dodsons
,

;

,

Tulliver

.
<EOS>
Mr.

,

Tom

when

,

,

,

;

;

<EOS>
Uncle

<EOS>
Tom
,

,

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

<EOS>

one

.
<EOS>
He

Tom

.
<EOS>
Trading
,

?
<EOS>
Tom

.
<EOS>
Why
,

<EOS>
Tom

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
He

,

's

.
<EOS>
All

;

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Tom

,

.

"

"

.
<EOS>
In

,

,
 
partly
,

that

between
near

,

which

;
partly
,

was
the

surprise

.
<EOS>
He
did
not

to

with

,
and

of

.
  
<EOS>
At

's

Philip
,

;

,

,

,

Guest

,

all

that

,

for

one

,

.
<EOS>
Did
he
not
desire
it
?
<EOS>
He
was

.
    
<EOS>
The
Wavering
Balance
  
<EOS>
I
said
that
Maggie
went
home
that
evening
from
the
Red
Deeps
with
a
mental
conflict
already
begun
.
<EOS>
You
have
seen
clearly
enough
,
in
her
interview
with
Philip
,
what
that
conflict
was
.
<EOS>
Here
suddenly
was
an
opening
in
the
rocky
wall
which
shut
in
the
narrow
valley
of
humiliation
,
where
all
her
prospect
was
the
remote
,
unfathomed
sky
;
and
some
of
the
memory
-
haunting
earthly
delights
were
no
longer
out
of
her
reach
.
<EOS>
She
might
have
books
,
converse
,
affection
;
she
might
hear
tidings
of
the
world
from
which
her
mind
had
not
yet
lost
its
sense
of
exile
;
and
it
would
be
a
kindness
to
Philip
too
,
who
was
pitiable
,
 
clearly
not
happy
.
<EOS>
And
perhaps
here
was
an
opportunity
indicated
for
making
her
mind
more
worthy
of
its
highest
service
;
perhaps
the
noblest
,
completest
devoutness
could
hardly
exist
without
some
width
of
knowledge
;
_
must
_
she
always
live
in
this
resigned
imprisonment
?
<EOS>
It
was
so
blameless
,
<EOS>
so
good
a
thing
that
there
should
be
friendship
between
her
and
Philip
;
the
motives
that
forbade
it
were
so
unreasonable
,
so
unchristian
!
<EOS>
But
the
severe
monotonous
warning
came
again
and
again
,
 
that
she
was
losing
the
simplicity
and
clearness
of
her
life
by
admitting
a
ground
of
concealment
;
and
that
,
by
forsaking
the
simple
rule
of
renunciation
,
she
was
throwing
herself
under
the
seductive
guidance
of
illimitable
wants
.
<EOS>
She
thought
she
had
won
strength
to
obey
the
warning
before
she
allowed
herself
the
next
week
to
turn
her
steps
in
the
evening
to
the
Red
Deeps
.
<EOS>
But
while
she
was
resolved
to
say
an
affectionate
farewell
to
Philip
,
how
she
looked
forward
to
that
evening

in
the
still
,

shade
of
the
hollows
,
away
from
all
that
was
harsh
and
unlovely
;
to
the
affectionate
,
admiring
looks
that
would
meet
her
;
to
the
sense
of
comradeship
that
childish
memories
would
give
to
wiser
,
older
talk
;
to
the
certainty
that
Philip
would
care
to
hear
everything
she
said
,
which
no
one
else
cared
for
!
<EOS>
It
was
a
half
-
hour
that
it
would
be
very
hard
to
turn
her
back
upon
,
with
the
sense
that
there
would
be
no
other
like
it
.
<EOS>
Yet
she
said
what
she
meant
to
say
;
she
looked
firm
as
well
as
sad
.
  
<EOS>
"
Philip
,
I
have
made
up
my
mind
;
it
is
right
that
we
should
give
each
other
up
,
in
everything
but

.
<EOS>
I
could
not
see
you
without
concealment
 
<EOS>
stay
<EOS>
,
I
know
what
you
are
going

say
,
 
it

's
wrong

that
make

necessary
;
but

is
bad
,
however

.
<EOS>
I
feel
that

would
be
bad

,

.
<EOS>
And
then
,

,

nothing

,
 
dreadful

;
and

must

,
and
it
would

harder
,
when
we
were
used
to
seeing
each
other
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Philip
's
face
had
flushed
,
and
there
was
a
momentary

of
expression
,
as
if
he
had
been
about
to
resist
this

with

.
  
<EOS>
But
he
controlled

,
and
said
,
with

:
"
<EOS>
Well
,
Maggie
,
if

,

for
one

;
let

,
for
the

.
"
  
<EOS>
He
took
her

,
and
Maggie
felt

to

;
his
quietness
made
her
all

sure
she
had
given
him
great
pain
,
and
she
wanted
to
show
him
how
unwillingly
she
had
given

.
<EOS>
They
walked
together

.
  
<EOS>
"
Let

,
"

,
"
where

stood
the

.
<EOS>
See

have

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
They

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
've

,
"
said

,
"
<EOS>
so

must

,
while

,
 
since

am
not

again
.
<EOS>
Please

this

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This

in
an

,
and

to

.
<EOS>
The
full

,

,

down

of

on

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall

for

,
"
she

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Will

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh

,
much

.
<EOS>
It
is
an
oil
-

.
<EOS>
You

,

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

;
"
<EOS>
but

many

,
 
sow

,

.
<EOS>
I
'm

,

.
<EOS>
I

;

,

,

;

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

is
a

to

,

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"

only

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

to
have
many

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

,

;

.
<EOS>
I

think
society
at

's

.
<EOS>
But
nothing
could
make
life
worth
<EOS>
the
purchase
-
money
of
pain
to

,
but
some

.
<EOS>
Yes
,
there
is
one
thing
,
 
a

answers
as

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Maggie
did
not

;

against
the
consciousness
that
Philip
's
words
had
set
her

vibrating

as

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

what
you

,
"
she

,
"

than

.
<EOS>
I
used
to
think
I
could
never

life
if

every

,
and

always

,

.
<EOS>
But
,

Philip
,
I
think

are
only
like

that

is

.
<EOS>
Is

not

to

,
<EOS>
whatever

?
<EOS>
I

in
that
for
the
last
two

,
even

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Maggie
,
"

,

;
"
and

,
which

by

all

.
<EOS>
Joy
and

are
not

;
resignation
is
the
willing

of
a
pain
that
is
not

,
that
you
do
n't
expect
to
be
allayed
.
<EOS>
Stupefaction
is
not
resignation
;
and
it
is
stupefaction
to
remain
in

,
 
to
shut

all
the
avenues
by
which
the
life
of
your
fellow
-

might
become
known

.
<EOS>
I
am
not
resigned
;
I
am
not

that
life
is
long
enough
to
learn
that
lesson
.
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
You
_
are
not
resigned
;
you
are
only
trying
to
stupefy
yourself
.
"
  
<EOS>
Maggie
's
lips
trembled
;
she
felt
there
was
some
truth
in
what
Philip
said
,
and
yet
there
was
a
deeper
consciousness
that
,
for
any

it
had
to
her

,
it
was
no

than

.
<EOS>
Her
double
impression
corresponded
to
the
double
impulse
of
the
speaker
.
<EOS>
Philip
seriously
believed
what
he
said
,
but
he
said
it
with
vehemence
because
it
made
an
argument
against
the
resolution
that
opposed
his
wishes
.
<EOS>
But
Maggie
's
face
,
made
more
childlike
by
the
gathering

,
touched
him
with
a
tenderer
,
less
egotistic
feeling
.
<EOS>
He
took
her
hand
and
said
gently
:
  
"
Do
n't
let
us
think
of
such
things
in
this
short
half
-

,
Maggie
.
<EOS>
Let

only

about

together
.
<EOS>
We
shall
be
friends
in
spite
of

.
<EOS>
We
shall
always
think
of
each
other
.
<EOS>
I
shall
be

to
live
as

as
you

,
because
I
shall
think
there
may

<EOS>
when
I
can
 
when

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
What

,

,
Philip
,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

would
have
made

about

,
and

,

.
<EOS>
You

,

.
<EOS>
That

Tom

.
<EOS>
I

_

_

.
<EOS>
That

do

.
<EOS>
I

,
 
I

;

.
<EOS>

,

?
"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
I

"

Love

sits

,
"

,

?

<EOS>
"
Oh

,

wo

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Let

,

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"

"

"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
You

;

,
 
all

.
<EOS>
And

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
"

<EOS>
"

;

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,

will
not
,
Maggie
;
no

has
strength

to
do
what
is
unnatural
.
<EOS>
It
is
mere

to

.
<EOS>
No
character
becomes

in
that

.
<EOS>
You
will
be
thrown

the

some

,

then
every

satisfaction
of
your
nature
that
you
deny
now

.
"
  
<EOS>
Maggie
started
and

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Philip
,
how
dare
you
shake

?
<EOS>
You

a

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
I

;
but
love
gives
insight
,
Maggie
,
and

often
gives
foreboding
.
<EOS>
_
Listen
_

,
 
<EOS>
let
_

books
<EOS>
;
do

,
 
be

,

.
<EOS>
It

less

.
"
  
<EOS>
Maggie
felt
unable
to

.
<EOS>
She
shook
her

and
walked
on
in
silence
,
till
they
came
to
the
end
of
the
Scotch

,
and

in

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
banish
me
from
this

forever
,

,
Maggie
?
<EOS>
Surely
I
may
come
and
walk
in

sometimes
?
<EOS>
If
I
meet
you
by
chance
,
there
is
no
concealment
in
that
?
"
  
<EOS>
It
is
the
moment
when
our
resolution
seems
about
to
become
irrevocable
 
when
the
fatal
iron
gates
are
about
to
close
upon
us
 
that
tests
our

.
<EOS>
Then
,
after
hours
of
clear
reasoning
and
firm
conviction
,
we
snatch
at
any
sophistry
that
will
nullify
our
long
struggles
,
and
bring
us
the
defeat
that
we
love
better
than
victory
.
  
<EOS>
Maggie
felt
her
heart
leap
at
this
subterfuge
of
Philip
's
,
and
there
passed
over
her
face
that
almost
imperceptible
shock
which
accompanies
any
relief
.
<EOS>
He
saw
it
,
and
they
parted
in
silence
.
  
<EOS>
Philip
's
sense
of
the
situation
was
too
complete
for
him
not
to
be
visited
with
glancing
fears
lest
he
had
been
intervening
too
presumptuously
in
the
action
of
Maggie
's
conscience
,
perhaps
for
a
selfish
end
.
<EOS>
But
no
!
 
<EOS>
he
persuaded
himself
his
end
was
not
selfish
.
<EOS>
He
had
little
hope
that
Maggie
would
ever
return
the
strong
feeling
he
had
for
her
;
and
it
must
be
better
for
Maggie
's
future
life
,
when
these
petty
family
obstacles
to
her
freedom
had
disappeared
,
that
the
present
should
not
be
entirely
sacrificed
,
and
that
she
should
have
some
opportunity
of
culture
,
 
<EOS>
some
interchange
with
a
mind
above
the
vulgar
level
of
those
she
was
now
condemned
to
live
with
.
<EOS>
If
we
only
look
far
enough
off
for
the
consequence
of
our
actions
,
we
can
always
find
some
point
in
the
combination
of
results
by
which
those
actions
can
be
justified
;
by
adopting
the
point
of
view
of
a
Providence
who
arranges
results
,
or
of
a
philosopher
who
traces
them
,
we
shall

it
possible
to
obtain
perfect
complacency
in
choosing
to
do
what
is
most
agreeable
to
us
in
the
present
moment
.
<EOS>
And
it
was
in
this
way
that
Philip
justified
his
subtle
efforts
to
overcome
Maggie
's
true
prompting
against
a
concealment
that
would
introduce
doubleness
into
her
own
mind
,
and
might
cause
new
misery
to
those
who
had
the
primary
natural
claim
on
her
.
<EOS>
But
there
was
a
surplus
of
passion
in
him
that
made
him
half
independent
of
justifying
motives
.
<EOS>
His
longing
to
see
Maggie
,
and
make
an
element
in
her
life
,
had
in
it
some
of
that
savage

to
snatch
an
offered
joy
which
springs
from
a
life
in
which
the
mental
and
bodily
constitution
have
made
pain
predominate
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
his
full
share
in
the
common
good
of
men
;
he
could
not
even
pass
muster
with
the
insignificant
,
but
must
be
singled
out
for
pity
,
and
excepted
from
what
was
a
matter

others
.
<EOS>
Even

Maggie
he
was
an
exception
;
it
was
clear
that
the
thought
of
his
being
her
lover
had
never
entered
her

.
  
<EOS>
Do
not
think
too
hardly
of
Philip
.
<EOS>
Ugly
and
deformed
people
have
great
need
of
unusual

,
because

likely

the
theory

,
as

is

.
<EOS>
The
temptations
of

are
much

,

ugliness

as

<EOS>
Does

type

the
utmost
trial
to
what
is
human

?
  
<EOS>
Philip

Another

satisfied
with
such
an
interpretation
;
he
had
seen
clearly
enough
that
there
was
something
distinct
from
anxiety
about
her
father
in
Maggie
's
excessive
confusion
.
<EOS>
In
trying
to
recall
all
the
details
that
could
give
shape
to
his
suspicions
,
he
remembered
only
lately
hearing
his
mother
scold
Maggie
for
walking
in
the
Red
Deeps
when
the
ground
was
wet
,
and
bringing
home
shoes
clogged
with
red
soil
;
<EOS>
still
Tom
,
retaining
all
his
old
repulsion
for
Philip
's
deformity
,
shrank
from
attributing
to
his
sister
the
probability
of
feeling
more
than
a
friendly
interest
in
such
an
unfortunate
exception
to
the
common
run
of
men
.
<EOS>
Tom
's
was
a
nature
which
had
a
sort
of
superstitious
repugnance
to
everything
exceptional
.
<EOS>
A
love
for
a
deformed
man
would
be
odious
in
any
woman
,
in
a
sister
intolerable
.
<EOS>
But
if
she
had
been
carrying
on
any
kind
of
intercourse
whatever
with
Philip
,
a
stop
must
be
put
to
it
at
once
;
she
was
disobeying
her
father
's
strongest
feelings
and
her
brother
's
express
commands
,
besides
compromising
herself
by
secret
meetings
.
<EOS>
He
left
home
the
next
morning
in
that
watchful
state
of
mind
which
turns
the
most
ordinary
course
of
things
into
pregnant

.
  
<EOS>
That
afternoon
,
about
half
-
past
three

,
Tom
was
standing
on
the

,
talking
with
Bob
Jakin
about
the
probability
of
the
good
ship
<EOS>
Adelaide
coming
in
,
in
a
day
or
two
,
with
results
highly

to

.
  
<EOS>
"
Eh
,
"
said
Bob
,
parenthetically
,

over

fields
on
the
other

of
the
river
,
"
there
goes
that
crooked
young
Wakem
.
<EOS>
I
know
him
or
his
shadder
as
far
off
as
I
can
see
'em
;
I
'm
allays
lighting
on
him
o
'
<EOS>
that
side
the
river
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
A
sudden
thought
seemed
to
have
darted
through
Tom
's
mind
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
go
,
Bob
,
"
he
said
;
"
I
've
something
to
attend
to
,
"
hurrying
off
to
the
warehouse
,
where
he
left
notice
for
some
one
to
take
his
place
;
he
was
called
away
home
on
peremptory
business
.
  
<EOS>
The
swiftest
pace
and
the
shortest
road
took
him
to
the
gate
,
and
he
was
pausing
to
open
it
deliberately
,
that
he
might
walk
into
the
house
with
an
appearance
of
perfect
composure
,
when
Maggie
came
out
at
the
front
door
in
bonnet

.
<EOS>
His
conjecture
was
fulfilled
,
and
he
waited
for

at

gate
.
<EOS>
She
started
violently
when
she
saw

.
  
<EOS>
"
Tom
,
how
is
it

are
come
home
?
<EOS>
Is
there
anything
the
matter
?
"
<EOS>
Maggie
spoke
in
a

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
come
to

with
you
to
the
Red
Deeps
,
and
meet
Philip
Wakem
,
"
said
Tom
,
the
central
fold
in
his
brow
,
which
had
become

with

,
deepening
as

spoke
.
  
<EOS>
Maggie
stood
helpless
,
pale
and

.
<EOS>
By
some
means
,
then
,
Tom
knew
everything
.
<EOS>
At
last
she
said
,
"
I
'm
not
going
,
"
and
turned

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
you
are
;
but
I
want

.
<EOS>
Where

father
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Out

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
my
mother
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
In
the
yard
,
I
think
,
with
the
poultry
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
go
in
,
then
,

?
"
  
<EOS>
They

in
together
,
and
<EOS>
Tom
,

,
said
to

,
"
Come

.
"
  
<EOS>
She

,
and
he

behind

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Maggie
,
tell

has

between

and
Philip
Wakem
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Does
my
father
know
anything
?
"
said
Maggie
,
still

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Tom

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
he
_
shall
_
know
,
if
you
attempt
to
use

toward
me
any
further
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
wish
to
use
deceit
,
"
said
Maggie
,
flushing
into
resentment
at
hearing
this
word
applied
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
Tell
me
the
whole

,
then
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
you
know

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
whether
I
know
it
or
not
.
<EOS>
Tell
me
exactly
what
has
happened
,
or
my
father
shall
know
everything
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
tell
it
for
my
father
's

,
then
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
it
becomes
you
to
profess

for
your
father
,
when
you
have
despised
his
strongest
feelings
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
never
do
wrong
,
Tom
,
"
said
Maggie
,
tauntingly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
if
I
know
it
,
"
answered
Tom
,
with

.
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
have
nothing
to
say
to
you
beyond
this
:
tell

what
has
passed
between
you
and
Philip
Wakem
.
<EOS>
When
did
you
first
meet
him
in
the
Red
Deeps
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
A
year
ago
,
"
said
Maggie
,
quietly
.
<EOS>
Tom
's
severity
gave
her
a
certain
fund
of
defiance
,
and
kept
her
sense
of
error
in
abeyance
.
<EOS>
"
You
need
ask
me
no
more
questions
.
<EOS>
We
have
been
friendly
a
year
.
<EOS>
We
have
met
and
walked
together
often
.
<EOS>
He
has
lent
me
books
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
that
all
?
"
said
Tom
,
looking
straight
at

with
his

.
  
<EOS>
Maggie
paused
a
moment
;
then
,
determined
to
make
an
end
of
Tom
's
right
to
accuse

of

,
she
said

:
  
"
No
,
not
quite
all
.
<EOS>
On
Saturday
he
told

that
he
loved

.
<EOS>
I
did
n't
think
of
it
before

;
I
had
only

as
an
old

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
_
encouraged
_
him
?
"
<EOS>
said
Tom
,
with
an
expression
of
disgust
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
told
him
that
I
loved
him
too
.
"
  
<EOS>
Tom
was
silent
a
few
moments
,
looking
on
the
ground
and
frowning
,
with
his
hands
in

.
<EOS>
At
last
he
looked
up
and
said

,
    
"
Now
,
then
,
Maggie
,
there
are
but

,
 
<EOS>
either

,

,
that
you

,

;

once

<EOS>
,

,

with
the
son
of
a

that
has

.
<EOS>
Choose
!
"
<EOS>
Tom
ended

,
going

to

large

,
drawing

,
and
opening

at
the
fly

,
where

writing
was
.
  
<EOS>
It

a

alternative
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
Tom
,
"
she

,
urged

of

,
"
do

.
<EOS>
I
will

you

Philip
,

,

,
 
to

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
He
_

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

;

.
<EOS>
Choose
,

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"
Do

_
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
"
I
ca

,

.
<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

?
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
"

"

,

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Maggie
felt

;

,

to

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Tom
,
"
she

in

,
"

wrong

;
but
I
was
so

,

Philip
.
<EOS>
And
I
think

and
hatred
are

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
!
"

Tom
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your

.
<EOS>
Say

;

,
in

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
_
must
_

Philip

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
will

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

not

.
<EOS>
That
is

only

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Say

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Maggie

the

of

and

.
<EOS>
Tom
closed
the
book
,
and

,
"
Now

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Not
a
word
was
spoken
as
they
walked
along
.
<EOS>
Maggie
was
suffering
in
anticipation
of
what
Philip
was
about
to
suffer
,
and
dreading
the
galling
words
that
would
fall
on
him
from
Tom
's
lips
;
but
she
felt
it
was
in
vain
to
attempt
anything
but
submission
.
<EOS>
Tom
had
his
terrible
clutch
on
her
conscience
and
her
deepest
dread
;
she
writhed
under
the
demonstrable
truth
of
the
character
he
had
given
to
her
conduct
,
and
yet
her
whole
soul
rebelled
against
it
as
unfair
from
its
incompleteness
.
<EOS>
He
,
meanwhile
,
felt
the
impetus
of
his
indignation
diverted
toward
Philip
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
know
how
much
of
an
old
boyish
repulsion
and
of
mere
personal
pride
and
animosity
was
concerned
in
the
bitter
severity
of
the
words
by
which
he
meant
to
do
the
duty
of
a
son
and
a
brother
.
<EOS>
Tom
was
not
given
to
inquire
subtly
into
his
own
motives
any
more
than
into
other
matters
of
an
intangible
kind
;
he
was
quite
sure
that
his
own
motives
as
well
as
actions
were
good
,
else
he
would
have
had
nothing
to
do
with
them
.
  
<EOS>
Maggie
's
only
hope
was
that
something
might
,
for
the
first
time
,
have
prevented
Philip
from
coming
.
<EOS>
Then
there
would
be
delay
,
 
then
she
might
get
Tom
's
permission
to
write
to
him
.
<EOS>
Her
heart
beat
with
double
violence
when
they
got
under
the
Scotch
firs
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
last
moment
of
suspense
,
she
thought
;
Philip
always
met
her
soon
after
she
got
beyond
them
.
<EOS>
But
they
passed
across
the
more
open
green
space
,
and
entered
the
narrow
bushy
path
by
the
mound
.
<EOS>
Another
turning
,
and
they
came
so
close
upon
him
that
both
Tom
and
Philip
stopped
suddenly
within
a
yard
of
each
other
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
moment
's
silence
,
in
which
Philip
darted
a
look
of
inquiry
at
Maggie
's
face
.
<EOS>
He
saw
an
answer
there
,
in
the
pale
,
parted
lips
,
and
the
terrified
tension
of
the
large
eyes
.
<EOS>
Her
imagination
,
always
rushing
extravagantly
beyond
an
immediate
impression
,
saw
her
tall
,
strong
brother
grasping
the
feeble
Philip
bodily
,
crushing
him
and
trampling
on
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
call
this
acting
the
part
of
a
man
and
a
gentleman
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Tom
said
,
in
a
voice
of
harsh
scorn
,
as
soon
as
Philip
's
eyes
were
turned
on
him
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
?
"
answered
Philip
,
haughtily
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mean
?
<EOS>
Stand
farther
from
me
,
lest
I
should
lay
hands
on
you
,
and
I
'll
tell
you
what
I
mean
.
<EOS>
I
mean
,
taking
advantage
of
a
young
girl
's
foolishness
and
ignorance
to
get
her
to
have
secret
meetings
with
you
.
<EOS>
I
mean
,
daring
to
trifle
with
the
respectability
of
a
family
that
has
a
good
and
honest
name
to
support
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
deny
that
,
"
interrupted
Philip
,
impetuously
.
<EOS>
"
I
could
never
trifle
with
anything
that
affected
your
sister
's
happiness
.
<EOS>
She
is
dearer
to
me
than
she
is
to
you
;
I
honor
her
more
than
you
can
ever
honor
her
;
I
would
give
up
my
life
to
her
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
n't
talk
high
-
flown
nonsense
to
me
,
sir
!
<EOS>
Do
you
mean
to
pretend
that
you
did
n't
know
it
would
be
injurious
to
her
to
meet
you
here
week
after
week
?
<EOS>
Do
you
pretend
you
had
any
right
to
make
professions
of
love
to
her
,
even
if
you
had
been
a
fit

for
her
,
when
neither
her
father
nor
your
father
would
ever

to
a

between

?
<EOS>
And
_
<EOS>
you
_
,
 
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
you
_
to
try
and
worm
yourself
into
the
affections
of
a
handsome
girl
who
is
not
eighteen
,
and
has
been
shut
out
from
the
world
by
her
father
's
misfortunes
!
<EOS>
That
's
your
crooked
notion
of
honor
,
is
it
?
<EOS>
I
call
it
base
treachery
;
I
call
it
taking
advantage
of
circumstances
to
win
what
's
too
good
for
you
,
 
what
you
'd
never
get
by
fair
means
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
manly
of
you
to
talk
in
this
way
to
_
me
_
,
"
said
Philip
,
bitterly
,
his
whole
frame
shaken
by
violent
emotions
.
<EOS>
"
Giants
have
an
immemorial
right
to
stupidity
and
insolent
abuse
.
<EOS>
You
are
incapable
even
of
understanding
what
I
feel
for
your
sister
.
<EOS>
I
feel
so
much
for
her
that
I
could
even
desire
to
be
at
friendship
with
_
<EOS>
you
_
<EOS>
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
be
very
sorry
to
understand
your
feelings
,
"
said
Tom
,
with
scorching
contempt
.
<EOS>
"
What
I
wish
is
that
you
should
understand
<EOS>
_
me
<EOS>
_
,
 
that
I
shall
take
care

_

_

,
and
that
if
you
dare
to
make

least

to

,

,

,
your

,

,
that
ought
to
have
put

,
shall
not

.
<EOS>
I

;
I
'll
hold
you

public

.
<EOS>
Who
would
n't
laugh
at

_
your
_

lover
to
a
fine
girl
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Tom
and
Maggie
walked
on
in
silence
for
some
yards
.
<EOS>
He
burst
out
,
in
a

voice
.
  
<EOS>
"
Stay
,
Maggie
!
"
said
Philip
,
making

to

.
<EOS>
Then

at
Tom
,
"
You
have
dragged
your
sister
here
<EOS>
,
I
suppose
,
that

may

.
<EOS>
These
naturally
seemed

the

.
<EOS>
But
you
are
mistaken
.
<EOS>
Let

speak
.
<EOS>
If

says

is

to
give

,
I

to
the

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
Tom

,

;

,

's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
enough
,

.
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
I
_
shall
not

;
but

.
<EOS>
But

;

that
I
can
never
seek
for
anything
but
good
to
what

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Tom
,

this

of
Philip
's
,
"
you
can
talk
of
seeking
good
for
her
and
what
belongs
to
her
now
;
did
you
seek
her
good
before
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
,
 
at
some
risk
,

.
<EOS>
But
I
wished
her
to
have
a
friend
for
life
,
 
who
would

her
,
who
would
do

more

than
a
coarse
and
narrow

brother
,
that
she
has
always

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
way
of
befriending
her
is
different
from

;
and
I
'll
tell
you
what
is
my

.
<EOS>
I
'll
save
her
from
disobeying
and
disgracing
her
father
;
I
'll
save
her
from
throwing
herself

on
you
,
 
from
making

a
laughing
-
stock
,
 
from
being

by
a
man
like
_
your
_
father
,
because

's

for

.
<EOS>
You
know

what
sort
of

you
were

for

.
<EOS>
I
'm
not
to
be
imposed
upon
by
fine
words
;
I
can
see
what
actions
mean
.
<EOS>
Come
away
,
Maggie
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
seized
Maggie
's
right
wrist
as
he
spoke
,
and
she
put
out
her
left
hand
.
<EOS>
Philip
clasped
it
an
instant
,
with
one
eager
look
,
and
then
hurried
away
.
  
<EOS>
Tom
and
Maggie
walked
on
in
silence
for
some
yards
.
<EOS>
He
was
still
holding
her
wrist
tightly
,
as
if
he
were
compelling
a
culprit
from
the
scene
of
action
.
<EOS>
At
last
Maggie
,
with
a
violent
snatch
,
drew
her
hand
away
,
and
her
pent
-
up
,
long
-
gathered
irritation
burst
into
utterance
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
suppose
that
I
think
you
are
right
,
Tom
,
or
that
I
bow
to
your
will
.
<EOS>
I
despise
the
feelings
you
have
shown
in
speaking
to
Philip
;
I
detest
your

,
unmanly

to
his
deformity
.
<EOS>
You
have
been
reproaching
other
people
all
your
life
;
you
have
been
always
sure
you
yourself
are
right
.
<EOS>
It
is
because
you
have
not
a
mind
large
enough
to
see
that
there
is
anything
better
than
your
own
conduct
and
your
own
petty

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Certainly
,
"
said
Tom
,
coolly
.
<EOS>
"
I
do

see
that
your
conduct
is
better
,

your

either
.
<EOS>
If

conduct
,
and
Philip
Wakem
's
conduct
,

,
why

you

its

?
<EOS>
Answer

that
.
<EOS>
I
know
what
I
have

in
my

,
and
I
've
succeeded
;
pray
<EOS>
,
what
good

to

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

,
"
said

,
still
with

:
<EOS>
"
I
know
I
've

wrong
,
 
often
,

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

I

you

.
<EOS>
If
_

_

,

,

;
I

.
<EOS>
But

have

;

;

,

.
<EOS>
You
have
no

;
you
have
no

and

own

.
<EOS>
It
is
a

to
be

;
it
is
not

for

,

.
<EOS>
You

nothing

.
<EOS>
You
thank

nothing

;
you

to

.
<EOS>
You
have
not
even
a
vision
of
feelings
by
the

your

are
mere

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"

,

,
"

,

than

's

,
 
than

.
<EOS>
Pray
,

,

,

?
<EOS>
By

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Because

,
Tom
,

"

"

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
You

,

.

Wakem

.
<EOS>
The

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very

;
that
is
your

.
"
<EOS>
said
Tom
,
more

than

;
"
you
need

no
more

what
a
wide
distance

is
between

.
<EOS>
Let

in

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Tom
went
back
to
St.
Ogg
's
,
to
fulfill
an
appointment
with
his
uncle
Deane
,
and
receive
directions
about
a
journey
on
which
he
was
to
set
out
the
next
morning
.
  
<EOS>
Maggie
went
up
to
her
own
room
to
pour
out
all
that
indignant
remonstrance
,
against
which
Tom
's
mind
was
close
barred
,
in
bitter
tears
.
<EOS>
Then
,
when
the
first
burst
of
unsatisfied
anger
was
gone
by
,
came
the
recollection
of
that
quiet
time
before
the
pleasure
which
had
ended
in
to
-
day
's
misery
had
perturbed
the
clearness
and
simplicity
of
her
life
.
<EOS>
She
used
to
think
in
that
time
that
she
had
made
great
conquests
,
and
won
a
lasting
stand
on
serene
heights
above
worldly
temptations
and
conflict
.
<EOS>
And
here
she
was
down
again
in
the
thick
of
a
hot
strife
with
her
own
and
others
'
passions
.
<EOS>
Life
was
not
so
short
,
then
,
and
perfect
rest
was
not
so
near
as
she
had
dreamed
when
she
was
two
years
younger
.
<EOS>
There
was
more
struggle
for
her
,
and
perhaps
more
falling
.
<EOS>
If
she
had
felt
that
she
was
entirely
wrong
,
and
that
Tom
had
been
entirely
right
,
she
could
sooner
have
recovered
more
inward
harmony
;
but
now
her
penitence
and
submission
were
constantly
obstructed
by
resentment
that
would
present
itself
to
her
<EOS>
no
otherwise
than
as
a
just
indignation
.
<EOS>
Her
heart
bled
for
Philip
;
she
went
on
recalling
the
insults
that
had
been
flung
at
him
with
so
vivid
a
conception
of
what
he
had
felt
under
them
,
that
it
was
almost
like
a
sharp
bodily
pain
to
her
,
making
her
beat
the
floor
with
her
foot
and
tighten
her
fingers
on
her
palm
.
  
<EOS>
And
yet
,
how
was
it
that
she
was
now
and
then
conscious
of
a
certain
dim
background
of
relief
in
the
forced
separation
from
Philip
?
<EOS>
Surely
it
was
only
because
the
sense
of
a
deliverance
from
concealment
was
welcome
at
any
cost
.
    
<EOS>
The
Hard
-
Won
Triumph
  
<EOS>
Three
weeks
later
,
when
Dorlcote
Mill
was
at
its
prettiest
moment
in
all
the
year
,
 
the
great
chestnuts
in
blossom
,
and
the
grass
all
deep
and
daisied
,
 
<EOS>
Tom
Tulliver
came
home
to
it
earlier
than
usual
in
the
evening
,
and
as
he
passed
over
the
bridge
,
he
looked
with
the
old
deep
-
rooted
affection
at
the
respectable
red
brick
house
,
which
always
seemed
cheerful
and
inviting
outside
,
let
the
rooms
be
as
bare
and
the
hearts
as
sad
as
they
might
inside
.
<EOS>
There
is
a
very
pleasant
light
in
Tom
's
blue
-
gray
eyes
as
he
glances
at
the
house
-
windows
;
that
fold
in
his
brow
never
disappears
,
but
it
is
not
unbecoming
;
it
seems
to
imply
a
strength
of
will
that
may
possibly
be
without
harshness
,
when
the
eyes
and
mouth
have
their
gentlest
expression
.
<EOS>
His
firm
step
becomes
quicker
,
and
the
corners
of
his
mouth
rebel
against
the
compression
which
is
meant
to
forbid
a
smile
.
  
<EOS>
The
eyes
in
the
parlor
were
not
turned
toward
the
bridge
just
then
,
and
the
group
there
was
sitting
in
unexpectant
silence
,
 
Mr.
Tulliver
in
his
arm
-
chair
,
tired
with
a
long
ride
,
and
ruminating
with
a
worn
look
,
fixed
chiefly
on
Maggie
,
who
was
bending
over
her
sewing
while
her
mother
was
making
the
tea
.
  
<EOS>
They
all
looked
up
with
surprise
when
they
heard
the
well
-
known
foot
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
's
up
now
,
Tom
?
"
said
his
father
.
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
bit
earlier
than
usual
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

o

"
  
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
The

.
  
<EOS>
Tom

"

<EOS>

.
"

"

.

<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr.

<EOS>
"

"

"

's

.
<EOS>
I

_

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Tom
never

;

.
<EOS>
Tom
_
was
_
good
;
and
in

that

all

,

that

,

.
<EOS>
She

this

that
,

,

.
  
<EOS>
There

much

talk
before

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Tulliver
naturally
wanted
to
hear
all
the
particulars
of
Tom
's
trading

,
and
he
listened
with
growing

and

.
<EOS>
He
was
curious
to
know

been

;
if

,
what
had
been

;
and
Bob
Jakin
's
part
in
the
business
threw
him
into

of

with
the
triumphant

of
that
remarkable

.
<EOS>
Bob
's
juvenile
history
,
so
far

it
had
come

Tulliver
's
knowledge
,
was
recalled
with
that

of
astonishing

it
displayed
,
which
is
observable
in
all

of

of
great
men
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
well
that
there
was
this
interest
of
narrative
to
keep
under
the
vague
but

sense
of
triumph
over
Wakem
,
<EOS>
which
would
otherwise
have
been
the
channel
his
joy
would
have
rushed
into
with
dangerous
force
.
<EOS>
Even
as
it
was
,
that
feeling
from
time
to
time
gave
threats
of
its
ultimate
mastery
,
in
sudden
bursts
of
irrelevant

.
  
<EOS>
It
was
long
before
Mr.
Tulliver
got
to
sleep
that
night
;
and
the

,
when
it
came
,
was
filled
with
vivid

.
<EOS>
At

,

,

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
's

,
Mr.
Tulliver
?
"
said

wife
.
<EOS>
He
looked
at

,
still

,
and
said
at
last
:
  
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
I
was
dreaming
 
<EOS>
did
I
make
a
noise
?
 
<EOS>
I
thought
I
'd
got
hold
of
him
.
"
    
<EOS>
A
Day
of
Reckoning
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Tulliver
was
an
essentially
sober
man
,
 
able
to
take
his
glass
and
not
averse
to
it
,
but
never
exceeding
the
bounds
of
moderation
.
<EOS>
He
had
naturally
an
active
Hotspur
temperament
,
which
did
not
crave
liquid
fire
to
set
it
aglow
;
his
impetuosity
was
usually
equal
to
an
exciting
occasion
without
any
such
reinforcements
;
and
his
desire
for
the
brandy
-
and
-
water
implied
that
the
too
sudden
joy
had
fallen
with
a
dangerous
shock
on
a
frame
depressed
by
four
years
of
gloom
and
unaccustomed
hard
fare
.
<EOS>
But
that
first
doubtful
tottering
moment
passed
,
he
seemed
to
gather
strength
with
his
gathering
excitement
;
and
the
next
day
,
when
he
was
seated
at
table
with
his
creditors
,
his
eye
kindling
and
his
cheek
flushed
with
the
consciousness
that
he
was
about
to
make
an
honorable
figure
once
more
,
he
looked
more
like
the
proud
,
confident
,
warm
-
hearted
,
and
warm
-
tempered
Tulliver
of
old
times
than
might
have
seemed
possible
to
any
one
who
had
met
him
a
week
before
,
riding
along
as
had
been
his
wo
nt
for
the
last
four
years
<EOS>
since
the
sense
of
failure
and
debt
had
been
upon
him
,
 
with
his
head
hanging
down
,
casting
brief
,
unwilling
looks
on
those
who
forced
themselves
on
his
notice
.
<EOS>
He
made
his
speech
,
asserting
his
honest
principles
with
his
old
confident
eagerness
,
alluding
to
the
rascals
and
the
luck
that
had
been
against
him
,
but
that
he
had
triumphed
over
,
to
some
extent
,
by
hard
efforts
and
the
aid
of
a
good
son
;
and
winding
up
with
the
story
of
how
Tom
had
got
the
best
part
of
the
needful
money
.
<EOS>
But
the
streak
of
irritation
and
hostile
triumph
seemed
to
melt
for
a
little
while
into
purer
fatherly
pride
and
pleasure
,
when
,
Tom
's
health
having
been
proposed
,
and
uncle
Deane
having
taken
occasion
to
say
a
few
words
of
eulogy
on
his
general
character
and
conduct
,
Tom
himself
got
up
and
made
the
single
speech
of
his
life
.
<EOS>
It
could
hardly
have
been
briefer
.
<EOS>
He
thanked
the
gentlemen
for
the
honor
they
had
done
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
glad
that
he
had
been
able
to
help
his
father
in
proving
his
integrity
and
regaining
his
honest
name
;
and
,
for
his
own
part
,
he
hoped
he
should
never
undo
that
work
and
disgrace
that
name
.
<EOS>
But
the
applause
that
followed
was
so
great
,
and
Tom
looked
so
gentlemanly
as
well
as
tall
and
straight
,
that
Mr.
Tulliver
remarked
,
in
an
explanatory
manner
,
to
his
friends
on
his
right
and
left
,
that
he
had
spent
a
deal
of
money
on
his
son
's
education
.
  
<EOS>
The
party
broke
up
in
very
sober
fashion
at
five
o'clock
.
<EOS>
Tom
remained
in
St.
Ogg
's
to
attend
to
some
business
,
and
Mr.
Tulliver
mounted
his
horse
to
go
home
,
and
describe
the
memorable
things
that
had
been
said
and
done
,
to
"
poor
Bessy
and
the
little
wench
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
air
of
excitement
that
hung
about
him
was
but
faintly
due
to
good
cheer
or
any
stimulus
but
the
potent
wine
of
triumphant
joy
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
choose
any
back
street
to
-
day
,
but
rode
slowly
,
with
uplifted
head
and
free
glances
,
along
the
principal
street
all
the
way
to
the
bridge
.
  
<EOS>
Why
did
he
not
happen
to
meet
Wakem
?
<EOS>
The
want
of
that
coincidence
vexed
him
,
and
set
his
mind
at
work
in
an
irritating
way
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
Wakem
was
gone
out
of
town
to
-
day
on
purpose
to
avoid
seeing
or
hearing
anything
of
an
honorable
action
which
might
well
cause
him
some
unpleasant
twinges
.
<EOS>
If
Wakem
were
to
meet
him
then
,
Mr.
Tulliver
would
look
straight
at
him
,
and
the
rascal
would
perhaps
be
forsaken
a
little
by
his
cool
,

impudence
.
<EOS>
He
would
know
by
and
by
that
an
honest
man
was
not
going
to
serve
_
him
<EOS>
_
any
longer
,
and
lend
his
honesty
to
fill
a
pocket
already
over
-
full
of
dishonest
gains
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
the
luck
was
beginning
to
turn
;
perhaps
the
Devil
did
n't
always
hold
the
best
cards
in
this
world
.
  
<EOS>
Simmering
in
this
way
,
Mr.
Tulliver
approached
the
yardgates
of
Dorlcote
Mill
,
near
enough
to
see
a
well
-
known
figure
coming

on

fine

.
<EOS>
They
met
about
fifty

from
the
gates
,
between
the
great

and

and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Tulliver
,
"
said

,

,

,
"
what

's
trick

did
,
 
spreading
those
hard

on
that
Far
Close
!
<EOS>
I
told

how
it
would

;
but
you

never

with

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
"
said
<EOS>
Tulliver
,

;
"
get

else
to
farm
for

,
then
,
as'll
ask
_
you
_
to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have

,

,
"

Wakem
,
really

's

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
've
not
been
drinking
,
"
said
Tulliver
;
"
I
want
no
drinking
to
help
me
make

my
mind
as
I
'll
serve
no
longer

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
well
!
<EOS>
you
may

to
-

,

;

your
insolent

and

.
"
<EOS>
(
Tulliver
was

road
to
hem

in
.
)
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
_
sha'n"t
<EOS>
_

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

think

.
<EOS>
You
're

big

raskill
to

hanged
 
<EOS>
you
're
   
<EOS>
"
  
"
Let
me
pass
,

,

I
'll

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Tulliver
,

horse
and
raising

,

;
and
Wakem
's
horse
,
rearing

backward
,
threw

rider
from

and
sent

.
<EOS>
Wakem
had
had
the

mind
to
