,
and
as
the
horse
only

,
he
might
have
risen

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
The

long

down
,

,
threw

,
which
seemed

.
<EOS>
He

,
who
was
in

,

Wakem
's

,

rested
on

,
and
flogged

.
<EOS>
Wakem

,

,

"
Father
,
father
!
"
  
<EOS>
Suddenly
,

,

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Get

you
 
go
!
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

Luke
 
mother
 
come

!
"
<EOS>
Maggie

,

.
  
<EOS>

;

confound

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

pain
<EOS>
i

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
Had

"

<EOS>

?
<EOS>
No

no

.

<EOS>

.

<EOS>
Sad

!
<EOS>
But

.

"

,
"

;

.
<EOS>
Apparently

.
<EOS>
Tom

<EOS>
Rest

.
  
<EOS>
Tom

,

,

,

Maggie

.
<EOS>

'll

to
pay
for
a
brick
grave
,
Tom
,
so
as
your
mother
and
me
can
lie
together
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
looked
away
from
them
all
when
he
had
said
this
,
and
lay
silent
for
some
minutes
,
while
they
stood
watching
him
,
not

to

.
<EOS>
The
morning
light
was
growing
clearer
for
them
,
and
they
could
see
the
heaviness
gathering
in
his

,
and
the

in

.
<EOS>
But

last

looked

said
,
    
"
I
had
my
turn
 
<EOS>
I
beat
him
.
<EOS>
That
was
nothing
but
fair
.
<EOS>
I
never
wanted
anything
<EOS>
but
what
was
fair
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
But
,
father
,

,
"

,

,
"
you

him
 
<EOS>
you

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He

,
    
"
No
,
my
wench
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't

.
<EOS>
What
's

to

?
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
love
a
raskill
   
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
His
voice
had

;
but

,
and
moved
his
lips
again

again
,

.
<EOS>
At
length

words

.
  
<EOS>
"
Does
God
forgive
raskills
?
 
<EOS>
but
if
He

,
He
wo
n't
be
hard
wi
'
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
His

moved

,
as

wanted

remove
some

weighed

.
<EOS>
Two

some

,
    
"
This

's
 
too
many
 
honest
man
 
puzzling
   
"
  
<EOS>
Soon
they
merged
into
mere

;
the
eyes
had
ceased
to
discern
;
and
then
came
the
final
silence
.
  
<EOS>
But
not
of
death
.
<EOS>
For
an
hour
or
more
the
chest
heaved
,
the
loud
,
hard

continued
,
getting
gradually

,
as
the
cold

gathered
on

.
  
<EOS>
At
last
there
was
total

,
and
poor
Tulliver
's
dimly
lighted
soul
had
forever
ceased
to
be
vexed
with
the
painful

of
this

.
  
<EOS>
Help

now
;

and

there
,

Turnbull
had

,

for

but

,
"
This
is
death
.
"
  
<EOS>
Tom

's

.
<EOS>
Their

,

,
    
"
Tom
,
forgive
me
 
let

always

each

"
;
and

.
    
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
The
Great
Temptation
_
  
<EOS>
A
Duet
in
Paradise
  
<EOS>
The

,

,

,

Deane
's
.
<EOS>
The
neat
little
lady

,
whose

are

the

with

her

are

,
is
of
course
Lucy
Deane
;
and
the
fine
young
man
who
is

to

in

of

"
King
Charles
"
lying

Stephen
Guest
,

,

Ogg
's
.
<EOS>
There

,

your

perceives
at

that
there

;

,

is

,

,

,

,

,
    
<EOS>
"

,

,

.

"
  
<EOS>

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

!
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>

"
<EOS>

,

No

to

until
I
write

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>

.
"
  
<EOS>
Stephen

<EOS>
Little

felt

.
<EOS>
She

,

<EOS>
The

;

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
The

;

"

"
  
believed

"

"

"

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

.

<EOS>
Stephen

;
but

.
<EOS>
Minny
's

;

,

_

.

,

"

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

of

,

,

Clearly
,

.
<EOS>

"
What

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Sinbad
was

,

<EOS>
She

,

of

,
lest

trivial
,
I

here

"
the

.
<EOS>
"
  
Was

Stephen
Guest
right
in
his
decided

that
this

eighteen
was
quite
the
sort
of
wife
a

would
not

of

,
 
a

was

other

,
not

-

,
but

,

of
little

?
<EOS>
Perhaps

did
not

in
her
;
perhaps
he
approved

own

of

chiefly

.
<EOS>
A
man
likes
his
wife
to
be
pretty
;
well
,
Lucy
was
pretty
,
but
not

.
<EOS>
A
man
likes
his
wife
to
be

,
gentle
,

,
and
not

;
and
Lucy
had
all

.
<EOS>
Stephen
was
not

in

her
,
and
was
conscious

judgment
in

to
Miss
Leyburn
,
the
daughter
of
the
county
member
,
although
Lucy
was
only
the
daughter

his
father
's

;

,

had
had
to
defy

a
slight

in
his
father
and
sisters
,
 
a

which
gives
a
young
man
an
agreeable

of
his
own

.
<EOS>
Stephen
was
aware
that
he
had
sense
and

enough
to
choose
the
wife
who
was
likely

make

,

.
<EOS>
He
meant
to
choose
Lucy
;
she
was
a
little
darling
,
and
exactly
the
sort
of
woman
he
had
always

.
    
<EOS>
First
Impressions
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
very
clever
,
Maggie
,
"
said
Lucy
.
<EOS>
She
was

on

at
Maggie
's
feet
,
after
placing
that
dark
lady

.
<EOS>
"
I
feel
sure
you
will
like
him
.
<EOS>
I
hope
you
will
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
very
difficult
to
please
,
"
said
Maggie
,
smiling
,
and
holding
up
one
of
Lucy
's
long

,
that
the
sunlight
might

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
gentleman
who
thinks
he
is
good
enough
for
Lucy
must
expect

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
he
's
a

.
<EOS>
And

,

away
,
I
almost
think
it
ca

.
<EOS>
But

,

could

any
one
<EOS>
but

to

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

not

,
"
said
Maggie
,
with

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
rather
not

.
<EOS>
When

are

,
they
begin
to

being
married
soon
,
"
said
Lucy
,

's

;
"
and
I
should
like

go

is
.
<EOS>
Sometimes

;
and
from
something
that
fell
from
papa
the

,

Mr.
Guest
are

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
At

,

did

;

.
<EOS>
It
_

_

that

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

"

,

.
<EOS>
"
Pray

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh

;
and
not

,
 
that

,

,
"

,

<EOS>
"

_

_
is

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

are

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
do

know
,
"

,

<EOS>
"

;

<EOS>

_

_

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Lucy

judge

.
  
<EOS>
"
Stand

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
your
pleasure
now
?
"

,

,
aerial
cousin
,
whose

quite

.
  
<EOS>
Lucy

a

,

said
,
    
"
I
ca

,

,

;

<EOS>

,

,

I

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Now

_

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

,
"

<EOS>
"
You

<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,
"

,

<EOS>

,
"
But

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
You

"

's

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
"

've

.
<EOS>
I

;

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
"

<EOS>
else

.
<EOS>

;

;

,

<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
That

.

<EOS>
"

,

!
"

,

"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,

,
"

,

<EOS>

,

.

<EOS>

"
Sketch

,
"

.
  
<EOS>

?
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh

,

Guest

.
<EOS>
Pray

.
"
  
<EOS>
Lucy
hurried

,
but
Maggie
did
not

of
opening

;

,
while

,
where

,

dear

Floss
,
that

.
<EOS>
The

-

came
through

,
and

were
busy

and

,

and

.
<EOS>
Yet
Maggie
's
eyes
began
to
fill

.
<EOS>
The
sight
of
the
old
scenes
had
made

so

that
even

she
had
only
been
able

her

Tom
's

as
we

in
good
news
of
friends
at
a
distance
,
rather
than
in
the
presence
of
a

which
we

.
<EOS>
Memory
and

urged
upon
her
a
sense

privation
too
keen
to
let
her
taste
what
was
offered
in
the

.
<EOS>
Her
future
,
she
thought
,
was
likely
to
be
worse
than

,
for

her
years
of

,

;

found
joyless

of

;
she
found
the
image
of

she
yearned
for
,
and
despaired

,

more

.
<EOS>
The

opening
door
roused

,
and

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
one
pleasure
,
I

,
Maggie
,

,
"

Lucy
,

.
<EOS>
"
That

music
,

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
He

<EOS>
"

"

wo

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
,
Lucy
   
"
said

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah

-

.
<EOS>
That

Stephen
,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
One
of
the
things
I
most
admire
in
Stephen
is
that
he
makes
a
greater
friend
of
Philip
than
any
one
.
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
too
late
for
Maggie
to
speak
now
;
the
drawingroom
door
was
opening
,
and
Minny
was
already
growling
in
a
small

at
the
entrance
of
a
tall

,
who
went
up
to
Lucy
and
took
her
hand
with
a
half
-
polite
,
half
-
tender
glance
and
tone
of
inquiry
,
which
seemed
to
indicate
that
he
was
unconscious
of
any
other

.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
me
introduce
you
to
my
cousin
,
Miss
Tulliver
,
"
said
Lucy
,
turning
with
wicked
enjoyment
toward
Maggie
,
who
now
approached
from
the
farther
window
.
<EOS>
"
This
is
Mr.
Stephen
Guest
.
"
  
<EOS>
For

Stephen
could
not
conceal
his
astonishment
at
the

of
this
tall
,
dark
-
eyed
nymph
with
her
jet
-
black
coronet
of

;
the
next
,
Maggie
felt
herself
,
for
the
first

in
her
life
,
receiving
the
tribute
of
a
very
deep

and
a
very

from
a

toward
whom
she
herself
was
conscious
of
timidity
.
  
<EOS>
This
new
experience
was
very
agreeable
to
her
,
so
agreeable
that
it
almost
effaced
her
previous
emotion
about
Philip
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
new
brightness
in
her
eyes
,
and
a
very

on
her

,
as

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
perceive
what
a
striking
likeness
you
drew
the
day
before
yesterday
,
"
said
Lucy
,
with
a
pretty
laugh
of
triumph
.
<EOS>
She
enjoyed
her
lover
's
confusion
;
the
advantage
was
usually
on
his
side
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
designing
cousin
of
yours
quite
deceived
me
,
Miss
Tulliver
,
"
said
Stephen
,
seating
himself
by

,
and
stooping
to

with

,
only
looking
at

furtively
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
said
you
had
light

and

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Nay
,
it
was
you
who
said

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I
only
refrained
from
destroying
your
confidence
in
your
own
second

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
I
could
always
err
in
the
same
way
,
"
said
Stephen
,
"
and
find
reality
so
much
more

my

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Now
you
have
proved
yourself
equal
to

,
"
said
Maggie
,
"
and
said
what
it
was
incumbent
on
you
to
say

the

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
flashed

at
him
;
it
was
clear
to
her
that
he
had
been

beforehand
.
<EOS>
Lucy
had
said

was
inclined
to

,
and

had
mentally

,
"
and
rather

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
An
alarming

of
devil
there
,
"

's
first

.
<EOS>
The

,
when
she
had
bent

,
was
,
"
I
wish
she
would
look
at
me
again
.
"
<EOS>
The
next
was
to
answer
,
    
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
all
phrases
of
mere
compliment
have
their
turn
to
be
true
.
<EOS>
A
man
is
occasionally

when

"
Thank

.
<EOS>
"
It
's
rather
hard
upon

that
he
must
use
the
same

with
which
all
the
world
declines
a
disagreeable

,
do
n't
you
think
so
,
Miss
Tulliver
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Maggie
,
looking
at

with
her

;
"

common

on

,

are
the
more
striking
,
because

are
felt
at

,
like
old

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
my

ought

,
"
said

,

,
"
seeing
that

were
so

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
compliment
can
be

,

an

of

,
"
said
Maggie
,
flushing

.
  
<EOS>
Lucy
was
rather
alarmed
;
she
thought
Stephen
and
Maggie
were
not
going
to
like

.
<EOS>
She
had
always
feared
lest
Maggie
should
appear
too
old
and

to

that
critical
gentleman
.
<EOS>
"
Why
,
dear
Maggie
,
"
she

,
"
you
have

;
and
now
,
I

,
you
are

because
some

ventures
to
admire

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
,
"
said
Maggie
;
"
I
like
too
well
to
feel
that
I
am
admired
,
but

never

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
never
pay
you
a

again
,
Miss
Tulliver
,
"
said
Stephen
.
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
;
that
will
be
a
proof
of
respect
.
"
  
<EOS>
Poor
Maggie
!
<EOS>
She
was
so
unused
to
society
that
she
could
take
nothing
as
a
matter
of
course
,
and
had
never
in
her
life
spoken
from
the
lips
merely
,
so
that
she
must
necessarily
appear
absurd
to
more
experienced
ladies
,
from
the
excessive
feeling
she
was
apt
to
throw
into
very
trivial
incidents
.
<EOS>
But
she
was
even
conscious
herself
of
a
little
absurdity
in
this
instance
.
<EOS>
It
was
true
she
had
a
theoretic
objection
to
compliments
,
and
had
once
said
impatiently
to
Philip
that
she
did
n't
see
why
women
were
to
be
told
with
a
simper
that
they
were
beautiful
,
any
more
than
old
men
were
to
be
told
that
they
were
venerable
;
still
,
to
be
so

by
a
common
practice
in
the
case
of
a
stranger
like
Mr.
Stephen
Guest
,
and
to
care
about
his
having
spoken
slightingly
of
her
before
he
had
seen
her
,
was
certainly
unreasonable
,
and
as
soon
as
she
was
silent
she
began
to
be
ashamed
of
herself
.
<EOS>
It
did
not
occur
to
her
that
her
irritation
was
due
to
the
pleasanter
emotion
which
preceded
it
,
just
as
when
we
are
satisfied
with
a
sense
of
glowing
warmth
<EOS>
an
innocent
drop
of
cold
water
may
fall
upon
us
as

smart
.
  
<EOS>
Stephen
was
too
well
bred
not
to
seem

that
the
previous

could
have
been
felt
embarrassing
,
and
at

talk

,

if

was
at

,
so

rain
the

of
her

on

than
those
worsted

that

.
  
<EOS>
"
Some
day
next
month
,
I

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
But
your
sisters
are
doing

I

;
they
are
to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah

;
but

carry

,
where

n't

.
<EOS>
I
see
you
are
not

of
fancy

,
Miss
Tulliver
,
"
said

,
looking

's

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Maggie
,
"
I
can
do
nothing

shirt

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
your
plain

,

,
"

,
"
that
I

I

as

.
<EOS>
Your

sewing
is

,

so

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
a

,

,
"
said

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Plain

was
the

I
could
get

,

I

.
"
  
<EOS>
Lucy
,
good

,

.
<EOS>
She
did
not

that
Stephen
should
know
that
<EOS>
;
Maggie

.
<EOS>
Perhaps

,
  
the

will
not

.
<EOS>
But

's

;

.
  
<EOS>
"
But

,

,
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
She

Kenn
entirely

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Now

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
I

Kenn
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

anything

of
Dr.
Kenn
?
<EOS>
Heaven

!
<EOS>
But
I
am
not

of
him
.
<EOS>
I
think
Kenn
one
of

.
<EOS>
I
do

,
and

.
<EOS>
But

,
 
a

eight

-

is

with
deal

because

.
<EOS>
That

,
 
taking

Grattan
,
who

.
<EOS>
He

less

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I
never

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

"

,
"

<EOS>
There

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I

's

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
there
I
ca
n't

,
"
said
Stephen
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,

"

,

.
  
<EOS>

That

"

,
"

.
<EOS>
He

;

,

Ogg

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do

?
"

Lucy
,

that

.
  
<EOS>
"
Decidedly
,

Leyburn
's

.
<EOS>
My

's

;

,
you

"
 
here
Stephen
drew

,

"
gifts
like
mine
involve

.
<EOS>
Do

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said

,

;
"
so

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,

,
"
said
Stephen
.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Now

never
discern

,
owing

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
She
does

,
"
he
thought
,
while
his

were

.
<EOS>
"
I
must

other

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Did
Lucy

be
present

Club
next

?
<EOS>
was

.
<EOS>
Then
followed
the
recommendation
to
choose
Southey
's
"
Life
of
Cowper
,
"
unless
she
were
inclined
to
be
philosophical
,
and
startle
the
ladies
of
St.
Ogg

by
voting
for
one
of
the
Bridgewater
Treatises
.
<EOS>
Of
course
Lucy
wished
to
know
what
these
alarmingly
learned
books
were
;
and
as
it
is
always
pleasant
to
improve
the

of
ladies
by
talking

at

know

,
Stephen
became
quite

in
an

of
Buckland
's

,
which

.
<EOS>
He

let

,

in

that

,

and
she
a

.
<EOS>

but
she

sweet
child

proving
to

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

?
"

,

<EOS>
"
There

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

,
"

,

<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>
"
I

Maggie
in

.
<EOS>
I

"
  
<EOS>
"
Apropos

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
_

"

"

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
Gentlemen
,

<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>

<EOS>
Certainly

.
<EOS>
Such

<EOS>
Besides

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
It

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Maggie
,

<EOS>
Confidential
Moments
  
<EOS>
When
Maggie
went
up
to
her
bedroom
that
night
,
it
appeared
that
she
was
not
at
all
inclined
to
undress
.
<EOS>
She
set
down
her
candle
on
the
first
table
that
presented
itself
,
and
began
to
walk
up
and
down
her
room
,
which
was
a
large
one
,
with
a
firm
,
regular
,
and
rather
rapid
step
,
which
showed
that
the
exercise
was
the
instinctive
vent
of
strong
excitement
.
<EOS>
Her
eyes
and
cheeks
had
an
almost
feverish
brilliancy
;
her
head
was
thrown
backward
,
and
her
hands
were
clasped
with
the
palms
outward
,
and
with
that
tension
of
the
arms
which
is
apt
to
accompany
mental
absorption
.
  
<EOS>
Had
anything
remarkable
happened
?
  
<EOS>
Nothing
that
you
are
not
likely
to
consider
in
the
highest
degree
unimportant
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
hearing
some
fine
music
sung
by
a
fine
bass
voice
,
 
but
then
it
was
sung
in
a
provincial
,
amateur
fashion
,
such
as
would
have
left
a
critical
ear
much
to
desire
.
<EOS>
And
she
was
conscious
of
having
been
looked
at
a
great
deal
,
in
rather
a
furtive
manner
,
from
beneath
a
pair
of
well
-
marked
horizontal
eyebrows
,
with
a
glance
that
seemed
somehow
to
have
caught
the
vibratory
influence
of
the
voice
.
<EOS>
Such
things
could
have
had
no
perceptible
effect
on
a
thoroughly
well
-
educated
young
lady
,
with
a
perfectly
balanced
mind
,
who
had
had
all
the
advantages
of
fortune
,
training
,
and
refined
society
.
<EOS>
But
if
Maggie
had
been
that
young
lady
,
you
would
probably
have
known
nothing
about
her
:
her
life
would
have
had
so
few
vicissitudes
that
it
could
hardly
have
been
written
;
for
the
happiest
women
,
like
the
happiest
nations
,
have
no
history
.
  
<EOS>
In
poor
Maggie
's
highly
-
strung
,
hungry
nature
,
 
just
come
away
from
a
third
-
rate
schoolroom
,
with
all
its
jarring
sounds
and
petty
round
of
tasks
,
 
these
apparently
trivial
causes
had
the
effect
of
rousing
and
exalting
her
imagination
in
a
way
that
was
mysterious
to
herself
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
that
she
thought
distinctly
of
Mr.
Stephen
Guest
,
or
dwelt
on
the
indications
that
he
looked
at
her
with
admiration
;
it
was
rather
that
she
felt
the
half
-
remote
presence
of
a
world
of
love
and
beauty
and
delight
,
made
up
of
vague
,
mingled
images
from
all
the
poetry
and
romance
she
had
ever
read
,
or
had
ever
woven
in
her
dreamy
reveries
.
<EOS>
Her
mind
glanced
back
once
or
twice
to
the
time
when
she
had
courted
privation
,
when
she
had
thought
all
longing
,
all
impatience
was
subdued
;
but
that
condition
seemed
irrecoverably
gone
,
and
she
recoiled
from
the
remembrance
of
it
.
<EOS>
No
prayer
,
no
striving
now
,
would
bring
back
that
negative
peace
;
the
battle
of
her
life
,
it
seemed
,
was
not
to
be
decided
in
that
short
and
easy
way
,
 
by
perfect
renunciation
at
the
very
threshold
of
her
youth
.
  
<EOS>
The
music
was
vibrating
in
her
still
,
 
Purcell
's

,
with

,
 
and
<EOS>

<EOS>

Brother

,

<EOS>
Maggie
always

;

<EOS>

.

<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>

.

ca

.
<EOS>

father

<EOS>

that

was
revealing
something
quite
new
to
her
;
and
she
was
absorbed
in
the
direct
,
immediate
experience
,
without
any
energy
left
for
taking
account
of
it
and
reasoning
about
it
.
<EOS>
Stephen
wilfully
abstained
from
self
-
questioning
,
and
would
not
admit
to
himself
that
he
felt
an
influence
which
was
to
have
any
determining
effect
on
his
conduct
.
<EOS>
And
when
Lucy
came
into
the
room
again
,
they
were
once
more
unconstrained
;
Maggie
could
contradict
Stephen
,
and
laugh
at
him
,
and
he
could
recommend
to
her
consideration
the
example
of
that
most
charming
heroine
,
Miss
Sophia
Western
,
who
had
a
great
"
respect
for
the
understandings
of
men
.
<EOS>
"
Maggie
could
look
at
Stephen
,
which
,
for
some
reason
or
other
she
always
avoided
when
they
were
alone
;
and
he
could
even
ask
her
to
play
his
accompaniment
for
him
,
since
Lucy
's
fingers
were
so
busy
with
that
bazaar
-
work
,
and
lecture
her
on
hurrying
the
tempo
,
which
was
certainly
Maggie
's
weak
point
.
  
<EOS>
One
day
 
it
was
the
day
of
Philip
's
return
 
Lucy
had
formed
a
sudden
engagement
to
spend
the
evening
with
Mrs.
Kenn
,
whose
delicate
state
of
health
,
threatening
to
become
confirmed
illness
through
an
attack

,
obliged

to

at
the
coming

into
the
hands
of
other
ladies
,
of
whom
she
wished
Lucy
to
be
one
.
<EOS>
The
engagement
had
been
formed
in
Stephen
's
presence
,
and
he
had
heard
Lucy
promise
to
dine
early
and
call
at
six

for
Miss
Torry
,
who
brought
Mrs.
Kenn
's
request
.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
is
another
of
the
moral
results
of
this
idiotic

,
"
Stephen
burst
forth
,
as
soon
as
Miss
Torry
had
left
the
room
,
 
"
taking
young
ladies
from
the
duties
of
the
domestic
hearth
into
scenes
of
dissipation
among
urn
-
rugs
and
embroidered

!
<EOS>
I
should
like
to
know
what
is
the
proper
function
of
women
,
if
it
is
not
to
make
reasons
for
husbands
to
stay
at
home
,
and
still
stronger

for
bachelors
to
go
out
.
<EOS>
If
this
goes
on
much
longer
,
the

of

will
be
dissolved
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
it
will
not
go
on
much
longer
,
"
said
Lucy
,
laughing
,
"
for
the
bazaar
is
to
take
place
on
Monday

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Thank
Heaven
!
"
said
Stephen
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Kenn
himself
said
the
other
day
that
he
did
n't
like
this
plan
of
making
vanity
do
the
work

;
but
just

,
so

has

without

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
he
say
so
?
"

little
Lucy
,
her
<EOS>
hazel

.
<EOS>
"
I
never

;
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm

_

_
,
"

Stephen
,

"

,

,
but
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
think

,
"
said
Lucy
,
shaking

,
with

,
and
there

.
<EOS>
But
it
was
tacitly
understood
that
Stephen
would
not
come
in
the
evening
;
and
on
the
strength

that

he
made
his
morning
visit
the
longer
,
not

good

bye
until
after

.
  
<EOS>
Maggie
was
seated
in
the
drawing
-
room
,
alone
,
shortly
after

,
with
Minny
on
her
lap
,
having
left
her
uncle
to
his
wine
and
his

,
and
her
mother
to
the
compromise
between
knitting
and
nodding
,
which
,
when
there
was
no
company
,
she
always
carried
on
in
the
dining

room
till

.
<EOS>
Maggie
was
stooping
to
caress
the
tiny

pet
,
and
comforting
him
for
his
mistress
's
absence
,
when
the
sound
of

on

made

,
and
she
saw
Mr.
Stephen
Guest
walking
up
the

,
as
if
he
had
come

from
the
river
.
<EOS>
It
was
very
unusual
to
see
him
so
soon
after
dinner
!
<EOS>
He
often
complained
that
their
dinner
-
hour
was
late
at
Park
House
.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
there
he
was
,
in
his
black
dress
;
he
had
evidently
been
home
,
and
must
have
come
again
by
the
river
.
<EOS>
Maggie
felt
her
cheeks
glowing
and
her
heart
beating
;
it
was
natural
she
should
be
nervous
,
for
she
was
not

alone
.
<EOS>
He
had
seen
her
look
up
through
the
open
window
,
and
raised
his
hat
as
he
walked
toward
it
,
to
enter
that
way
instead
of
by
the
door
.
<EOS>
He
blushed
too
,
and
certainly
looked
as
foolish

young
man
of
some
wit
and
self

can

,
as

in
with

,
and

,
with

,
    
<EOS>
"
You
are
surprised
to
see

again
,
Miss
Tulliver
;
I
ought

for
coming
upon
you
by

,

I
wanted
to
come
into
the
town
,
and
I

man

;
so

from

"
Maid

"
for

;
I
forgot

.
<EOS>
Will
you
give
them
to
her
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Maggie
,
who
had
risen

with
Minny
in
her
arms
,
and
now
,
not

what
else

do
,
sat
down

.
  
<EOS>
Stephen
laid
down
his
hat
,
with
the
music
,
which
rolled
on
the
floor
,
and
sat
down
in
the

close

.
<EOS>
He
had
never
done
so
before
,
and
both

and
Maggie
were
quite
aware
that
it
was
an
entirely
new
position
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
you
pampered
minion
!
"
said
Stephen
,
leaning
to
pull
the
long
curly
ears
that
drooped
over
Maggie
's
arm
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
a
suggestive
remark
,
and
as
the
speaker
did
not
follow
it
up
by
further
development
,
it
naturally
left
the
conversation
at
a

.
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
Stephen
like
some
action
in
a
dream
that
he
was
obliged
to
do
,
and
wonder
at
himself
all

while
,
 
to
go
on
stroking
Minny
's
head
.
<EOS>
Yet
it
was
very
pleasant
;
he
only
wished
he
dared
look
at
Maggie
,
and
that
she
would
look
at
him
,
 
<EOS>
let
him
have
one
long

into
those

,
strange

of
hers
,
and
then
he
would
be
satisfied
and
quite
reasonable

.
<EOS>
He
thought

was
becoming
a
sort

,
to

long

from
Maggie
;
and

continually
to
find

some

by

could
have
it
without

.
<EOS>
As

,

had

,

like

,

unable

,
and

's

.
  
<EOS>
But
this
must
end
some
time
<EOS>
,

,

_

_

,

's

.
<EOS>
Stephen
at

,

.
<EOS>

?
  
<EOS>
"

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
<EOS>
Then

"
if

.

<EOS>
A

;

is

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do

?
"
  
<EOS>
A

"

"
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
It
<EOS>
_

"

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

Deane

<EOS>

,

"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
Maggie

,
 
it

<EOS>
But

<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
Stephen

;
he

did

Wakem

,
for

.
<EOS>
It
was
of
no

to

.
<EOS>
Maggie
was

at

with

,
and

chill

;
and
he
 
<EOS>
he
looked
like

simpleton
for
having
come
.
<EOS>
A

,
entirely
superfluous
visit
of
that
sort
was
sure
to
make
a
man
disagreeable

.
<EOS>
Of

was
palpable

Maggie
's
thinking
that

had

in
his
own

for

setting
off
again
and

.
  
<EOS>
A
boyish
state
of
mind

an

young

five
-
and
-
twenty
,
not
without
legal
knowledge
!
<EOS>
But
a
reference
to
history
,
perhaps
,
may
make
it
not
incredible
.
  
<EOS>
At
this
moment
Maggie
's
ball
of
knitting
-

rolled
along
the
ground
,
and
she
started
up
to
reach
it
.
<EOS>
Stephen
rose
too
,
and
picking
up
the
ball
,
met
her
with

,
complaining
look
that
gave
his

quite
a
new

to
Maggie
,
whose
own

.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
,
"
said
Stephen
,
in
a
tone
that
had
the

.
<EOS>
He
dared
not
put
out
his
hand
;
he
thrust
both
hands
into
his
tail
-

as
he

.
<EOS>
Maggie
thought
she
had
perhaps
been
rude
.
  
<EOS>
"
Wo
n't
you
stay
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she

,
not

,
for

would
have
seemed
rude
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

,
"
said
Stephen
,
looking

half
-

,

,
as

.
<EOS>
"
The
boat
is

.
<EOS>
You

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
  
"
And
that

is

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
<EOS>
(
Maggie
did

's

this

.
)
  
<EOS>
"
Wo

?
"

,
in

;
but

"

,
"
<EOS>
for

now
toward
the
open

,
and
he
was
obliged
to
take

and

.
<EOS>
But
he
thought
of
something
to
make

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
take
my
arm
,
"
he
said
,
in

,

.
  
<EOS>
There
is
something
strangely
winning
to
most
women
in
that
offer
of
the
firm

;
the
help
is
not
wanted
physically
at
that
moment
,
but
the

of

,
the

strength
that
is
outside

and

theirs
,
meets

.
<EOS>
Either

that

,

.
<EOS>
And
they
walked
together

and

,

;

Stephen

the

,

Philip

<EOS>
But
I
begin
to
think
there
can
never
come
much
happiness
to
me
from

;
I
have

.
<EOS>
I
wish

could
make
myself
a

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Now
you
are

to

old

Maggie
,
 
the
thought
I
used
to
combat
,
"
said
Philip
,
with
a

.
<EOS>
"
You

.
<EOS>
I

again
,
there

no

except

one
's

.
<EOS>
What
would
become
of
me
,
if
I
tried
to

from
pain
?
<EOS>
Scorn
and
cynicism
would
be

;
unless

could

into
some
kind

,
and
fancy

a
favorite
of
Heaven
because
I

not

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

had
taken
on
some

as
Philip
went
on

;
the

evidently

.
<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>
He
shrank

to
the

of

,
of

that
had

.
<EOS>
It

of

;
it
would

had
for

.
<EOS>
He
could
not

;
for

.
<EOS>
His

was
stamped
,
even

rest

his

,
with
the

that

,
 
that

that

saw

.
  
<EOS>
But

was
conscience

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Philip
,
"
she
said
,
with
her
childish

when

,
"
you

,
I

.
<EOS>
I

"
,

.
<EOS>
I

;
so

.
"
  
<EOS>
Maggie
was

,

<EOS>
Had

something

_
she

,
 
something
about
a
lover

Lucy
's
?
<EOS>
It

;
it

to
her

,
and
to

of
what
had

.
<EOS>
She

,

position
by
that
positive

sometimes

.
  
<EOS>
"
What

,
Maggie
?
<EOS>
Has

?
"
<EOS>
Philip

that

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
nothing
,
"

,

.
<EOS>
Philip

not
have
that

;
she

.
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,

"

<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

!
<EOS>
"

,

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Philip

,

<EOS>
Stephen

.
<EOS>

"

"
  
<EOS>
"

;

"

<EOS>
Philip

,

"

"

"

<EOS>

"

"
music
,

!
<EOS>
We

's

.
"
  
<EOS>
Maggie
always
tried

.
<EOS>
She

Stephen

.

,

.
<EOS>
Poor
Maggie
!
<EOS>
She
looked

.
<EOS>

"

"

"

<EOS>
"

"

"
Ah
!

<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>

"

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

open

.
<EOS>
That

in
the
Red
Deeps
.
<EOS>
There
seemed
to
be
some
reproach
in
the
words
;
did
Philip
mean
that
?
<EOS>
She
wished
she
had
assured
him
more
distinctly
in
their
conversation
that
she
desired
not
to
renew
the
hope
of
love
between
them
,
_
only
_
because
it
clashed
with
her
inevitable
circumstances
.
<EOS>
She
was
touched
,
not
thrilled
by
the
song
;
it
suggested
distinct
memories
and
thoughts
,
and
brought
quiet
regret
in
the
place
of
excitement
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
way
with
you
tenors
,
"
said
Stephen
,
who
was
waiting
with
music
in
his
hand
while
Philip
finished
the
song
.
<EOS>
"
You
demoralize
the
fair
sex
by
warbling
your
sentimental
love
and
constancy
under
all
sorts
of
vile
treatment
.
<EOS>
Nothing
short
of
having
your
heads
served
up
in
a
dish
like
that
mediæval
tenor
or
troubadour
,
would
prevent
you
from
expressing
your
entire
resignation
.
<EOS>
I
must
administer
an
antidote
,
while
Miss
Deane
prepares
to
tear
herself
away
from
her
bobbins
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Stephen
rolled
out
,
with
saucy
energy
,
      
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
,
wasting
in
despair
,
  
Die
because
a
woman
's
fair
?
"
  
and
seemed
to
make
all
the
air
in
the
room
alive
with
a
new
influence
.
<EOS>
Lucy
,
always
proud
of
what
Stephen
did
,
went
toward
the
piano
with
laughing
,
admiring
looks
at
him
;
and
Maggie
,
in
spite
of
her
resistance
to
the
spirit
of
the
song
and
to
the
singer
,
was
taken
hold
of
and
shaken
by
the
invisible
influence
,
 
was
borne
along
by
a
wave
too
strong
for
her
.
  
<EOS>
But
,
angrily
resolved
not
to
betray
herself
,
she
seized
her
work
,
and
went
on
making
false
stitches
and
pricking
her
fingers
with
much
perseverance
,
not
looking
up
or
taking
notice
of
what
was
going
forward
,
until
all
the
three
voices
united
in
"
Let
us
take
the
road
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
there
would
have
been
a
subtle
,
stealing
gratification
in
her
mind
if
she
had
known
how
entirely
this
saucy
,
defiant
Stephen
was
occupied
with
her
;
how
he
was
passing
rapidly
from
a
determination
to
treat
her
with
ostentatious
indifference
to
an
irritating
desire
for
some
sign
of

from
her
,
 
some
interchange
of
subdued
word
or
look
with
her
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
long
before
he
found
an
opportunity
,
when
they
had
passed
to
the
music
of
"
The
Tempest
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Maggie
,
feeling
the
need
of
a
footstool
,
was
walking
across
the
room
to
get
one
,
when
Stephen
,
who
was
not
singing
just
then
,
and
was
conscious
of
all

,
guessed
her
want
,
and
flew
to

,

with

at

,
which
made

not
to
return
a

.
<EOS>
And
then
,
to
have
the

carefully
by
a
too
self
-
confident

,
 
not
_
any
_
self
-

,
but
one

,
who
suddenly

humble

,

,

,
to

in

,

,
 
these

will

a
little
of
the
too
ready
,

into

woman
's

,
compelled
as

is
in
her
girlish
time
to
learn
her
life
-
lessons
in
very
trivial

.
<EOS>
And
to
Maggie
such
things
had
not
been
every
-
day
incidents
,
but
were
a
new
element
in

life
,
and
found
her
keen

for
homage
quite
fresh
.
<EOS>
That
tone
of
gentle

obliged
her
to
look
at
the

that
was
bent

,
and
to

,
"
No
,
thank
you
"
;
and
nothing

,
as

.
  
<EOS>
It
was
but

ordinary
act

politeness
in
Stephen
;
it
had
hardly

two
minutes
;
and
Lucy
,
who
was

,

.
<EOS>
But
to
Philip
's
mind
,
filled
already
with
a
vague

that
was
likely

in

,
this

in
Stephen
,

's

,
which
was

,

with

previous

,
as
to

.
<EOS>
Stephen
's

,

in
again
,
jarred
upon

nervous

as
if

had

the

of
sheet
-

,
and
he
felt

to

.
<EOS>
He
had
really
seen
no
communicable
ground
for
suspecting
any
ususual

between
Stephen
and
Maggie
;
his
own
reason
told
him
so
,
and
he
wanted
to
go
home
at
once
that
he
might
reflect
coolly
on
these
false

,
till
he
had

of
their

.
<EOS>
But
then
,
again
,
he
wanted
to
stay
as
long
as
Stephen
stayed
,
 
always
to
be
present
when
Stephen
was

Maggie
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
poor
Philip
so
natural
,
nay
,

,
that
any

should
fall

!
<EOS>
There

for

if

Stephen
Guest
;
and

Philip
to

own

in
the

of

less

.
<EOS>
He
was
beginning
to
play

under
this
deafening

,
and

was

,

's

.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,

Philip
!
"

,

,
"

've

.
<EOS>

's

,

"

"

<EOS>
"

As

"
  
<EOS>

,
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Ah
!
"

,
"
he
must
find
farming
a
heavy
item
,
 
an
expensive
hobby
.
<EOS>
I
never
had
a
hobby
myself
,
never

give
in

.
<EOS>
And
the

.
<EOS>
They
shoot

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Lucy

's

of
Mr.
Wakem
's

.
<EOS>
But
it
ceased

,

.
<EOS>
Lucy
,
accustomed

watch
all

,

,

had

,
for

,

.
<EOS>
His

.
  
<EOS>

aunt

,

,

,

,

?
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
Eh

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No

.

"

,

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
(

,

.

<EOS>
Lucy

<EOS>
"
Are

wo

,

?
"
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

,

sure
.
<EOS>
I
'm
very

;
I
've

.
<EOS>
Did

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,

wo

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
Now
,

"
    
<EOS>
Wakem
in
a
New
Light
  
<EOS>
Before
three

had
passed
after
the
conversation
you
have
just
overheard
between
Lucy
and
her
father
she
had
contrived
to
have
a
private

with
Philip
during
a
visit
of
Maggie
's
to
her
aunt
Glegg
.
<EOS>
For

and
a

Philip
turned
over
in

with

all
that

told

in

,
till

had
thoroughly
resolved

a

of

.
<EOS>
He
thought

saw
before

now
a
possibility
of
altering
his
position
with
respect
to
Maggie
,
and
removing

least

.
<EOS>
He
laid

and

with

of
a

-

in
the
days
of
his
first

,
and

.
<EOS>
His

was
as
bold
as

calculated
.
<EOS>
Having
watched
for
a
moment
when
his
father
had
nothing
more

than
the
newspaper
,
he
went
behind

,
laid
a

on

,
and
said
,
    
"
Father
,
will

,
and
look

my
new

?
<EOS>
I
've

now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm

,

"

<EOS>
"

"
  
<EOS>
"

,

?
 
<EOS>
a

light

from

"

<EOS>
He

<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>

's
 
<EOS>
what

that

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Philip

<EOS>
He

,

in

.
<EOS>
He

father

,

,
 
one

<EOS>
"
Bless

!
<EOS>
what

?
"

,

<EOS>
"

'd

<EOS>

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

"

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
what
person
?
"

<EOS>
"
Miss
Tulliver
.
<EOS>

something

;

.
"
  
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Philip

.
  
<EOS>
"
And

?
"

,

<EOS>
"
Yes
;
I
saw

's

.
<EOS>
We
met
often
in
that
thicket
 
<EOS>
the
Red

near

.
<EOS>
I

;
I

woman
.
<EOS>
I
have
thought

her

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Go
on
,

!
<EOS>
And

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
<EOS>
I
never

till

,
and
she

brother

.
<EOS>
I

she

.
<EOS>
But

,
 
if

,
 
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

?
"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
No
,

,
"

"

do

.
<EOS>
You

to

;
but
I

that

was
because
you

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think

sons

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
The
girl

,

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
We

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
I
ca

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I
ca

.

"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Philip

<EOS>
"
You

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ridiculous

!
"

<EOS>
"
What

?
<EOS>

!
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
_

"

"

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

"

;

<EOS>
All

Ogg
's
,
I

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Wakem
darted

question
at
his
son
;
but
Philip
was
not
looking

,
and

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not

!
"
said

,
rising
again
,
and
forgetting
everything
else
in

,
half

,

.
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
a
deuced

.
<EOS>

's
all
stuff
about
an

,

's

to
a

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
girls
are
not
apt
to

under
those

,
"
said
Philip
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
then
,
"
said
Wakem
,
rather

,
trying
to
recover
his
previous

,
"

you
,

,

to
what
was
never

to

.
"
  
<EOS>
Wakem
strode
to
the
door
,
and
without
looking
round
again
,
banged
it
after
him
.
  
<EOS>
Philip
was
not
without
confidence
that
his
father
would
be
ultimately
wrought
upon
as
he
had
expected
,
by
what
had
passed
;
but
the
scene
had
jarred
upon
his
nerves
,
which
were
as
sensitive
as
a
woman
's
.
<EOS>
He
determined
not
to
go
down
to
dinner
;
he
could
n't
meet
his
father
again
that
day
.
<EOS>
It
was
Wakem
's
habit
,
when
he
had
no
company
at
home
,
to
go
out
in
the
evening
,
often
as
early
as
half
-
past
seven
;
and
as
it
was
far
on
in
the
afternoon
now
,
Philip
locked
up
his
room
and
went
out
for
a
long
ramble
,
thinking
he
would
not
return
until
his
father
was
out
of
the
house
again
.
<EOS>
He
got
into
a
boat
,
and
went
down
the
river
to
a
favorite
village
,
where

<EOS>

<EOS>
Charity

<EOS>

<EOS>
We

of

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

;

,

;

himself

.
"
  
<EOS>
Lucy

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"

She

<EOS>
Maggie

.
<EOS>
She

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It

,

,

.
<EOS>

have
Stephen
Guest
at
her
feet
,
offering
her
a
life
filled
with
all
luxuries
,
with
daily
incense
of
adoration
near
and
distant
,
and
with
all
possibilities
of
culture
at
her
command
.
<EOS>
But
there
were
things
in
her
stronger
than
vanity
,
 
passion
and
affection
,
and
long
,
deep
memories
of
early
discipline
and
effort
,
of
early
claims
on
her
love
and
pity
;
and
the
stream
of
vanity
was
soon
swept
along
and
mingled
imperceptibly
with
that
wider
current
which
was
at
its
highest
force
today
,
under
the
double
urgency
of
the
events
and
inward
impulses
brought
by
the
last
week
.
  
<EOS>
Philip
had
not
spoken
to
her
himself
about
the
removal
of
obstacles
between
them
on
his
father
's
side
,
 
he
shrank
from
that
;
but
he
had
told
everything
to
Lucy
,
with
the
hope
that
Maggie
,
being
informed
through
her
,
might
give
him
some
encouraging
sign
that
their
being
brought
thus
much
nearer
to
each
other
<EOS>
was
a
happiness
to
her
.
<EOS>
The
rush
of
conflicting
feelings
was
too
great
for
Maggie
to
say
much
when
Lucy
,
with
a
face
breathing
playful
joy
,
like
one
of
Correggio
's
cherubs
,
poured
forth
her
triumphant
revelation
;
and
Lucy
could
hardly
be
surprised
that
she
could
do
little
more
than
cry
with
gladness
at
the
thought
of
her
father
's
wish
being
fulfilled
,
and
of
Tom
's
getting
the
Mill
again
in
reward
for
all
his
hard
striving
.
<EOS>
The
details
of
preparation
for
the
bazaar
had
then
come
to
usurp
Lucy
's
attention
for
the
next
few
days
,
and
nothing
had
been
said
by
the
cousins
on
subjects
that
were
likely
to
rouse
deeper
feelings
.
<EOS>
Philip
had
been
to
the
house
more
than
once
,
but
Maggie
had
had
no
private
conversation
with
him
,
and
thus
she
had
been
left
to
fight
her
inward
battle
without
interference
.
  
<EOS>
But
when
the
bazaar
was
fairly
ended
,
and
the
cousins
were
alone
again
,
resting
together
at
home
,
Lucy
said
,
    
"
You
must
give
up
going
to
stay
with
your
aunt
Moss
the
day
after
to
-
morrow
,
Maggie
;
write
a
note

,
and
tell
her
you
have
put
it

at
my
request
,
and
I
'll
send
the
man
with

.
<EOS>
She
wo
n't
be
displeased
;
you
'll
have
plenty

time
to
go
by
-
and
-
by
;
and
I
do
n't
want

to
go

of
the
way
just
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
indeed
I
must
go
,
dear
;
I
ca
n't
put
it
off
.
<EOS>
I
would
n't
leave
aunt
Gritty
out
for
the
world
.
<EOS>
And
I
shall
have
very
little

,
for
I
'm
going
away
to
a
new
situation
on
the
25th
of
June
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Maggie
!
<EOS>
"
said
Lucy
,
almost
white
with

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
did

tell
you
,
dear
,
"
said
Maggie
,

,
"
because
you
've

so

.
<EOS>
But
some

wrote

,
Miss

,

I

,

other

I

of
hers

,
and
then
make
trial
of
a
situation
with
her
as

.
<EOS>
I
wrote
yesterday
to
accept
the
offer
.
"
  
<EOS>
Lucy
felt
so
hurt
that
for
some

she
was
unable

.
  
<EOS>
"
Maggie
,
"
she

last
,
"

me

tell

to
take
_
such
_
a
step
 
and
now
!
"
<EOS>
She

a
little
,
and
then
added
,
"
<EOS>
And
Philip
?
<EOS>
I
thought
everything
was

.
<EOS>
Oh
,
Maggie
,

?
<EOS>
Give

;
let
me

.
<EOS>
There

now

you

Philip
apart
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"

Maggie
,

.
<EOS>
"
There
is
Tom
's
feeling
.
<EOS>
He
said
I
must
give

I
married
Philip
.
<EOS>
And
I
know
he
will
not
change
 
at
least
not
for
a
long
while
 
unless
something
happened

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
will

;

's

this

.
<EOS>
And
this
good
news
about
the
Mill
will

.
<EOS>
And
I
'll
talk
to

Philip
.
<EOS>
Tom
's
always
very
compliant
to
me
;
I
do
n't
think
he
's
so

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
must
go
,
"
said
Maggie
,
in
a
distressed

.
<EOS>
"
I
must
leave
some
time
to
pack
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
press
me
to
stay
,
dear
Lucy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Lucy
was
silent
for
two
or
three
minutes
,
looking
away
and
ruminating
.
<EOS>
At
length
she
knelt
down
by
her
cousin
,
and
looking
up
in
her
face
with
anxious

,
said
,
    
"
Maggie
,
is
it
that
you
do
n't
love
Philip
well
enough
to
marry
him
?
<EOS>
Tell
me
 
trust
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Maggie
held
Lucy
's
hands
tightly
in
silence
a
little
while
.
<EOS>
Her
own
hands
were
quite
cold
.
<EOS>
But
when
she
spoke
,
her
voice
was
quite
clear
and
distinct
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Lucy
,
I
would
choose
to
marry
him
.
<EOS>
I
think
it
would
be
the
best
and
highest
lot
for
me
,
 
to
make
his

.
<EOS>
He
loved
me
first
.
<EOS>
No

else
could
be
quite
what
he
is
to

.
<EOS>
But
I
ca
n't
divide

from

for

.
<EOS>
I
must
go
away
,
and

.
<EOS>
Pray
do
n't

about

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Lucy
obeyed
in
pain
and
wonder
.
<EOS>
The
next

she
said
was
,
    
"
Well
,
dear
Maggie
,
at
least
you
will
go

the
dance
at
Park
House
to
-

,
and
have
some

,
before

go
to
pay
these
dull
dutiful
visits
.
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
here
come
aunty
and
the
tea
.
"
    
<EOS>
The
Spell
Seems
Broken
  
The
suite
of
rooms
opening
into
each
other
at
Park
House
looked
duly
brilliant
with
lights
and
flowers
and
the
personal
splendors
of
sixteen
couples
,
with
attendant
parents
and
guardians
.
<EOS>
The
focus
of
brilliancy
was
the
long
drawing
-
room
,
where
the
dancing
went
forward
,
under
the
inspiration
of
the
grand
piano
;
the
library
,
into
which
it
opened
at
one
end
,
had
the
more
sober
illumination
of
maturity
,
with
caps
and
cards
;
and
at
the
other
end
the
pretty
sitting
-
room
,
with
a
conservatory
attached
,
was
left
as
an
occasional
cool
retreat
.
<EOS>
Lucy
,
who
had
laid
aside
her
black
for
the
first
time
,
and
had
her
pretty
slimness
set
off
by
an
abundant
dress
of
white
crape
,
was
the
acknowledged
queen
of
the
occasion
;
for
this
was
one
of
the
Miss
Guests
'
thoroughly
condescending
parties
,
including
no
member
of
any
aristocracy
higher
than
that
of
St.
Ogg
's
,
and
stretching
to
the
extreme
limits
of
commercial
and
professional
gentility
.
  
<EOS>
Maggie
at
first
refused
to
dance
,
saying
that
she
had
forgotten
all
the
figures
 
<EOS>
it
was
so
many
years
since
she
had
danced
at
school
;
and
she
was
glad
to
have
that
excuse
,
for
it
is
<EOS>
ill
dancing
with
a
heavy
heart
.
<EOS>
But
at
length
the
music
wrought
in
her
young
limbs
,
and
the
longing
came
;
even
though
it
was
the
horrible
young
Torry
,
who
walked
up
a
second
time
to
try
and
persuade
her
.
<EOS>
She
warned
him
that
she
could
not
dance
anything
but
a
country
-
dance
;
but
he
,
of
course
,
was
willing
to
wait
for
that
high
felicity
,
meaning
only
to
be
complimentary
when
he
assured
her
at
several
intervals
that
it
was
a
"
great
bore
"
<EOS>
that
she
could
n't
waltz
,
he
would
have
liked
so
much
to
waltz
with
her
.
<EOS>
But
at
last
it
was
the
turn
of
the
good
old
-
fashioned
dance
which
has
the
least
of
vanity
and
the
most
of
merriment
in
it
,
and
Maggie
quite
forgot
her
troublous
life
in
a
childlike
enjoyment
of
that
half
-
rustic
rhythm
which
seems
to
banish
pretentious
etiquette
.
<EOS>
She
felt
quite
charitably
toward
young
Torry
,
as
his
hand
bore
her
along
and
held
her
up
in
the
dance
;
her
eyes
and
cheeks
had
that
fire
of
young
joy
in
them
which
will
flame
out
if
it
can
find
the
least
breath
to
fan
it
;
and
her
simple
black
dress
,
with
its
bit
of
black
lace
,
seemed
like
the
dim
setting
of
a
jewel
.
  
<EOS>
Stephen
had
not
yet
asked
her
to
dance
;
had
not
yet
paid
her
more
than
a
passing
civility
.
<EOS>
Since
yesterday
,
that
inward
vision
of
her
which
perpetually
made
part
of
his
consciousness
,
had
been
half
screened
by
the
image
of
Philip
Wakem
,
which
came
across
it
like
a
blot
;
there
was
some
attachment
between
her
and
Philip
;
at
least
there
was
an
attachment
on
his
side
,
which
made
her
feel
in
some
bondage
.
<EOS>
Here
,
then
,
Stephen
told
himself
,
was
another
claim
of
honor
which
called
on
him
to
resist
the
attraction
that
was
continually
threatening
to
overpower
him
.
<EOS>
He
told
himself
so
;
and
yet
he
had
once
or
twice
felt
a
certain
savage
resistance
,
and
at
another
moment
a
shuddering
repugnance
,
to
this
intrusion
of
Philip
's
image
,
which
almost
made
it
a
new
incitement
to
rush
toward
Maggie
and
claim
her
for
himself
.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
he
had
done
what
he
meant
to
do
this
evening
,
 
he
had
kept
aloof
from
her
;
he
had
hardly
looked
at
her
;
and
he
had
been
gayly
assiduous
to
Lucy
.
<EOS>
But
now
his
eyes
were
devouring
Maggie
;
he
felt
inclined
to
kick
young
Torry
out
of
the
dance
,
and
take
his
place
.
<EOS>
Then
he
wanted
the
dance
to
end
that
he
might
get
rid
of
his
partner
.
<EOS>
The
possibility
that
he
too
should
dance
with
Maggie
,
and
have
her
hand
in
his
so
long
,
was
beginning
to
possess
him
like
a
thirst
.
<EOS>
But
even
now
their
hands
were
meeting
in
the
dance
,
 
were
meeting
still
to
the
very
end
of
it
,
though
they
were
far
off
each
other
.
  
<EOS>
Stephen
hardly
knew
what
happened
,
or
in
what
automatic
way
he
got
through
the
duties
of
politeness
in
the
interval
,
until
he
was
free
and
saw
Maggie
seated
alone
again
,
at
the
farther
end
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
He
made
his
way
toward
her
round
the
couples
that
were
forming
for
the
waltz
;
and
when
Maggie
became
conscious
that
she
was
the
person
he
sought
,
she
felt
,
in
spite
of
all
the
thoughts
that
had
gone
before
,
a
glowing
gladness
at
heart
.
<EOS>
Her
eyes
and
cheeks
were
still
brightened
with
her
childlike
enthusiasm
in
the
dance
;
her
whole
frame
was
set
to
joy
and
tenderness
;
even
the
coming
pain
could
not
seem
bitter
,
 
she
was
ready
to
welcome
it
as
a
part
of
life
,
for
life
at
this
moment
seemed
a
keen
,
vibrating
consciousness
poised
above
pleasure
or
pain
.
<EOS>
This
one
,
this
last
night
,
she
might
expand
unrestrainedly
in
the
warmth
of
the
present
,
without
those
chill
,
eating
thoughts
of
the
past
and
the
future
.
  
<EOS>
"
They
're
going
to
waltz
again
,
"
said
Stephen
,
bending
to
speak
to
her
,
with
that
glance
and
tone
of
subdued
tenderness
which
young
dreams
create
to
themselves
in
the
summer
woods
when
low
,
cooing
voices
fill
the
air
.
<EOS>
Such
glances
and
tones
bring
the
breath
of
poetry
with
them
into
a
room
that
is
half
stifling
with
glaring
gas
and
hard
flirtation
.
  
<EOS>
"
They
are
going
to
waltz
again
.
<EOS>
It
is
rather
dizzy
work
to
look
on
,
and
the
room
is
very
warm
;
shall
we
walk
about
a
little
?
"
  
<EOS>
He
took
her
hand
and
placed
it
within
his
arm
,
and
they
walked
on
into
the
sitting
-
room
,
where
the
tables
were
strewn
with
engravings
for
the
accommodation
of
visitors
who
would
not
want
to
look
at
them
.
<EOS>
But
no
visitors
were
here
at
this
moment
.
<EOS>
They
passed
on
into
the
conservatory
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
strange
and
unreal
the
trees
and
flowers
look
with
the
lights
among
them
!
"
<EOS>
said
Maggie
,
in
a
low
voice
.
<EOS>
"
They
look
as
if
they
belonged
to
an
enchanted
land
,
and
would
never
fade
away
;
I
could
fancy
they
were
all
made
of
jewels
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
was
looking
at
the
tier
of
geraniums
as
she
spoke
,
and
Stephen
made
no
answer
;
but
he
was
looking
at
her
;
and
does
not
a
supreme
poet
blend
light
and
sound
into
one
,
calling
darkness
mute
,
and
light
eloquent
?
<EOS>
Something
strangely
powerful
<EOS>
there
was
in
the
light
of
Stephen
's
long
gaze
,
for
it
made
Maggie
's
face
turn
toward
it
and
look
upward
at
it
,
slowly
,
like
a
flower
at
the
ascending
brightness
.
<EOS>
And
they
walked
unsteadily
on
,
without
feeling
that
they
were
walking
;
without
feeling
anything
but
that
long
,
grave
,
mutual
gaze
which
has
the
solemnity
belonging
to
all
deep
human
passion
.
<EOS>
The
hovering
thought
that
they
must
and
would
renounce
each
other
made
this
moment
of
mute
confession
more
intense
in
its
rapture
.
  
<EOS>
But
they
had
reached
the
end
of
the
conservatory
,
and
were
obliged
to
pause
and
turn
.
<EOS>
The
change
of
movement
brought
a
new
consciousness
to
Maggie
;
she
blushed
deeply
,
turned
away
her
head
,
and
drew
her
arm
from
Stephen
's
,
going
up
to
some
flowers
to
smell
them
.
<EOS>
Stephen
stood
motionless
,
and
still
pale
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
may
I
get
this
rose
?
"
said
Maggie
,
making
a
great
effort
to
say
something
,
and
dissipate
the
burning
sense
of
irretrievable
confession
.
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
am
quite
wicked
with
roses
;
I
like
to
gather
them
and
smell
them
till
they
have
no
scent
left
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Stephen
was
mute
;
he
was
incapable
of
putting
a
sentence
together
,
and
Maggie
bent
her
arm
a
little
upward
toward
the
large
half
-
opened
rose
that
had
attracted
her
.
<EOS>
Who
has
not
felt
the
beauty
of
a
woman
's
arm
?
<EOS>
The
unspeakable
suggestions
of
tenderness
that
lie
in
the
dimpled
elbow
,
and
all
the
varied
gently
lessening
curves
,
down
to
the
delicate
wrist
,
with
its
tiniest
,
almost
imperceptible
nicks
in
the
firm
softness
.
<EOS>
A
woman
's
arm
touched
the
soul
of
a
great
sculptor
two
thousand
years
ago
,
so
that
he
wrought
an
image
of
it
for
the
Parthenon
which
moves
us
still
as
it
clasps
lovingly
the
timeworn
marble
of
a
headless
trunk
.
<EOS>
Maggie
's
was
such
an
arm
as
that
,
and
it
had
the
warm
tints
of
life
.
  
<EOS>
A
mad
impulse
seized
on
Stephen
;
he
darted
toward
the
arm
,
and
showered
kisses
on
it
,
clasping
the
wrist
.
  
<EOS>
But
the
next
moment
Maggie
snatched
it
from
him
,
and
glared
at
him
like
a
wounded
war
-
goddess
,
quivering
with
rage
and
humiliation
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
dare
you
?
"
<EOS>
She
spoke
in
a
deeply
shaken
,
half
-
smothered
voice
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
right
have
I
given
you
to
insult
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
She
darted
from
him
into
the
adjoining
room
,
and
threw
herself
on
the
sofa
,
panting
and
trembling
.
  
<EOS>
A
horrible
punishment
was
come
upon
her
for
the
sin
of
allowing
a
moment
's
happiness
that
was
treachery
to
Lucy
,
to
Philip
,
to
her
own
better
soul
.
<EOS>
That
momentary
happiness
had
been
smitten
with
a
blight
,
a
leprosy
;
Stephen
thought
more
lightly
of
_
her
_
than
he
did
of
Lucy
.
  
<EOS>
As
for
Stephen
,
he
leaned
back
against
the
framework
of
the
conservatory
,
dizzy
with
the
conflict
of
passions
,
 
love
,
rage
,
and
confused
despair
;
<EOS>
despair
at
his
want
of
self
-
mastery
,
and
despair
that
he
had
offended
Maggie
.
  
<EOS>
The
last
feeling
surmounted
every
other
;
to
be
by
her
side
again
and
entreat
forgiveness
was
the
only
thing
that
had
the
force
of
a
motive
for
him
,
and
she
had
not
been
seated
more
than
a
few
minutes
when
he
came
and
stood
humbly
before
her
.
<EOS>
But
Maggie
's
bitter
rage
was
unspent
.
  
<EOS>
"
Leave
me
to
myself
,
if
you
please
,
"
she
said
,
with
impetuous
haughtiness
,
"
and
for
the
future
avoid
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Stephen
turned
away
,
and
walked
backward
and
forward
at
the
other
end
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
There
was
the
dire
necessity
of
going
back
into
the
dancing
-
room
again
,
and
he
was
beginning
to
be
conscious
of
that
.
<EOS>
They
had
been
absent
so
short
a
time
,
that
when
he
went
in
again
the
waltz
was
not
ended
.
  
<EOS>
Maggie
,
too
,
was
not
long
before
she
re
-
entered
.
<EOS>
All
the
pride
of
her
nature
was
stung
into
activity
;
the
hateful
weakness
which
had
dragged
her
within
reach
of
this
wound
to
her
self
-
respect
had
at
least
wrought
its
own
cure
.
<EOS>
The
thoughts
and
temptations
of
the
last
month
should
all
be
flung
away
into
an
unvisited
chamber
of
memory
.
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
to
allure
her
now
;
duty
would
be
easy
,
and
all
the
old
calm
purposes
would
reign
peacefully
once
more
.
<EOS>
She
re
-
entered
the
drawing
-
room
still
with
some
excited
brightness
in
her
face
,
but
with
a
sense
of
proud
self
-
command
that
defied
anything
to
agitate
her
.
<EOS>
She
refused
to
dance
again
,
but
she
talked
quite
readily
and
calmly
with
every
one
who
addressed
her
.
<EOS>
And
when
they
got
home
that
night
,
she
kissed
Lucy
with
a
free
heart
,
almost
exulting
in
this
scorching
moment
,
which
had
delivered
her
from
the
possibility
of
another
word
or
look
that
would
have
the
stamp
of
treachery
toward
that
gentle
,
unsuspicious
sister
.
  
<EOS>
The
next
morning
Maggie
did
not
set
off
to
Basset
quite
so
soon
as
she
had
expected
.
<EOS>
Her
mother
was
to
accompany
her
in
the
carriage
,
and
household
business
could
not
be
dispatched
hastily
by
Mrs.
Tulliver
.
<EOS>
So
Maggie
,
who
had
been
in
a
hurry
to
prepare
herself
,
had
to
sit
waiting
,
equipped
for
the
drive
,
in
the
garden
.
<EOS>
Lucy
was
busy
in
the
house
wrapping
up
some
bazaar
presents
for
the
younger
ones
at
Basset
,
and
when

was
a
loud
ring
at
the
door
-
bell
,
Maggie
felt
some
alarm
lest
Lucy
should
bring
out
Stephen
to
her
;
it
was
sure
to
be
Stephen
.
  
<EOS>
But
presently
the
visitor
came
out
into
the
garden
alone
,
and
seated
himself
by
her
on
the
garden
-
chair
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
Stephen
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
can
just
catch
the
tips
of
the
Scotch
firs
,
Maggie
,
from
this
seat
,
"
said
Philip
.
  
<EOS>
They
had
taken
each
other
's
hands
in
silence
,
but
Maggie
had
looked
at
him
with
a
more
complete
revival
of
the
old
childlike
<EOS>
affectionate
smile
than
he
had
seen
before
,
and
<EOS>
he
felt
encouraged
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
she
said
,
"
I
often
look
at
them
,
and
wish
I
could
see
the
low
sunlight
on
the
stems
again
.
<EOS>
But
I
have
never
been
that
way
<EOS>
but
once
,
 
to
the
churchyard
with
my
mother
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
there
,
I
go
there
,
continually
,
"
said
Philip
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
nothing
but
the
past
to
live

.
"
  
<EOS>
A
keen

and

to
put
her

in
Philip
's
.
<EOS>
They
had
so
often
walked
hand
in
hand
!
  
<EOS>
"
I
remember
all

spots
,
"
she
said
,
 
"
just
where

told

particular

,
beautiful

never
heard

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
go
there
again
soon
,
wo

,

?
"
said
Philip
,
getting

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
Mill
will
soon

your

's

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
but

shall

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
only
hear

.
<EOS>
I
am
going
away
again
;
Lucy
has
not
told

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
the
future
will
never
join
on
to
the
past
again
,
Maggie
?
<EOS>
That
book
is
quite
closed
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
gray

that
had
so

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
That

never
will

,
Philip
,
"
she

,

;
"
I
desire

that
will
break

of
the
past
.
<EOS>
But

my
brother

one

.
<EOS>
I
can
do
nothing
willingly
that
will
divide

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is

,
Maggie
?
"

Philip
,

to

.
  
<EOS>
"
The
only
reason
,
"
said
Maggie
,
with
calm

.
<EOS>
And
she
believed

.
<EOS>
At
that

she
felt
as
if
the
enchanted
cup
had
been
dashed
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
The

that
gave

self
-

had
not

,
and
she
looked
at
the
future

a

calm
choice
.
  
<EOS>
They
sat
hand
in
hand
without
looking

other
or

minutes
;
in

's

first

were
more

the

,
and
she
was
looking
at
Philip
in

Red
Deeps
.
  
<EOS>
Philip
felt
that
he
ought
to
have

in
that

of
hers
;
she
was

-

.
<EOS>
Why
was
he
not

happy
?
<EOS>
Jealousy
is
never
satisfied
with
anything
short
of
an
omniscience
that
would
detect
the
subtlest
fold
of
the
heart
.
    
<EOS>
In
the
Lane
  
Maggie
had
been
four
days
at
<EOS>
her
aunt
Moss
's
giving
the
early
June
sunshine
quite
a
new
brightness
in
the
care
-
dimmed

of
that
affectionate
woman
,
and
making

for

cousins
great

,
who

learning
her
words
and

by
heart
,
as
if

had
been
a

perfect

and

.
  
<EOS>
She
was
standing
on
the

her

and
a

the

,
at
that

in
the
life
of

before

-

.
<EOS>
The
great

round
the
hollow

were
as
dreary
and

as
ever
,
but
over
the
old
garden
-
wall
<EOS>
the

rose
-

were
beginning
to
toss
their

,
and

gray
wood
and
old

of
the
house
,

its
higher

,
had

the

,
that
suited
the
quiescent

.
<EOS>
Maggie
,
with
her
bonnet
over
her
arm
,
was
smiling
down
at
the
hatch
of
small
fluffy
chickens
,
when
her
aunt

,
    
"
Goodness
me
!
<EOS>
who

that
gentleman
coming
in

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
a

on
a

bay
horse
;
and
the

and

of
the
horse
were
streaked
black
with

.
<EOS>
Maggie
felt
a
beating
at
head

heart
,
horrible
as
the
sudden

to
life
of
a

who

.
  
<EOS>
"
Who

,

?
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
It

Mr.
Stephen
Guest
,
"

,
rather

.
<EOS>
"
My
cousin
Lucy
's
 
a
gentleman
who
is
very

at

.
"
  
<EOS>
Stephen
was
already
close
to

,
had
jumped
off
his
horse
,
and
now

.
  
<EOS>
"
Hold

horse
,
Willy
,
"

Moss
to
the
twelve

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
thank
you
,
"
said
Stephen
,

's

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
<EOS>
May
I

?
"
  
<EOS>
He

,
such
as

man
gets
when

some

that

.
<EOS>
He

,

thought
by
Mrs.

of

.
<EOS>
Good
Mrs.
Moss
,

,

in
,

,

the

of

,

,
put

,

.
  
<EOS>
Stephen
turned
too
,
and
walked
by
her
side
,
leading

horse
.
  
<EOS>
Not
a
word
was
spoken
till
they
were
out
in
the

,
and

,

,

,

,
    
"
There

.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know

to

in

position
that
forced

to

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
are

,
"
said
Stephen
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Of

is

what
a
man
has
to

;
it
is
only
your
woman
's

that
you
care
about
.
"
  
<EOS>
Maggie
gave
a
slight
start
,
such
as
might
have
come
from

.
  
<EOS>
"

"

!
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
A
Family
Party
  
<EOS>
Maggie

<EOS>
She

,

"
<EOS>
The
thirst

rise
  
Doth

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

"

"

"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
dearest

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
that

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.

"

<EOS>
"

,

,

<EOS>

.

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>
"

.
"
  
<EOS>
He

deep

,

,

.
<EOS>
Maggie

,
perhaps

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

;

"

<EOS>
"

"
  
<EOS>
"

?
"

.
<EOS>
He

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
"

.
"
  
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
Maggie

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Memory
was

.
  
<EOS>
They

,
Stephen
rowing
,

,
past

;
on

,
which

.
<EOS>
The

of

young
,

day
,
the

of

,

a

bird
heard
now
<EOS>
and

,
as

,

,

?
<EOS>

;
otherwise

;

?
<EOS>
and

,

.
<EOS>
Maggie

only

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
At

was
so

to
fits
of
absence
,
that
she
was
likely
enough
to
let
her
waymarks
pass
unnoticed
.
  
<EOS>
But
at
last
Stephen
,
who
had
been
rowing
more
and
more
idly
,
ceased
to
row
,
laid
down
the
oars
,
folded
his
arms
,
and
looked
down
on
the
water
as
if
watching
the
pace
at
which
the
boat
glided
without
his
help
.
<EOS>
This
sudden
change
roused
Maggie
.
<EOS>
She
looked
at
the
far
-
stretching
fields
,
at
the
banks
close
by
,
and
felt
that
they
were
entirely
strange
to
her
.
<EOS>
A
terrible
alarm
took
possession
of
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
have
we
passed
Luckreth
,
where
we
were
to
stop
?
<EOS>
"
she
exclaimed
,
looking
back
to
see
if
the
place
were
out
of
sight
.
<EOS>
No
village
was
to
be
seen
.
<EOS>
She
turned
around
again
,
with
a
look
of
distressed
questioning
at
Stephen
.
  
<EOS>
He
went
on
watching
the
water
,
and
said
,
in
a
strange
,
dreamy
,
absent
tone
,
"
Yes
,
a
long
way
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
what
shall
I
do
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Maggie
,
in
an
agony
.
<EOS>
"
We
shall
not
get
home
for
hours
,
and
Lucy
?
<EOS>
O
God
,
help
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
She
clasped
her
hands
and
broke
into
a
sob
,
like
a
frightened
child
;
she
thought
of
nothing
but
of
meeting
Lucy
,
and
seeing
her
look
of
pained
surprise
and
doubt
,
perhaps
of
just
upbraiding
.
  
<EOS>
Stephen
moved
and
sat
near
her
,
and
gently
drew
down
the
clasped
hands
.
  
<EOS>
"
Maggie
,
"
he
said
,
in
a
deep
tone
of
slow
decision
,
"
let
us
never
go
home
again
,
till
no
one
can
part
us
,
 
till
we
are
married
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
unusual
tone
,
the
startling
words
,
arrested
Maggie
's
sob
,
and
she
sat
quite
still
,
wondering
;
as
if
Stephen
might
have
seen
some
possibilities
that
would
alter
everything
,
and
annul
the
wretched
facts
.
  
<EOS>
"
See
,
Maggie
,
how
everything
has
come
without
our
seeking
,
 
in
spite
of
all
our
efforts
.
<EOS>
We
never
thought
of
being
alone
together
again
;
it
has
all
been
done
by
others
.
<EOS>
See
how
the
tide
is
carrying
us
out
,
away
from
all
those
unnatural
bonds
that
we
have
been
trying
to
make
faster
round
us
,
and
trying
in
vain
.
<EOS>
It
will
carry
us
on
to
Torby
,
and
we
can
land
there
,
and
get
some
carriage
,
and
hurry
on
to
York
and
then
to
Scotland
,
 
and
never
pause
a
moment
till
we
are
bound
to
each
other
,
so
that
only
death
can
part
us
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
only
right
thing
,
dearest
;
it
is
the
only
way
of
escaping
from
this
wretched
entanglement
.
<EOS>
Everything
has
concurred
to
point
it
out
to
us
.
<EOS>
We
have
contrived
nothing
,
we
have
thought
of
nothing
ourselves
.
"
  
<EOS>
Stephen
spoke
with
deep
,
earnest
pleading
.
<EOS>
Maggie
listened
,
passing
from
her
startled

to
the

after
that
belief
that
the
tide
was

all
,
that
she
might

swift

,

.
<EOS>
But

of
past

;
and
the
sudden
horror
lest
now
,

,
the
moment
of
fatal

was

,
called

.
  
<EOS>
"
Let

!
"
<EOS>
she

,
in

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
You
have
wanted
to

.
<EOS>
You

;

.
<EOS>
It

.
"
  
<EOS>
Stung

,

released

,

,
and

,
in

Maggie
's

.
<EOS>
If

to

,

must

.
<EOS>
But

was

;
the
one
thing

was
,
that

.
<EOS>
At

said
,
in

,
    
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't

that
we
had
passed
Luckreth
till

next

;
and

came

that

.
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
justify
it
;
I
ought

told

.
<EOS>
It

to

,

,

I
do
you
.
<EOS>
Shall

boat
and
try

?
<EOS>
I

Lucy
that
I
was

,

;
and
you
shall
be

.
<EOS>
No

can

you
,
because
I
have

.
"
  
<EOS>
Maggie
was

;
it
was

's

than
this
picture
he
had
called

himself

while

;
easier

,

.
<EOS>
He

had
acted

.
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
She
had
reproached

for
being
hurried

irrevocable

,
 
she
,
who
had
been
so
weak
herself
.
  
<EOS>
"
As

should

feel
what
happened

you
 
just

,
"
she

,
with

of

,
 
the

of
love
,
asking
for
more

.
<EOS>
This

to
the
idea
of
Stephen
's

was
more
fatal
than
the
other

,
because

less

that

of
others
'

which

.
  
<EOS>
He
felt
all
the
relenting
in
her
look
and

;
it
was

again
.
<EOS>
He
moved
to
her
side
,
and
took
her

,
leaning

on

,

.
<EOS>
He
dreaded
to

another

,
he
dreaded
to

another

,
that
might

.
<EOS>
Life
hung
on
her

;
everything
else
was
hopeless
,

,

.
<EOS>
They
glided
along
in
this

,

that

as

,
both

lest

divided

,
 
till

aware
that
the

had
gathered
,
and
that

perceptible

of

was

,
so
that
the
whole

of
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
be
chill
,
Maggie
,
in
this
thin

.
<EOS>
Let
me
raise
the
cloak
over

.
<EOS>
Get
up
an
instant
,
dearest
.
"
  
<EOS>
Maggie
obeyed
;
there
was
an
unspeakable
charm
in
being
told
what
to
do
,
and
having
everything
decided
for
her
.
<EOS>
She
sat
down
again
covered
with

,
and
Stephen
took

his
oars
again
,
making

;
for
they
must

to

.
<EOS>
Maggie
was
hardly
conscious
of
having
said

anything
decisive
.
<EOS>
All
yielding
is
attended
with
a
less
vivid
consciousness
than
resistance
;
it
is
the
partial
sleep
of
thought
;
it
is
the
submergence
of
our
own

by
another
.
<EOS>
Every

tended
to
lull
her
into

.
<EOS>
That
dreamy
gliding
in
the
boat
which
had
lasted
for
four
hours
,
and
had
brought
some

;
the

of
her
fatigued

from
the

of

boat
at
this
unknown

from

,
and

,
 
all

from
Stephen

seem

,

iron

.
<EOS>
And

the
present

with

,

was
enough
to

her

.
  
<EOS>
Presently
Stephen
observed
a
vessel
coming
after

.
<EOS>
Several
vessels
,
among
them
the
steamer
to
Mudport
,
had
passed

with
the
early
tide
,
but
for
the
last

had
seen

.
<EOS>
He

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Maggie
,

,
"

"

,

,

.
<EOS>
You

,

;

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
We

.
<EOS>
It
is
really

best

.
<EOS>
They

.
<EOS>
I
've

.
<EOS>
I
can

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Maggie

;
but
she
was

,
 
one

.
  
<EOS>
Stephen
hailed

.
<EOS>
It
was
a
Dutch
vessel
going
to
Mudport
,
the
English
mate
informed

,
and
,

wind

,
would
be
there

.
  
<EOS>
"
We
had

,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
I
was

.
<EOS>
But

'm

;

this

<EOS>
my

.
<EOS>

?
 
and

.
<EOS>
I
'll

.
"
  
<EOS>
Maggie
,
now

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

;

.
<EOS>
But

Stephen

strength
 
was

;

came
food
,
and

,

_

_

.
<EOS>
Everything

.
<EOS>
Stephen

;

to

the
five

,

belongs
,

,

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
Every

was
thrown
into
unmarked

by
the

that
Maggie
must
be
his
.
<EOS>
The

had
been
taken
now
;
he
had
been
tortured
by

,
he
had
fought

with

,
he
had
hesitated
;
but

was

.
<EOS>
He

forth

,
his

,
his

,
his
belief
that
their

must

,
that

would
give

;
that

;
that

easy

,

;
and
now

never
_
<EOS>
would
_

;
he
would
belong

,
and

all
that

his
was
hers
<EOS>
,

no

hers
.
<EOS>
Such

,
uttered

low

by
the
one
voice
that
has

the

,
have

a

effect
 
on

.
<EOS>
To

;

were

;

,
there
<EOS>
_

,

here
below
which

,

.
<EOS>
Stephen
's

made
the

such

;
and
the
vision
for
the
time
excluded
all
realities
,
 
all
except
the
returning
sun
-
gleams
which
broke
out
on
the
waters
as
the
evening
approached
,
and
mingled
with
the
visionary
sunlight
of
promised
happiness
;
all
except
the
hand
that
pressed
hers
,
and
the
voice
that
spoke
to
her
,
and
the
eyes
that
looked
at
her
with
grave
,
unspeakable
love
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
to
be
no
rain
,
after
all
;
the
clouds
rolled
off
to
the
horizon
again
,
making
the
great
purple
rampart
and
long
purple
isles
of
that
wondrous
land
which
reveals
itself
to
us
when
the
sun
goes
down
,
 
the
land
that
the
evening
star
watches
over
.
<EOS>
Maggie
was
to
sleep
all
night
on
the
poop
;
it
was
better
than
going
below
;
and
she
was
covered
with
the
warmest
wrappings
the
ship
could
furnish
.
<EOS>
It
was
still
early
,
when
the
fatigues
of
the
day
brought
on
a
drowsy
longing
for
perfect
rest
,
and
she
laid
down
her
head
,
looking
at
the
faint
,
dying
flush
in
the
west
,
where
the
one
golden
lamp
was
getting
brighter
and
brighter
.
<EOS>
Then
she
looked
up
at
Stephen
,
who
was
still
seated
by
her
,
hanging
over
her
as
he
leaned
his
arm
against
the
vessel
's
side
.
<EOS>
Behind
all
the
delicious
visions
of
these
last
hours
,
which
had
flowed
over
her
like
a
soft
stream
,
and
made
her
entirely
passive
,
there
was
the
dim
consciousness
that
the
condition
was
a
transient
one
,
and
that
the
morrow
must
bring
back
the
old
life
of
struggle
;
that
there
were
thoughts
which
would
presently
avenge
themselves
for
this
oblivion
.
<EOS>
But
now
nothing
was
distinct
to
her
;
she
was
being
lulled
to
sleep
with
that
soft
stream
still
flowing
over
her
,
with
those
delicious
visions
melting
and
fading
like
the
wondrous
aerial
land
of
the
west
.
    
<EOS>
Waking
  
<EOS>
When
Maggie
was
gone
to
sleep
,
Stephen
,
weary
too
with
his
unaccustomed
amount
of
rowing
,
and
with
the
intense
inward
life
of
the
last
twelve
hours
,
but
too
restless
to
sleep
,
walked
and
lounged
about
the
deck
with
his
cigar
far
on
into
midnight
,
not
seeing
the
dark
water
,
hardly
conscious
there
were
stars
,
living
only
in
the
near
and
distant
future
.
<EOS>
At
last
fatigue
conquered
restlessness
,
and
he
rolled
himself
up
in
a
piece
of
tarpaulin
on
the
deck
near
Maggie
's
feet
.
  
<EOS>
She
had
fallen
asleep
before
nine
,
and
had
been
sleeping
for
six
hours
before
the
faintest
hint
of
a
midsummer
daybreak
was
discernible
.
<EOS>
She
awoke
from
that
vivid
dreaming
which
makes
the
margin
of
our
deeper
rest
.
<EOS>
She
was
in
a
boat
on
the
wide
water
with
Stephen
,
and
in
the
gathering
darkness
something
like
a
star
appeared
,
that
grew
and
grew
till
they
saw
it
was
the
Virgin
seated
in
St.
Ogg
's
boat
,
and
it
came
nearer
and
nearer
,
till
they
saw
the
Virgin
was
Lucy
and
the
boatman
<EOS>
was
Philip
,
 
no
,
not
Philip
,
but
her
brother
,
who
rowed
past
without
looking
at
her
;
and
she
rose
to
stretch
out

and
call
to
him
,
and
their
own
boat
turned
over
with

,
and
they
began
to
sink
,
till
with
one

dread
she
seemed
to
awake
,
and
find
she
was
a
child
again
in
the
parlor
at
evening
twilight
,
and
Tom
was
not
really

.
<EOS>
From
the
soothed
sense
of
that
false

she
passed
to
the
real

,
 
to
the
plash
of
water
against
the
vessel
,
and
the
sound
of
a
footstep
on
the
deck
,
and
the
awful
starlit
sky
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
moment
of
utter
bewilderment
before
her
mind
could
get
disentangled
from
the
confused
web
of
dreams
;
but
soon
the
whole
terrible
truth
urged

upon

.
<EOS>
Stephen
was
not
by
her
now
;
she
was
alone
with
her
own
memory
and
her
own
dread
.
<EOS>
The
irrevocable
wrong
that
must
blot
her
life
had
been
committed
;
she
had
brought
sorrow
into
the
lives
of
others
,
 
into
the
lives
that
were
knit
up
with
hers
by
trust
and

.
<EOS>
The
feeling
of
a
few
short
weeks
had
hurried
her
into
the
sins
her
nature
had
most
recoiled
from
,
 
breach
of
faith
and
cruel

;
she
had
rent
the
ties
that
had
given
meaning
to

,
and
had
made
herself
an

,
with
no

but
the
wayward

of
her
own
passion
.
<EOS>
And
where
would
that
lead
her
?
<EOS>
Where
had
it
led
her
now
?
<EOS>
She
had
said
she
would
rather
die
than
fall
into
that
temptation
.
<EOS>
She
felt
it
now
,
 
now
that
the
consequences
of
such
a
fall
had
come
before
the
outward
act
was
completed
.
<EOS>
There
was
at
least
this
fruit
from
all
her
years
of
striving
after
the
highest
and
best
,
 
that
her

though
betrayed
,
beguiled
,
ensnared
,
could
never
deliberately
consent
to
a
choice
of
the
lower
.
<EOS>
And
a
choice
of
what
?
<EOS>
O
God
!
<EOS>
not
a
choice
of
joy
,
but
of
conscious

and

;
for
could
she
ever
cease
to
see
before
her
Lucy
and
Philip
,
with
their
murdered

and

?
<EOS>
Her
life
with
Stephen
could
have
no

;
she
must
forever

and
wander

,
driven
by
uncertain

;
for
she
had
let
go
the
clue
of
life
,
 
that
clue
which
once
in
the
far
-
off
years
her
young
need
had
clutched
so
strongly
.
<EOS>
She
had
renounced
all
delights
then
,
before
she
knew

,
before
they
had
come
within

.
<EOS>
Philip
had
been
right
when
he
told

that
she
knew
nothing
of

;
she
had
thought

;
she
saw

face

,
 
that
sad
,
patient
,

strength
which
holds
the
clue
of
life
,
 
and
saw
that
the
thorns
were
forever
pressing
on

.
<EOS>
The
yesterday
,
which
could
never
be
revoked
,
 
if
she
could
have
changed

now
for
any
length
of
inward

,
she
would
have
bowed
beneath
that

with
a
sense
of
rest
.
  
<EOS>
Day
break
came
and
the

light
,
while
her
past

was
grasping
her
in
this
way
,
with
that

which
comes
in
the

of

.
<EOS>
She
could
see
Stephen
now
lying
on
the
deck
still

,
and
with

of

there
came
a

of

that
found

way
in

.
<EOS>
The
worst
bitterness
of
parting
 
<EOS>
the
thought
that
urged
the
sharpest
inward
cry
for
help
 
was
the
pain
it
must
give
to
_
him
_
.
<EOS>
But

everything
was
the

at
her
own
possible
failure
,
the
dread
lest
her
conscience
should
be
benumbed
again
,
and
not
rise
to
energy
till
it
was
too
late
.
<EOS>
Too
late
!
<EOS>
it
was
too
late
already
not
to
have
caused
misery
;
too
late
for
everything
,
perhaps
,
but
to
rush
away
from
the
last
act
of
baseness
,
 
the
tasting
of
joys
that
were
wrung
from

.
  
<EOS>
The
sun
was
rising
now
,
and
Maggie
started
up
with
the
sense
that
a
day
of
resistance
was
beginning
for
her
.
<EOS>
Her
eyelashes
were
still
wet
with
tears
,
as
,
with
her
shawl
over
her
head
,
she
sat

at

slowly

.
<EOS>
Something
roused
Stephen
too
,
and
getting
up
from
his
hard
bed
,
he
came
to
sit
beside
her
.
<EOS>
The
sharp
instinct
of
anxious
love
saw
something
to
give
him
alarm
in
the

.
<EOS>
He
had
a
hovering
dread
of
some
resistance
in

's

he
would

.
<EOS>
He
had
the

that
he
had
robbed

perfect

;
there

too

,
for

that
,

her

should

,
his

would
have
been
odious
,
and
she
would
have
a

to

.
  
<EOS>
But
Maggie
did
not
feel
that
right
;
she
was
too
conscious
of
fatal
weakness
in

,
too
full
of
the
tenderness
that
comes
with
the

for

.
<EOS>
She
let
him
take
her
hand
when
he
came
to
sit
down

her
,
and
smiled

him
,
only

;
she
could

nothing
to
pain

till

of
possible

was
nearer
.
<EOS>
And
so
they
drank
their
cup
of
coffee
together
,
and
walked
about
the
deck
,
and

's

in

,
each
with

;
but

,
which
he
trusted
to
the
coming

;
in
her

was
a

resolve
on
which
she
was

.
<EOS>
Stephen
was
continually
,
through

,
expressing

at

,

she

,

to

.
<EOS>
For

had

good
night
's

,

that
she
did

mind
about
being
on
the
vessel
,

,

.
<EOS>
But

will

in

,

Stephen

,
under

had

.
<EOS>
He

,

,
to

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
But

,

a

of
the
new
,

with
which
she
met

.
<EOS>
And
they
were

.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
we
are
in

Mudport
,
"
he

.
"
<EOS>
Now
,
dearest
,
"

,
"
the

your

.
<EOS>
On
the
land
we
can
command

.
<EOS>
In

,

that
will
seem

.
"
  
<EOS>
Maggie
felt

to

;

.
<EOS>
She

.
  
<EOS>
"
We
shall
not

;
we

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

's

.
  
<EOS>
"
We
shall
not
,
"
he

.
<EOS>
"
I
'll

.
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
as
he
had
dreaded
 
<EOS>
there
was
a
struggle
coming
.
<EOS>
But
neither

them
dared
to
say

till

boat
was
let
down
,
and

to

-

.
<EOS>
Here

was
a

of

the

of
the
steamboat
to
St.
Ogg
's
.
<EOS>
Maggie
had
a
dim
sense
,

,

Stephen
was

,
that

.
<EOS>
But

was

along
,
and
was
indifferent

everything

coming

.
  
<EOS>
A

and

-

,
and
Stephen
gave
the
order
for

.
<EOS>
Maggie
took
no
notice
of
this
,
and
only
said
,
"
Ask
them
to
show
us
into
a
room
where
we
can

down
.
"
  
<EOS>
When
they

,
Maggie
did
not

,
and
Stephen
,
whose

had

,

,

,
    
<EOS>
"
I
'm

;
we
must

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Maggie
,
"
he
said
,

,
and
speaking

feels

,
"

kill

?
<EOS>
What

now
?
<EOS>
The
whole

is
done
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

is
not
done
,
"

Maggie
.
<EOS>
"
Too
much
is
done
,
 
more
than
we
can

trace
of
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
go
no
farther
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
try
to
prevail
with
me
again
.
<EOS>
I
could
n't
choose
yesterday
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
What
was
he
to
do
?
<EOS>
He
dared
not
go
near
her
;
her
anger
might
leap
out
,
and
make

barrier
.
<EOS>
He

backward
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Maggie
,
"
he
said
at

,

,
and
speaking

,
"
have
some
pity
 
<EOS>
hear
me
 
forgive

for
what

.
<EOS>
I
will

;
I

.
