trusted
me
more
than
any
one
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
marry
you
;
I
can
not
take
a
good
for
myself
that
has
been
wrung
out
of
their
misery
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
the
force
that
ought
to
rule
us
,
 
this
that
we
feel
for
each
other
;
it
would
rend
me
away
from
all
that
my
past
life
has
made
dear
and
holy
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
set
out
on
a
fresh
life
,
and
forget
that
;
I
must
go
back
to
it
,
and
cling
to
it
,
else
I
shall
feel
as
if
there
were
nothing
firm
beneath
my
feet
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
God
,
Maggie
!
<EOS>
"
said
Stephen
,
rising
too
and
grasping
her
arm
,
"
you
rave
.
<EOS>
How
can
you
go
back
without
marrying
me
?
<EOS>
You
do
n't
know
what
will
be
said
,
dearest
.
<EOS>
You
see
nothing
as
it
really
is
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
do
.
<EOS>
But
they
will
believe
me
.
<EOS>
I
will
confess
everything
.
<EOS>
Lucy
will
believe
me
 
she
will
forgive
you
,
and
 
and
 
oh
,
_
<EOS>
some
_
good
will
come
by
clinging
to
the
right
.
<EOS>
Dear
,
dear
Stephen
,
let
me
go
!
 
<EOS>
do
n't
drag
me
into
deeper
remorse
.
<EOS>
My
whole
soul
has
never
consented
;
it
does
not
consent
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Stephen
let
go
her
arm
,
and
sank
back
on
his
chair
,
half
-
stunned
by
despairing
rage
.
<EOS>
He
was
silent
a
few
moments
,
not
looking
at
her
;
while
her
eyes
were
turned
toward
him
yearningly
,
in
alarm
at
this
sudden
change
.
<EOS>
At
last
he
said
,
still
without
looking
at
her
,
    
"
Go
,
then
,
 
leave
me
;
do
n't
torture
me
any
longer
,
 
I
ca
n't
bear
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
Involuntarily
she
leaned
toward
him
and
put
out
her
hand
to
touch
his
.
<EOS>
But
he
shrank
from
it
as
if
it
had
been
burning
iron
,
and
said
again
,
    
"
Leave
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Maggie
was
not
conscious
of
a
decision
as
she
turned
away
from
that
gloomy
averted
face
,
and
walked
out
of
the
room
;
it
was
like
an
automatic
action
that
fulfils
a
forgotten
intention
.
<EOS>
What
came
after
?
<EOS>
A
sense
of
stairs
descended
as
if
in
a
dream
,
of
flagstones
,
of
a
chaise
and
horses
standing
,
then
a
street
,
and
a
turning
into
another
street
where
a
stage
-
coach
was
standing
,
taking
in
passengers
,
and
the
darting
thought
that
that
coach
would
take
her
away
,
perhaps
toward
home
.
<EOS>
But
she
could
ask
nothing
yet
;
she
only
got
into
the
coach
.
  
<EOS>
Home
 
<EOS>
where
her
mother
and
brother
were
,
Philip
,
Lucy
,
<EOS>
the
scene
of
her
very
cares
and
trials
 
was
the
haven
toward
which
her
mind
tended
;
the
sanctuary
where
sacred
relics
lay
,
where
she
would
be
rescued
from
more
falling
.
<EOS>
The
thought
of
Stephen
was
like
a
horrible
throbbing
pain
,
which
yet
,
as
such
pains
do
,
seemed
to
urge
all
other
thoughts
into
activity
.
<EOS>
But
among
her
thoughts
,
what
others
would
say
and
think
of
her
conduct
was
hardly
present
.
<EOS>
Love
and
deep
pity
and
remorseful
anguish
left
no
room
for
that
.
  
<EOS>
The
coach
was
taking
her
to
York
,
farther
away
from
home
;
but
she
did
not
learn
that
until
she
was
set
down
in
the
old
city
at
midnight
.
<EOS>
It
was
no
matter
;
she
could
sleep
there
,
and
start
home
the
next
day
.
<EOS>
She
had
her
purse
in
her
pocket
,
with
all
her
money
in
it
,
 
a
bank
-
note
and
a
sovereign
;
she
had
kept
it
in
her
pocket
from
forgetfulness
,
after
going
out
to
make
purchases
the
day
before
yesterday
.
  
<EOS>
Did
she
lie
down
in
the
gloomy
bedroom
of
the
old
inn
that
night
with
her
will
bent
unwaveringly
on
the
path
of
penitent
sacrifice
?
<EOS>
The
great
struggles
of
life
are
not
so
easy
as
that
;
the
great
problems
of
life
are
not
so
clear
.
<EOS>
In
the
darkness
of
that
night
she
saw
Stephen
's
face
turned
toward
her
in
passionate
,
reproachful
misery
;
she
lived
through
again
all
the
tremulous
delights
of
his
presence
with
her
that
made
existence
an
easy
floating
in
a
stream
of
joy
,
instead
of
a
quiet
resolved
endurance
and
effort
.
<EOS>
The
love
she
had
renounced
came
back
upon
her
with
a
cruel
charm
;
she
felt
herself
opening
her
arms
to
receive
it
once
more
;
and
then
it
seemed
to
slip
away
and
fade
and
vanish
,
leaving
only
the
dying
sound
of
a
deep
,
thrilling
voice
that
said
,
"
Gone
,
forever
gone
.
"
    
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
The
Final
Rescue
<EOS>
_
  
<EOS>
The
Return
to
the
Mill
  
Between
four
and
five
o'clock
on
the
afternoon
of
the
fifth
day
from
that
on
which
Stephen
and
Maggie
had
left
St.
Ogg
's
,
Tom
Tulliver
was
standing
on
the
gravel
walk
outside
the
old
house
at
Dorlcote
Mill
.
<EOS>
He
was
master
there
now
;
he
had
half
fulfilled
his
father
's
dying
wish
,
and
by
years
of
steady
self
-
government
and
energetic
work
he
had
brought
himself
near
to
the
attainment
of
more
than
the
old
respectability
which
had
been
the
proud
inheritance
of
the
Dodsons
and
Tullivers
.
  
<EOS>
But
Tom
's
face
,
as
he
stood
in
the
hot
,
still
sunshine
of
that
summer
afternoon
,
had
no
gladness
,
no
triumph
in
it
.
<EOS>
His
mouth
wore
its
bitterest
expression
,
his
severe
brow
its
hardest
and
deepest
fold
,
as
he
drew
down
his
hat
farther
over
his
eyes
to
shelter
them
from
the
sun
,
and
thrusting
his
hands
deep
into
his
pockets
,
began
to
walk
up
and
down
the
gravel
.
<EOS>
No
news
of
his
sister
had
been
heard
since
Bob
Jakin
had
come
back
in
the
steamer
from
Mudport
,
and
put
an
end
to
all
improbable
suppositions
of
an
accident
on
the
water
by
stating
that
he
had
seen
her
land
from
a
vessel
with
Mr.
Stephen
Guest
.
<EOS>
Would
the
next
news
be
that
she
was
married
,
 
or
what
?
<EOS>
Probably
that
she
was
not
married
;
Tom
's
mind
was
set
to
the
expectation
of
the
worst
that
could
happen
,
 
not
death
,
but
disgrace
.
  
<EOS>
As
he
was
walking
with
his
back
toward
the
entrance
gate
,
and
his
face
toward
the
rushing
mill
-
stream
,
a
tall
,
dark
-
eyed
figure
,
that
we
know
well
,
approached
the
gate
,
and
paused
to
look
at
him
with
a
fast
-
beating
heart
.
<EOS>
Her
brother
was
the
human
being
of
whom
she
had
been
most
afraid
from
her
childhood
upward
;
afraid
with
that
fear
which
springs
in
us
when
we
love
one
who
is
inexorable
,
unbending
,
unmodifiable
,
with
a
mind
that
we
can
never
mould
ourselves
upon
,
and
yet
that
we
can
not
endure
to
alienate
from
us
.
  
<EOS>
That
deep
-
rooted
fear
was
shaking
Maggie
now
;
but
her
mind
was
unswervingly
bent
on
returning
to
her
brother
,
as
the
natural
refuge
that
had
been
given
her
.
<EOS>
In
her
deep
humiliation
under
the
retrospect
of
her
own
weakness
,
 
in
her
anguish
at
the
injury
she
had
inflicted
,
 
she
almost
desired
to
endure
the
severity
of
Tom
's
reproof
,
to
submit
in
patient
silence
to
that
harsh
,
disapproving
judgment
against
which
she
had
so
often
rebelled
;
it
seemed
no
more
than
just
to
her
now
,
 
who
was
weaker
than
she
was
?
<EOS>
She
craved
that
outward
help
to
her
better
purpose
which
would
come
from
complete
,
submissive
confession
;
from
being
in
the
presence
of
those
whose
looks
and
words
would
be
a
reflection
of
her
own
conscience
.
  
<EOS>
Maggie
had
been
kept
on
her
bed
at
York
for
a
day
with
that
prostrating
headache
which
was
likely
to
follow
on
the
terrible
strain
of
the
previous
day
and
night
.
<EOS>
There
was
an
expression
of
physical
pain
still
about
her
brow
and
eyes
,
and
her
whole
appearance
,
with
her
dress
so
long
unchanged
,
was
worn
and
distressed
.
<EOS>
She
lifted
the
latch
of
the
gate
and
walked
in
slowly
.
<EOS>
Tom
did
not
hear
the
gate
;
he
was
just
then
close
upon
the
roaring
dam
;
but
he
presently
turned
,
and
lifting
up
his
eyes
,
saw
the
figure
whose
worn
look
and
loneliness
seemed
to
him
a
confirmation
of
his
worst
conjectures
.
<EOS>
He
paused
,
trembling
and
white
with
disgust
and
indignation
.
  
<EOS>
Maggie
paused
too
,
three
yards
before
him
.
<EOS>
She
felt
the
hatred
in
his
face
,
felt
it
rushing
through
her
fibres
;
but
she
must
speak
.
  
<EOS>
"
Tom
,
"
she
began
faintly
,
"
I
am
come
back
to
you
,
 
<EOS>
I
am
come
back
home
 
for
refuge
 
to
tell
you
everything
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
find
no
home
with
me
,
"
he
answered
,
with
tremulous
rage
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
disgraced
us
all
.
<EOS>
You
have
disgraced
my
father
's
name
.
<EOS>
You
have
been
a
curse
to
your
best
friends
.
<EOS>
You
have
been
base
,
deceitful
;
no
motives
are
strong
enough
to
restrain
you
.
<EOS>
I
wash
my
hands
of
you
forever
.
<EOS>
You
do
n't
belong
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Their
mother
had
come
to
the
door
now
.
<EOS>
She
stood
paralyzed
by
the
double
shock
of
seeing
Maggie
and
hearing
Tom
's
words
.
  
<EOS>
"
Tom
,
"
said
Maggie
,
with
more
courage
,
"
I
am
perhaps
not
so
guilty
as
you
believe
me
to
be
.
<EOS>
I
never
meant
to
give
way
to
my
feelings
.
<EOS>
I
struggled
against
them
.
<EOS>
I
was
carried
too
far
in
the
boat
to
come
back
on
Tuesday
.
<EOS>
I
came
back
as
soon
as
I
could
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
believe
in
you
any
more
,
"
said
Tom
,
gradually
passing
from
the
tremulous
excitement
of
the
first
moment
to
cold
inflexibility
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
been
carrying
on
a
clandestine
relation
with
Stephen
Guest
,
 
as
you
did
before
with
another
.
<EOS>
He
went
to
see
you
at
my
aunt
Moss
's
;
you
walked
alone
with
him
in
the
lanes
;
you
must
have
behaved
as
no
modest
girl
would
have
done
to
her
cousin
's
lover
,
else
that
could
never
have
happened
.
<EOS>
The
people
at
Luckreth
saw
you
pass
;
you
passed
all
the
other
places
;
you
knew
what
you
were
doing
.
<EOS>
You
have
been
using
Philip
Wakem
as
a
screen
to
deceive
Lucy
,
 
the
kindest
friend
you
ever
had
.
<EOS>
Go
and
see
the
return
you
have
made
her
.
<EOS>
She
's
ill
;
unable
to
speak
.
<EOS>
My
mother
ca
n't
go
near
her
,
lest
she
should
remind
her
of
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Maggie
was
half
stunned
,
 
too
heavily
pressed
upon
by
her
anguish
even
to
discern
any
difference
between
her
actual
guilt
and
her
brother
's
accusations
,
still
less
to
vindicate
herself
.
  
<EOS>
"
Tom
,
"
she
said
,
crushing
her
hands
together
under
her
cloak
,
in
the
effort
to
speak
again
,
"
whatever
I
have
done
,
I
repent
it
bitterly
.
<EOS>
I
want
to
make
amends
.
<EOS>
I
will
endure
anything
.
<EOS>
I
want
to
be
kept
from
doing
wrong
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
_
will
_
keep
you
?
"
said
Tom
,
with
cruel
bitterness
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Not
religion
;
not
your
natural
feelings
of
gratitude
and
honor
.
<EOS>
And
he
 
he
would
deserve
to
be
shot
,
if
it
were
not
   
<EOS>
But
you
are
ten
times
worse
than
he
is
.
<EOS>
I
loathe
your
character
and
your
conduct
.
<EOS>
You
struggled
with
your
feelings
,
you
say
.
<EOS>
Yes
!
<EOS>
_
I
_
have
had
feelings
to
struggle
with
;
but
I
conquered
them
.
<EOS>
I
have
had
a
harder
life
than
you
have
had
;
but
I
have
found
_
<EOS>
my
_
comfort
in
doing
my
duty
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
sanction
no
such
character
as
yours
;
the
world
shall
know
that
_
I
_
feel
the
difference
between
right
and
wrong
.
<EOS>
If
you
are
in
want
,
I
will
provide
for
you
;
let
my
mother
know
.
<EOS>
But
you
shall
not
come
under
my
roof
.
<EOS>
It
is
enough
that
I
have
to
bear
the
thought
of
your
disgrace
;
the
sight
of
you
is
hateful
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Slowly
Maggie
was
turning
away
with
despair
in
her
heart
.
<EOS>
But
the
poor
frightened
mother
's
love
leaped
out
now
,
stronger
than
all
dread
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
child
!
<EOS>
I
'll
go
with
you
.
<EOS>
You
've
got
a
mother
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Oh
,
the
sweet
rest
of
that
embrace
to
the
heart
-
stricken
Maggie
!
<EOS>
More
helpful
than
all
wisdom
is
one
draught
of
simple
human
pity
that
will
not
forsake
us
.
  
<EOS>
Tom
turned
and
walked
into
the
house
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
in
,
my
child
,
"
Mrs.
Tulliver
whispered
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
'll
let
you
stay
and
sleep
in
my
bed
.
<EOS>
He
wo
n't
deny
that
if
I
ask
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
mother
,
"
said
Maggie
,
in
a
low
tone
,
like
a
moan
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
never
go
in
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
wait
for
me
outside

<EOS>
St.
Ogg
's
Passes
Judgment
  
<EOS>
It
was
soon
known
throughout
St.
Ogg
's
that
Miss
Tulliver
was
come
back
<EOS>
;
she
had
not
,
then
,
eloped
in
order
to
be
married
to
Mr.
Stephen
Guest
,
 
at
all
events
,
Mr.
Stephen
Guest
had
not
married
her
;
which
came
to
the
same
thing
,
so
far
as
her
culpability
was
concerned
.
<EOS>
We
judge
others
according
to
results
;
how
else
?
 
not
knowing
the
process
by
which
results
are
arrived
at
.
<EOS>
If
Miss
Tulliver
,
after
a
few
months
of
well
-
chosen

,
had
returned
as
Mrs.
Stephen
Guest
,
with
a
post
-

_

_
,
and
all
the
advantages
possessed
even
by
the
most
unwelcome
wife
of
an
only
son
,
public
opinion
,
which
at
St.
Ogg
's
,
as
else
where
,
always
knew
what
to
think
,
would
have
judged
in
strict
consistency
with
those
results
.
<EOS>
Public
opinion
,
in
these
cases
,
is
always
of
the
feminine
gender
,
 
not
the
world
,
but
the
world
's
wife
;
and
she
would
have
seen
that
two
handsome
young
people
 
the
gentleman
of
quite
the
first
family
in
St.
Ogg
's
 
having
found
themselves
in
a
false
position
,
had
been
led
into
a
course
which
,
to
say
the
least
of
it
,
was
highly
injudicious
,
and
productive
of
sad

and
disappointment
,
especially

that
sweet
young
thing
,
Miss
Deane
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Stephen
Guest
had
certainly
not
behaved
well
;
but
then
,
young
men
were
liable
to
those

;
and
bad

might
seem

Stephen
Guest

from
her
cousin
's
lover
<EOS>
(
indeed

_
had
_

young
Wakem
,
 
old
Wakem
himself
had
mentioned
it

.
"
<EOS>

"

,
"

Kenn

,

.
"
<EOS>

,

.
"

.
<EOS>

,

Kenn

.
<EOS>
That

"
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
Oh
,

_
,
"

.
  
<EOS>
Maggie
dwelt

had

back

her
mother
and
brother
,
which

.
<EOS>
When

,

Kenn

;
there

on

.
<EOS>
He

,
and
walked
up

hearth

.
<EOS>
At
last
he

,
and
said
,

Maggie
,
    
"
Your
prompting
to
go
to
your
nearest
friends
,
 
to
remain
where
all
the
ties
of
your
life
have
been

,
 
is
a
true

,
to
which
the
Church
in
its
original

and

responds
,
opening

arms
to
the
penitent
,
watching
over
its
children
to
the
last
;
never

them
until
they
are
hopelessly
reprobate
.
<EOS>
And
the
Church
ought
to
represent
the
feeling
of
the
community
,
so
that
every
parish
should
be
a
family
knit
together
by
Christian

under
a

.
<EOS>
But
the
ideas
of
discipline
and
Christian
fraternity
are
entirely
relaxed
,
 
they
can
hardly
be
said
to
exist
in
the
public

;

hardly

except
in

,

they

;
and
if
I
were
not
supported
by
the
firm
faith
that
the
Church
must
ultimately
recover
the
full
force
of
that
constitution
which
is
alone
fitted
to
human
needs
,
I
should
often
lose
heart
at
observing
the
want
of
fellowship
and
sense
of
mutual
responsibility
among
my
own
flock
.
<EOS>
At
present
everything
seems
tending
toward
the
relaxation
of
ties
,
 
toward
the
substitution
of
wayward
choice
for
the
adherence
to
obligation
,
which
has
its
roots
in
the
past
.
<EOS>
Your
conscience
and
your
heart
have
given
you
true
light
on
this
point
,
Miss
Tulliver
;
and
I
have
said
all
this
that
you
may
know
what
my
wish
about
you
 
what
my
advice
to
you
 
would
be
,
if
they
sprang
from
my
own
feeling
and
opinion
unmodified
by
counteracting
circumstances
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Dr.
Kenn
paused
a
little
while
.
<EOS>
There
was
an
entire
absence
of
effusive
benevolence
in
his
manner
;
there
was
something
almost
cold
in
the
gravity
of

and

.
<EOS>
If
Maggie
had
not
known
that
his
benevolence
was
persevering
in
proportion
to
its
reserve
,
she
might
have
been
chilled
and

.
<EOS>
As

was
,
she
listened
expectantly
,
quite
sure
that
there
would
be
some
effective
help
in
his
words
.
<EOS>
He
went
on
.
  
<EOS>
"
Your
inexperience
of
the
world
,
Miss
Tulliver
,
prevents
you
from
anticipating
fully
the
very
unjust
conceptions
that
will
probably

formed
concerning

,
 
conceptions
which
will
have

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
do
,
 
I
begin
to
see
,
"
said

,
unable

this

of

.
<EOS>
"
I
know
I
shall
be

.
<EOS>
I
shall
be
thought
worse
than
I
am
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
perhaps
do
not

,
"

Kenn
,

more

,
"
that

which
ought

of

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
where
is

?
"

poor

,

that
no

.
  
<EOS>
"
He

;

.
<EOS>
He

vindicated

;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Dr.
Kenn

.
  
<EOS>
"
That

,

I

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

,

there

.
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
For

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

"

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
I

have
no

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
If

Lucy
 
to

;

<EOS>

"

,

"

<EOS>
They

.
<EOS>
If

,
because

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

"

,

,

influence

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

that

I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

not

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
I
shall
come

;
I
shall
bear

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
When
Maggie
had
left
him
,
Dr.
Kenn
stood
ruminating
with
his
hands
behind
him
,
and
his
eyes
fixed
on
the

,
under
a
painful
sense
of
doubt
and
difficulty
.
<EOS>
The
tone
of
Stephen
's
letter
,
which
he
had
read
,
and
the
actual
relations
of
all
the
persons
concerned
,
forced
upon
him
powerfully
the
idea
of
an
ultimate
marriage
between
Stephen
and
Maggie
as
the
least
evil
;
and
the
impossibility
of
their
proximity
in
St.
Ogg
's
on
any
other
supposition
,
until
after
years
of
separation
,
threw
an
insurmountable
prospective
difficulty
over
Maggie
's
stay
there
.
<EOS>
On
the
other
hand
,
he
entered
with
all
the
comprehension
of
a
man
who
had
known
spiritual
conflict
,
and
lived
through
years
of
devoted
service
to
his
fellow
-
men
,
into
that
state
of
Maggie
's
heart
and

which
made
the
consent
to
the
marriage
a
desecration
to
her
;
her
conscience
must
not
be
tampered
with
;
the
principle
on
which
she
had
acted
was
a
safer
guide
than
any
balancing
of
consequences
.
<EOS>
His
experience
told
him
that
intervention
was
too
dubious
a
responsibility
to
be
lightly
incurred
;
the
possible
issue
either
of
an

to
restore
the
former

with

and
Philip
,
or
of
counselling
submission
to
this
irruption

a
new

,
was
hidden
in
a
darkness
all
the
more
impenetrable
because
each
immediate
step
was
clogged
with
evil
.
  
<EOS>
The
great
problem
of
the
shifting
relation
between
passion
and
duty
is
clear
to
no
man
who
is
capable
of
apprehending
it
;
the
question
whether
the
moment
has
come
in
which
a
man
has

below
the

of
a

that
will

any

,
and
must
accept

of
a

against
which
he
had

as
a

,
is
one
for
which
we
have
no
master
-
key
that
will
fit
all
cases
.
<EOS>
The
casuists
have
become
a
byword
of
reproach
;
but
their
perverted
spirit
of
minute
discrimination
was
the
shadow
of
a
truth
to
which
eyes
and

are
too
often
fatally
sealed
,
 
the
truth
,
that
moral
judgments
must
remain
false
and
hollow
,
unless
they
are
checked
and
enlightened
by
a
perpetual
reference
to
the
special
circumstances
that
mark
the
individual
lot
.
  
<EOS>
All
people
of
broad
,
strong
sense
have
an
instinctive
repugnance
to
the
men
of
maxims
;
because
such
people
early
discern
that
the
mysterious

of
our

is
not
to

by

,

that

to

all

divine

and

that
spring

and

.
<EOS>
And
the
man
of
maxims
is
the
popular

of
the
minds
that
are
guided
in
their
moral

solely

,
thinking
that
these
will
lead

to

by

,

,

,
 
without

of

,

a
life
vivid
and
intense
enough
to
have
created

wide
fellow
-

with

that
is

.
    
<EOS>
Showing
That
Old
Acquaintances
Are
Capable
of
Surprising
Us
  
<EOS>
When
Maggie
was
at

again
,
her

news

an

line
of
conduct
in
aunt
Glegg
.
<EOS>
As

Maggie
had
not

,

Glegg
had
half

.
<EOS>
She
felt

that
Maggie
was

;
that

than
that
her
niece
and
legatee

.
<EOS>
When

Tom

,
and

,

of
Tom
for

sister
until

was

.
<EOS>
If

"
kin
"

shred
of

,
pray
what

?
<EOS>
Lightly
to

in
one

your
own

that
would

to
alter

will
,
had
never

the

;
and
though
Mrs.
Glegg
had
always

ill
of
Maggie
's

at

perhaps

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

were

Glegg
's

;
nothing

had

among

but

along

of

,

.
<EOS>
She
quarrelled
with
Mr.

,
whose

,
flowing

into

for
Lucy
,
made

;
and

,

"

all

,

Glegg
brought
from
Mr.

's

.
<EOS>
Then
Mrs.
Glegg
felt
that
she
had
adequate

-
ground
;
then
she
laid
aside

,
and
was
ready
to
meet
all

.
<EOS>
While
Mrs.
Pullet
could
do
nothing
but
shake

and
cry
,
and
wish
that
cousin
Abbot
had
died
,
or

had

,

,

,

could

's
again
,

"
acquaintances
"
knew

it
all
,

only

Mrs.

,

,

about

,

ill

!
  
<EOS>
Again
she
had
a
scene
of
remonstrance
with
Tom
,
all
the
more
severe
in
proportion
to
the
greater
strength
of
her
present
position
.
<EOS>
But
Tom
,
like
other
immovable
things
,
seemed
only
the
more
rigidly
fixed
under
that
attempt
to
shake
him
.
<EOS>
Poor
Tom
!
<EOS>
he
judged
by
what
he
had
been
able
to
see
;
and
the
judgment
was
painful
enough
to
himself
.
<EOS>
He
thought
he
had
the
demonstration
of
facts
observed
through
years
by
his
own
eyes
,
which
gave
no
warning
of
their
imperfection
,
that
Maggie
's
nature
was
utterly
untrustworthy
,
and
too
strongly
marked
with
evil
tendencies
to
be
safely

with
leniency
.
<EOS>
He
would
act
on
that
demonstration
at
any
cost
;
but
the
thought
of
it
made
his
days
bitter
to
him
.
<EOS>
Tom
,
like
every
one
of
us
,
was
imprisoned
within
the
limits
of
his
own
nature
,
and
his
education
had
simply
glided
over
him
,
leaving
a
slight
deposit
of
polish
;
if
you
are
inclined
to
be
severe
on
his
severity
,
remember
that
the
responsibility
of
tolerance
lies
with
those
who
have
the
wider
vision
.
<EOS>
There
had
arisen
in
Tom
a
repulsion
toward
Maggie
that
derived
its
very
intensity
from
their
early
childish
love
in
the
time
when
they
had
clasped
tiny
fingers
together
,
and
their
later
sense
of
nearness
in
a
common
duty
and
a
common
sorrow
;
the
sight
of
her
,
as
he
had
told
her
,
was
hateful
to
him
.
<EOS>
In
this
branch
of
the
Dodson
family
aunt
Glegg
found
a
stronger
nature
than
her
own
;
a
nature
in
which
family
feeling
had
lost
the
character
of
clanship
by
taking
on
a
doubly
deep
dye
of
personal
pride
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Glegg
allowed
that
Maggie
ought
to
be
punished
,
 
she
was
not
a
woman
to
deny
that
;
she
knew
what
conduct
was
,
 
but
punished
in
proportion
to
the
misdeeds

threw
her
arms
round
Maggie
's
neck
,
and
leaned
her
pale
cheek
against
the
burning
brow
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
stole
out
,
"
said
Lucy
,
almost
in
a
whisper
,
while
she
sat
down
close
to
Maggie
and
held
her
hand
,
"
when
papa
and
the
rest
were
away
.
<EOS>
Alice
is
come
with
me
.
<EOS>
I
asked
her
to
help
me
.
<EOS>
But
I
must
only
stay
a
little
while
,
because
it
is
so
late
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
easier
to
say
that
at
first
than
to
say
anything
else
.
<EOS>
They
sat
looking
at
each
other
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
as
if
the
interview
must
end
without
more
speech
,
for
speech
was
very
difficult
.
<EOS>
Each
felt
that
there
would
be
something
scorching
in
the
words
that
would
recall
the
irretrievable
wrong
.
<EOS>
But
soon
,
as
Maggie
looked
,
every
distinct
thought
began
to
be
overflowed
by
a
wave
of
loving
penitence
,
and
words
burst
forth
with
a
sob
.
  
<EOS>
"
God
bless
you
for
coming
,
Lucy
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
sobs
came
thick
on
each
other
after
that
.
  
<EOS>
"
Maggie
,
dear
,
be
comforted
,
"
said
Lucy
now
,
putting
her
cheek
against
Maggie
's
again
.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
grieve
.
"
<EOS>
And
she
sat
still
,
hoping
to
soothe
Maggie
with
that
gentle
caress
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
mean
to
deceive
you
,
Lucy
,
"
said
Maggie
,
as
soon
as
she
could
speak
.
<EOS>
"
It
always
made
me
wretched
that
I
felt
what
I
did
n't
like
you
to
know
.
<EOS>
It
was
because
I
thought
it
would
all
be
conquered
,
and
you
might
never
see
anything
to
wound
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
,
dear
,
"
said
Lucy
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
you
never
meant
to
make
me
unhappy
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
trouble
that
has
come
on
us
all
;
you
have
more
to
bear
than
I
have
 
<EOS>
and
you
gave
him
up
,
when
 
you
did
what
it
must
have
been
very
hard
to
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
They
were
silent
again
a
little
while
,
sitting
with
clasped
hands
,
and
cheeks
leaned
together
.
  
<EOS>
"
Lucy
,
"
Maggie
began
again
,
"
_
he
_
struggled
too
.
<EOS>
He
wanted
to
be
true
to
you
.
<EOS>
He
will
come
back
to
you
.
<EOS>
Forgive
him
 
he
will
be
happy
then
   
"
  
<EOS>
These
words
were
wrung
forth
from
Maggie
's
deepest
soul
,
with
an
effort
like
the
convulsed
clutch
of
a
drowning
man
.
<EOS>
Lucy
trembled
and
was
silent
.
  
<EOS>
A
gentle
knock
came
at
the
door
.
<EOS>
It
was
Alice
,
the
maid
,
who
entered
and
said
,
    
"
I
dare
n't
stay
any
longer
,
Miss
Deane
.
<EOS>
They
'll
find
it
out
,
and
there
'll
be
such
anger
at
your
coming
out
so
late
.
"
  
<EOS>
Lucy
rose
and
said
,
"
<EOS>
Very
well
,
Alice
,
 
in
a
minute
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
to
go
away
on
Friday
,
Maggie
,
"
she
added
,
when
Alice
had
closed
the
door
again
.
<EOS>
"
When
I
come
back
,
and
am
strong
,
they
will
let
me
do
as
I
like
.
<EOS>
I
shall
come
to
you
when
I
please
then
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Lucy
,
"
said
Maggie
,
with
another
great
effort
,
"
I
pray
to
God
continually
that
I
may
never
be
the
cause
of
sorrow
to
you
any
more
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
pressed
the
little
hand
that
she
held
between
hers
,
and
looked
up
into
the
face
that
was
bent
over
hers
.
<EOS>
Lucy
never
forgot
that
look
.
  
<EOS>
"
Maggie
,
"
she
said
,
in
a
low
voice
,
that
had
the
solemnity
of
confession
in
it
,
"
you
are
better
than
I
am
.
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
   
"
  
<EOS>
She
broke
off
there
,
and
said
no
more
.
<EOS>
But
they
clasped
each
other
again
in
a
last
embrace
.
    
<EOS>
The
Last
Conflict
  
<EOS>
In
the
second
week
of
September
,
Maggie
was
again
sitting
in
her
lonely
room
,
battling
with
the
old
shadowy
enemies
that
were
forever
slain
and
rising
again
.
<EOS>
It
was
past
midnight
,
and
the
rain
was
beating
heavily
against
the
window
,
driven
with
fitful
force
by
the
rushing
,
loud
-
moaning
wind
.
<EOS>
For
the
day
after
Lucy
's
visit
there
had
been
a
sudden
change
in
the
weather
;
the
heat
and
drought
had
given
way
to
cold
variable
winds
,
and
heavy
falls
of
rain
at
intervals
;
and
she
had
been
forbidden
to
risk
the
contemplated
journey
until
the
weather
should
become
more
settled
.
<EOS>
In
the
counties
higher
up
the
Floss
<EOS>
the
rains
had
been
continuous
,
and
the
completion
of
the
harvest
had
been
arrested
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
for
the
last
two
days
,
the
rains
on
this
lower
course
of
the
river
had
been
incessant
,
so
that
the
old
men
had
shaken
their
heads
and
talked
of
sixty
years
ago
,
when
the
same
sort
of
weather
,
happening
about
the
equinox
,
brought
on
the
great
floods
,
which
swept
the
bridge
away
,
and
reduced
the
town
to
great
misery
.
<EOS>
But
the
younger
generation
,
who
had
seen
several
small
floods
,
thought
lightly
of
these
sombre
recollections
and
forebodings
;
and
Bob
Jakin
,
naturally
prone
to
take
a
hopeful
view
of
his
own
luck
,
laughed
at
his
mother
when
she
regretted
their
having
taken
a
house
by
the
riverside
,
observing
that
<EOS>
but
for
that
they
would
have
had
no
boats
,
which
were
the
most
lucky
of
possessions
in
case
of
a
flood
that
obliged
them
to
go
to
a
distance
for
food
.
  
<EOS>
But
the
careless
and
the
fearful
were
alike
sleeping
in
their
beds
now
.
<EOS>
There
was
hope
that
the
rain
would
abate
by
the
morrow
;
threatenings
of
a
worse
kind
,
from
sudden
thaws
after
falls
of
snow
,
had
often
passed
off
,
in
the
experience
of
the
younger
ones
;
and
at
the
very
worst
,
the
banks
would
be
sure
to
break
lower
down
the
river
when
the
tide
came
in
with
violence
,
and
so
the
waters
would
be
carried
off
,
without
causing
more
than
temporary
inconvenience
,
and
losses
that
would
be
felt
only
by
the
poorer
sort
,
whom
charity
would
relieve
.
  
<EOS>
All
were
in
their
beds
now
,
for
it
was
past
midnight
;
all
except
some
solitary
watchers
such
as
Maggie
.
<EOS>
She
was
seated
in
her
little
parlor
toward
the
river
,
with
one
candle
,
that
left
everything
dim
in
the
room
except
a
letter
which
lay
before
her
on
the
table
.
<EOS>
That
letter
,
which
had
come
to
her
to
-
day
,
was
one
of
the
causes
that
had
kept
her
up
far
on
into
the
night
,
unconscious
how
the
hours
were
going
,
careless
of
seeking
rest
,
with
no
image
of
rest
coming
across
her
mind
,
except
of
that
far
,
far
off
rest
from
which
there
would
be
no
more
waking
for
her
into
this
struggling
earthly
life
.
  
<EOS>
Two
days
before
Maggie
received
that
letter
,
she
had
been
to
the
Rectory
for
the
last
time
.
<EOS>
The
heavy
rain
would
have
prevented
her
from
going
since
;
but
there
was
another
reason
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Kenn
,
at
first
enlightened
only
by
a
few
hints
as
to
the
new
turn
which
gossip
and
slander
had
taken
in
relation
to
Maggie
,
had
recently
been
made
more
fully
aware
of
it
by
an
earnest
remonstrance
from
one
of
his
male
parishioners
against
the
indiscretion
of
persisting
in
the
attempt
to
overcome
the
prevalent
feeling
in
the
parish
by
a
course
of
resistance
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Kenn
,
having
a
conscience
void
of
offence
in
the
matter
,
was
still
inclined
to
persevere
,
 
was
still
averse
to
give
way
before
a
public
sentiment
that
was
odious
and
contemptible
;
but
he
was
finally
wrought
upon
by
the
consideration
of
the
peculiar
responsibility
attached
to
his
office
,
of
avoiding
the
appearance
of
evil
,
 
an
"
appearance
"
that
is
always
dependent
on
the
average
quality
of
surrounding
minds
.
<EOS>
Where
these
minds
are
low
and
gross
,
the
area
of
that
"
appearance
"
is
proportionately
widened
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
he
was
in
danger
of
acting
from
obstinacy
;
perhaps
it
was
his
duty
to
succumb
.
<EOS>
Conscientious
people
are
apt
to
see
their
duty
in
that
which
is
the
most
painful
course
;
and
to
recede
was
always
painful
to
Dr.
Kenn
.
<EOS>
He
made
up
his
mind
that
he
must
advise
Maggie
to
go
away
from
St.
Ogg
's
for
a
time
;
and
he
performed
that
difficult
task
with
as
much
delicacy
as
he
could
,
only
stating
in
vague
terms
that
he
found
his
attempt
to
countenance
her
stay
was
a
source
of
discord
between
himself
and
his
parishioners
,
that
was
likely
to
obstruct
his
usefulness
as
a
clergyman
.
<EOS>
He
begged
her
to
allow
him
to
write
to
a
clerical
friend
of
his
,
who
might
possibly
take
her
into
his
own
family
as
governess
;
and
,
if
not
,
would
probably
know
of
some
other
available
position
for
a
young
woman
in
whose
welfare
Dr.
Kenn
felt
a
strong
interest
.
  
<EOS>
Poor
Maggie
listened
with
a
trembling
lip
;
she
could
say
nothing
but
a
faint
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
I
shall
be
grateful
"
;
and
she
walked
back
to
her
lodgings
,
through
the
driving
rain
,
with
a
new
sense
of
desolation
.
<EOS>
She
must
be
a
lonely
wanderer
;
she
must
go
out
among
fresh
faces
,
that
would
look
at
her
wonderingly
,
because
the
days
did
not
seem
joyful
to
her
;
she
must
begin
a
new
life
,
in
which
she
would
have
to
rouse
herself
to
receive
new
impressions
;
and
she
was
so
unspeakably
,
sickeningly
weary
!
<EOS>
There
was
no
home
,
no
help
for
the
erring
;
even
those
who
pitied
were
constrained
to
hardness
.
<EOS>
But
ought
she
to
complain
?
<EOS>
Ought
she
to
shrink
in
this
way
from
the
long
penance
of
life
,
which
was
all
the
possibility
she
had
of
lightening
the
load
to
some
other
sufferers
,
and
so
changing
that
passionate
error
into
a
new
force
of
unselfish
human
love
?
<EOS>
All
the
next
day
she
sat
in
her
lonely
room
,
with
a
window
darkened
by
the
cloud
and
the
driving
rain
,
thinking
of
that
future
,
and
wrestling
for
patience
;
for
what
repose
could
poor
Maggie
ever
win
except
by
wrestling
?
  
<EOS>
And
on
the
third
day
 
this
day
of
which
she
had
just
sat
out
the
close
 
<EOS>
the
letter
had
come
which
was
lying
on
the
table
before
her
.
  
<EOS>
The
letter
was
from
Stephen
.
<EOS>
He
was
come
back
from
Holland
;
he
was
at
Mudport
again
,
unknown
to
any
of
his
friends
,
and
had
written
to
her
from
that
place
,
enclosing
the
letter
to
a
person
whom
he
trusted
in
St.
Ogg
's
.
<EOS>
From
beginning
to
end
it
was
a
passionate
cry
of
reproach
;
an
appeal
against
her
useless
sacrifice
of
him
,
of
herself
,
against
that
perverted
notion
of
right
which
led
her
to
crush
all
his
hopes
,
for
the
sake
of
a
mere
idea
,
and
not
any
substantial
good
,
 
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
his
_
hopes
,
whom
she
loved
,
and
who
loved
her
with
that
single
overpowering
passion
,
that
worship
,
which
a
man
never
gives
to
a
woman
more
than
once
in
his
life
.
  
<EOS>
"
They
have
written
to
me
that
you
are
to
marry
Kenn
.
<EOS>
As
if
I
should
believe
that
!
<EOS>
Perhaps
they
have
told
you
some
such
fables
about
me
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
they
tell
you
I
've
been
"
travelling
.
<EOS>
"
My
body
has
been
dragged
about
somewhere
;
but
_
I
_
have
never
travelled
from
the
hideous
place
where
you
left
me
;
where
I
started
up
from
the
stupor
of
helpless
rage
to
find
you
gone
.
  
<EOS>
"
Maggie
!
<EOS>
whose
pain
can
have
been
like
mine
?
<EOS>
Whose
injury
is
like
mine
?
<EOS>
Who
besides
me
has
met
that
long
look
of
love
that
has
burnt
itself
into
my
soul
,
so
that
no
other
image
can
come
there
?
<EOS>
Maggie
,
call
me
back
to
you
!
<EOS>
Call
me
back
to
life
and
goodness
!
<EOS>
I
am
banished
from
both
now
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
motives
;
I
am
indifferent
to
everything
.
<EOS>
Two
months
have
only
deepened
the
certainty
that
I
can
never
care
for
life
without
you
.
<EOS>
Write
me
one
word
;
say
"
Come
!
"
<EOS>
In
two
days
I
should
be
with
you
.
<EOS>
Maggie
,
have
you
forgotten
what
it
was
to
be
together
,
 
to
be
within
reach
of
a
look
,
to
be
within
hearing
of
each
other
's
voice
?
"
  
<EOS>
When
Maggie
first
read
this
letter
she
felt
as
if
her
real
temptation
had
only
just
begun
.
<EOS>
At
the
entrance
of
the
chill
dark
cavern
,
we
turn
with
unworn
courage
from
the
warm
light
;
but
how
,
when
we
have
trodden
far
in
the
damp
darkness
,
and
have
begun
to
be
faint
and
weary
;
how
,
if
there
is
a
sudden
opening
above
us
,
and
we
are
invited
back
again
to
the
life
-
nourishing
day
?
<EOS>
The
leap
of
natural
longing
from
under
the
pressure
of
pain
is
so
strong
,
that
all
less
immediate
motives
are
likely
to
be
forgotten
 
till
the
pain
has
been
escaped
from
.
  
<EOS>
For
hours
Maggie
felt
as
if
her
struggle
had
been
in
vain
.
<EOS>
For
hours
every
other
thought
that
she
strove
to
summon
was
thrust
aside
by
the
image
of
Stephen
waiting
for
the
single
word
that
would
bring

to
her
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
_
read
_
<EOS>
the
letter
<EOS>
:
she
heard

uttering

,
and
the
voice

with
its
old

.
<EOS>
All

she
had
been
filled

through
which
she
must

,

.
<EOS>
And

,
close

,

another

!
<EOS>
And

<EOS>
It

"
Come
!
"
  
<EOS>
But

<EOS>
No
,

must

;

;

,

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
She

,

,
with

;

that

.
<EOS>
It

that
no

,

<EOS>
"

,

;

"
  
<EOS>

"

,

!
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
You

.
"
  
<EOS>
She

<EOS>
To

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

?
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.

,

.

<EOS>

!
<EOS>
there

,
that
might
dash
against
her
boat
as
she
passed
,
and
cause
her
to
perish
too
soon
.
<EOS>
What
were
those
masses
?
  
<EOS>
For
the
first
time
Maggie
's
heart
began
to
beat
in
an
agony
of
dread
.
<EOS>
She
sat
helpless
,
dimly
conscious
that
she
was
being
floated
along
,
more
intensely
conscious
of
the
anticipated
clash
.
<EOS>
But
the
horror
was
transient
;
it
passed
away
before
the
oncoming
warehouses
of
St.
Ogg
's
.
<EOS>
She
had
passed
the
mouth
of
the
Ripple
,
then
;
<EOS>
_
now
<EOS>
_
,
she
must
use
all
her
skill
and
power
to
manage
the
boat
and
get
it
if
possible
out
of
the
current
.
<EOS>
She
could
see
now
that
the
bridge
was
broken
down
;
she
could
see
the
masts
of
a
stranded
vessel
far
out
over
the
watery
field
.
<EOS>
But
no
boats
were
to
be
seen
moving
on
the
river
,
 
such
as
had
been
laid
hands
on
were
employed
in
the
flooded
streets
.
  
<EOS>
With
new
resolution
,
Maggie
seized
her
oar
,
and
stood
up
again
to
paddle
;
but
the
now
ebbing
tide
added
to
the
swiftness
of
the
river
,
and
she
was
carried
along
beyond
the
bridge
.
<EOS>
She
could
hear
shouts
from
the
windows
overlooking
the
river
,
as
if
the
people
there
were
calling
to
her
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
till
she
had
passed
on
nearly
to
Tofton
that
she
could
get
the
boat
clear
of
the
current
.
<EOS>
Then
with
one
yearning
look
toward
her
uncle
Deane
's
house
that
lay
farther
down
the
river
,
she
took
to
both
her
oars
and
rowed
with
all
her
might
across
the
watery
fields
,
back
toward
the
Mill
.
<EOS>
Color
was
beginning
to
awake
now
,
and
as
she
approached
the
Dorlcote
fields
,
she
could
discern
the
tints
of
the
trees
,
could
see
the
old
Scotch
firs
far
to
the
right
,
and
the
home
chestnuts
,
 
oh
,
how
deep
they
lay
in
the
water
,
 
deeper
than
the
trees
on
this
side
the
hill
!
<EOS>
And
the
roof
of
the
Mill
 
<EOS>
where
was
it
?
<EOS>
Those
heavy
fragments
hurrying
down
the
Ripple
,
 
what
had
they
meant
?
<EOS>
But
it
was
not
the
house
,
 
the
house
stood
firm
;
drowned
up
to
the
first
story
,
but
still
firm
,
 
or
was
it
broken
in
at
the
end
toward
the
Mill
?
  
<EOS>
With
panting
joy
that
she
was
there
at
last
,
 
joy
that
overcame
all
distress
,
 
Maggie
neared
the
front
of
the
house
.
<EOS>
At
first
she
heard
no
sound
;
she
saw
no
object
moving
.
<EOS>
Her
boat
was
on
a
level
with
the
upstairs
window
.
<EOS>
She
called
out
in
a
loud
,
piercing
voice
,
    
"
Tom
,
where
are
you
?
<EOS>
Mother
,
where
are
you
?
<EOS>
Here
is
Maggie
!
"
  
<EOS>
Soon
,
from
the
window
of
the
attic
in
the
central
gable
,
she
heard
Tom
's
voice
,
    
<EOS>
"
Who
is
it
?
<EOS>
Have
you
brought
a
boat
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
I
,
Tom
,
 
Maggie
.
<EOS>
Where
is
mother
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
is
not
here
;
she
went
to
Garum
the
day
before
yesterday
.
<EOS>
I
'll
come
down
to
the
lower
window
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Alone
,
Maggie
?
"
said
Tom
,
in
a
voice
of
deep
astonishment
,
as
he
opened
the
middle
window
,
on
a
level
with
the
boat
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Tom
;
God
has
taken
care
of
me
,
to
bring
me
to
you
.
<EOS>
Get
in
quickly
.
<EOS>
Is
there
no
one
else
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Tom
,
stepping
into
the
boat
;
"
I
fear
the
man
is
drowned
;
he
was
carried
down
the
Ripple
<EOS>
,
I
think
,
when
part
of
the
Mill
fell
with
the
crash
of
trees
and
stones
against
it
;
I
've
shouted
again
and
again
,
and
there
has
been
no
answer
.
<EOS>
Give
me
the
oars
,
Maggie
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
not
till
Tom
had
pushed
off
and
they
were
on
the
wide
water
,
 
<EOS>
he
face
to
face
with
Maggie
,
 
that
the
full
meaning
of
what
had
happened
rushed
upon
his
mind
.
<EOS>
It
came
with
so
overpowering
a
force
,
 
<EOS>
it
was
such
a
new
revelation
to
his
spirit
,
of
the
depths
in
life
that
had
lain
beyond
his
vision
,
which
he
had
fancied
so
keen
and
clear
,
 
that
he
was
unable
to
ask
a
question
.
<EOS>
They
sat
mutely
gazing
at
each
other
,
 
Maggie
with
eyes
of
intense
life
looking
out
from
a
weary
,
beaten
face
;
Tom
pale
,
with
a
certain
awe
and
humiliation
.
<EOS>
Thought
was
busy
though
the
lips
were
silent
;
and
though
he
could
ask
no
question
,
he
guessed
a
story
of
almost
miraculous
,
divinely
protected
effort
.
<EOS>
But
at
last
a
mist
gathered
over
the
blue
-
gray
eyes
,
and
the
lips
found
a
word
they
could
utter
,
 
the
old
childish
"
Magsie
!
"
  
<EOS>
Maggie
could
make
no
answer
but
a
long
,
deep
sob
of
that
mysterious
,
wondrous
happiness
that
is
one
with
pain
.
  
<EOS>
As
soon
as
she
could
speak
,
she
said
,
"
We
will
go
to
Lucy
,
Tom
;
we
'll
go
and
see
if
she
is
safe
,
and
then
we
can
help
the
rest
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Tom
rowed
with
untired
vigor
,
and
with
a
different
speed
from
poor
Maggie
's
.
<EOS>
The
boat
was
soon
in
the
current
of
the
river
again
,
and
soon
they
would
be
at
Tofton
.
  
<EOS>
"
Park
House
stands
high
up
out
of
the
flood
,
"
said
Maggie
.
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
they
have
got
Lucy
there
.
"
  
<EOS>
Nothing
else
was
said
;
a
new
danger
was
being
carried
toward
them
by
the
river
.
<EOS>
Some
wooden
machinery
had
just
given
way
on
one
of
the
wharves
,
and
huge
fragments
were
being
floated
along
.
<EOS>
The
sun
was
rising
now
,
and
the
wide
area
of
watery
desolation
was
spread
out
in
dreadful
clearness
around
them
;
in
dreadful
clearness
floated
onward
the
hurrying
,
threatening
masses
.
<EOS>
A
large
company
in
a
boat
that
was
working
its
way
along
under
the
Tofton
houses
observed
their
danger
,
and
shouted
,
"
Get
out
of
the
current
!
"
  
<EOS>
But
that
could
not
be
done
at
once
;
and
Tom
,
looking
before
him
,
saw
death
rushing
on
them
.
<EOS>
Huge
fragments
,
clinging
together
in
fatal
fellowship
,
made
one
wide
mass
across
the
stream
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
coming
,
Maggie
!
"
<EOS>
Tom
said
,
in
a
deep
,
hoarse
voice
,
loosing
the
oars
,
and
clasping
her
.
  
<EOS>
The
next
instant
the
boat
was
no
longer
seen
upon
the
water
,
and
the
huge
mass
was
hurrying
on
in
hideous
triumph
.
  
<EOS>
But
soon
the
keel
of
the
boat
reappeared
,
a
black
speck
on
the
golden
water
.
  
<EOS>
The
boat
reappeared
,
but
brother
and
sister
had
gone
down
in
an
embrace
never
to
be
parted
;
living
through
again
in
one
supreme
moment
the
days
when
they
had
clasped
their
little
hands
in
love
,
and
roamed
the
daisied
fields
together
.
  
<EOS>
Conclusion
  
<EOS>
Nature
repairs
her
ravages
,
 
repairs
them
with
her
sunshine
,
and
with
human
labor
.
<EOS>
The
desolation
wrought
by
that
flood
had
left
little
visible
trace
on
the
face
of
the
earth
,
five
years
after
.
<EOS>
The
fifth
autumn
was
rich
in
golden
cornstacks
,
rising
in
thick
clusters
among
the
distant
hedgerows
;
the
wharves
and
warehouses
on
the
Floss
were
busy
again
,
with
echoes
of
eager
voices
,
with
hopeful
lading
and
unlading
.
  
<EOS>
And
every
man
and
woman
mentioned
in
this
history
was
still
living
,
except
those
whose
end
we
know
.
  
<EOS>
Nature
repairs
her
ravages
,
but
not
all
.
<EOS>
The
uptorn
trees
are
not
rooted
again
;
the
parted
hills
are
left
scarred
;
if
there
is
a
new
growth
,
the
trees
are
not
the
same
as
the
old
,
and
the
hills
underneath
their
green
vesture
bear
the
marks
of
the
past
rending
.
<EOS>
To
the
eyes
that
have
dwelt
on
the
past
,
there
is
no
thorough
repair
.
  
<EOS>
Dorlcote
Mill
was
rebuilt
.
<EOS>
And
Dorlcote
churchyard
 
where
the
brick
grave
that
held
a
father
whom
we
know
,
was
found
with
the
stone
laid
prostrate
upon
it
after
the
flood
 
had
recovered
all
its
grassy
order
and
decent
quiet
.
  
<EOS>
Near
that
brick
grave
there
was
a
tomb
erected
,
very
soon
after
the
flood
,
for
two
bodies
that
were
found
in
close
embrace
;
and
it
was
visited
at
different
moments
by
two
men
who
both
felt
that
their
keenest
joy
and
keenest
sorrow
were
forever
buried
there
.
  
<EOS>
One
of
them
visited
the
tomb
again
with
a
sweet
face
beside
him
;
but
that
was
years
after
.
  
<EOS>
The
other
was
always
solitary
.
<EOS>
His
great
companionship
was
among
the
trees
of
the
Red
Deeps
,
where
the
buried
joy
seemed
still
to
hover
,
like
a
revisiting
spirit
.
  
<EOS>
The
tomb
bore
the
names
of
Tom
and
Maggie
Tulliver
,
and
below
the
names
it
was
written
,
                   
"
In
their
death
they
were
not
divided
.
"
   
<EOS>
